An effective semantic segmentation algorithm is essential for the development of autonomous driving systems. However, the performance of semantic segmentation algorithms can vary widely depending on factors such as the size and quality of the dataset, the architecture of the algorithm, and the optimization process. In this paper, we present a novel approach for customizing the architecture of a semantic segmentation algorithm using a genetic algorithm. Our approach begins with a pre-defined set of architectural parameters, which are optimized using a genetic algorithm. We evaluate our approach on the Cityscapes dataset, and compare the performance of our customized architecture to that of the pre-defined architecture. Our results show that our approach can produce a customized architecture that significantly improves the performance of the semantic segmentation algorithm.

An important problem in statistics is that of estimating the inverse covariance matrix of a multivariate normal distribution, given a small number of samples from it. In this paper, a new algorithm is proposed for estimating the inverse covariance matrix in this setting. The algorithm is based on a l_0 regularization technique, which encourages sparsity in the solution. This is particularly useful when the number of variables is large, and many of the variables are correlated with each other. The proposed algorithm is compared with existing algorithms for inverse covariance estimation, and it is shown to perform well in terms of mean squared error and computational time.

The paper presents a novel method for the detection of brain tumors based on mathematical analysis and symmetry information. The proposed method has been tested on a large dataset of MRI images and has shown promising results in terms of both accuracy and speed. Abstract
We present a multi-scale non-local active contour model for segmenting meaningful objects in SAR images. The model is based on a multi-scale active contour framework, where the energy of the active contour is defined by a non-local similarity measure. The non-local similarity measure is computed using a Gaussian filter, which defines a local neighborhood around each point. Within this local neighborhood, a non-local similarity measure is computed using a weighted sum of the similarities between each point and its neighbors. The weights are determined by the Gaussian filter. The model is trained using a set of annotated SAR images, where the annotations are provided by a human expert. The model is evaluated on a separate test set, and the results are compared to the performance of a baseline active contour model. The results show that the proposed model significantly outperforms the baseline model in terms of accuracy and speed.

Keywords: SAR images, active contours, object segmentation, non-local similarity measure.

Abstract:

Here is an abstract for the academic paper titled "SEGMENT3D: A Web-based Application for Collaborative Segmentation of 3D Images used in the Shoot Apical Meristem":

This paper proposes a novel method to investigate the collisions of open heavy flavor mesons, using Regge theory. Abstract:
Traditional single-focus image fusion algorithms assume that the image to be fused has only one focus. However, in reality, an image often has multiple focuses, and it is difficult for a single-focus fusion algorithm to achieve both clear targets and backgrounds. In this paper, a multi-focus image fusion algorithm based on similarity characteristics is proposed. The algorithm first extracts the texture and flatness characteristics of the image blocks, and then uses the K-means clustering algorithm to classify the blocks into texture blocks and flatness blocks. Finally, the texture blocks and the flatness blocks are fused separately. The experimental results show that the proposed algorithm can effectively fuse the multi-focus image and improve the quality of the fused image.

In this paper, we investigate the impact of self-supervised pre-training and transductive inference for segmentation of medical images. Abstract
Deep learning has achieved great success in image segmentation tasks, yet the mechanisms that lead to their performance remain unclear. We investigate this question in the context of pixel-level segmentation of fluorescence microscopy images. We train deep neural networks to segment images of cells into foreground (cell) and background (background). We find that despite having access to millions of training images, the networks converge quickly and with a high degree of similarity across different trainings. In order to gain insight into the networks' decisions, we propose a novel method to visualize the attention weights of a attention-based segmentation model. From these visualizations, we make three main discoveries. First, the networks learn to focus on pixels that are most salient for segmentation, and largely ignore pixels that are cluttered or ambiguous. Second, despite being trained on images of cells, the networks tend to first detect foreground objects that are similar in size and appearance to cells, but are not cells, and only then proceed to detect cells. Third, the networks are able to generalize to unlabeled cell types not seen during training, but performance degrades as the cell type deviates further from the trained cell types. Based on these findings, we discuss how deep neural networks segment images, and how they generalize to new cell types.

In this paper, we present a novel approach for cochlea image segmentation based on a Bayesian logistic shape model. The proposed method utilizes a probabilistic model that describes the spatial distribution of pixels in the image, allowing for more accurate and robust segmentation compared to traditional thresholding techniques. The Bayesian inference algorithm is employed to estimate the model parameters and infer the most likely segmentation. The experimental results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms existing approaches in terms of accuracy and running time.

In this paper, we introduce a new approach for automatic quality evaluation of noisy-labeled image segmentation datasets. Our approach, which we refer to as Pick-and-Learn, involves using a pre-trained image segmentation model to select the most confident and accurate labels for each pixel in an image, and then learning a quality evaluation model based on the selected labels. We show that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the Cityscapes and KITTI datasets, and that it is effective at selecting confident and accurate labels for training deep learning models. We also demonstrate that our approach is general and can be used to select confident and accurate labels for other types of datasets, such as medical imaging and satellite imagery. Finally, we discuss the limitations of our approach and potential future work.

Abstract:
Image segmentation is crucial for image analysis and computer vision tasks. However, this process can be challenging and prone to overfitting, particularly when dealing with class imbalance. This paper aims to analyze the impact of class imbalance on overfitting in neural networks for image segmentation. We propose a novel approach to address the issue by combining deep learning with traditional computer vision techniques. Our method comprises a preprocessing phase, where the class imbalance is addressed using bootstrapping and an enhanced Label Distribution Learning (LDL) technique. We then train a U-Net deep learning model for image segmentation. The proposed method is evaluated on the publicly available Cityscapes dataset, which consists of 32 classes and 2600 images. Our experiments show that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of Intersection over Union (IoU) and pixel accuracy, thereby demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed approach in handling class imbalance and reducing overfitting in image segmentation tasks.

Abstract:

Abstract:

Furthermore, we enforce the consistency between the predictions from the labeled and unlabeled data to improve the segmentation performance. Extensive experiments on public datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach against the state-of-the-art semi-supervised segmentation methods.

An S-fold of an N=3 superconformal field theory (SCFT) is a way of obtaining a new SCFT by identifying a particular light cone direction and restricting the fields of the original theory to live on the sphere at infinity in this direction. We give a general construction for obtaining an S-fold of an N=3 SCFT starting from an arbitrary N=3 SCFT and an R-symmetry group G. This construction involves a particular parabolic subgroup P of G and a choice of an invariant vector under the action of P. The resulting S-fold theory has a superconformal symmetry group of the form P  SU(2)  SU(2)  U(1) and is characterized by the choice of P and the invariant vector. We discuss how to compute S-fold theories for a number of explicit examples, including the ABJM and AHM theories. We find that in many cases, the S-fold theory is once again an N=3 SCFT, but there are also cases where it is a non-supersymmetric SCFT or an ordinary field theory. Finally, we use the S-fold construction to give a simple proof of the uniqueness of the ABJM and AHM SCFTs.

Abstract:

We also find that the process exhibits a multifractal structure, with a spectrum that is not a simple power law but instead exhibits a complex, multi-modal structure. Abstract:

"A comprehensive study of the magnetic properties of the URhIn$_{5}$ compound is presented. The magnetic behavior of this compound was found to be anisotropic, with the easy axis oriented along the $c$-axis. The magnetization was found to follow a modified Curie-Weiss law with the magnetic moment oriented along the $c$-axis. The effective magnetic moment was found to be $4.6 \, \mu_{B}$. The temperature dependence of the magnetization was best described by a modified Bloch equation. The magnetic anisotropy was found to be approximately $1.2 \cdot 10^{-5}$ emu/mol, with the easy axis along the $c$-axis. Abstract
Domain generalization has attracted increasing attention, but most studies focus on learning domain-invariant feature representations or adopting specific architectures such as multi-task learning or transfer learning. In this paper, we propose a model-agnostic approach that learns semantic features from raw data in an unsupervised manner, which can be easily integrated into any deep learning models without requiring domain-specific training data. Specifically, we represent each input sample as a semantic vector in a high-dimensional space, and utilize an unsupervised learning algorithm to learn a mapping function from the input space to the semantic space. In the semantic space, data from different domains are encouraged to be clustered together, which effectively facilitates domain generalization. We evaluate our approach on two benchmark datasets, and experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach compared to the state-of-the-art.

The phonographic market is a rapidly growing industry that has seen significant changes in recent years, with the rise of streaming platforms and the increasing digitization of music. Active mean fields (AMFs) model image intensities as a Gaussian mixture model (GMM) with weights controlled by an external active signal. We derive an analytical solution for the Gaussian mixture model (GMM) with a weighted mean kernel. We show that the resulting family of energy functions specializes both the classical Chan-Vese energy and the more recent Rudin-Osher-Fatemi (ROF) energy, with the narrowband ROF energy as a particular case. Our work provides a new derivation of the ROF energy and a better understanding of its relationship to other energy functions in the literature. Furthermore, the AMF model allows us to define a new metric for goodness-of-fit of a segmentation, which we show to be more expressive than the commonly used variation information.

**Abstract**

This paper explores the concept of thin games, which are games with a finite number of outcomes and a minimum number of players required to play the game. We introduce a new class of thin games called concurrent Hyland-Ong games, which are characterized by the presence of two or more players who can win or lose simultaneously. We study the properties of these games and develop a framework for analyzing their outcomes. Our results show that concurrent Hyland-Ong games can have a variety of outcomes, including multiple winners, multiple losers, and ties. We also explore the relationship between concurrent Hyland-Ong games and other classes of thin games, such as symmetric games and asymmetric games. This paper analyzes the stability and monotonicity of some discretizations of the Biot's model. First, we study the stable finite element schemes for the homogeneous model, namely the constant coefficient case. We show that the classical Galerkin finite element method is stable and monotone under very mild conditions on the coefficient, and remains so even in the presence of a small perturbation in the data. Then, we consider the non-homogeneous model, where the coefficient varies in space according to a given field. We propose and analyze an auxiliary variable method that consists in introducing an extra variable through a Lagrange multiplier. This method is shown to be stable and monotone under reasonable assumptions on the data, and provides an efficient way to account for the variability of the coefficient.

The paper examines the two-dimensionalization of low-magnetic-Reynolds-number flows in a strong magnetic field. Face mask detection and extraction from video sequences have received increasing attention due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the widespread use of face masks. **Abstract:**
In this paper, we present a novel approach for accelerated inference in Markov Random Fields (MRFs) using smooth Riemannian optimization. Traditional inference methods in MRFs are known for their computational complexity and time-consuming nature, particularly when dealing with large-scale datasets. Our research aims to address this challenge by proposing an efficient and effective optimization technique. We utilize the smooth Riemannian structure of the MRF energy function to derive a novel optimization algorithm that converges faster and exhibits better numerical properties compared to existing methods. Our approach is based on the iterative optimization of a smooth and differentiable objective function, which allows for efficient gradient computation and avoids the need for costly discrete optimizations.

Our experimental evaluations demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed method in terms of computational efficiency and accuracy. We compare our approach to state-of-the-art methods on standard benchmark datasets, showing significant speed improvements and comparable or improved likelihood accuracy. The proposed method is applicable to various domains where MRFs are commonly used, including computer vision, natural language processing, and statistical learning. We believe that our work will contribute to the accelerated inference process in MRFs and facilitate the application of these models to larger and more complex datasets.

The molecular Stark energy, alignment, and orientation generated by the combined permanent and induced electric dipole interactions are studied using the topology of surfaces. The topology of the most stable surfaces for given molecular geometry is determined by the minimal homology cycle on the corresponding Gaussian surface. Diluted magnetic semiconductors (DMS) have attracted a lot of attention due to their potential use in spintronics and the valleytronic applications. Sn/Cr/Te is among the few II-VI DMS with a ferromagnetic ground state. However, the complexity of theSn 5s electron configuration, the presence of multiple parallel bands, and the strong hybridization between the sp and sp electrons in this material system, make its electronic structure a very challenging issue. In this paper, we have investigated the effect of the Te content and the electron beam irradiation on the magnetic properties of Sn/1-x/Cr/x/Te. Magnetic measurements show an increase in the Curie temperature with the Te content and thermal stability of the as-grown samples. Electron beam irradiation leads to the rapid growth of the crystalline grains, and hence, the magnetization increases. The mechanisms involved in these phenomena are discussed in terms of electronic structure calculations.

An important aspect in the development of quantum technology is the ability to produce quantum bits (qubits) that can be reliably controlled and manipulated. Nanowire resonators have shown promise as a platform for qubit operation, due to their unique optical properties and ability to confine light in a small volume. In this work, we investigate the broadband quantum efficiency enhancement in high index nanowire resonators. By optimizing the design of the resonator, we are able to achieve a broadband enhancement of the quantum efficiency, resulting in a wider range of qubit operation. Furthermore, we investigate the effects of fabrication parameters on the quantum efficiency of the resonator and develop a model to predict the optimal fabrication conditions. Our work provides a basis for the development of nanowire resonators for qubit applications.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "CE-Net: Context Encoder Network for 2D Medical Image Segmentation" would include:

Medical image segmentation is crucial for the analysis and interpretation of 2D medical images, such as X-rays, MRIs, and CT scans. However, manual segmentation is time-consuming and prone to errors. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to 2D medical image segmentation using a Context Encoder Network (CE-Net). Our method utilizes a deep learning architecture that incorporates contextual information from the image to improve segmentation accuracy. We evaluate our method on a dataset of 2D medical images and compare it to state-of-the-art segmentation algorithms. Our results show that CE-Net significantly improves segmentation accuracy, especially in challenging cases where contextual information is crucial. Brain tumor segmentation refers to the process of identifying and distinguishing tumor regions from normal ones within multimodal (e.g., T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), T2-weighted MRI, and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)) medical images. In this paper, we present a novel approach for brain tumor segmentation that leverages the strengths of different features across different modalities. Our method involves two main steps: (1) feature disentanglement, where we extract robust features that are modality-independent; and (2) gated fusion, where we combine the features from all modalities in a gate-controlled manner. The proposed method was evaluated on 100 multimodal MRI brain tumor segmentation images from the BraTS 2020 validation dataset, and compared to results from 11 other state-of-the-art methods. Our approach achieved a Dice similarity coefficient of 0.83, which is significantly higher than the average of all compared methods (0.80).

The Riemann Hypothesis, one of the most significant and enigmatic problems in mathematics, posits that the Riemann Zeta function possesses all its non-trivial zeros on the line $\Re(s)=\frac{1}{2}$. In this paper, we consider the behavior of the derivatives of the Riemann Zeta function and investigate the zeros of these derivatives. Our results show that the first, second, and third derivatives of the Riemann Zeta function have zeros that are closely related to the Riemann Hypothesis. We find that the zeros of the first derivative correspond to the non-trivial zeros of the Riemann Zeta function, while the zeros of the second and third derivatives correspond to the non-trivial zeros of the Riemann Zeta function with an additional constraint on the real part of the complex variable. Our findings offer new insights into the behavior of the Riemann Zeta function and its relationship to the Riemann Hypothesis.

Semantic segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision with a wide range of applications. In this paper, we explore the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for semantic segmentation, with a focus on learning high-level image prior. We propose a novel architecture called DeepLab, which combines a CNN with a fully connected conditional random field (CRF). The CNN is designed to learn a high-level prior of the image, which is then used to refine the segmentation results with the CRF. Abstract: We present a family of reduced relative entropy (RRE) techniques for the a posteriori analysis of multiphase problems in elastodynamics. These techniques are based on the use of RRE functions, which are functions that satisfy the equations of motion for the system with a reduced relative entropy. We show that these RRE functions can be used to construct efficient and accurate a posteriori error estimates for the system. We also present a technique for the a priori analysis of multiphase problems in elastodynamics based on the use of RRE functions. This technique is shown to be efficient and accurate as well.

Abstract:
One of the crucial requirements for training a robust semantic image segmentation model for traffic condition analysis is the ground truth annotation of the training dataset. We propose a novel approach for improving the quality of ground truth annotations and evaluate its impact on model performance. In this paper, we demonstrate a spectral level reconstruction method for the intrinsic $B$-mode power in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation. The intrinsic $B$-mode power is a measure of the gravitational lensing of the CMB radiation by the large-scale structure of the universe. This reconstruction method is based on the idea of minimizing the difference between the measured $B$-mode power spectrum and the power spectrum of the reconstructed intrinsic $B$-mode power. The reconstruction is performed by using a linear least squares fitting algorithm. The fitting algorithm is applied to the measured $B$-mode power spectrum, which is obtained by averaging the power spectrum over a set of input spectra. The reconstructed intrinsic $B$-mode power is then obtained by multiplying the fitting coefficients by the input spectra. The reconstructed intrinsic $B$-mode power is compared to the measured $B$-mode power spectrum to evaluate the performance of the reconstruction method. The reconstruction method is shown to be effective in recovering the intrinsic $B$-mode power in the CMB radiation.

Here is the abstract for the academic paper titled "Qubit state tomography in superconducting circuits via weak measurements":

Quantum state tomography (QST) provides a powerful tool to characterize and verify the behavior of quantum systems. We present a novel scheme for quantum state tomography of a qubit in a superconducting circuit using weak measurements. Weak measurements provide a way to estimate the expectation value of a operator with a small amount of backaction, which is important for preserving the quantum state during the measurement. We show that by combining weak measurements with a simple preparation scheme, we can perform efficient state tomography, even in the presence of noise and imperfections in the circuit. Our approach is based on a linear inversion technique, which allows us to reconstruct the density matrix of the qubit with high fidelity. We validate our approach by performing state tomography on a superconducting transmon qubit and comparing the results with theoretical predictions. Our work provides a new direction for quantum state tomography in superconducting circuits and is an important step towards scalable and robust quantum technologies.

This abstract provides a brief overview of the paper, highlighting the main results and conclusions. It emphasizes the importance of weak measurements in preserving the quantum state during the measurement process, and how this technique can be used to perform efficient state tomography in superconducting circuits. The abstract also mentions the validation of the approach through experimental results, providing a clear indication of the paper's contribution to the field of quantum technologies.

The UK government has announced a freeze on its anti-spam campaign, which aims to reduce the number of unwanted emails and text messages sent to people's phones. The move comes after a recent survey found that more than half of British adults have received unwanted messages, with many saying they had received spam about pension schemes and eye surgery. "We are committed to tackling the blight of spam texts and emails head-on," said a spokesman for the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport. "That is why we are taking decisive action to protect the public and halt the spam merchants." 

The spokesman said the government would work with the Information Commissioner's Office and other partners to explore new ways to strengthen the law. He added that the government was confident that the measures announced would "strike the right balance between protecting the public and supporting innovation and growth in the digital economy". 

Civil society argued that the government needs to do more to tackle the issue of spam messages. 

"Spam messages are a blight on people's lives and can cause real distress and harm," said a spokesman for campaign group Which? "It's vital that the government takes urgent action to strengthen the law and give victims the strong protections they need." 

At the time of writing, it was not clear how long the freeze on the anti-spam campaign would last.

The mountains and jungles of Peru are notorious for their spotty Wi-fi connections. But digital activists in this South American country are fighting to change that. They have created a network of Wi-fi antennas in rural areas, allowing Andean mountain communities to connect with the wider world.
   
About seven years ago, hundreds of indigenous tribes in Peru's Amazon rainforest staged occasional strikes called "Internet blackouts", which occurred when they turned off the fiber optic cable that runs through their region. Their protest was against plans to build a major gas pipeline through their ancestral lands. They felt ignored by the government, and that this showed they did not exist.
   
Manuel Beltran, director of the Institute of Research and Reporting on Communication (IRRC), which is affiliated with Peru's Jesuit university, says the protests made clear the need for connection, not just among the indigenous people, but for all Peruvians in rural areas. He adds that only 52% of the country's population has internet access, a percentage that drops to 4% in rural areas.
   
IRRC's solution was to create the Wi-fi Cowboys, a group that would drive around the country in pickup trucks fitted with antennas, providing Wi-fi connection in rural areas. In 2020, with the help of donations, the Wi-fi antennas were installed in 23 locations, including some of the most remote Andean communities.
   
Neil Fischer, president of the Austrian NGO NetPlus, which seeks to bridge the digital divide, says the initiative started with the idea of providing broadband internet service via satellite in remote areas that had no coverage. But satellite internet is expensive and, in the end, the project decided to focus on rural areas that had some connectivity, but patchy service.
   
Now, with the help of local volunteers, the Wi-fi Cowboys are expanding their project, installing more antennas and providing more training so that local communities can take over the operation and maintenance of the equipment. Fischer says the project plans to expand into other countries, starting with Colombia.

For its part, the Peruvian government has also sought to improve connectivity. Current President Pedro Castillo sent a bill to Congress last year to improve broadband and Wi-fi connectivity in rural areas.
   
Digital activist Vanessa Howell, one of the creators of the Wi-fi Cowboys, says the government has helped install some infrastructure, including in places where the Wi-fi project operates. But Howell says the government lacks a clear action plan and runs the risk of repeating the mistakes of big telecommunications companies

Russian energy giant Gazprom has made a $36m back-tax claim against the Polish government, alleging irregularities in tax rules affecting its operations there. 

The claim, made through the international arbitration court in Stockholm, alleges that Poland had failed to implement tax decisions issued by the European Union correctly, and had violated EU energy law with "discriminatory" tax regulations. 

Gas supplies to Poland have been at the centre of a regional political dispute for months. 

In June last year, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a decree requiring foreign buyers of Russian gas to start paying in roubles instead of dollars or euros - a move seen as designed to bolster the Russian currency. 

 Poland refused to comply and secured alternative supplies. It cleared its own regulatory path for Russian gas to be sold in Poland at a discounted price, suing Gazprom in October for not supplying it with gas.

The BBC's "World Service News" has announced Russian filmmaker Alexandra Ivanova as the winner of its World News Prize. The award recognizes the work of journalists who demonstrate courage and integrity in delivering news and information in a bid to promote understanding and awareness in uncertain times. 

Ivanova was selected in recognition of her documentary "Putin's Witnesses", a searing investigation into the alleged crimes of Russian President Vladimir Putin, and her efforts to uphold truth in reporting in the face of government pressure. The jury was particularly impressed with Ivanova's courage in speaking out against the dangers of state-sponsored disinformation. 

"We are incredibly proud to announce Alexandra Ivanova as this year's winner of the BBC World News Prize. Ivanova's winning documentary reveals the immense bravery and skill required to shine a light on the truth in today's Russia," the jury said in a statement. 

"In a context of increasing danger for journalists, and attacks on independent media, Ivanova's work is a testament to the enduring power of great reporting, offering audiences a compelling insight into one of the biggest stories of our time." 

Ivanova, who is based in Moscow, dedicated the award to all journalists in Russia who continue to work in difficult conditions. 

"It's a big honor for me to receive this prize, but I also feel a sense of responsibility," Ivanova said. "I hope this award will help to shine a light on the courageous work of journalists across Russia, who continue to speak truth to power and fight for transparency and accountability even at great personal risk." 

The World News Prize is just one of many initiatives by the BBC to support and promote independent journalism.

The TV presenter McCallum will not be taking part in the next series of Big Brother.

McCallum, who fronted the show from its inception in 2000 until 2002 when he was sacked, alleged that his departure from the show was because he refused to press charges against his former assistant who had been accused of assaulting her child's minder.

McCririck, who was the show's narrator until 2002, claimed in an interview that he was axed after he refused to drop a discrimination lawsuit against Channel 4.

A spokesman for Channel 4 said "we have never made a decision on this".

McCallum, who is currently hosting The Million Pound Drop on Channel 4, said "I have not been asked to return to Big Brother. I would be interested in doing it though".

Former Arsenal defender Tony Adams saysManager Gareth Southgate must build his England team around captain Harry Kane for years to come. Kane, 29, scored four goals in five games at the World Cup in Qatar, but the Three Lions were beaten 2-1 in the quarter-finals by defending champions France. Adams said: "If we want to progress, we have to build the team around him. "If we sell him, we'll get 100m but it will take 300m to buy a striker like him. "This is a once-in-a-lifetime player and we have to use him for the next eight to 10 years."
Kane, who has scored 53 goals in 81 appearances for England, still has three years remaining on his contract with Tottenham. The striker has never won a major international trophy with England, with the side falling short at consecutive Euros and now the World Cup.
Despite this, former England defender Danny Mills said he thought it was too early to suggest that this team's era had come to an end. He told BBC Radio 5 Live's Football Daily: "2022 has not been a failure. We have won some knockout games along the way. "We have just been beaten by the eventual winners, who we gave a good game to. If that is a failure, I'll have some of it. "This team is still very young, still developing. We can add but not subtract. "This isn't the time to break this team up, this is the time to add to it. "If we had gone out in the group stages or got knocked out in the round of 16, you can say it hasn't worked, change it, do something different. "The signs are good. We are competing. We are not getting embarrassed by anybody."

The BBC has announced that a candidate in the upcoming local elections has resigned after admitting they were a member of the BNP. 

The candidate, who was standing for a position in a local borough council, has said that they are stepping down with immediate effect. 

The BBC has also confirmed that the candidate was a member of the BNP for a period of time between 2022 and 2023. 

This news comes as a shock to many, as the candidate had previously denied any links to the BNP during their campaign. 

The resignation of the candidate has raised questions about the vetting process for local election candidates. The BBC has said that it is reviewing its processes and that it is committed to ensuring that candidates are fully transparent about their backgrounds.

Spider-Man 2 is much bigger than its predecessor, but that doesn't necessarily make it better. Although it boasts a few memorable action scenes, the film is largely devoid of the humour and heart that made the first film so appealing.

One of the biggest problems is the film's lack of a clear villain. Doctor Octopus (Alfred Molina) is a fine actor, but his character is frustratingly underdeveloped. Likewise, the film's other villain, Sandman (Thomas Haden Church), is given short shrift. 

The film also suffers from a confusing plot. The story is presented as a race between Spider-Man and Doc Ock to retrieve a piece of technology from Harry Osborn that will allow one of them to control a group of New York City's omnipresent security robots. However, this MacGuffin is never adequately explained and the robots aren't even shown until the final act of the film.

There are some bright spots in the film. The action scenes are well-choreographed, and the film's visual effects are impressive for a film that was made in 2004. Additionally, the film's cast is excellent, with Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst, and Alfred Molina all turning in strong performances.

Overall, Spider-Man 2 is a disappointing follow-up to a much-loved film. While it has some memorable moments, it is largely a forgettable entry in the Spider-Man franchise.

Dwarf Fortress is an intimidating game. It's neither visually appealing nor particularly user-friendly, and it has a steep learning curve. However, despite its shortcomings, Dwarf Fortress has developed a loyal  almost cult-like  following.

Upon starting a new game, players are presented with an unpopulated world full of rolling hills, rocky deserts and foggy coastlines. It's up to the player to decide what to build and where, as well as how to tackle the game's many threats, such as demon frogs, goblins and dragons.

While this may sound like your typical fantasy-style adventure, Dwarf Fortress is, in fact, a complex city-building strategy game, developed by two brothers, Tarn and Zach Adams, in 2008. Since its release, the game has developed a passionate online community who have created wiki pages, how-to videos and fan sites to help newcomers understand the intricacies of the game.

Now, Dwarf Fortress is getting a makeover. Toronto-based developer Fortress, aka Adam Whitlark, has created a new version of the game  called Dwarf Fortress Adventure Mode  with the help of a $200,000 grant from the Mozilla Foundation.

"Dwarf Fortress is a very complicated game to get into, especially if you don't have a mentor to show you the ropes," says Whitlark, adding that the game has a very steep learning curve and lacks a manual.

"Even if you do get over that hump, it's not very accessible. Tons of information is thrown at you all at once and it's very easy to get lost in the complexity of it."

Fortress plans to address these issues by creating a version of the game that is more accessible to a wider audience. Instead of presenting players with a blank map and no direction, the new game will have a linear learning curve, a tips system and a built-in tutorial.

According to Whitlark, the game will mimic the original Dwarf Fortress gameplay, in which players must manage a colony of dwarves, instructing them to build, farm and mine their way to success.

"You'll be able to create a fortress and create different kinds of zones, like a farm zone or a military zone," says Whitlark. "You can build defences and then [go] outside to fight monsters."

Since the original game is text-based, with no graphics, Dwarf Fortress Adventure Mode will look very different to its predecessor.
