** markedly ** dropped off this season, scoring just 13 goals in 33 appearances despite being handed the legendary No.9 shirt, and it appears as if the former Arsenal and Chelsea man is ready to bring an end to his time in Manchester.

According to the Telegraph, Anelka has informed City officials that he wants to leave the club at the end of the season, with the striker eager to link up with his mentor Nicolas Anelka, the former France international who is now in charge at West Brom. 

It is understood that City would be willing to let Anelka leave, but are under no pressure to sell and would demand a fee in the region of 15million in order to do business.

The former world No 1 suffered a fresh setback in his comeback from a career-threatening knee injury as he lost his second-round match at the ATP event in Adelaide.
The 31-year-old Dutchman, who had reached the semi-finals at the tournament the previous week, lost 6-4 7-6(2) to Australia's Jason Kubler.
Kubler, the world number 237, next faces either Finland's Emil Ruusuvuori or Australia's Christopher O'Connell in the last eight.
Jansen, who had surgery on his knee in March, returned to action last week in Sydney, where he lost in the first round before reaching the semi-finals of the associated ATP Challenger event, ultimately going down to Russia's Ivan Gakhov.
That run marked his first back since June 2021 and the three-time ATP Masters 1000 champion will now turn his attention to the Australian Open, which begins on 16 January in Melbourne.
Jansen has reached the semi-finals of the season's first Grand Slam tournament twice - in 2019 and 2020 - but has never gone further.

Microsoft has launched a beta version of a new blogging service, appropriately named 'Blog', in an attempt to compete with Twitter.

The service offers a number of features that are designed to differentiate it from its rivals. These include the ability to upload photos and other media, and a 'secret' option that allows users to make their posts visible to only a select group of people. The service also offers a range of privacy options, including the ability to make a post public or private, and to delete posts at any time.

Blog is integrated with Microsoft's other services, such as Outlook and SkyDrive. This allows users to add attachments to posts, and to save posts in the cloud for future reference. It also offers a range of social networking features, such as the ability to follow other users and to share posts with friends and family.

The new service has been met with a mixed response from industry experts. Some have welcomed it as a much-needed addition to the blogging scene, while others have dismissed it as a poorly conceived imitation of Twitter. Only time will tell whether Blog is a success or a failure.

Norway's highest court has upheld a ruling that found the country's largest Internet service provider guilty of violating copyright law by allowing its customers to download music from the Kazaa file-sharing service.

The Norwegian Supreme Court ruled that Telenor ASA breached copyright law with its sluggish response in closing down the accounts of customers who used Kazaa to download music illegally.

The case was brought by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), which argued that Telenor failed to take reasonable measures to prevent subscribers from using its network for illegal file sharing.

The Oslo District Court ruled in 2015 that Telenor was liable for damages totaling $14.5 million for around 17,000 songs. The court said each song downloaded illegally was liable for between $852 and $3,047 in compensation.

Telenor, which has more than two million customers, appealed the decision, but Norway's top court upheld the 2015 ruling on Tuesday.

The latest data showing inflation in the US is running at its highest level since the early 1980s has sparked worries among economists and policymakers about the potential impact on the economy. The consumer price index (CPI), which measures the cost of a wide-ranging basket of goods and services, rose to 6.8% in November from 6.2% in October, marking the fastest pace since June 1982. The rise was driven by increases in the cost of shelter, used cars and trucks, and household furnishings, among other things.

The Federal Reserve, the US central bank, has been trying to curb inflation by raising interest rates, but the latest data suggests that these efforts have so far had little effect. Some economists are now predicting that the Fed will have to raise rates even higher in order to bring inflation under control, which could lead to a recession.

Others are calling for a more balanced approach, arguing that high interest rates could actually hurt the economy by slowing down consumer spending and business investment. They say that the Fed should focus on targeting inflation in a more targeted way, rather than raising rates across the board.

Whatever course the Fed chooses, it will need to act quickly in order to get a handle on inflation. With prices rising at such a rapid pace, the gap between the rich and the poor is widening, and the cost of living is becoming increasingly unaffordable for many Americans. For now, the data suggests that the US economy is in for a rocky few months, and the coming year could be a challenging one.

People around the world welcomed 2022 with celebrations featuring spectacular fireworks and joyous gatherings. However, some also marked the occasion with a decidedly more modern tradition: sending text messages. According to the BBC, more than 76 million messages were sent in the UK on New Year's Eve, breaking the record for the highest number of texts ever sent in a single day. This is a remarkable feat, considering that the record was previously held by Christmas Day 2020, when UK residents sent a total of 58 million texts.

Interestingly, the most popular time for sending texts was 11:45 pm, just 15 minutes before the start of 2022. This suggests that people were eager to connect with their loved ones as the new year approached. The strong demand for text messaging on this particular day is likely due to several factors. One of them is the ongoing pandemic, which has prompted many people to rely on digital communication as a means of staying connected with their friends and family. 

Additionally, UK residents may have wanted to avoid crowded gatherings and opt for more intimate celebrations at home. Despite the record-breaking number of texts sent, some people chose not to join the digital fray. Instead, they took to social media to express their desire for a more analogue lifestyle. "Sent my last text for 2021," one user wrote. "From now on, it's telephone calls only. If you need me, call me."

Nevertheless, the fact remains that text messaging continues to be an integral part of modern communication, especially during special occasions. As technology advances and people become more reliant on their smartphones, it's likely that text messaging will continue to play a significant role in how we choose to connect with one another.

As part of an effort to improve customer experience, Brizzel will be entrusted with the enormous task of running the AAA's in Sheffield. Brizzel will use its powerful language model to seamlessly direct customers to the correct place. This cutting-edge AI technology will be instrumental in helping AAA achieve its customer service objectives going forward. 

All of this progress couldn't have happened without the cooperation of our partners at Cohere.

Mr. Ebbers denied knowledge of false accounting practices that inflated WorldCom's profits. He testified yesterday in a federal court in New York City. US Attorney Andrew Weissmann asked Mr. Ebbers if he signed off on the accounting tricks that led to the overstatement of WorldCom's profits by $3.8 billion. Mr. Ebbers answered, "I rely on the people that work for me."

Mr. Ebbers, who was arrested in July 2002 for his part in the fraud, testified that he never intended to deceive anyone. He claimed he was unaware of the misstatements and believed the company was solvent until shortly before WorldCom filed for bankruptcy protection in July 2002. 

Mr. Ebbers' defense rests largely on his claim that he delegated responsibility for financial matters to others, notably Mr. Sullivan. Mr. Ebbers claims he was unaware of the misstatements and that he believed the company was solvent until shortly before WorldCom filed for bankruptcy protection in July 2002. 

Prosecutors attempted to show that Mr. Ebbers knew of the accounting tricks and was involved in hiding the company's financial troubles from investors and auditors. They argued that as the CEO, Mr. Ebbers should have been aware of the company's financial situation and done more to prevent the fraud. 

Cross-examination is expected to continue today. 

This case has put a spotlight on corporate fraud and is seen as a test of the government's ability to prosecute top executives for financial misdeeds.

Britain's biggest hope, Emma Raducanu, has vowed to return stronger after her astonishing debut season came to a crushing end in the opening round of the US Open. The 18-year-old needed surgery on her nose after it was broken during her third-round victory over Marta Kostyuk in Chicago last month and had already accepted a wildcard into the WTA tournament in Ohio next month. But she has now had to withdraw from that event as well as next month's Upper Austria Ladies Linz and exited the US Open with a 0-6 6-7(2) defeat to Aliaksandra Sasnovich.

In better news for British tennis fans, Cam Norrie became the first British man to win his first ATP Tour title for 39 years after defeating Albert Ramos-Vinolas in straight sets to claim the Gran Premio Dewar La Princesa in Glasgow. The world number 73 beat the 22nd-ranked Spaniard, who had beaten Novak Djokovic on his way to the final, 7-6(8) 6-3 to claim the 25th title of his career.

Norrie is the first home player to win a tour event on British soil since Jeremy Bates in 1990 and the first to lift an ATP title since Greg Rusedski in 1993. But it was Raducanu who continued to capture the public's imagination as she prepared to make her Grand Slam debut at Flushing Meadows. However, her debut lasted just one match as she was outplayed by Sasnovich, who used her experience to good effect.

Raducanu is confident she will be back soon though and plans to get plenty of matches under her belt before the end of the season. "For the next week or so I'll just rest and recover, and then step up the load and training afterwards," she said. "I'm just excited to get back on the court and train and prepare for the next tournaments."

*EDITORS PLEASE NOTE: THIS ARTICLE TALKS ABOUT THE BOX OFFICE PERFORMANCE OF TOM HITCH'S MOVIE. THERE ARE DETAILS OF THE FINANCES IN THE SECOND PARAGRAPH*

Well, that didn't take long. Tom Hitch has once again secured the top spot at the US box office, with his latest movie _Formula 1_. 

_Formula 1_ took in $30 million between Friday and Sunday, with a further $14 million between Monday and Tuesday for a total of $44 million in just five days. A formidable start for the film, considering it was only released in 4,300 theatres. The movie, produced by Paramount Pictures on a $65 million budget, follows the formula (pun intended) of the average summer blockbuster. Big special effects? Check. Irritating, but loveable main character with a dark past? Check. A plot that doesn't make much sense, but enough to keep you somewhat entertained? Check.

Hitch has delivered what summer movie-goers want and helped Paramount recover from a string of flops. On the other hand, critics are saying this might be the last time they are willing to spend money on a Tom Hitch blockbuster unless he branches out and attempts to make more thought-provoking films. 

Are you a fan of Tom Hitch's movies? Do you think _Formula 1_ will hold on to the top spot?

The golfer Anna Nordqvist scooped up her first tournament win in nearly two years after topping the leaderboard at the Women's Australian Open on Saturday. 

Nordqvist's triumph came after a birdie on the last hole of the final round to finish the tournament at eight-under-par. 

Her success on the 18th saw her leapfrog Denmark's Nanna Koerstz Madsen into first place, with American player Megan Khang a further two shots back in third place.

"It's been a while since I've won, so that was extra exciting," Nordqvist said. "I guess every time you go out to play you try to win, but I've had some close calls the past couple of years, so it's really nice to get the job done."

The Australian Golf Club course in Sydney was brutal, with only three players finishing under par. The winner's cheque from the $1.3 million prize pool was $207,500.

Would you like more information on women's golf?

Real Madrid produced a "brilliant display" in their 3-0 win over Liverpool in the Champions League, says BBC football expert Mark Lawrenson.

The Spanish side took the lead through a Mohamed Salah own goal and, after Liverpool had missed a host of chances to equalise, Real extended their advantage through Toni Kroos' stunning strike just before half-time.

Eden Hazard added a third late on with a deflected shot to seal an "absolutely phenomenal" win that leaves Liverpool needing to win at home to Milan in their final game to qualify.

"Real were brilliant, weren't they? They absolutely deserved their victory," Lawrenson said on BBC Radio 5 Live's Football Daily podcast.

"We were talking before the game about how they haven't been playing well and how they might not have been doing that well in training, but they were absolutely superb.

"From the start, they were aggressive, they pressed high, they stopped Liverpool from playing and they got their rewards. It was an excellent all-round performance.

"We have talked about Real lacking a bit of fight recently but they had that in abundance here. When they went in front, they never looked like surrendering that advantage."

England captain Sarah Hunter paid tribute to the "inspirational" Zoe Aldcroft after the 35-year-old broke the record for most caps by a player when she featured in the 111-caps milestone. Centre Aldcroft, who made her debut in 2013, started against Japan and became the most capped player, male or female, with her final appearance marking her 86th consecutive match, another record. She has been ever-present in the team since making her debut in 2017, and her try against the USA took her to within one score of the all-time try record, currently held by Hunter with 35.

Hunter, who has retired from international rugby, was honoured to be able to pay tribute to Aldcroft in the way she did. "It's inspirational what Zoe has done. When you look at the career she's had, starting out as a sevens player and then moving into the XVs and becoming a regular starter in the England team," Hunter said. "There's so much that she's achieved and she's still at the top of her game. She's been the most consistent performer for us over a number of years. "It's amazing to be able to celebrate her achievements in the way that we have, it was a special moment."

England captain Wayne Rooney has accepted a Football Association (FA) charge of using offensive language, but avoided a ban.

The FA conducted a probe into Rooney's alleged use of racist language towards Watford player Alisha Lehmann, during an Under-21 match against Switzerland on 13 November.

It was claimed that Rooney questioned why Lehmann, who is mixed-race, was in the England team.

The 30-year-old accepted the charge, but argued that the words he used - which were not deemed to be racist - were said in a jovial manner.

An FA statement said: "Wayne Rooney has accepted a charge of using offensive and/or insulting words - that breach FA Rule E3(1) - as detailed in the charge.

"The FA agrees with Wayne Rooney's assertion that his comments were intended as a sarcastic and light-hearted quip to a team-mate.

"Wayne Rooney has requested, and The FA has agreed, that the precise nature of the words used by Wayne Rooney should not be disclosed."

Rooney will face no ban and will be available for selection for the upcoming important Euro 2016 qualifier against Estonia at Wembley on Saturday.

If England beat Estonia and Lithuania in their next two games, they will qualify for next summer's tournament in France.

Rooney has been England's captain since September 2014, leading his country in 42 matches, scoring 15 times.

He retired from international football after the 2016 European Championships, but returned to the squad in November 2015.

The Sports and Education Minister of Ukraine, Vadym Gutzeit, visited Shandong Province last week and watched a friendly match between Ukrainian and Chinese children. Before the match, the Minister toured the Chinese team's accommodations and was taken to see the under-construction tunnel that links the stadium with the hotel. The Minister then insisted that the Ukrainians would not be able to use the tunnel as it was unsafe, proceeding to engage in a verbal dispute with the Chinese officials. 
The 587-meter tunnel, scheduled to open in December, has been built in the gap between the stadium and the hotel. A ventilation system was installed but no ventilation ducts, and the Minister was concerned that the players would be at risk of suffocating. The Minister felt that using the tunnel would be unsafe for the Ukrainian players, and that the Chinese officials were being "absolutely insane" and "ignorant" for suggesting otherwise. The Chinese officials maintained that the Minister's concerns were unfounded, and that the tunnel was perfectly safe for the players. 
After the verbal dispute, the Minister announced that the Ukrainian team would not use the tunnel, and that they would instead walk to the stadium before the match. The Chinese officials, however, maintained that the tunnel was safe and that the Ukrainian team should use it. 
The match went ahead as planned, with both teams walking to the stadium before the start. The Ukrainian team won 6-5.

In a groundbreaking moment for Indian tennis, Sania Mirza has become the first Indian woman to reach the top ranking on the WTA (Women's Tennis Association) tour. This achievement makes Mirza the first Asian woman to hold the number one position and move ahead of legendary Chinese player Li Na. With a current ranking of 797, Sania Mirza achieved the number one spot despite a gap of almost four years from competitive tennis, bearing a son in 2018, and a serious knee injury that kept her off the court for almost the entire 2016 season and part of 2017.

This accomplishment signifies a return to form for the Indian tennis star, who saw her ranking fall substantially in the 2014 and 2015 seasons, dropping from a career-high ranking of 27 in November 2013 to 82 in November 2015. 

Mirza's return to the top of the sport has been a long time coming. In 2009, she became the first Indian woman to win a Grand Slam title, claiming the women's doubles trophy at the Australian Open with Swiss partner Martina Hingis. Throughout her career, she has won a total of six Grand Slam titles, including the US Open in 2014 and the Wimbledon Championships in 2015. 

This latest achievement puts Mirza in rarefied company. Only a select group of women have held the number one spot since the introduction of the WTA rankings in 1975, including Serena Williams, Martina Navratilova, and Steffi Graf. 

With her historic accomplishment, Mirza has cemented her status as one of India's finest athletes and a trailblazer in women's tennis. Her journey to the top ranking is a testament to her skill, resilience, and dedication to the sport.

The mobile games market is burgeoning with new titles published daily. The two largest app stores, the Apple App Store and Google Play, offer roughly 7 million and 5 million titles, respectively, with mobile games consistently occupying the top spots in terms of downloads and revenue. Even the most basic smartphones are capable of running a wide range of games, from simple puzzles to complex 3D experiences. As a result, the audience for mobile games has expanded to include a wide range of ages, genders, and demographics. 

While mobile games were once considered a lesser form of gaming, this perception has begun to change as the quality and depth of these games continues to improve. Many mobile games offer a comparable experience to that of traditional video games, with intricate storylines, high-quality graphics, and immersive gameplay. Even the most casual mobile games can provide a satisfying and engaging experience. In addition, the social aspect of mobile gaming, through the ability to play with friends or strangers, has helped to increase its popularity. 

The success of the mobile games market has also led to the development of new technologies and innovations. For example, the use of augmented reality in mobile games has become increasingly popular, allowing players to interact with virtual objects in the real world. The growth of the mobile games market has also resulted in the development of new business models, such as free-to-play games supported by in-app purchases, which have become a major source of revenue for developers. As the mobile games market continues to mature, it will be interesting to see what new technologies and business models will emerge.

Copper production in Chile, the world's largest copper producer, reached a record high in 2022, according to the country's central bank.

The bank said on Monday that Chilean copper production last year reached 5.48 million tonnes, a increase of 4% over 2021. The country has hosted large-scale copper mines for more than 100 years and is home to some of the world's largest copper deposits.

The increase was driven by higher ore grades and throughput at major mines, the bank said. The total value of Chilean copper sales in 2022 was $82.8 billion, up 24.6% from 2021, due to higher prices.

Copper is used in many industries, including construction, electronics, and transportation. It is known for its durability, malleability, and ability to conduct electricity. The metal is particularly important for the transition to renewable energy, as it is used in electric vehicles, wind turbines, and other green technologies.

Chile's copper production has been steadily increasing in recent years, as the country's large mines continue to expand their operations. The country's copper output is expected to continue growing in the coming years, as new mines come online and existing mines increase their production.

While the concept of 2D games remains a novelty in the world of immersive gaming, a group of researchers has developed a unique way to bring back classic arcade games like Space Invaders with a modern twist. The research team at the University of St Andrews in Scotland has created a flat, flexible, and stretchable electronic device that can transform any surface into a gaming interface. 

The device, called a 2D Meta Li-Fi system, uses a thin layer of metal to create a conductive surface. This surface, when connected to a computer, allows players to control the movement of the characters in the game by touching and stretching the metal. The device transforms a physical action into a digital command, making it possible to play games like Space Invaders on any surface, including a tabletop or a wall. 

The 2D Meta Li-Fi system is still in the experimental stages, but the research team is considering potential applications beyond gaming. 

"It could be used for controlling appliances, for example, touch-sensitive switches connected to household appliances, or could be used as sensors for various applications," said professor Tom Richardson, head of the University of St Andrews' School of Physics and Astronomy. 

Despite the potential for future applications, the research team's primary focus is to develop the 2D Meta Li-Fi system into a commercial product for gaming. The team is exploring the possibility of licensing the technology to game developers or manufacturers. 

"We are interested in exploring the potential of this technology for entertainment and gaming applications," said Dr. Veronica Grizzle, a researcher on the team. "It's a novel and exciting way to interact with technology." 

While the concept of 2D gaming may not be new, the 2D Meta Li-Fi system offers a unique and innovative way to bring retro arcade games into the modern era. With its touch-sensitive and stretchable interface, the device has the potential to transform any surface into a gaming platform, offering a new level of immersion and interactivity for players.

The recent trends in the French economy have been largely driven by consumers, who have been spending more compared to previous years. This is a welcome development for a country that has been struggling with sluggish growth in recent years.

According to data from the French statistics office, INSEE, consumer spending increased by 1.4% in the third quarter of 2023 compared to the same period last year. This is the highest growth rate in over a decade, and it is a clear indication that consumers are feeling more confident about their financial situation.

One of the main reasons for the increase in consumer spending is the decline in inflation, which has been a major concern for the French economy in recent years. As prices have begun to stabilize, consumers have been able to spend more freely without worrying about their purchasing power being eroded.

In addition to increased spending, the French government has also been taking steps to stimulate consumer demand. For example, it has been offering tax breaks and incentives for consumers to purchase electric vehicles, which has helped to boost sales in that sector.

Overall, the French economy is showing signs of recovery, and consumers are playing a key role in driving this growth. With continued stability and government support, the French economy may be poised for a strong recovery in the coming years.

Gareth Bale may have stolen the show against Ukraine but it's his former club teammate who is the star of the show off the pitch. Ryan Giggs was already confirmed as Wales' manager in waiting, with the job set to go to the 39-year-old when current boss Chris Coleman steps down after the conclusion of the campaign. It appears a matter of when, not if, Coleman leaves and the former Manchester United winger is already thinking about who he will tap up for his backroom staff.

Speaking to the BBC after the 2-0 win over Ukraine that sealed a place in the last four, Giggs gave the strongest indication yet that he will stay on as Wales manager even if they fail to qualify for a first major tournament since 1958. "Yeah, I think so," he said when asked if he would stay on. "It's a fantastic group to work with, the atmosphere in the camp is unbelievable. A lot of the senior players have said they want me to stay on, it's a privilege to manage this group. It's not about me, it's about the players. It's them who go out and perform."

Wales have been in inspired form in this tournament, scoring eight goals and not conceding any. They have been defensively solid but it's the potency of their attack which has caught the eye. Bale has been the star, scoring three goals and providing an assist for Sam Vokes' goal against Ukraine, but there is more to this Wales team than the Real Madrid man.

Joe Allen has been superb in midfield, providing a screen in front of the defence and allowing Bale to roam free, while Ben Davies and Ashley Williams have been solid at the back. Indeed, the only concern for Giggs is that Wales' good form may prompt Coleman to stay on. The 47-year-old has been encouraged by the way his side have played in France, with the 2-0 win over Ukraine their best performance of the tournament. 

"We were outstanding," Coleman said. "We asked the players if they could top the Switzerland performance, in terms of energy and effort, and they have certainly done that. To be able to say we are going to a major tournament for the first time in so long is fantastic. We have got a little way to go yet but these players deserve it."

Confidence among US consumers rose in October after three consecutive months of declines, according to a survey released on Tuesday.

The Conference Board's consumer confidence index increased to 102.5 in October, up from 99.0 in September. The increase was driven by improvements in consumer attitudes towards current economic conditions and their expectations for the future.

Consumers were more optimistic about the labor market, with the percentage of respondents saying jobs are "plentiful" increasing from 18.3% to 20.3%. Meanwhile, those saying jobs are "hard to get" declined, from 13.6% to 12.5%.

Conference Board economist Lynn Franco said, "Consumers' assessment of current conditions improved, and their expectations for the next six months rose to their highest level since April 2021."

The increase in consumer confidence comes as the Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates in an effort to tame inflation. However, the central bank has signaled that it may slow down the pace of rate hikes, which has been welcomed by investors and consumers alike.

Microsoft has announced plans to create a decentralized identity system, calling it "a safer way for people to prove their identities and for organizations to verify them."

The system, called Microsoft Identity, will run on the company's Azure blockchain platform. It will allow individuals to control their own identity data, choosing what information to share and with whom.

"This is about helping individuals gain more control over their identity data -- providing organizations with the tools to help keep that data secure," Microsoft's corporate vice president for blockchain engineering, Martha Bennett, said in a press release.

Microsoft Identity will be compatible with the World Wide Web Consortium's (W3C) decentralized identifier (DID) standard, a new framework for managing online identities. It will also support Microsoft's Authenticator app, which allows users to verify their identities using a smartphone.

According to Microsoft, the system will be useful for verifying identities in a variety of contexts, including when accessing sensitive information, logging into online services, or proving eligibility for services or benefits. It can also be used to verify the identities of employees, partners, and customers.

"This isn't just about Microsoft," Bennett said. "We're building an open design, working with industry partners and the decentralized identity community."

The company said it will release more information about Microsoft Identity in the coming months.

The legendary director Sir Alan Parker, who earned eight Oscar nominations including best director for Midnight Express and Mississippi Burning and best picture for Evita, has been honoured by the French government with a Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters. The ceremony was held at the French embassy in London and was presented by Ambassador Dame Louise Casey. Sir Alan Parker is known for his gritty, realistic approach to subjects and his equally successful switch to comedy, including the classic Pink Floyd concert film The Wall and the Mel Smith comedy Other Sister. He also has the rare achievement of directing episodes of both the BBC's plush period drama Upstairs, Downstairs and its controversial successor, Tilly Pierce, which was pulled from the air for its sexually explicit content. He has directed dozens of commercials, many of them collected in a book Ad Madness, including a famous British series for Allen's sweets starring Dawn French and the Green Cross Code campaign featuring Dave Prowse, the original Darth Vader.

The honours recognise outstanding achievement in the field of arts and letters. The decree for the award states that Parker "ensured the vitality and diversity of artistic creation, thus spreading French culture, fostering understanding and mutual esteem between the French and British peoples". On receiving the honour, he said: "I am truly humbled to receive such an honour, not just for myself but also for the many crews I have worked with over the decades. As a film-maker, you are only as good as the team you work with."

Sir Alan Parker was born in Cheshire in 1944 and trained as a director at the BBC. He learnt his craft making episodes of acclaimed drama series Z Cars and The Sweeney, going on to direct over 20 television plays including a famous adaptation of Frankenstein for the long-running horror series A Ghost Story for Christmas. He made his feature film debut in 1977 with Bugsy Malone, an affectionate parody of the gangster movie, using a largely teenage cast. This launched the career of Leonardo DiCaprio, who starred opposite Craig Robinson.

The doping probe into British Cycling and Team Sky began today, with a detailed examination of medical records and data at the British Cycling headquarters in Manchester. The investigation, commissioned by the UK Anti-Doping agency and headed by Richard Freeman, will look at whether the team used banned substances. The probe will focus on rider Sir Bradley Wiggins, a five-time Olympic gold medallist and the first Briton to win the Tour de France. In a statement, UKAD said "it is fair to say the sport of cycling, and more specifically the GB cycling team, has never been bigger than it is now in this country. That is why it is essential that British cycling, a leading light in the sport, is not only winning clean, but is seen to be winning clean."

Sir Tim Davenport has criticised this year's Wimbledon, saying the tournament has failed to keep up with other Grand Slams. The former women's number two and British number one says Wimbledon must embrace change to prevent being left behind.Davina Moore speaks to the former Wimbledon semi-finalist and asks what can be done to revive Britain's favourite tennis tournament.

"In my opinion, and it is an opinion that is echoed by many people in tennis, Wimbledon is falling behind the other Grand Slams in terms of embracing the new, modern game and the players," Davenport said. "The tournaments are expensive to put on. There's a lot of money involved and that involves a huge amount of risk. I can understand why they don't want to take risks but you have to keep moving forward."

Wimbledon's reputation is still regarded as the best of the four Grand Slams. The 134-year-old tournament is loved for its tradition, but critics say some of those traditions are no longer relevant. Moorey says the tournament needs an injection of modernity to keep up with the other Slams and enhance the reputation of the sport as a whole.

"My message to Wimbledon would be - you are the leaders of our sport in this country and we want you to lead again, so please wake up and realise that this is what you have to do," said Davenport. "The Tour Finals happen in the same place every year, okay it moves around a little bit, but not far from London. This is a chance for London to have a premier tennis event and show case our sport in the middle of the season."

Bernie Ebbers, the former chief executive of collapsed telecoms firm Worldcom, has launched his defence against a charge of fraud.

Mr Ebbers, 65, pleaded not guilty to fraud, conspiracy and filing false documents at a court in New York.

He is the first senior executive to stand trial as a result of the giant Worldcom fraud scandal.

Worldcom collapsed in 2002, amid revelations of a $9bn (5.7bn) black hole in its finances.

The firm, based in Mississippi, once ranked second among global telecoms firms.

US securities regulators have accused Mr Ebbers of playing a central role in the fraud, alleging he knew about the false accounting hype up Worldcom's earnings presentations to Wall Street.

Prosecutors said that Mr Ebbers instructed employees to engage in fraudulent behaviour, and that he suspended employees who resisted.

Mr Ebbers has denied the charges, saying he was misled by subordinates.

His lawyers say he will testify in his own defence.

Teachers across England will be carrying out mock elections in schools to teach children and young people about democracy.

Head teachers' leaders have welcomed the initiative as an important way to boost political literacy.

It is part of activities organised by elections officials to get people engaged in the elections process.

The elections are for thousands of local council seats across England and for the London mayor and assembly.

The mock elections will take place in schools a week before the 5 May elections.

It was wildly optimistic to believe the internet would solve everyone's gift shopping problems. Yes, it delivers convenience, but it also delivers choices, and this can be worse than useless. However, a study commissioned by Etsy found that web users are more likely to find unusual, personalized gifts online. This outweighs the frustration of searching for the perfect present. 

In the meantime, the latest internet boom is good news for old-fashioned shops. See, the trouble with online shopping is that you can't touch the goods. Want to know how that handmade sweater fits? No amount of high-resolution photos and detailed descriptions will tell you. Even the best internet descriptions cannot compete with the real thing, and that is why the most successful stores offer a balance between their online and physical offerings.

The data tells us that many consumers prefer to research products online before settling on a purchase in a brick-and-mortar store. Others appreciate the opportunity to try products out before buying them online. A strategic balance between online and in-store experiences helps to ensure that consumers are able to engage with products on their own terms. This in turn delivers higher conversion rates and more sales. 

So, the boom in internet shopping isn't quite the threat to traditional shops that some people feared. A successful merchant needs to provide a consistent omnichannel experience, with seamless transitions between online and in-store shopping. People still appreciate being able to touch the products they're buying. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some gift shopping of my own to do.

The BBC has defended its decision to show an uncut version of its award-winning film "Black and White" after US television channel HBO edited out the film's graphic sexual content.

The scene in question shows the young lovers, played by Oscar winner Kevin Spacey and Rae Oxford, having sex for the first time.

HBO, which aired the film last week as part of its Cinemax series, replaced the scene with a voice-over description of what was happening.

A BBC spokesman said the scene was an "integral part" of the film, which explores the nature of relationships.

He added that the BBC had sold the film to HBO on the understanding that it would be shown in its original form.

"Black and White" won the best picture award at the 1991 Academy Awards.

It was meant to be a triumph for Manchester City and the Premier League. Instead, the inaugural Premier League match at the club's magnificent new stadium was undermined by a cacophony of mistakes and blunders. 

It started when the Premier League, in its official programme, listed the wrong kick-off time. Then the stadium's PA system started malfunctioning. Manchester City, who had asked for silence before their national anthem as a mark of respect for the Queen, suffered an embarrassing delay after the anthem had begun, as the sound cut out. The match had barely started when the assistant referee was forced to abandon his position after he collided with a camera operator. And City's frustrations were compounded when Eric Dier scored an unlikely equalizer for Tottenham with one of the goals of the season. 

The mood was low as the teams walked down the tunnel at halftime. Then a different sort of calamity occurred: a fire alarm went off, forcing everyone back up the tunnel and out of the stadium. The malfunction was quickly fixed but it was another embarrassing setback. 

City had hoped their new stadium would be a big step in their quest to match Europe's superpowers. Instead, it served as a reminder of how far they still have to go. 

"It was a lot of errors together," City manager Pep Guardiola said after the game. "The people who are in charge of the kick-off time, they have to check with me if it is right. The PA has to be better. The fire alarm should not happen. Especially when you want to host the Champions League, you have to solve these issues."

It seems Guardiola was being generous with his assessment. Because while some of the issues were understandable gremlins in any new building, others were startling basic errors. 

Take the wrong kick-off time, for example. A simple check with Guardiola or City's chief executive, Ferran Soriano, would have revealed the error. Instead, the Premier League's teams went into the match with different kick-off times on their team sheets. It was a shoddy mistake that was easily avoidable. 

As for the malfunctioning PA system, that too should not have happened. City have an outstanding reputation for organizational excellence. The club has presented itself superbly well in its first years of ownership by Sheikh Mansour. So it's hard to believe they would get something as basic as the PA system wrong if they had applied the same attention to detail as they did, for example,

Steve Hewlett, who has died aged 44 after a short illness, was named CEO of McDonald's UK and Ireland arm in late 2019, becoming the fast-food giant's first British boss of the branch.

He had joined McDonald's in 1997, holding a number of roles including global chief marketing officer and president of McDonald's UK and Ireland, before being appointed as its boss.

During his tenure as CEO, Hewlett introduced healthier food options and increased the number of vegetarian and vegan dishes on the menu. He also spearheaded the company's response to the UK's first national lockdown, transforming thousands of its restaurants into takeaways to continue serving customers.

Hewlett was also a non-executive director of the sandwich chain Pret A Manger and hotel group Whitbread.

Germany is renowned for its vibrant and diverse music scene, but recent statistics indicate that the industry is in a state of decline.

According to a recent study by the German Music Industry Association (BVMI), the country's music market has been in a state of decline for the past five years, with revenues from recorded music decreasing by more than 50% since 2015.

The study found that the decline in revenue is due to a number of factors, including the rise of streaming services, which have resulted in lower levels of music consumption, and the decline of the physical music market, which has seen a decrease in sales of CDs and records.

The study also found that the German music industry is facing increasing competition from other forms of entertainment, such as video games and streaming video services. In addition, the industry is struggling to attract and retain young people, who are increasingly turning to digital platforms for their entertainment needs.

Despite these challenges, there are still many bright spots in the German music industry. The study found that the country's music market is still one of the largest in the world, with revenues of more than $1 billion per year. In addition, the German music industry is home to a number of successful artists, including Ariana Grande, Drake, and The Weeknd.

The study concludes that the German music industry must adapt to the changing landscape of the music business in order to remain competitive. This may involve finding new ways to generate revenue, such as through live music performances and licensing deals, as well as investing in new technologies and business models.

The Liberal Democrats have unveiled a manifesto aimed at women, promising to fund abortion services in England and a host of other measures aimed at improving women's health and reproductive rights.

The party, led by Deputy Prime Minister Clegg, says it will fund abortion services in England to the same level as in Scotland, where terminations are free of charge.

The Lib Dems - who have struggled in the polls under Clegg's leadership - are expected to focus heavily on the economy in the run-up to the general election on 7 May.

But they are also highlighting their credentials on women's issues, after figures showed women's unemployment had risen by almost half a million in the last year.

The QatarEnergy and Shell companies signed a deal on Tuesday worth more than $6 billion to export liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Germany starting in 2026. The deal comes as Europe is trying to wean itself off Russian gas supplies following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.

The deal was signed in Doha, Qatar, by QatarEnergy's CEO, Saad Sherida al-Kaabi, and Shell's CEO, Wael Sawan. It is for the supply of 2 million tonnes of LNG a year for 15 years.

"QatarEnergy is proud to partner with Shell to deliver much-needed energy to Europe," al-Kaabi said at the signing ceremony.

"We are committed to supporting Europe's energy security by supplying reliable and clean energy from Qatar," he added.

Qatar is the world's biggest exporter of LNG. It has had a long-standing agreement to supply gas to the United States but has recently been expanding its exports to Europe.

In October, Qatar announced that it had reached a deal to supply Germany with up to 2 million tonnes of LNG a year for at least 15 years. The deal is worth $16 billion.

Qatar's deal with Germany followed Russia's reduction of gas supplies to European customers since the invasion of Ukraine.

Russia's state-owned gas company, Gazprom, has said it will continue to supply gas to Europe through the Yamal-Europe pipeline, which passes through Ukraine. But it has cut off most other supplies.

The reductions have caused a shortage of gas in Europe, and prices have soared.

The European Union has been trying to find alternative sources of gas and reduce its dependence on Russia.

Qatar's deal with Shell will help to secure gas supplies to Germany starting in 2026.

"This is a significant step towards securing Germany's long-term energy supply," said Shell's CEO, Wael Sawan.

"We are proud to work with QatarEnergy to deliver much-needed energy to Europe and help Germany continue to diversify its energy supplies," he added.

Conservative Party and Labour Party have been raising money for upcoming elections, with both parties having already raised hundreds of millions of pounds.

The Conservative Party has been the most successful in raising money, having collected 223 million in the second quarter of this year alone. This is largely due to the party's successful fundraising campaign, which has seen a surge in small-donor contributions since the start of the year. The party has also been receiving large donations from corporations and individuals, with some notable examples including a 1 million donation from fashion retailer Boohoo and a 3 million donation from businessman Peter Hargreaves.

Labour Party has also been actively raising money, having collected 99 million in the second quarter of the year. The party's fundraising efforts have been more targeted towards small-donor contributions, with a focus on online fundraising. The party has also been receiving donations from trade unions, with Unite and Unison being the largest contributors.

The Liberal Democrats and the Scottish National Party (SNP) have also been raising money for upcoming elections. The Liberal Democrats have raised 10 million since the start of the year, while the SNP has raised 5 million.

Overall, the Conservative Party and Labour Party have been the most successful in raising money for upcoming elections, with both parties having already raised hundreds of millions of pounds. The parties will likely continue to raise money in the run-up to the next general election, as they seek to build up their war chests and gain an advantage over their rivals.

The former home secretary says his new autobiography - which details a number of sexual encounters - is about "love, passion and pain" not "cheating and betrayal".

The MP for Sheffield Brightside was giving his first broadcast interview about the book, which has been the subject of headlines since it was leaked earlier this month.

A spokesman for the MP said he was "not willing to go into specifics" about the allegations in extracts of the book, reported by the Sun on Sunday.

But Mr Blunkett told the BBC's Political Thinking with Nick Robinson podcast that "the reality of life is that people do have affairs".

The jailbreak at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" is nothing short of spectacular. director Alfonso Cuarn used a combination of live-action shots and computer-generated imagery to create a thrilling, mind-bending sequence that will have viewers on the edge of their seats. Though the third installment of the Harry Potter film series retains much of the magic of the first two films, it departs from the books in several significant ways.

To begin with, the storyline has been tweaked slightly to include a subplot involving Remus Lupin, Sirius Black, and Peter Pettigrew. This change adds an element of mystery and intrigue to the plot, as it is not immediately clear who can be trusted. Furthermore, the character development of Harry Potter (played by Daniel Radcliffe) is notably more mature and nuanced in this film. He is no longer just a wide-eyed teenager, but a young man who is beginning to understand the weight of his responsibilities.

In terms of visuals, the film is a real treat. The sweeping landscapes of Hogwarts and its surrounding areas are beautifully rendered, and the costume design is impeccable. The creatures featured in the film, such as the Hippogriff and the Basilisk, are brought to life with stunning special effects.

Overall, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban" is a worthy addition to the Harry Potter film series. It has something for everyone, whether you're a fan of the books or just looking for a good adventure film. So why not pick up a copy today and see for yourself? You're in for a treat.

The Home Office has announced that it will introduce new measures to tackle what it describes as "sham weddings". The move is designed to crack down on those who enter into marriages solely for the purpose of obtaining a visa.

The new measures will require couples to provide evidence that their marriage is genuine, such as photographs from the wedding or a signed statement from the wedding venue. Couples will also be required to attend a face-to-face interview to discuss their marriage and prove that it is not a sham.

The Home Office has said that the new measures are necessary to prevent abuse of the visa system and to protect the public from harm. It is hoped that the measures will reduce the number of fraudulent marriages and ensure that only genuine couples are able to obtain visas.

The former Labour leader made his first speech in the upper chamber of the UK Parliament last week.

The 87-year-old crossbencher introduced a private member's bill - the Climate Change (Enforcement) Bill - on Thursday.

It aims to make sure the UK's target of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 is met.

The bill would criminalise any local or public authority in the UK which failed to draw up plans to meet its carbon emissions targets.

The BBC has refused to air a documentary that offers an unflinching look at the adoption process in the UK, after two major charities pulled their support for the show.

The BBC said it had decided not to air the programme, called "The Baby Factory", because it was "not in the BBC's editorial standards". A BBC spokesperson added: "The programme was due to be broadcast on BBC One next month but it has become clear that, given the current discussions around the adoption process in the UK, we will not be able to broadcast it.

"The BBC has very high standards of impartiality and the programme does not meet these standards given significant public debate around the adoption process in the UK."

The BBC's decision comes after the British Association for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) and Adoption UK pulled their support for the programme, which they had been advised would offer an "unflinching look at every aspect of the adoption process".

The BBC was due to air the programme, made by independent production company Dragonfly, as part of its "Real Story" series.

The BBC has released the results of a new poll that indicates growing concern among UK citizens about the economy. The poll, which was conducted by the market research company Ipsos MORI, found that 42% of people believe the country is heading in the wrong direction. This represents an increase of 6% since January.

The results of the poll come as the UK economy continues to struggle with the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The country has seen a sharp increase in inflation, with prices rising by 10.1% in the 12 months to September. This has led to a decrease in real wages and increased pressure on household budgets.

The poll also found that people are increasingly worried about their personal financial situation. 43% of people said they are concerned about their finances, an increase of 6% since January. This is likely due to a combination of rising prices and the end of government support schemes such as furlough.

The BBC poll indicates that people are concerned about the direction the UK economy is heading in and their personal financial situation. With inflation continuing to rise and no end in sight to the conflict in Ukraine, it seems likely that these concerns will continue to grow.

The government will announce a reduction in the legal limit for alcohol in blood for drivers from today in an effort to reduce deaths and serious injuries on the roads, Transport Minister Grant Shapps has said. The move is part of a range of new measures aimed at getting motorists to change their behaviour and could save 21 lives and prevent 246 serious injuries over the next 10 years, officials say.

The plan will be unveiled alongside an advertising campaign highlighting the increased risks of drinking and driving. Mr Shapps said too many people were still needlessly killed or injured on British roads "because of alcohol". He said he wanted to ensure that "by law, drivers are not allowed to drive with excess alcohol". The current limit of 80mg of alcohol in 100ml of blood will be reduced to 50mg from the spring.

The move follows a public consultation which found wide support for lowering the limit. Road safety charity Brake said the change would bring the UK into line with the rest of Europe and could save "scores of lives". The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) said the move was "long overdue". The new limit will bring England, Wales and Northern Ireland in line with Scotland, where the limit was reduced to 50mg in 2014.

Mr Shapps said it was important that the police were able to take "immediate action" where necessary by using hand-held breathalysers to enforce the new limit. The Department for Transport said it would be supporting the police by funding the necessary devices. The minister said he did not expect the change to be widely welcomed by drinkers but argued it was a necessary move to help keep the roads safe.

"It's great many people will celebrate the new year with a drink but it's crucial we all respect the limit," he said. "We're bringing this limit into line with the rest of Europe where it is generally recognised that if you are above 50mg then you are twice as likely to be involved in a fatal crash." The Department for Transport said it hoped the combination of the lower limit and the advertising campaign would make drivers think about their behaviour.

Chief Constable Anthony Bangham, the National Police Chiefs Council lead for roads policing, said officers were "often the first responders to the devastation caused by drink-driving, and see firsthand the consequences of this criminal behaviour". He said: "Drink-driving destroys lives and the police will always take robust action against those who break the law." The new advertising campaign will show people the steps they can take to

Japanese police have arrested the CEO of one of the country's largest advertising firms on suspicion of padding his firm's books by at least $330m.

The Tokyo Securities Exchange ordered Dentsu to suspend trading in its shares last Friday.

The Japanese mogul, Tadashi Ishii, stepped down from his role after the company revealed it had found "serious" accounting irregularities. 

Ishii, who denies the allegations, is accused of having ordered the systematic faking of documents to make it look like the company had earned at least 44.6bn ($332m) from 2013 to 2015. 

The 83-year-old executive was detained on Tuesday night after questioning at Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department. 

Ishii has admitted to the reporting inaccuracy but claims it was not a deliberate act.

"I sincerely apologise again for causing a great deal of concern to a wide range of people, including shareholders and investors, through the false publication of the financial statements," he said in a statement. 

"It is true that there was a big mistake in management, but it is incorrect to say that it was a fraudulent act." 

Dentsu, one of Japan's most influential advertising agencies, has faced a string of scandals in recent years related to its ties with Japan's powerful Ministry of Finance.

The next Bond movie, Casino Royale, is a gripping thriller that will keep audiences on the edge of their seats. It is a fresh take on the classic spy genre, with a focus on action and suspense. The film follows James Bond as he is assigned to investigate a mysterious organization known as "Quantum". The plot is full of twists and turns, as Bond uncovers a dangerous plot that could have global consequences. 

The film is packed with iconic Bond moments, including a thrilling casino scene, a high-stakes poker game, and a thrilling car chase. It also features a star-studded cast, including Daniel Craig, Eva Green, and Mads Mikkelsen. 

Casino Royale is a must-watch for fans of the Bond franchise and those looking for an action-packed thriller. It is a perfect blend of suspense, action, and iconic Bond moments that will keep audiences entertained from beginning to end.

The future of mobile phone design may be unconventional. Instead of a flat screen with a touch interface, it may involve physical buttons which pop up when needed and even parts which detach and fly around  all controlled by gestures and even facial expressions.

A phone which can be controlled by singing to it, or by looking at it  without the need to touch it at all  is being developed by Canadian company NextInput. It is very early days yet, but the founding team, which consists of four PhD students from the University of Toronto, is confident it can make the technology work.

And they are not the only ones looking at how interaction with mobile devices might change. IBM recently showed off a prototype phone with a curved screen which can detect different levels of pressure in a user's finger, allowing for new ways of interacting with the device. And a project at the University of Bristol is looking at mobiles which can be controlled by gestures made in mid-air above the screen.

"Humans can express an array of emotions and commands better through gestures than with touch or buttons," saysSIDDQ, the Bristol project. "Therefore, in the future, mobile interaction should become more gesture-based."

The Bristol team has developed a mid-air gesture recognition system, using a standard camera, which it claims is 95% accurate. In a video on the university's website, a user is seen holding an iPad in front of them and manipulating various applications on it using gestures  with their fingers never needing to touch the screen. The gestures include zooming in by drawing an infinity symbol in front of the device, and flicking through a set of photos by simply pointing at the screen and waving a finger.

The advantage of such a system, say the researchers, is that it allows for a much more intuitive user experience. "Most people are already familiar with using gestures to point, wave, or hold up their finger to indicate they are thinking," says the project.

Dr Anne Roudaut, a senior research fellow at Bristol's Centre for Human-Computer Interaction, leads the project, which is due to conclude in September. "Most interactive systems do not allow for mid-air gestures," she told the BBC. "They often require the user to be within a certain distance or for the gestures to be made on a specific area of the screen.

"Our system has the advantage of being able to recognise gestures made in the air, which makes it more natural and intuitive for users."

Police have increasingly been issuing fines to pubs that remain open beyond curfew hours as Britons flock to boozers to mark the end of lockdown restrictions. According to the Police Federation, 97 fines were issued between February and December last year. londonlpzg@gmail.com

Concerns have been raised that the fines are not being issued evenly across the country. Communities across the UK are divided into tier categories depending on their Covid-19 cases. Essentially, this determines what restrictions a region needs to abide by. However, the breakdown of fines shows that most were given in the tier system's 'medium' risk category. 

According to the BBC, 29 fines were given in 'medium' tier Lincolnshire, while neighbouring Nottinghamshire - also in 'medium' tier - received six. This suggests that the fines are more a reflection of where the police prioritise their resources, rather than a clear picture of which pubs are breaking the rules.

Britons who break the rules may face fines of 1,000.

Arsne Wenger has ruled out the possibility of Arsenal signing another goalkeeper before the transfer window closes on Tuesday. The Gunners have been linked with a move for Leicester's England international keeper Danny Ward, after it emerged that backup keeper Aaron Ramsdale may not be fit enough to face Manchester United on Friday night in their first Premier League game of the season. But Wenger, whose side beat Bayern Munich 2-1 in the final friendly of their pre-season tour of America, said he was happy with the goalkeepers he had.

"We have 2m goalkeeper who we bought last year and who has been out for six months because of two operations, we have an experienced goalkeeper in Alex Runarsson and we have Matt Macey, who is back after a loan," he said. "So that's not a position where I expect something to happen. We are not close to doing something there."

Wenger also said he was unconvinced that the club needed to sign a new defender, despite the departure of William Saliba to Marseille on loan ahead of next month's transfer deadline. The Frenchman said the club had been keen to keep the 19-year-old, who joined Arsenal from Saint-Etienne for 27m last year, but that the player wanted to play regular first-team football.

"He is a player who needs to play," said Wenger. "He agreed to come here because he wanted to play, we agreed to buy him because we hoped he can play. He has decided to go on loan and we lose a player but we have to respect that."

EuroDisney, the European theme park that was the inspiration of the late Walt Disney, has struggled financially in recent years and is vowing a turnaround.

The company, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, announced that it would be restructuring its operations, cutting costs, and investing in new attractions and hotels.

EuroDisney, which is located in Marne-la-Vallee, France, just east of Paris, opened in 1992. It was originally conceived as a way to bring the Disney magic to Europe, but it has struggled to compete with other attractions in the region.

The park has been losing money for years, and in recent months, it has been hit by a series of strikes by workers who are protesting the company's plans to cut costs.

Despite these challenges, the company is vowing to turn things around. 

The restructuring plan includes a proposal to cut costs by 200 million ($220 million) over the next two years. This would be achieved through a variety of measures, including the reduction of staff and the closure of some hotels and restaurants.

The company also plans to invest in new attractions and hotels, which it hopes will help to attract more visitors to the park.

In the quiet village of Berrechid, in Morocco's fertile plains, just north of the capital, Rabat, a group of young men are going through their paces on a dusty cross-country running track.

They are here to train with one of Morocco's greatest sporting heroes, Hicham El Guerrouj, who stands beside me, watching intently. 

El Guerrouj is an icon in Morocco. He is the nation's most revered athlete, a legend who, in 2004, became the first Moroccan to win two Olympic golds, in Athens, in the 1,500m and 5,000m races. A hero who, after a glittering career, retired from competition five years ago. 

Now, he wants to pass on his knowledge and passion for the sport to the next generation of Moroccan runners.

El Guerrouj's ambition is to discover and train young runners from Morocco to compete internationally and, one day, win medals for Morocco.

He has set up this cross-country academy to develop a new generation of runners, and lengthen Morocco's stride in the world of athletics.

About 40 athletes are currently enrolled in the programme, ranging in age from 14 to 20. Each has shown impressive potential, and has been selected from clubs across Morocco to join the academy.

"It's not just about discovering talented runners, it's also about creating role models for the younger generation, to educate them and teach them the importance of hard work, dedication and discipline," El Guerrouj says.

El Guerrouj has partnered with Emirati entrepreneur Ahmed Al Maktoum, whose company AH Sports Management has created and funded the academy.

"We share the same passion and we want to deliver the best from Africa to the world," says Al Maktoum.

The academy is housed in a modern complex in Berrechid, which includes accommodation, gym and recovery rooms, as well as the cross-country track.

El Guerrouj and his team of coaches work with the runners on every aspect of their performance.

"We are not just focusing on the technique, but on the mental and physical preparation too," he says.

"It's important that the athletes understand what they need to do to improve, and to learn the importance of consistency in their training."

While the academy aims to create elite runners, El Guerrouj is keen to emphasise the importance of education.

The future of one of television's most iconic franchises, Star Trek, is reportedly in jeopardy as a result of a dispute between the show's management and its crew. 

The cast and crew of Star Trek: Discovery, which is currently in its third season, say they have been locked out of shooting the remainder of the season without pay. 

Television's first Patrick Stewart-led Star Trek series, Star Trek: Picard, has also been delayed from its planned summer release date, with very little information about when it may now air. 

According to reports, the Discovery cast and crew were notified of the lockout on Friday, and have been banned from speaking about it publicly. 

The show's production company, CBS Studios, has yet to comment on the dispute.

Czech tennis player Lucie afov has led her country to victory in the Fed Cup final and been named athlete of the year  despite being suspended from tennis since January following a positive drugs test. afov, who is 33 years old and the highest-ranked Czech player in history, says she will give more details later in the year but has confirmed that the substance found was a banned substance.

The Czech Republic team overcame a determined French team 3-2 in the women's team tennis event in Prague to win their sixth title in the last eight years. afov, who has won two Grand Slam titles, did not play in the tournament, but her absence was not felt as her teammates Barbora Krejkov and Kateina Siniakov won the deciding tie against Caroline Garcia and Kristina Mladenovic. 

The president of the Czech Tennis Federation, Ivo Min, said afov had been in contact with lawyers and the Czech Anti-Doping Agency, and that she had been dealing with "a difficult situation". He added that she had tested positive in January, before the Australian Open, but had only informed the federation of the result last week.

We have witnessed an astonishing feat in the world of aviation  a solo pilot flight around the world without the aid of hyper-advanced technology or a drop of fossil fuel. Yet the man who designed and created the solar-powered aircraft has been overlooked by the Oscars.

Bas Lansdorp is the pioneer of a game-changing aircraft which has propelled us into a new age of sustainable aviation, and yet his work has not been recognised by the Academy. While the filmmaker Alex Crenn, director of another 'round-the-world' story, has been nominated for an Oscar for Best Documentary Feature for his film, "Final Ascent: The Carl Boenish Story", about a climber who died, Lansdorp's groundbreaking contribution has been ignored. 

Is the film industry, like the aviation industry, going to take a while longer to leave no fossil behind? 

This seems to be the case  especially when it comes to telling the stories of pioneering visionaries in the field of sustainable technology. Even when it comes to the story of Lansdorp's game-changing pilot initiative, the footage of the plane in action doesn't make it to the screen. Instead, we see the pilot, linnet Harvey, gently stirring a pot on a camping stove as the solar-powered aircraft soars through the sky above.

Sure, it's a nice shot, but it doesn't do justice to the remarkable engineering feat that this aircraft represents. It's like showing theElephant in Wartime and cutting before we see the (completely vegetarian) elephant charge through the gates of Baghdad. 

We wanted to hear more about the engineering inspiration behind the plane, and from the man himself, so we spoke to Lansdorp, the CEO of Holland-based Mobilia Ventures, who designed and created the single-seater aircraft, known as the Panther. 

"First of all, it was very difficult to find a builder who had experience with building aircraft," he said. "There were only two candidates, and one of them didn't have enough capacity. We ended up working with a boat builder in Portugal."

Portugal? Not the most convenient location for an aircraft builder. So why go there? 

"There was one guy who had built a lot of very high-end boats, and they have a lot of experience with doing stuff with carbon fibre, which is super expensive and tricky to work with," said Lansdorp. This seemed like an inspired choice considering that carbon fibre is both

Former US President Ted Kennedy has criticised the Obama administration's plans to raise taxes on wealthy investors, saying that the increases are "unfair" and will have a negative impact on the economy.

Kennedy, who is a strong supporter of the Democratic Party, made the comments in an interview with the BBC. He said that while he agrees that the wealthy should pay their fair share of taxes, the proposed increases would do more harm than good.

"I believe in a fair tax system, where the wealthy pay their fair share," Kennedy said. "But these tax increases would not be fair. They would not only impact the wealthy, but also the middle class. And they would have a negative impact on the economy as a whole."

The Obama administration has proposed a number of tax increases as part of its efforts to reduce the deficit and improve the economy. These include an increase in the top income tax rate from 35% to 39.6%, as well as an increase in the capital gains tax rate from 15% to 20%.

Kennedy argued that the proposed increases would make the US less competitive and would drive away business and investment. He also said that the increases would be particularly hard on small business owners and entrepreneurs, who are often taxed at the same rate as the wealthy.

"Small business owners and entrepreneurs are the engines of our economy," Kennedy said. "They create jobs and drive innovation. But they are also often taxed at the same rate as the wealthiest individuals. These tax increases would make it even harder for them to succeed."

The former president also criticised the Obama administration's efforts to raise taxes on high-income earners through the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. He said that the so-called "Cadillac tax" on high-cost insurance plans would hurt middle-class families and lead to job losses.

"The 'Cadillac tax' is a tax on health insurance plans that cost more than a certain amount," Kennedy said. "It's supposed to help pay for Obamacare. But it's going to hurt middle-class families and lead to job losses. It's just another example of how this administration's policies are hurting the American people."

Kennedy has been a strong critic of the Obama administration's economic policies, particularly its handling of the deficit and the economy. He has argued that the administration's policies are too focused on taxing the wealthy and are not doing enough to promote economic growth.
