U2 have become the first rock band to break the Ticketmaster ticket sales record, with more than 450,000 tickets sold for their upcoming tour. 

The figure tops the previous record of 350,000, held by English singer Harry Styles, whose 2022 world tour began in April. 

U2's five-month Love Loop tour begins in May, starting in Europe before heading to the United States and Canada, with 46 shows in total. 

It will be in support of their latest album, Songs of Surrender, which will be released in March. 

The Irish rockers, who have been going for more than four decades, will be joined on the road by support acts such as Beck and Haim. 

The ticket sales include a four-night run at Dublin's Croke Park, with the band also playing multiple nights in London, Barcelona, Paris and Berlin. 

Last week, Ticketmaster released a statement saying it was working to solve ongoing issues that fans were having with ticket sales. 

After a pre-sale for fans who had pre-ordered the band's new album, many were left empty-handed after waiting in a virtual queue for hours.

The former Tory minister Jonathan Djanogly has died at the age of 67.

Mr Djanogly, who had been a minister in David Cameron's government, died on Friday night, his family said.

The Conservative MP for Huntingdon in Cambridgeshire was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2017.

He stepped down from his post as a minister in 2018 and resigned as an MP in 2019.

In a statement, his family said: "It is with great sadness we have to announce that Jonathan Djanogly peacefully passed away on Friday night, surrounded by his family.

"Jonathan was not only a devoted husband, father and grandfather, but a loyal friend to so many.

"We would like to say thank you to all the NHS staff, particularly those at Peterborough Hospital, who cared for Jonathan with such warmth, diligence and professionalism over the past four years."

Mr Djanogly served as an MP for 35 years, first being elected to Huntingdon in 1997.

He became a minister in 2010, first at the Department for Work and Pensions and later at the Ministry of Justice.

During his time in government, he proposed changes to the costs law that would have allowed lawyers to charge their clients for looking at documents that may not be used in court cases.

The proposal, known as "Jackson", was later watered down.

Tory MPs paid tribute to Mr Djanogly, with many describing him as a "good friend".

Sir Charles Walker, the Conservative MP for Broxbourne, said his "thoughts and prayers" were with Mr Djanogly's family.

"Jonathan was a good and kind man who believed in public service and served his constituents and country with dedication," he added.

The Federal Trade Commission is cracking down on ringtone sellers that charge customers without their explicit consent. The FTC has issued a warning to companies that use text messages to gather phone numbers for ringtone downloads, telling them to get express consent from customers before charging them. The announcement comes after several cases were opened against companies accused of charging customers without consent. In one case, a company must pay nearly $50 million to customers who were charged for ringtones they did not want. 

The FTC's warning has shaken up the ringtone industry. Some companies are already complying with the new rules and are changing their policies to obtain express consent. Others are waiting to see how the situation plays out. The FCC is hoping that the warning will be enough to stop the unwanted charges. 

The case against the ringtone companies is just one of many the FTC is currently involved in. The FTC is cracking down on all types of companies that charge customers without their consent. As part of their effort, the FTC has issued warnings to several large companies, including a major social media platform.

The annual Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is one of the technology world's biggest events, where companies big and small come to showcase their latest products. This year, the event is being held in Las Vegas from January 5th to the 8th. Here are some of the gadgets that have been announced so far:

- The Samsung Galaxy S10: This is Samsung's latest flagship smartphone, which features a new design, a faster processor, and improved cameras.
- The LG V50: This is a new smartphone from LG that features a 6" display, a dual camera system, and a built-in stylus.
- The HTC Vive Pro: This is a new virtual reality headset from HTC that features a higher resolution display and improved tracking technology.
- The Sony PlayStation VR: This is a new virtual reality headset from Sony that features a sleeker design and improved tracking technology.
- The Nintendo Switch: This is a new gaming console from Nintendo that features a portable design and the ability to connect to a TV.

These are just a few of the many gadgets that will be on show at CES 2019. Stay tuned for more updates as the event progresses.

The UK government has announced plans to expedite the deportation of terror suspects to their countries of origin. The announcement comes after a recent spike in terror-related activities in the country.

Under the new policy, the government will seek to revoke the citizenship of individuals convicted of, or facing prosecution for, terrorism-related activities. The policy is expected to affect dozens of individuals who are either in prison or under surveillance by the authorities.

The move has been criticized by human rights groups and opposition parties, who argue that it would violate individuals' rights and could lead to unfair outcomes. They also argue that it could lead to individuals being deported to countries where they may face persecution or unfair treatment.

The government has defended the policy, arguing that it is necessary to protect the public from the threat of terrorism. They argue that individuals who are convicted of, or facing prosecution for, terrorism-related activities should not be allowed to remain in the UK.

Former British Prime Minister Gordon Brown is a politician with a strong work ethic and a passion for public service. Born in Scotland in 1951, Brown attended the University of Edinburgh, where he earned a bachelor's degree in history. He later received a master's degree in economics from the University of London.

Brown began his political career in the Labour Party, serving as a member of the Scottish Parliament from 1999 to 2001. He was elected to the British Parliament in 1983 and quickly rose through the ranks, serving as Chancellor of the Exchequer from 1997 to 2007. During this time, he implemented a series of economic policies that helped to stabilize the British economy and reduce unemployment.

In 2007, Brown was elected as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, succeeding Tony Blair. One of his first actions as prime minister was to introduce a stimulus package to help the economy through the financial crisis. He also implemented a series of reforms to the public services, including the National Health Service and education system.

Brown was a strong advocate for the environment and worked to promote renewable energy sources. He also led the effort to create a carbon emissions trading system in the United Kingdom.

Despite his many accomplishments, Brown's time as prime minister was marked by several challenges, including the global economic crisis and the rise of the Scottish National Party. In 2010, he resigned as prime minister and was replaced by David Cameron.

Since leaving office, Brown has remained active in politics and public service. He has served as the United Nations Special Envoy for Global Education and as a member of the International Olympic Committee. He has also written several books on politics and economics.

Overall, Gordon Brown is a seasoned politician with a strong track record of public service. His contributions to the British economy and public services are widely recognized, and he continues to be an influential figure in British politics.

Ministers have questioned aides to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex over their decision to accept public funds for a royal jet after they had already spent thousands of pounds on private jets. The couple, who are reportedly on a sabbatical in America, are said to have refused to discuss the matter. Allies of Prince Harry insist he is not averse to discussing anything related to his personal finances or those of his wife, and the couple have led the way on transparency.

However, a spokesperson for the couple declined to comment on whether they had followed the guidelines on the use of chartered flights laid down by the Royal Family. They are said to be somewhat puzzled at the furore, because flying by commercial jet is not possible when touring as the Prince and Princess of Wales do.

The controversy emerged after it was revealed that the six-month-long trip, during which the couple visited four countries, cost UK taxpayers 490,000 for travel and accommodation. Of this, 298,000 was used to pay for the private jets. 

This was labelled obscene by Labour MP John Mann, who has written to the forensic auditor, Nigel Boardman, to ask whether the use of private jets was truly necessary. Theres an issue of regularity and propriety here, he said. Alan Milburn, the governments social mobility commissioner, also questioned whether it was appropriate for the Sussexes to fly by private jet. Its a nonsense to say that Prince Harry cant fly commercially, he told the BBC Radio 4 programme, Westminster Hour.

The QatarEnergy and Shell have struck a deal for the sale and purchase of liquefied natural gas (LNG) that will help keep Europe's gas stores filled as winter approaches. QatarEnergy is selling two LNG shipments to Shell, with the first delivery expected in early October. The deal comes as Europe is trying to replace gas supplies from Russia. The International Energy Agency said on Friday that nearly 60% of Russian gas exports to Europe had been replaced by alternative supplies.

Shell revealed the deal involving QatarEnergy on Sunday at the Gastech conference in Milan. Qatar is the world's biggest LNG exporter and Shell is the biggest buyer of LNG. The deal comes as European gas prices have surged since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

In a statement, QatarEnergy said: "This transaction reflects the long-standing relationship between QatarEnergy and Shell, and our mutual focus on delivering reliable energy supplies to customers and markets worldwide."

The deal is another sign that Qatar is taking an increasingly important role in helping Europe reduce its dependence on Russian energy imports. The country has been able to increase its LNG exports to Europe.

Qatar's LNG shipments to Europe have nearly doubled this year compared with last year, according to data from energy intelligence firm Vortexa. In the first seven months of 2022, Europe received 29 LNG carrier shipments from Qatar, compared with 16 shipments during the same period last year.

England has been handed a tough draw in the World Rugby Sevens series, with hosts Singapore pooled with series leaders New Zealand and last year's runners-up Australia.

England, who are ninth in the series standings after the first four rounds, face a group also containing Samoa and France in the eighth round of the competition.

The top eight sides in the 10-team round-robin groups progress to the quarter-finals.

England's men's team won the first ever rugby sevens gold medal at the 2018 Commonwealth Games but have never won the World Rugby Sevens Series title.

The eighth round of the series takes place in Singapore on 15-16 March.

The demise of Dirty Den at the hands of his onscreen wife, Angie, is one of the most memorable moments in soap history. It was watched by almost 14 million viewers, making it one of the most watched episodes of EastEnders ever. 

The episode, which aired in April 1998, saw Den Watts (played by Leslie Grantham) discover that his wife, Angie (played by Anita Dobson), had been having an affair with his best friend, Ian Beale (played by Adam Woodyatt). In retaliation, Den served Angie with divorce papers and slept with her sister, Sue (played by Sadie Frost). 

However, their marriage was far from over. Angie managed to convince Den to give their relationship another chance, and the couple reunited. But their happiness was short-lived. 

A year later, in April 1999, Den discovered that Angie had been lying to him about her affair with Ian. Enraged, he flew into a rage and violently attacked her. 

As he tried to strangle her with his bare hands, Angie's son, Ricky (played by Sid Owen), entered the room and tried to stop Den. During the tussle that followed, Den fell back and hit his head on the fireplace. 

Ricky and Angie looked on in horror as Den lay motionless on the floor. Both realized that he was dead, and Ricky immediately called for an ambulance. 

The episode ended with a shocked Angie looking at the body of her dead husband as the title sequence played. 

The scene is widely regarded as one of the most iconic and memorable in the history of British soap operas. The episode was watched by an average of 13.8 million viewers, with a peak of 15.1 million as Den fell to his death.

The UK's first ever banning of a AI-powered chatbot has occurred, with the High Court ordering that the chatbot "Collins" cannot be used in court proceedings. This landmark decision sets a precedent for how AI technology is to be used in the future. The case, which was brought by the Bar Council, argued that the use of AI in court proceedings risked undermining the public's trust in the justice system. 

The ban on Collins, which was developed by the company ROSS Intelligence, Inc., stems from the concern that allowing AI to participate in legal proceedings may threaten the integrity of court proceedings. The judge argued that allowing Collins to contribute alongside humans creates an errant hybrid of human and AI participation, and that this goes against the core of legal proceedings in the UK. 

While this decision marks a turning point in the use of AI in the UK, it's unclear what the future holds for AI technology in the country. With this decision, the UK has set a standard for the legal industry, but it's unclear if other industries will follow suit. While AI offers unprecedented potential and advancement, clearly defining the boundaries and regulations of AI technology is becoming increasingly more urgent.

Britain's Tim Henman finally won his battle with rival Greg Rusedski as he reached the quarter-finals of the Nasdaq-100 Open in Miami.
The Briton has lost the last six times they have met, including two five-set matches at Grand Slam events.
But Henman earned a straight-set victory 6-3 7-6 against the Canadian in Florida.
And the 30-year-old admitted his relief at finally getting one over on his friend of 15 years.
"It's been a long time coming, I'm very happy," said the world number 48, who faces Russia's Marat Safin next.
"To beat Greg you have to play very solid and take your chances when they come along and I was able to do that today."

Rusedski, ranked nine places higher than his rival at 29 in the world, made a confident start to the match but could not maintain his early advantage.
And Henman, who has never beaten his rival on a hard court, took full advantage to win in one hour and 42 minutes.

"I played well today," added Henman. "I executed my game plan well and played smart tennis.
"I stuck to my guns and played aggressively when I had the opportunity. I served well and came up with some big first serves at the right time."

The win took Henman into his first quarter-final of 2004 and his first since August 2002.
And the triumph was all the more sweet given it came against a player who has had the better of him for so long.

"It's nice to get a win against Greg," added Henman. "We've known each other for 15 years, we're good friends and it's special to beat him.
"I know what he's capable of and I know how dangerous he is but today it went my way."

Australia has been ranked as the world's most attractive destination for foreign investment, according to a new report.

The Annual Investment Meeting's (AIM) most recent report ranks Australia first among all countries in the world in terms of foreign direct investment (FDI). The study notes that Australia's successful COVID-19 vaccination rollout and its openness to international travel have been particularly appealing to potential investors.

The AIM report also reveals that Australia's overall score has increased from 6.9 in 2020 to 7.3 in 2022. The increase is attributed to the country's strong economic recovery, as well as its low inflation and interest rates.

The report also shows that Australia's investment environment is particularly favourable for investors in the manufacturing, resources, and financial services sectors.

The Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has rejected the initial shortlist of candidates for the upcoming by-election for the Westminster seat representing Police And Crime Commissioner. All the candidates on the list, composed by the Local Government Elections Office, were black, and the Mayor argued that this violated the Equality Act 2010.

The statement from City Hall argued that the shortlist should have been diversified to include candidates from different backgrounds. The statement from the Mayor's office read: "We have always been clear that the shortlisting process must be fair and transparent, and that the independent oversight of the selection process is essential.

"We have therefore decided to reject the initial shortlist. We are confident that the committee will take on board the issues raised and appoint a diverse shortlist in line with the Equality Act 2010 and we look forward to receiving that shortlist in the coming days."

Reacting to the decision, Bryan Plummer, the chairman of the Local Government Elections Office, revealed that they would be appealing the decision. He argued that the shortlist complied with the law and that the appeal would be made on the basis that the Mayor did not have the power to reject the list.

Mr Plummer said: "We issued a fair and legal shortlist based on the candidates' applications and the independent assessment centre recommendations.

"All candidates that were recommended and offered an interview complied with the equality criteria for the role and the Local Government etc. (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976, as well as the relevant guidance from the Equality and Human Rights Commission."

The role has been vacant since Dame Cressida Dick's resignation in August this year.

Daniel Pountney has been banned from the game for 18 months and fined 2,500 for breaching the Football Association's betting rules.

The former Norwich, Preston and Wolverhampton Wanderers defender admitted to placing bets on 3,581 football matches or related markets between November 2013 and November 2019.

In accepting the charges, he avoided a hearing.

If any individual is convicted of gambling on a match or competition in which they are involved - as a participant, coach or director - they face a minimum ban of four years and a maximum punishment of life.

In addition to the suspension, which is effective immediately, Pountney will also receive a fine of 1,750, plus 750 for admitting the offence and co-operating with the FA's investigation.

The US economy showed solid GDP growth in the first quarter of the year, with a gain of 3.0%. The figure was in line with expectations and was driven by a rebound in consumer spending, which rose by 1.9% after a sluggish performance in the previous quarter. The growth was also boosted by a rise in government spending and a weaker dollar, which helped to boost exports.

The rebound in consumer spending was led by a rise in spending on services, such as healthcare and education, while spending on goods remained sluggish. This suggests that the US economy is continuing to shift towards a more service-based economy.

The rise in government spending was driven by increased spending on both defense and non-defense programs. Defense spending has been a major driver of growth in the US economy in recent years, and the Trump administration has continued to ramp up defense spending.

The weaker dollar has helped to boost exports, as US goods become more competitive on international markets. This has been a major factor in the recent strong performance of the US economy, and the Trump administration has been keen to keep the dollar weak in order to protect American jobs.

All in all, the first quarter GDP growth figures show that the US economy is continuing to grow at a solid pace, despite the recent stock market turmoil and concerns about the impact of the Trump administration's trade policies.

The US has asked the UN's top court to rule on whether it is legally responsible for smoking-related illnesses in Indonesia, which could cost billions of dollars.

Indonesia has argued that the US has violated the 1965 International Convention on Civil and Political Rights by not stopping American companies from selling cigarettes.

The US Supreme Court ruled in 2005 that such lawsuits could not be brought in US courts.

The Supreme Court's decision was based on a 1992 law that gave the US government exclusive jurisdiction over claims against foreign states.

Now Indonesia is trying to sue the US in the UN's International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague.

The case poses a significant challenge to the US, as it could potentially leave it open to a string of costly lawsuits by other countries.

"We're facing potentially hundreds of billions of dollars in liability," said a lawyer for the US, Edwin Cooper.

In 2019, Indonesia announced that it was seeking compensation of $74bn (58bn) from the US, to help cover the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses.

The country is home to one of the world's largest tobacco markets and has been described by the World Health Organization (WHO) as the biggest market for cigarettes in the world. 

The country's legal team argued that the US had breached the 1965 convention by not stopping American companies from selling "hazardous and harmful" products.

The US argued in its opening statement that Indonesia's case should be thrown out by the court, on the basis that the UN convention does not provide a legal basis for the case.

It also argued that the 1965 convention refers only to the consumption of products within the US, not their sale abroad.

Sony revealed its latest PlayStation development, the PlayStation Portable (PSP), at the E3 gaming expo in Los Angeles. 

The handheld device represents a significant breakthrough for Sony, creating entirely new ways for gamers to play together both inside and outside the home.

The PSP will have wireless connectivity and a vivid colour screen displaying technical specifications of 160mm diagonal, 480 x 272 resolution, and 16.8 million colours.

It will enable users to download games from the Internet and store a large library of games on its high capacity 4GB flash memory card. It can even connect wirelessly to the PlayStation 3 (PS3) and PlayStation 2 (PS2) consoles, allowing users to transfer digital content from their PS3 games to the PSP, and back again, so they can continue playing games on the move.

It will go on sale in Japan on December 12, 2004, with a US release scheduled for March 24, 2005, and a European release date scheduled for September 1, 2005.

Disney has agreed to pay $2.8m to settle charges that it failed to adequately disclose the role it played in the making of a documentary about the re-opening of Disneyland Paris.

The BBC's investigation into the documentary, The Magic Returns, found the company had not made clear its involvement.

Disney had provided hotel accommodation for a crew of six journalists from BBC News, as well as assistance with travel and access to the re-opening. 

In addition, the company required the journalists to attend a "training session" prior to filming, with senior Disney executives present. The session was not disclosed to viewers. 

Disney has now agreed to pay a fine to the BBC's Commercial Affairs Department, as well as the BBC's investigative journalism budget. 

A Disney spokesperson said the company had "apologised to the BBC and are grateful for their cooperation in this matter". 

The BBC has also asked Disney to ensure its journalists are given clearer guidelines about disclosure.

The much-anticipated sequel to the superhero film 'Harmony' directed by Mullaperiyar Gopinath Nair, titled 'Vanity', has been postponed due to creative differences between the director and the producers. The film was previously set to release in theatres on April 12, 2023. 

The film's leading cast, including Mohanlal, Priya Manikandan, and Raashii Khanna, have expressed their disappointment with the delay, with some speculating that the project may be shelved altogether. 

Producer Jackrabbit Motion Pictures issued a statement regarding the matter, stating that the company was dedicated to making the sequel accessible to audiences as soon as possible and that they were working closely with the director to resolve the issues. 

Despite the delay, fans can expect the film to be released in summer 2024 in all its glory. 

Spoiler alert: The sequel will focus on how Clarity, the protagonist played by Priya Manikandan, inherits her mother's abilities and becomes the next superhero, fighting evil and protecting the town of Bon happtit.

The one-time pad, an encryption technique invented nearly a century ago, relies on short key phrases. But a new study suggests that even when those phrases are nonsensical, their patterns can still be revealing. Benjamin Sparrey and Daniel Hughes of the University of Bristol in the U.K. examined four famously secure messages encoded using one-time pads. They found that, with enough contextual information about the authors and their backgrounds, they could guess at the content of the messages, despite having no knowledge of the key phrases used. For instance, they were able to infer the content of a message that Soviet spy John Cairncross sent to Moscow in 1943, despite having no knowledge of the keyphrase that Cairncross used. (They did have access to a 1987 book that gave six possible one-time pads that the author believed Cairncross might have used.)

The findings, presented last week at the IEEE European Symposium on Security and Privacy in Paris, underscore the importance of using appropriate one-time pads and cutting down on contextual information that might leak. In an email to The Register, Sparrey wrote that the one-time pad remains a secure encryption technique if used properly. "The reason why I performed this research is because I think it is important for people to realize just how secure the one-time pad is if used properly, and to understand the circumstances in which security may be broken," Sparrey wrote. "I hope that this research can be used to further educate people on the strengths and weaknesses of this beautiful and elegant encryption technique."

The film governing the roost in this week's movie chart is clearly the comedy caper, *The Pacifier*. It retains the top spot in the US and opens in pole position in the UK. 

The film stars Brad Pitt as a spy who has been appointed as guardian to his murdered best friend's newborn baby girl. Jenny, his colleague, (played by Angelina Jolie) is reluctantly recruited to assist him. Naturally, chaos and comedy ensue as the pair struggle to cope with the challenges of looking after a young baby, with neither having any experience in childcare. The somewhat exhausted plotline does not appear to have affected the choice of movie-goers, however, who have sent it to the top of the chart. The all-star cast includes the likes of Vince Vaughn, Maria Bello and Adam Brody. 

Interestingly, this week's chart includes a surge in animated films. Perhaps fuelled by the success of *The Pacifier*, family films are clearly popular at the moment. They occupy four of the top ten slots. This may be a timing issue, with the schools now out for the summer. It is also possible that the recent heatwave has encouraged people to stay at home in the evenings, preferring to watch films rather than brave the mosquitos and humidity. Either way, there is certainly a summer theme to this week's chart.

GlaxoSmithKline is the UK's largest pharmaceutical company. Its vaccines have helped to eradicate smallpox and save millions of lives. It is now turning its attention to malaria and tuberculosis, while expanding its research into oncology - the science of cancer. 

But it has had a bumpy ride of late. Last year its profits fell by more than a quarter. It has had to cope with the decline of a key asthma drug and with losses from its consumer healthcare division. 

The company is now pulling back from some of its less profitable products and is making a clear shift towards pharmaceuticals, a move that analysts say is overdue. 

In the UK, the company is best known for Panadol, a household name for painkillers. But it also makes Nicorette, the nicotine replacement spray. 

Both are part of the consumer healthcare division, which has struggled in recent years as price cuts and a decline in the US operation saw sales fall. 

Last year the company took a 1.6bn ($2.1bn) charge to cover the impairment of the division. It has since been trying to offload the unit, but a sale has proved difficult as offers have been below what the company feels it is worth.

Instead, it is now carving out a separate consumer healthcare company, which it will spin off in the middle of next year. The new venture will be listed on the London Stock Exchange and the company expects it to be "a leading listed global consumer healthcare company".

That move, along with the sale of a number of skincare brands, is designed to focus the company on prescription drugs and vaccines. 

In the six months to 30 June, sales of pharmaceuticals rose more than 7% to 4.2bn, while the consumer healthcare division saw a 2% fall to 1.8bn. 

Overall, the company saw a 3% rise in like-for-like sales, but core operating profit fell by more than 17% to 1.4bn.

GSK's pharmaceuticals business is a major player in the industry. It is the second-largest seller of vaccines in the world and has a growing portfolio of cancer drugs.

Here is a draft of the body of a BBC news article titled "Two Nigerian banks set to merge":

For weeks, speculation had been rife in Nigeria's financial world that two of the country's largest banks were planning to merge. Today, Access Bank and Diamond Bank confirmed those rumours, saying they hope to complete the merger by the end of June 2019, subject to approval by regulators and shareholders.

This merger is a significant development in Nigeria's banking industry and is likely to have far-reaching consequences for other banks in the country.

Former Olympic champion Kelly Holmes has said "it's a bit weird" to be asked for her views on the doping scandal that has engulfed British Cycling and Team Sky.

Holmes, who won 800m and 1500m gold at the 2004 Athens Olympics, said "it was a different era" when she ran, adding that she was "not sure I believe" some of the allegations about cyclists using performance-enhancing drugs.

The 44-year-old was speaking after being appointed a member of the British Olympic Association's (BOA) athlete commission.

Her comments come in the wake of a series of investigations into doping in cycling, including UK Sport and Cycling Weekly's 'Catch Me If You Can' investigation earlier this year.

And the BOA has appointed a former head of UK Anti-Doping, Andy Parkinson, to conduct an independent review into British cycling to investigate "alleged failings" ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

"It's a bit weird answering questions about cycling when I'm on the Olympic committee because I know nothing about cycling," Holmes told the PA news agency.

"It was a different era, I'm not sure I believe everything that is said. I just know that I never got asked to take drugs, I was never offered drugs - I was never exposed to it.

"So for me to comment on the sport now, I don't think it's fair because I don't know enough about it."

Holmes' appointment to the BOA's athlete commission was announced by Dame Katherine Grainger, the chair of the body.

"I am thrilled to become a member of the BOA's athlete commission," said Holmes.

"It is an honour to join such an esteemed group of people and I look forward to representing Britain's athletes and helping to shape the future of the Olympic movement."

The chairman of Euronext has reportedly written to the board of the London Stock Exchange (LSE) to express his interest in making a bid for the company.

JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay more than $607m to settle a landmark lawsuit that accused the largest US bank of profiting from racial slavery in the 19th century.

The agreement, pending court approval, is the largest civil settlement in US history connected to the slave trade.

It followed a years-long investigation involving chattel slavery, the practice of enslaved people being sold and traded like livestock.

Lawyers for slain George Floyd's family also applauded the settlement, which stems from a lawsuit filed on behalf of three racial justice groups - Equal Justice Institute, Grassroots Organizations Operating Together and the Committee for Equality and Inclusion.

"This monetary compensation underscores the importance of reckoning with the nation's long history of discrimination and systemic racism, and the critical need for amends," the lawyers said in a statement.

JPMorgan, which has denied any wrongdoing, said the settlement included $350m in cash for the plaintiffs and $250m for small business development and mortgage programs in minority communities.

It also agreed to a five-year programme to help dismantle systemic racism at the bank and other measures.

"We believe this settlement is an important step toward addressing the historical injustices described in the lawsuit, and, importantly, will provide meaningful opportunities to create generational wealth in historically underserved Black communities," said JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon.

"I regret the role that our bank played more than 150 years ago in perpetuating systemic racism and there is no place for racism in our society," he added.

JPMorgan's admission of guilt and the settlement followed years of investigations into the bank's historical ties to slavery.

In 2016, news outlets reported that JPMorgan had publicly apologised after it was found that two of its predecessor firms had sold enslaved people in the 1800s.

Researchers looking into the bank's past found that two Manhattan-based firms, JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Wachovia, had been major players in the slave trade.

They determined that more than 1,250 enslaved people were sold through JPMorgan's progenitors between 1856 and 1863.

During that period, financial institutions, including Wachovia and its predecessor institutions, helped manage the wealth of enslavers and the money generated from the sale of enslaved people.

JPMorgan was also accused of continuing to profit from slavery after the Civil War by delaying the emancipation of enslaved people.

The BBC reports that moviegoers in the United States returned to the cinema in droves for James Cameron's blockbuster sequel, Avatar: The Way of Water, but simultaneous streaming releases continue to hit the box office hard.

The latest offering from the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, is topping the box office for the second week running, but with a significant decline in ticket sales. 

The superhero sequel collected an impressive $108 million over the week, but ticket sales were more than 50 percent down from the first week's total. 
The film has generated $367 million in total thus far in the US and $1.3 billion globally. 

Industry experts suggest that the film will struggle to make back its hefty $200 million production budget, let alone turn a profit, despite its promising start. 

Box office analyst Jeff Bock told the BBC: "Streaming is where it's at these days, and Wakanda Forever is proof of that."

"This isn't the first super-successful movie to see a steep drop in its second weekend," he added. "People are simply choosing to stream movies at home now more than ever." 

Disney+, which hosts Marvel's franchise, does not disclose streaming numbers.

Bruno Andrade handed Sunderland a first-half lead but goals from Jack Hamilton and Paul McGinn turned the game around for the visitors. 
The Black Cats had been poised to sign veteran goalkeeper Scott Carson, but that appeared to have sparked the players into life in the meantime. 

Queens Park Rangers had hopes of climbing into the play-off places but instead fell to a second successive league defeat. 

Andrade, making his first start since early October, gave the hosts the perfect start after four minutes, turning in the area and drilling a low shot beyond Dieng. 

The QPR goalkeeper then produced a superb save to keep out Ross Stewart's header as Sunderland began where they left off in the first half. But the visitors gradually worked their way into the game. 
Home goalkeeper Wright had to be in the right place at the right time to make a vital block from Lyndon Dykes' close-range shot just before the half-hour mark. 

The Scotland international then got down well to his right to push Andre Dozzell's shot behind. 
QPR did not have to wait much longer to equalise as they scored with their next attack, Hamilton netting with a first-time shot from close range after Christopher Todibo had headed Isaiah Brown's cross back into the mix. 

Andrade went close to regaining Sunderland's lead but his looping header dropped just wide. 
However, it was QPR who finished the first half the strongest, with Dykes denied again by Wright, who also kept out a shot from Manny Onariase. 

The visitors kicked on after the break and took the lead in the 54th minute when McGinn netted with a first-time shot from 20 yards after Sunderland failed to clear a free-kick. 
It could have been 3-1 just two minutes later but Todibo spurned a great chance, slicing a shot wide from 10 yards. 
Sunderland pushed for an equaliser in the final half-hour, but they could not break down QPR's resolute defence. 

That threat became even more pronounced in the final 10 minutes after formations were shuffled to bring on more attacking options, but the visitors held on to take the points back to London.

It was the must-have gift this Christmas and Americans opened their wallets to buy MP3 players in record numbers.

Figures just released show that more than 50 million MP3 players were sold in the US last year.

The devices, which allow people to store thousands of songs on a pocket-sized machine, appeared on the market in 1997.

But it was only when Apple introduced the iPod in 2001 that the format began its march to dominance.

The figures for 2003 show that more than 10 million iPods were sold, making it the most popular MP3 player in the US.

The director of the NPD Group, an independent market research company, said he believed the iPod's success was due to its usability.

"That, combined with being on the market longer than its competitors, has given Apple a significant lead in the market," said Russ Crupnick.

Apple's iPod comes in three versions - the original iPod, the iPod mini and the iPod shuffle.

The most expensive, the original iPod, sells for $399 and has a 6 gigabyte hard drive, which holds about 1,000 songs.

The least expensive, the iPod shuffle, sells for $99 and although it has no screen, it can hold up to 240 songs.

Ben Stokes will miss the first two matches of England's four-test series in India while his teammate, all-rounder Will Jacks, is set to make his debut.

The 2022 Spirit Awards took place on Saturday April 16 in Santa Monica. The annual awards ceremony spotlights independent filmmaking, and this year's event was no different. Among the night's big winners were the Netflix films "Knock Down the House" and "The Forty-Year-Old Version," which won the Best Feature award and the Best Documentary award, respectively. 

The film "Sideways" took home three awards in all, including Best Actor for Paul Giamatti, Best Actress for Virginia Madsen, and Best Supporting Actor for Thomas Hayden Church. "This is really a great honor," Giamatti said upon accepting his award. "I'm a huge fan of independent filmmaking, and to be recognized by the Spirit Awards is a real privilege." Madsen was similarly grateful in her acceptance speech. "I'm so thrilled to be here among so many amazing women," she said. "Thank you to the Spirit Awards for honoring independent filmmaking and for supporting female-led projects." 

Church, who emerged from a supporting role in "Sideways" to star in "Easy A" and "Best Picture" winner "Fargo," gave an earnest speech in which he thanked the filmmakers for creating a "great movie." He also joked about his character's memorable scene in which he soils himself while drunkenly dancing. "I'm so sorry, Mom," he said with a laugh. "I know you raised me better than that."

German stock exchange operator Deutsche Boerse has raised its dividend for the first time in three years after increasing profits, with chief executive Theodor Weimer saying the company is back on track.

The group  which owns the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, among others  increased its dividend for the fiscal year 2022 to 70 euro cents ($73 cents) per share, up from 50 euro cents the previous year, with the company saying it was resuming its normal dividend policy.

The move comes after Deutsche Boerse reported a 14% increase in its annual profits, with earnings reaching 727 million euros ($790 million)  helped by increased revenue from its clearing and settlement business.

We exited the transformation phase with our data and analytics business and are back on track with a strong set of annual results, Deutsche Boerse CEO Theodor Weimer said. All our businesses contributed to this success.

The company reported that its revenue from its data, analytics and index business  which includes its Refinitiv platform  increased by 10% to 1.17 billion euros, with the company noting that it had achieved its goal of increasing recurring revenues to 65% of the units total revenue.

Deutsche Boerse also reported increases in its revenue from its cash and derivatives markets, as well as its clearing and settlement business, with the company saying that it was benefiting from increased client activity and higher revenues from partner workflows.

However, the company said that it had incurred significantly higher costs in the fourth quarter of 2022, with Deutsche Boerse saying that it had invested in its IT infrastructure as well as in the build-out of the new data centre in Frankfurt.

Nevertheless, the company said that it was confident that it could continue to increase its profits in the future, with Mr Weimer saying: We enter the new fiscal year with confidence.

Our strong performance gives us comfort in reiterating our medium-term guidance of low to mid-single digit organic revenue growth and consistent annual increases in the dividend per share.

Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair has said that European countries should set more ambitious climate change targets, in the wake of the Ukraine war. He said that current targets were "weak and vague" and that, despite the current cost of living crisis, there was a need to "go faster" in the transition to renewable energy. Mr Blair also said that the Cop26 summit in Glasgow last year had not achieved as much as had been hoped for. Cop26, the 2021 United Nations climate change conference, aimed to produce a legally binding agreement that kept the target of 1.5C warming within reach.

Mr Blair spoke to the BBC's Nick Robinson as he launched a report by his think tank, the Tony Blair Institute for Global Change. In the report, the former Labour prime minister said that European countries should work towards achieving a net-zero carbon economy by 2035. He also called for the creation of a new international organisation, to be known as the Energy Collaboration Club, to work with developing countries to accelerate the transition to clean energy.

Mr Blair's call came as the government announced a new partnership with the United States to end the use of oil and gas from Russia. The 270m package will see the UK end its dependence on Russian oil by the end of the year, and Russian gas by the end of 2022. The money will be used to help British households with the cost of living, and to reduce the country's reliance on fossil fuels. 

The announcement was made as Business Secretary Grant Shapps began a two-day visit to the United States to discuss cooperation on climate change and clean energy.

The state pension should be overhauled to stem the "crippling" effect of inflation on pensioners, a former government adviser has said.

Prof David Blanchflower, who used to sit on the Treasury's independent fiscal policy panel, said the state pension "hasn't kept up with the times".

All but the richest retirees should receive a proportionate increase in their state pensions in line with inflation, he said.

The government said it was committed to ensuring the state pension was "fair and sustainable".

Prof Blanchflower, a professor of economics at Dartmouth College in the US, said: "The state pension is absolutely key to pensioners' living standards.

"But at the moment, it hasn't kept up with the times. It's handcuffed, in the sense that it doesn't go up as much as prices."

He said the state pension should be increased in line with inflation every year, but with a cap applied to the richest 10% of pensioners.

This would benefit the vast majority of pensioners, who are more likely to be in poverty, he said.

Those who have built up large private pensions would not be hit by the change, he added.

"This is not a crazy idea. If you're wealthy and you've got a lot of money in the bank, you don't really need the state pension.

"But many pensioners are very poor, and for them, the state pension is often their only source of income."

Prof Blanchflower served on the Treasury's independent fiscal policy panel from 2010 to 2016.

A government spokesperson said: "The state pension is an essential part of retirement planning, and we are committed to ensuring it is fair and sustainable for taxpayers both now and in the future.

"We regularly review the basic state pension, and wider pension policy, to ensure it reflects changes in society and remains affordable for taxpayers."

Britain's Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski survived a thrilling five-setter to give their country a winning start to their Davis Cup campaign in Austria yesterday.
The British pair needed three hours and 45 minutes to overcome Austrian wild cards Jurgen Melzer and Alexander Peya 6-3 6-7 7-6 6-7 6-3 in the first round of the World Group play-off.
The victory gave Britain a 1-0 lead in the best-of-five match and sets up a fascinating second day's action in Graz with two singles matches and the doubles to come.
Henman and Rusedski appeared to be in total control early in the match as they took the first set but the Austrians, who have been unbeaten at home in the Davis Cup since 1997, fought back to take the match to a deciding fifth set.
And it was the Britons who finally put their opponents away to give Peter Lundgren, the captain who guided Sweden to the 2004 title, a winning start to his tenure.
Britain's chances have been improved by the absence from the Austrian team of Thomas Muster, who has won a record 43 Davis Cup singles matches, and Stefan Koubek, who has been ranked in the top 30.
Moya, a twice former French Open finalist, has decided to concentrate on preparing for next month's Wimbledon instead of playing in the Davis Cup tie against Britain.

The chairman of cricket's world governing body has described the departure of its chief executive as "unfortunate" and denied that he had resigned.

Greg Barclay, who was appointed independent chairman of the International Cricket Council (ICC) earlier this year, said he was disappointed at the "inaccurate" reporting around the departure of chief executive Manu Sawhney.

And he confirmed that Sawhney, who joined the ICC in 2019, remains in his role.

"Manu Sawhney continues as ICC CEO and plays a central role in the delivery of our ambitions to grow the sport," Barclay said in a statement.

"The board of directors is disappointed at the inaccurate reporting in relation to Manu's status and we consider this to be irresponsible reporting.

"We have an excellent relationship with Manu and he has our full support as we look to deliver our ambitions."

Sawhney was appointed ICC chief executive in April 2019, replacing David Richardson.

He had joined the organisation two years earlier as its commercial and development officer and was the leading candidate to replace Dave Richardson, who resigned to take up the role of general manager of cricket at the ICC.

The development comes after the ICC announced a wide-ranging review of its structure on Friday, which will see the inclusion of two additional independent directors, as it looks to rebuild trust and restore its reputation after a series of scandals involving the UAE's governing body.

ICC members voted unanimously to undertake the review, which will be led by Indra Nooyi, the former CEO of PepsiCo, and will start in January.
