"She's effortlessly watchable, with a voice that soars across the auditorium," wrote one critic. Another commented that "the magic of this production is that it appeals to both children and adults alike."

The director, Timothy Sheader, has said that he wanted to create a production that would appeal to a wide audience, and he seems to have succeeded. "This is a show that will leave you feeling uplifted and full of joy," wrote one critic. 

The Poppins musical is sure to be a hit with audiences of all ages and is a must-see for fans of the original stories.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is weighing whether to bring charges against Marsh & McLennan for its failure to disclose $120 million in fees paid to a former colleague of Jared Kushner's, according to people familiar with the matter. 

The regulator is questioning whether the insurance broker failed to disclose the payments because it wanted to retain the business of Marsh & McLennan's unit, which advises corporations on employee insurance benefits, people familiar with the matter said. 

The former colleague, Brian Greene, met Kushner while working at Marsh & McLennan in 2008. According to witnesses, Greene and Kushner did not get along. But when Greene left to launch his own insurance brokerage in 2012, he tapped Kushner to join the board of his new firm, Entrenchment. 

Entrenchment sold insurance to clients of Marsh & McLennan, and the two companies had a revenue-sharing agreement. But the SEC is questioning whether the fees Marsh & McLennan paid to Entrenchment were in fact payments for Greene, who remains close to Kushner, according to two people familiar with the matter.

The BBC news article body:

The former home secretary David Blunkett has warned that the row over his comments about the impact of immigration on Britain risks distracting from the government's efforts to promote greater integration.

Mr Blunkett, who was speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, also said he had never claimed that immigration had been a force for ill in this country.

But he accepted that the issue of immigration could become a greater political issue in the run-up to the next general election.

The Labour former cabinet minister urged all parties to back the government's integrated communities strategy, due to be published later this month.

The IMF has agreed to provide Turkey with a fresh loan of $5bn to support the country's economic recovery. The announcement comes after Turkey's currency, the lira, reached a record low against the US dollar last week, amid a currency crisis and fears of an economic downturn.

The loan, which is subject to approval by the IMF's executive board, will comprise $3.3bn in emergency funding and $1.7bn in standby credit. It is the latest in a series of loans provided by the IMF to Turkey in recent years, as the country struggles with a faltering economy and high inflation.

The IMF said the loan would provide critical support to Turkey's economy, helping to stabilize the country's currency and support economic growth. It also urged Turkey to implement responsible monetary and fiscal policies, and to take steps to strengthen the country's economic institutions.

In a statement, the IMF said: "The Turkish authorities have demonstrated a strong commitment to address the economic challenges facing the country and have taken important steps to stabilize the economy. However, given the scale of the economic challenges facing Turkey, further policy adjustments and reforms are necessary to achieve sustainable and balanced growth."

The announcement came as Turkey's president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, announced a series of measures aimed at strengthening the country's economy, including the introduction of a new economic team and a plan to reduce government spending.

The US state department has ordered the evacuation of non-essential staff from its Baghdad embassy, following a rocket attack hours earlier.

A US official told Reuters news agency that the attack was "probably" carried out by Iran.

It was the second rocket attack on the embassy this year.

Tensions have been rising between the US and Iran, with each side having blamed the other for attacks on ships in the Gulf.

The order to evacuate non-essential staff and members of their families was issued on Saturday, and affects about 50 people, a US official told Reuters. Essential staff will remain at the embassy.

The rocket attack came a day after the US killed an Iranian general, Qasem Soleimani, in a drone strike in Iraq.

The BBC has learned that some of the world's leading financial institutions have been hit by a major security breach.

Sources have told the BBC that the US bank, JPMorgan, and the Bank of New York Mellon were both affected by the breach, which was identified in August.

It is believed the hackers were able to install malicious software on the banks' computers, allowing them to spy on the institutions.

The attackers are thought to have been based in Russia, although this has not been confirmed.

The breach is believed to have been discovered when the banks noticed that some of their computers had started to communicate with IP addresses in Russia.

When they investigated, they found that the malicious software had been installed on their computers, and they were able to remove it.

The banks have not commented on the breach, but a spokesperson for JPMorgan said: "We have multiple layers of protection and we are confident in the integrity of our controls."

The Bank of New York Mellon said: "We maintain a robust, multi-layered security protocol and routinely monitor our systems for signs of trouble."

"When issues are identified, we take appropriate actions to address them and mitigate risk."

It is not clear how many computers were affected, but sources have told the BBC that the number was significant.

This is not the first time that banks have been targeted by hackers. In 2014, a number of high-profile institutions were hit by a breach known as Carbanak.

That attack, which was believed to have been carried out by a group of Russian hackers, resulted in the theft of hundreds of millions of dollars.

The breach of the Bank of New York Mellon and JPMorgan is significant because of the size of the two institutions and the potential for large-scale theft.

It is not clear if any money was stolen in this breach, but sources have told the BBC that the attackers were interested in spying on the banks, rather than stealing money.

The sources said that the malicious software was designed to allow the hackers to see what was happening on the banks' computers, rather than to allow them to steal money.

However, the breach has raised concerns about the security of computers in banks, and it is likely that the attackers will try to target other institutions.

Scotland's already-thin midfield has been further depleted after Billy Gilmour joined John McGinn on the sidelines through injury, with manager Steve Clarke now fearing a Euro 2020 nightmare.

The Scots began their campaign with an impressive 2-0 win over the Czech Republic last week but face much stiffer opposition in their second group game against Croatia on Sunday. 

Clarke had hoped to field the same side that started the opening match but he will now have to make do without Chelsea's Gilmour following a knee problem the midfielder picked up in training on Tuesday. 

The 20-year-old has been a revelation for club and country in the last 12 months and his absence robs Scotland of a much-needed creative outlet in central midfield.

McGinn was already an injury doubt because of a calf problem and the Aston Villa man now looks certain to miss out on Sunday's crucial match at Hampden. 

Scotland have plenty of cover in midfield but losing two of their starters in quick succession is far from ideal ahead of such a crucial match.

Britain's Tim Henman struggled with cramps and nausea but still produced a superb fightback to defeat Canada's Greg Rusedski 1-6, 7-6, 6-3, 6-4 in the fourth round of the Wimbledon championships on Monday.

The 2 hour, 54 minute contest, watched by a centre court crowd that included Prince Charles, was one of the greatest ever seen at the All England Club.

Henman, the seventh seed, fought back from a double break down in the second set, saved a Rusedski match point in the ensuing tie break and recovered from 2-0 and 3-1 down in the final set.

The 27-year-old will face Xavier Malisse of Belgium, the 30th seed, in the quarter-finals.

It was another miserable Wimbledon for Rusedski, the Canadian who was favourite to win the title after the exits of Andre Agassi, Pete Sampras and Gustavo Kuerten.

The big-serving world number four has now failed to win any of his six meetings with Henman here, although three of those encounters have gone to five sets.

Henman, who had been suffering from a virus before the match, started sluggishly and Rusedski took full advantage.

The Canadian dominated the first set, breaking his opponent's serve in the fourth and eighth games before taking the opener in just 25 minutes.

Henman's movement was laboured and his face drawn with pain but he broke back when Rusedski was serving for the second set and went on to force a tie break.

Rusedski appeared to have gained the upper hand when he led 5-4 in the tie break but Henman fought back to take it 8-6 on his fourth set point.

The crowd sensed a comeback and cheered loudly when Henman broke serve in the first game of the third set.

Rusedski twice fought back from a break down but Henman, increasingly more mobile, broke again in the eighth game and took the set.

The Canadian looked shattered and he failed to hold in the opening game of the final set. Henman broke again in the sixth game to seal the match.

The dollar gained against the yen on Thursday, lifted by a boost in U.S. Treasury yields after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan signaled the central bank may raise interest rates sooner than expected.

The yen tumbled to 138.63 on the dollar from 136.84 in North American trade on Wednesday. The euro fell to 67.80 cents from 68.74.

In a speech to a conference in Washington D.C. on Wednesday, Greenspan said that while the Fed has been concerned about inflation expectations, "experience suggests that it is important to monitor the evolution of actual inflation."

Greenspan's comments were interpreted by many as a signal that the Fed may raise rates sooner than the consensus forecast among economists for a move in the second quarter of 2005.

At a press conference after the speech, Greenspan said a rate rise sooner than the second quarter would depend on the data, but that the Fed was concerned that households may be encouraged to take on too much debt.

Many analysts believe the Fed will stay on hold until 2005, despite a recent uptick in core inflation data. The next scheduled meeting of the Fed's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee is on Dec. 9.

The UK government has been accused of routing asylum seekers to Scotland by refusing applications more quickly in English cities. Scottish ministers say decisions in London are taking up to 38 days compared with just six in Glasgow. UK government figures show the average time from application to decision was nine days in London and eight days in Birmingham, but just six days in Glasgow. It has led to claims that the Home Office is effectively routing asylum seekers north. Opposition parties have described the situation as utterly shameful.

Scottish Minister Jenny Gilruth called the disparities completely unacceptable and said the situation was getting worse, not better. She accused the UK government of failing to properly manage our asylum system and said this was forcing more and more people to make dangerous journeys across Europe.

The Home Office said it did not comment on operational policy. But it said decisions were made on individual cases based on all available evidence and that there was no basis for suggesting there was a targeted policy towards particular groups.

Scottish migration minister Jenny Gilruth told the BBC the differences in processing times between Glasgow and other cities were stark and added the situation was getting worse, not better. Glasgow has traditionally been seen as a welcoming city for refugees and migrants  but that no longer appears to be the case. 

Would you like more information on immigration policies in the UK?

By. Staff writer. BBC News.bbc.com

It is only the second time in the event's 52-year history that a squad has been honoured in this way and Gerda Steinberg, 67, who completed the 4x100m freestyle relay in the final, dedicated the award toISL Education.

The independent school in Brent, London, teaches 150 children with autism, with its relay team comprising four teachers.

Ms Steinberg, who is from Berlin and has been a teacher for 40 years, said she was " thrilled " with the honour.

"When I saw the letter from the Queen, I had to take five deep breaths and then I started shaking because I was so excited," she added.

Why did they get medals?

The relay team finished second in their heat in the open-age 4x100m freestyle relay, progressing to the finals where they again finished second.

The teachers say they have been driven by the desire to show that age and disability should not be barriers to taking part in sport.

Ms Steinberg said: "We are not elite athletes. We are ordinary people who have jobs and families and other commitments."

She said the team had shown anything was possible if you put your mind to it.

"It's a lovely feeling to be part of something so wonderful, to show that anything is possible if you work hard enough," she added.

The team also included deputy headteacher Sarah Rennie, 35, Caroline Tooby, 44, and Jo Heath, 34, who are both teachers at the school.

Headteacher Sally-Ann Widney, who swam in the heats, said she was "delighted" with the honour, adding it had been a "fantastic" achievement for the team.

The relay squad were presented with their medals on Tuesday at a ceremony at Buckingham Palace.

The BBC news article could start with:

British citizens were told to leave Iraq immediately on Wednesday, according to a statement released by the Foreign Office. This comes after the British Embassy in Baghdad was attacked by protesters. The attack on the embassy resulted in the death of one demonstrator and injuries to others.

This advice comes as thousands of protesters in Baghdad have stormed the Iranian Embassy, as well as the United Nations headquarters. The British Embassy, which is close to the US Embassy, was not attacked. It is unclear whether the attack on the British Embassy was intentional. Many other embassies in the area have already been evacuated, leaving the British Embassy as one of the very few still remaining in the country.

Foreign Secretary, Jack Straw, has said that the advice to British citizens is kept under constant review. However, there are no immediate plans to evacuate other British Embassies in the region. This announcement comes only a few days after President George W. Bush and Iraqi Prime Minister, Jalal Talabani, agreed to set a deadline for the withdrawal of US forces from Iraq.

The US industrial giant General Electric (GE) has reported a jump in third-quarter profits and raised its full-year outlook, saying the world economy looked "excellent" despite the war in Ukraine and inflation.

Chief Executive Larry Culp said GE's diverse array of products, from wind turbines to medical imaging equipment, was helping it to weather the impact of the pandemic and the global supply chain crisis.

But he warned that Russia's invasion of Ukraine was creating "uncertainty and volatility" in economies around the world.

"Despite that, we see an excellent economy," he said. "Orders across the majority of our businesses are robust."

GE, which is slated to spin off its healthcare business in early 2023 and its energy businesses later this year, raised its full-year profit forecast to between $2.80 and $3.50 per share, from $2.35 to $2.80 previously.

The Boston-based company reported earnings per share of $0.49, compared with analysts' expectations of $0.36 per share.

Revenue for the third quarter was $17.64bn, compared with $18.49bn a year earlier. Analysts had expected $16.77bn.

The UK government has announced that the final licensed hunts in England will take place on Wednesday. The hunts are set to go ahead despite widespread protests from animal welfare groups who are furious that the government has not yet banned the cruel hunting of foxes. It is anticipated that tens of thousands of people will gather to protest the hunts on Saturday. 

The Countryside Alliance, which represents hunters, said it was a historic moment and claimed "the future of hunting in Britain is now at stake". They have consistently opposed any attempt to ban hunting and have said that the government is "demonising" their community. Failing to secure an exemption for hunting from the Scottish ban has led many English hunters to join hunts in Scotland.

Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has so far been non-committal on the future of the ban and has refused to comment on whether he supported fox hunting. However, it is understood that he is under pressure from MPs in his own party, who are mostly opposed to fox hunting, not to delay the implementation of further restrictions.

Boro missed the chance to move into the automatic promotion places as they were held to a draw by Charlton at the Riverside.

Marcus Tavernier scored with two first-half penalties, both won by Isaiah Jones, as Chris Wilder's side recovered from a sluggish start.

But Charlton's Alex Gilbey and Morgan Fox scored before the break to level, with Boro losing flyers Jones and captain Jonny Howson to injury.

Wilder said: "The story of the night is the two penalties we got and didn't get. We were deserved winners and in the end it was a tough game."

Defeat for promotion-chasing Middlesbrough saw them miss the chance to leapfrog Fulham and Bournemouth, who both won, with Sheffield United not in action because of Covid-19 cases at Reading.

After a quiet start to the game, Jones ran at the Charlton defence and was brought down by Ryan Inniss just inside the box.

Tavernier sent Dillon Phillips the wrong way from the spot to score his 15th goal of the season in all competitions.

The visitors looked dangerous from set-pieces throughout the game and equalised from one just before the half-hour mark.

Albion loanee Gilbey met a Ryan Matton cross at the back post, with his effort deflecting in off Luke Daniels.

The visitors then went ahead five minutes later when Fox was left unmarked from a corner to head in on the bounce.

Boro had scored penalties in each of their last four games in all competitions - with Tavernier scoring each time - and their run continued after Jones was brought down in the box seven minutes before half-time.

This time Phillips got a hand to Tavernier's effort but could not keep it out as Boro scored for a 43rd successive game in all competitions, equalling a club record.

Jones was carried off on a stretcher after the penalty and will have a scan on a suspected knee injury on Monday.

Wilder said: "He's gone for a scan now but it doesn't look good. We'll see how he is but it could be an issue for him for the rest of the season."

Both sides had chances to win the game in the second half, with Phillips saving from Martin Payer and Joe Lumley keeping out a Jonathan Leko effort at the other end.

Boro remain third in the table, level on points with Bournemouth and one point behind Fulham, while

Bill Gates, the world's richest man, has opened the biggest consumer electronics show in the US.

The Microsoft chairman used his keynote speech at the CES 2003 trade show in Las Vegas to announce a new version of Microsoft's Media Player.

Mr Gates revealed the new version of the software, due for release in the second half of this year, will include the ability to link to a variety of digital devices, including portable music devices and mobile phones.

The software will also have increased language support, including Chinese, and be easier to use, he said. See tomorrow's BBC news for more on Mr Gates' speech.

The trade show, one of the biggest of its kind, is expected to attract about 150,000 visitors before it closes on Sunday.

The body of a movie, which has been linked to pirated copies of the film circulating on peer-to-peer networks, has hit the nets.

The Academy Award-winning director of the film has urged people not to download the movie, as it will affect the box office performance of the film.

The movie, which stars two of the most famous actors in Hollywood, was released in cinemas last week.

The MPAA, which represents the six major film studios, has also warned people against downloading pirated copies of the movie.

A spokesman for the MPAA said that the film industry was working hard to protect its copyright material.

The challenges of marathon running are testing a trio of actors: Harry Potter star Daniel Radcliffe, Star Wars actor Mark Hamill and actress Katee Sackhoff, best known as Starbuck in Battlestar Galactica. They have been competing in a series of marathons for charity. The actors have been documenting their progress on Twitter and fundraising for charity. "I always knew that I wanted to do some sort of challenging charity work when I finished the Potter films," Radcliffe told the BBC's Newsbeat. The actor, whose final Potter film came out in July, has undertaken a "marathon challenge" in aid of the Brain Tumour Charity. Along with his two fellow actors, he is hoping to complete seven marathons in seven days on seven continents. So far, the team has completed marathons in Antarctica and South Africa. 

Radcliffe says he has always wanted to take on a big challenge. "The idea of having something that was going to take a long time, several years to train for and then a lot of endurance to get through once it began, really appealed to me," he said. He admits that he is "not a natural runner". "I have got very broad shoulders, which is not a good thing when it comes to running - you want to be as lean as possible," he said. "I am also not very good at pacing myself. "Whenever I have run long distances in the past I have started too fast and then slowed down dramatically over the last few miles." 

Radcliffe says the first marathon, in Antarctica, was "pretty brutal". But it was nothing compared with the second, in South Africa. "It was 37C (99F), which is about as hot as it gets," he says. "By about mile 18, 19 I was properly sick. "We were all hallucinating at that point. Mark [Hamill] imagined that his feet were on fire. Mine were sort of dissolving, I thought my shoes were filled with water." 

The third marathon is due to take place in Australia on 20 November. The actor says that taking on the challenge with Sackhoff and Hamill has made the experience "a lot easier". "We three are a very unlikely trio," he says. "There is a nice camaraderie that has built up between us. "We have also had a lot of celebrity runners join us along the way. "Knowing that all these people are supporting us and knowing that every step we take is going towards ultimately trying to cure cancer, that is

The Balkan oil pipeline has been given the go-ahead, ending years of debate and controversy. The pipeline will run from the Adriatic coast to the Bulgarian border, passing through Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, and Serbia. It will be capable of transporting up to 1.2 million barrels of oil per day. The project is expected to create thousands of jobs and boost the economies of the countries involved. 

However, environmentalists have raised concerns about the potential impact on the region's ecosystems. They argue that the pipeline will disrupt the natural habitats of endangered species and increase the risk of spills and leaks. The project's supporters have said that all necessary precautions will be taken to protect the environment. 

The pipeline is a joint project between the governments of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, and Serbia, as well as several private investors. It is expected to cost around $1.2 billion to complete. The project has been controversial from the start, with environmentalists and local communities opposed to it. However, the governments involved have argued that it is a necessary and worthwhile investment that will bring significant benefits to the region. 

The go-ahead for the pipeline marks the end of a long and difficult process, and the beginning of a new chapter for the Balkans. It remains to be seen whether the pipeline will live up to its promises of economic growth and improved infrastructure, or whether it will become a source of environmental degradation and conflict.

Sales for the period encompassing Thanksgiving to Christmas Eve were up a modest 2.3% from last year, but down from the 8.5% increase in 2021, according to a Mastercard SpendingPulse report.

For the holiday season, online sales were up 7.6%, while in-store sales were down 3.4%.

Mastercard SpendingPulse measures in-store and online retail sales across all forms of payment.

Analysts had been forecasting a more modest holiday sales increase of around 3% to 4%, given the squeeze on consumer budgets from high inflation and the fact that many people have exhausted their savings during the pandemic.

"Inflation diminished the holiday shopping season," said Steve Sadove, senior adviser for Mastercard and former CEO and chairman of Saks Incorporated.

"Consumers had a healthy dose of caution as 61% were concerned about inflation," he said.

Rising prices and the lack of merchandise as a result of supply chain bottlenecks has forced retailers to entice customers with deep discounts. That was especially true for popular gift items including toys and electronics. 

The National Retail Federation, the largest retail trade group, is expected to release final holiday sales figures next week. 

According to figures from Salesforce, electronics and toy sales were down in December. Online sales fell off in the final weeks of the season as consumers shopped earlier this year amid concerns over inflation and product availability.

Still, holiday sales are expected to have exceeded the NRF's projection of between 6% and 8% growth, given the backdrop of inflation and the fact that retailers started discounting in October to entice buyers.

The German government has called for significant reform of the European Union, following a rocky period for the bloc characterized by Brexit, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the war in Ukraine. In a major speech delivered in Brussels, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz outlined his vision for the EU, saying that the union needed to become more competitive and assertive on the global stage. 

Scholz argued that the EU should become a more prominent player in the world, by boosting its defenses, increasing its energy independence, and promoting digital innovation. He also proposed that the EU should adopt a unified approach to foreign policy, by agreeing on common positions and increasing its strategic autonomy. 

The chancellor's remarks come as Germany takes over the EU's rotating presidency, and they reflect Berlin's desire to shape the future of the bloc as it emerges from a period of upheaval. Scholz's proposals are likely to meet resistance from some member states, particularly those who fear a loss of national sovereignty. However, they are also likely to be welcomed by those who believe that the EU needs to become more proactive in addressing the challenges of the 21st century. 

Overall, Scholz's call for EU reform reflects Germany's desire to strengthen the bloc's foundations and ensure its continued relevance in a rapidly changing world. As the EU faces an increasingly complex and uncertain future, Germany's leadership is likely to be crucial in shaping the direction of the union.

Music is at a "zombie" state in Germany, dominated by US pop and chart-topping hits from the 1990s and early 2000s, according to a prominent classical music critic.
Daniel Barenboim warned that the country was no longer producing music which was " competitve on the international market" and risked becoming a "museum" of its own musical history.
The conductor and pianist, who is Spanish-Argentinian and has lived in Germany for 40 years, said he felt a "sense of panic" about the lack of infrastructure to support young musicians.

His comments came in a interview to be published on Sunday in the weekly Der Spiegel on the eve of his 80th birthday on 15 November.

Barenboim accused the country's arts establishment of ignoring the current generation of musicians in favour of celebrities and vintage stars who appealed to a mainstream audience.

"Pop and old stars are booked for the next 10 years. There is no space for young musicians," he said.

"Nothing happens anymore, and that's why Germany has become a museum country. Either you play Bach and Beethoven or you play pop music. There is no in-between."

He said that the days when Germany could produce world-class musicians such as Anne-Sophie Mutter and Herbert von Karajan, who had "filled the major concert halls of the world", were over.

"Germany is no longer a music-producing country. It's a catastrophe," he added. "The infrastructure is collapsing. There used to be a musical education in Germany that was the best in the world. Now it's a zombie state."

Barenboim, who was born in Buenos Aires in 1942, said that he had moved to Germany in 1982 because he had been offered the chance to establish the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra as a world-class ensemble - a dream that had been realised.

But he added that he had a "sense of panic" about the lack of opportunities for young musicians in Germany, once considered the centre of the classical music world.

"There is not enough being done in Germany to help young musicians find their place," he said. "All they can do is emigrate and that breaks my heart."

The long-serving Conservative Party chairman, Sir Graham Brady, has urged change at the top of the party with a reshuffle of its senior MPs. 

The Tory backbencher, who has represented Altrincham and Sale West since 1997, suggested that Prime Minister Boris Johnson should consider a reshuffle of his cabinet to promote "a new generation" of ministers. 

His intervention came in a speech to the Conservative Party's local council forum on Saturday night, shortly after the Prime Minister agreed to postpone the overhaul of parliament's upper house - a key element of the government's controversial reform agenda.

Sir Graham acknowledged that the decision to delay the implementation of the reform bill had triggered the resignation of three senior ministers, but defended the Prime Minister, saying that he had listened to the "legitimate concerns" of his cabinet.

Despite the rapid rollout of next-generation networks, a new study shows that mobile multimedia services are slow to catch on. The study, conducted by consulting firm Accenture, found that although many consumers have access to broadband networks, they are not taking advantage of the faster data speeds and new multimedia services that are now available. The study found that only about 20% of mobile users have downloaded any multimedia content, such as ringtones, images, or videos. Furthermore, only about 6% of users download multimedia content on a regular basis. The study also found that users are hesitant to download multimedia content due to concerns about cost, privacy, and the overall usability of the services.

Accenture suggests that network operators work to improve consumer education about the availability and usability of mobile multimedia services. Additionally, the study suggests that network operators should focus on providing more compelling content and offers to encourage greater adoption. Accenture concludes that the slow uptake of mobile multimedia reflects the early stage of development of these services and predicts that adoption will increase as networks become more pervasive and as users become more comfortable with the technology.

The future is now in your pocket. Smartphones are becoming more and more powerful, with advances in technology making them more like mini-computers than anything else. The processing power of the average smartphone is now greater than that of the computers that sent man to the moon in the 1960s. Along with the exponential growth of computing power, the functionality of smartphones has expanded considerably. With the tap of a finger, users can now send messages, connect with friends, pay bills, and even control their smart homes. This is just the beginning. As technology continues to advance, smartphones will become even more integrated into our lives. It's not too far-fetched to imagine a future where smartphones are used for everything from managing our finances to monitoring our health. The future is indeed in your pocket.

The first big film festival of the year has come to a close. The Sundance film festival concluded over the weekend, after showcasing some of the best feature films on offer this year. The festival is known for premiering potential award winners and critical hits, with previous editions launching the likes of CODA, Nomadland, and Get Out. This year's festival was no different, and films about war and geopolitical conflict were the biggest winners. The median age of the jurors awarding the prizes was 42 years old, and person of colour awarded the top prizes. Here are the biggest winners from this year's festival:

- Winner of the Grand Jury Prize: Triangle of Sadness, a pitch black satire of the fashion industry, portrayed as a microcosm for the greed and inequality that defines the current moment. The film is Swedish writer/director Ruben stlund's English language debut.

- Winner of the Audience Award: On the Count of Three, a directorial debut from actor Michael Sarnoski, depicts a man dealing with grief after the death of his wife. 

- The world premiere of Girls Can't Shoot Films, an Egyptian film about three friends working in the film industry who must navigate sexism and misogyny, won a special jury award.

Indian IT giant Wipro has reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter results, with net profit rising to 3,408 crore, up 4.9% year on year.

The company said it had won deals worth $1.3bn in the three months to 31 March, helping its order book to rise for the sixth consecutive quarter.

Wipro's chief executive Thierry Delaporte said the company had "accelerated our transformation and delivered results ahead of expectations".

However, its revenue grew just over 1% year on year to 15,670 crore, slightly down on the 15,965 crore predicted by analysts.

Mr Delaporte said that the company was benefiting from investments in its digital, cloud and cybersecurity offerings.

"We are well-positioned to take advantage of growing demand for digital transformation and IT operations across industries," he said.

Wipro forecasts revenue growth in the fast range of 1.5 to 2.5% in the financial year to 31 March 2024, with a profit growth rate in fast range of 7.5 to 9.5%.

England captain Owen Farrell paid tribute to his "good friend" and former teammate Maro Itoje after Billy Vunipola's injury against Japan ruled him out of the rest of the November Tests.

Farrell will lead England against Australia on Saturday in the second of four Tests at Twickenham.

Both teams have a chance to win the Cook Cup, with England topping the table because of their superior points difference.

Australia make six changes to their side for the match as they bid to avenge their 2023 Rugby World Cup quarter-final loss to England.

One of those changes sees Itoje replace Vunipola, who suffered a calf injury early on in the 60-5 win against Japan.

"We have known each other for a long time and he is a good friend of mine. It is sad to see him go, but these things happen," Farrell told BBC Radio 5 Live.

"It seemed to happen so quickly, but he seems to be in a good place and is happy with the decision that he has made.

"Sometimes things aren't meant to be and you have just got to accept that. He will be a big loss but it does provide an opportunity for someone else."

Suave and sophisticated, or ruthless and cynical? Military leaders yesterday published leaked documents allegedly from London's elite foreign policy circle, warning that the Western alliance is drifting towards a catastrophic war with Russia "whether we like it or not". The goldsmiths, bankers and diplomats who belong to the advisory group known as the Cabinet Office's National Security Council were said to have warned that the UK was ill-prepared for the looming conflict. 
But today one of the ringleaders, the businessman and philanthropist Goldsmith, denied suggesting that the UK should rip up its treaties with Ukraine and instead work to build up a united front with Russia. 

Speaking on the fringes of the Conservative party conference in Birmingham, Goldsmith said he was "not sure" who had written the leaked document recording the discussion among the National Security Council's members, but that it was "not an accurate representation" of what he said. 
"We have a situation where for seven years we have been telling the Russians systematically that any intervention in Ukraine will be met with extremely strong responses, and we are painting ourselves into a corner where we can't really back down," he said.

Plaid Cymrus MP for Arfon, Hywel Williams, has said a blaze at his cottage was a deliberate act of arson.

Police are treating the fire, which destroyed the Welsh language centre at Porthmadog, as suspicious.

Mr Williams said he believed it was started by people who opposed his political views.

The MP has been a vocal supporter of Welsh language rights and has often led protests.

North Wales Police said inquiries were ongoing.

Whilst this is being treated as suspicious, at this stage there is no evidence to suggest any political motivation, it said in a statement.

Police are following several lines of inquiry and investigations are ongoing.

Mid and West Wales Fire and Rescue Service sent crews from five different stations after the fire broke out at the Welsh Language Centre in Portmadog, Gwynedd, just before 17:15 BST on Saturday.

Within minutes the building was well alight, with 50 firefighters needed to bring the blaze under control, the fire service said.

The fire is being treated as suspicious and investigators are working to establish the cause of the blaze.

No-one was injured during the fire, which completely destroyed the centre.

Mr Williams said: Having spoken to the police I am convinced that this was a deliberate act of arson, carried out by people who oppose my political views and activities.

Opposing Plaid Cymru and the Welsh language is not a crime  but deliberately setting fire to property and endangering the lives of residents and the emergency services is utterly despicable.

Whilst the police investigation is ongoing, I am convinced that this was a targeted attack and I am offering a substantial reward for any information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible.

The former primary school, which closed in 2006, had been due to be converted into a Welsh language nursery.

The low-cost airline industry has always had a significant impact on the travel industry. As these airlines have become more popular, they have forced traditional airlines to reduce their prices. This has resulted in an increase in the number of people who can afford to travel by air. However, the low-cost airline industry has also had a negative impact on the Eurotunnel.

The Eurotunnel is a rail tunnel that connects England and France. It is a popular way to travel between the two countries as it is faster than flying and more convenient than taking a ferry. However, the low-cost airlines have made it possible for people to fly between the two countries for a lower price than taking the Eurotunnel. This has resulted in a decrease in the number of people using the Eurotunnel.

This has had a significant impact on the Eurotunnel. In recent years, the tunnel has been forced to reduce its prices in order to compete with the low-cost airlines. This has resulted in a decrease in profits for the tunnel. If the low-cost airline industry continues to grow, it is possible that the Eurotunnel may be forced to close.

Verizon Communications has completed its $8.5bn (5.7bn) takeover of US rival MCI.

The deal, first proposed in February, was approved by MCI shareholders and regulators last month.

Verizon, which is due to release quarterly results on Thursday, is the largest US telecoms firm with more than 140 million customers.

The company has struggled this year, as its consumer division has lost phone subscribers.

It has tried to combat the trend by offering discounts on its most popular plans and cutting 8,000 jobs.

The acquisition of MCI, the country's second-largest local phone company, will give Verizon access to MCI's 1.5 million business customers and about three million consumer subscribers.

The deal includes a provision that bars Verizon from selling its wireless business for two years.

It started with a seemingly simple request for help finding a specific clip of the movie Pretty Woman. 

 Copier saleswoman Jenna Harkness wanted to show a customer the moment when Julia Robertss character speaks the line: You guys are the best. 

Thats when Harkness discovered something strange: Searching the term Pretty Woman script yielded incorrect results from a number of websites  including the official Pretty Woman IMDB page. The top search results were irrelevant excerpts from plays and various books that had nothing to do with the 1990 romantic comedy. Even Google Translate returned a Henan restaurant menu. 

It was like crawling through a rabbit hole, Harkness said. How is this even possible? 

Its an unexpected predicament that highlights an inconvenient truth for giants like Google, Facebook and Twitter: Despite their vast reach and influence, todays most popular search and social media platforms dont always deliver the most accurate results. Instead, they rely on a patchwork of algorithms that often prioritize engagement and ads over genuinely useful information. 

And that could be changing. In a world where misinformation runs rampant, these companies are beginning to explore how to make their platforms more conversational. Think chatbots and voice-powered digital assistants, not just lists of blue links. As they do, they're learning that talking is harder than it seems. Especially when it comes to figuring out what you actually meant to say. 

Earlier this year, Google introduced MUM (Multitask Unified Model), a quantum leap in search technology that aims to understand intent and context to deliver more relevant results. It can, for example, help you plan a whole trip in minutes  from figuring out the best way to get to a destination to knowing what attractions are must-sees. (It can also, apparently, help you shop for wigs, for whatever thats worth.) 

Twitter recently launched a new conversational search engine, which uses a topic model to find tweets about multiple subjects  without relying on the exact words or hashtags used in a search. Then there's ChatGPT, the AI chatbot that can draft essays, debug code and now, it seems, help orchestrate dinner parties. It's all a far cry from the early days of search in the 1990s, when results were generally taken from a list of relevant websites.

The body of a BBC news article titled "Election 'could be terror target'":

The UK election on Thursday could be a "terror target", the Metropolitan Police's counter-terrorism chief has said.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Lucy D'Orsi said that while there was no specific threat, the polls and vote counting halls were potentially vulnerable.

She said there was a "heightened state of readiness" among police.

Meanwhile, the UK's security service MI5 has been accused by Labour of "failure" over female Muslim officers.

A Labour spokesperson said MI5 had "failed to properly address concerns raised" by women who had experienced sexual harassment.

About 1,000 armed officers will be on duty across the country to tackle any potential terror threats to the election.

Concerns about election security have been sparked by the recent London Bridge attack, where the terrorist pleaded guilty to trying to murder people attending a polling station.

Counter-terrorism officers are working with electoral officials and polling station staff to identify and protect potential targets, the Met said.

"While there is no specific threat to the election, we have to be realistic and realise that those intent on disrupting our democratic process may seek to exploit the election," said Ms D'Orsi.

"This could involve targeting polling stations, operational electoral sites or personnel, or both.

"We therefore have a heightened state of readiness across the country to identify and deal with any such threats."

In addition to the armed officers, more than 50,000 trained staff from polling stations and local councils will be working to ensure the election runs smoothly.

The Electoral Commission said the election "must be safe and secure" for everyone involved.

"This is clearly a challenging and stressful time for those involved in delivering the election, and we are doing everything we can to support voters, candidates, and staff," said Bob Posner, the commission's director of political finance and regulation.

The dollar slipped to a new low yesterday after European investors sold the currency in response to the US Supreme Court ruling that the federal government cannot enforce the voting rights act.

 The euro surged to its highest level against the dollar in nearly 20 years, amid concerns that the ruling could leave Congress with insufficient representation of the voters in several states, which in turn could impede the federal government's efforts to respond to the deepening economic crisis.

 A weak dollar is good news for European exporters, but not for the millions of Americans who owe money to foreign lenders. The greenback has already fallen almost 15 percent in the past 12 months, and some analysts are predicting it could decline further.

Valves computer game Half-Life 2 swept the Bafta awards, winning five awards, including the best game.

Half-Life 2 is the eagerly anticipated sequel to Valves critically acclaimed Half-Life, which was voted the best PC game of last year.

The game, released in November 2004, saw players returning to the role of Dr Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist at the Black Mesa research facility.

In the game, Dr Freeman emerges from a long stint in stasis to find that Black Mesa has been devastated by an alien invasion, and that he is the only one who can save the world.

 BAFTAs best game award was one of five awarded to Half-Life 2. The other awards were for best gameplay, best graphics, best sound and best original score.

The Glazer family have owned Manchester United since 2005, but their influence has been felt far beyond the pitch. The club has been accused of treating fans as "customers" and "assets" while becoming one of the most profitable sides in world football. Manchester United fans protested ahead of their game with Everton in November 2021 with many accusing the Glazer family of greed. 

The critics argue that the American owners have helped engineer a seismic shift in the balance of power in English football, with the Premier League's big clubs earning billions from broadcast deals and exploiting their commercial might, at the expense of the rest. The Glazers have also been blamed by fans for United's poor performances on the pitch, with the club failing to win a Premier League title since 2013.

The family have been reluctant to put their funds into the squad, with the club paying a world record fee of 89m for Paul Pogba in 2016 - though the Frenchman returned to United in a 50m deal in 2022. While they have been unpopular with many fans, the Glazers have maintained that they have invested more than 1.3bn in Manchester United since 2005.

The family have also been involved in a string of controversial moves, such as the failed attempt to create a European Super League with a number of other major European clubs.

The future of the Glazer family at Manchester United remains a hot topic, with the club's fans continuing to call for their ownership to end. The family has insisted that they are committed to the club's success and are working to restore United to their former glory. 

Malcolm Glazer, who passed away in May 2021, was the patriarch of the Glazer family and was the primary driving force behind the takeover of Manchester United in 2005. Here is a Q&A exploring his role in the takeover and the impact he had on the club.

Question: What was Malcolm Glazer's role in the takeover of Manchester United?

Answer: Malcolm Glazer was the driving force behind the takeover of Manchester United in 2005. He led the consortium of investors that purchased the club for 790m. He was the largest shareholder in the club, with a net worth of $4.2 billion according to Forbes. 

Question: Why did the Glazers buy Manchester United?

Answer: The Glazers were attracted to Manchester United due to the club's global brand and the potential for revenue generation through marketing and merchandise. The club also had a strong history and a loyal fanbase

Tennis: Britain's Tim Henman has withdrawn from next month's Australian Open because of injury, allowing Romanian Andrei Pavel to take his place in the main draw.

The ATP international committee has confirmed that the 18-year-old, who reached the quarter-finals of last week's Adelaide International, will take the wildcard entry.

Pavel, who moved to London as a refugee when he was 11, is ranked 96th in the world.

He will now face either American Taylor Dent or Argentina's Martin Vassallo Arguello in the first round of the season's first Grand Slam in Melbourne, which starts on 16 January.

British number two Greg Rusedski is hoping to finalise his schedule in the next few days.

The 31-year-old Canadian-born player has been selected to play in the Sydney International, which begins on 10 January, as part of his build-up to the Australian Open.

His place in Sydney was confirmed after Swiss world number seven Roger Federer withdrew because of a knee injury.

British number one Andrew Murray will also play in Sydney as he steps up his preparations for the Australian Open.

Britain will no longer tolerate the "chronic and systemic" failure of other countries to criminalize hijacking planes, the foreign secretary has said.

Dominic Raab said such action was needed to tackle a "startling" rise in hostage-taking and suicide bombings.

Writing in the Sunday Telegraph, he said the UK would "take the lead" in imposing sanctions on any state that failed to act.

Mr Raab said another seven countries had joined the UK and US in taking action since the start of the year.

The foreign secretary's comments come after the Manchester bombing trial heard that Islamic State (IS) had planned to target aircraft.

John Thompson, a member of the UK's Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (JTAC), told the trial of eight people accused of plotting the Manchester Arena bombing in 2017 that IS had aimed to "gain leverage" by seizing aircraft.

The defendant Elshafee Elghnawni, who denies being involved in the plot, told the court he had been instructed to carry out a hijacking as part of his terrorist training in Syria.

Mr Raab said the "absurd" criminalization of aircraft hijacking in some countries had allowed IS to "exploit" Britain and other countries as a "safe haven" for hostage-taking and suicide bombings.

"Second, we will impose sanctions on any state that fails to criminalize this practice - going further than the UK has done before," he added.

"And third, we will take the lead in introducing a legal obligation on airlines and insurers to give advance notice of any impending hijack - so we can intervene to prevent it."

Mr Raab said the UK had secured the cooperation of another seven countries - Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and New Zealand - in the last year, taking the total number of countries who have criminalized aircraft hijacking to 24.

The foreign secretary said that while most countries had banned aircraft hijacking, the failure of some to take action had allowed a "dangerous gap" in international security.

"We are closing that gap," he said.

"Working with allies, we will take the action necessary to stamp out this dangerous practice."

Daniel Robinson has swapped rugby league for rugby union and is aiming for success with Newcastle Falcons. The BBC highlights the key points from his interview with BBC Look North.

At the age of 16, Daniel Robinson decided he wanted to be a professional rugby player.

It was a decision which took him on a journey - via London, Newcastle and Australia - which has led to him achieving his dream.

Now 25, the full-back has made it back to his home city with Newcastle Falcons after seven years in rugby league with London Broncos and Newcastle Knights in Australia.

"When I made the choice at 16 it was to become a pro rugby player no matter what standard that was," he said.

"I've gone through a lot of sacrifices, a lot of things you miss out on through the season, especially growing up in London with no family up here, but it was all worth it."

It has been an eventful journey for Robinson since making his debut for the London Broncos in the Championship seven years ago.

He has experienced promotion to the Super League and subsequent relegation back to the Championship, as well as winning the League Leaders' Shield with the Broncos in 2018.

But it was not all plain sailing for the now 25-year-old, who admits he has had to adapt to different styles of rugby and learn how to deal with being dropped from teams.

"It was a tough start, I was 18 and straight away I was playing men's rugby, training full-time, and the physicality of it and the speed of the game was a step up," he said.

"I'd played age group representative rugby for London and England so I'd played at high levels of rugby but never really consistently played men's rugby.

"I think it was just the physicality and speed of the game, getting used to that and learning how to look after myself and survive in that environment."

As for the differences between the two codes, Robinson says there are "a lot of key fundamentals that are similar".

"It is a bit more free-flowing in union, there are more phases and a lot more kicking but, in terms of basics, passing and catching, it is very similar," he added.

"I'd like to say I'm pretty versatile. I've always been able to handle the ball and I enjoy that side of the game.

"I like the contact as well, I like the physical side

The Indian government has unveiled a budget for the poor, with the country's finance minister saying it would help lift citizens out of poverty.

The budget, which is the government's annual financial plan, includes measures such as increased spending on healthcare, education, and social security. It also includes tax breaks for the poor and subsidies for farmers.

The government has said the budget is aimed at helping to reduce poverty in the country, which is home to more than 800 million people living in poverty.

"This budget is aimed at accelerating the efforts to achieve universal coverage of essential health services and ensuring inclusive education and livelihood opportunities for all," said Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman.

"This is an anti-poverty budget. We are particularly focusing on agriculture, rural development, health and education."

The budget has been welcomed by some, with many praising the government's focus on social spending.

"This budget has a clear focus on social spending and infrastructure development, which is a positive step towards addressing some of the key challenges facing the country," said Dr. Rajiv Kumar, who is the vice-chairman of the Indian government's Economic Advisory Council.

However, others have criticized the budget for not doing enough to address the needs of the poor.

"The budget is lacking in details and fails to address the needs of the poor and vulnerable," said Harsh Mander, who is a rights activist and director of the Centre for Equity Studies in Delhi.

Camera phones are rapidly growing in popularity, with new models being released at a dizzying rate. These phones are revolutionizing the way we take pictures and share them with the world. Whether you're a professional photographer or just someone who likes to take pictures for fun, a camera phone is a must-have.

One of the main reasons why camera phones are so popular is because they allow you to take pictures wherever you are. No longer do you need to carry around a separate camera and worry about losing it or breaking it. With a camera phone, you always have a high-quality camera at your fingertips.

Another reason why camera phones are so popular is because they make it easy to share pictures with friends and family. Most camera phones come with built-in apps that allow you to instantly share your pictures on social media or via text message. This makes it easy to stay connected with loved ones and share your experiences with the world.

Finally, camera phones are popular because they are constantly evolving and improving. Just a few years ago, the quality of camera phone pictures was nowhere near what it is today. With each new model, camera phones are becoming more and more powerful and versatile. If you're looking for a phone that takes great pictures, there's no need to look any further than a camera phone.

Liverpool manager Steven Gerrard has played down the club's chances of ending their long wait for a sixth European Cup.

The Reds have been drawn against Champions League holders Real Madrid in the last 16, with the first leg to be played at the Bernabeu on 22 February.

Liverpool have not won Europe's premier competition since 2005, when they beat AC Milan in Istanbul.

"I think it's naturally a bonus for the players when the draw is made and you get that excitement and that rush for a period of time, but that can die down very quickly," Gerrard said.

"We have got to keep our feet on the ground. We are playing the current holders of the competition, who have won it for the last four years, so it is a big ask."

Gerrard managed Liverpool's U18s and U23s before being promoted to first-team manager in January following the sacking of Brendan Rodgers.

He has led the club to third in the Premier League, three points behind leaders Manchester City with a game in hand, and through to the FA Cup fourth round.

"I think the team we have now compares to the team we had when we won it in 2005, in terms of ability and quality," Gerrard said.

"But the one thing that is killing us at the moment is we are not killing off teams when we are on top in games. We are not managing games well enough, we are making mistakes in crucial times and not taking our chances."

The singer was named the winner of the MTV EMA's first ever "Biggest Fans" award, voted on by fans online.

The Biggest Fans award is the latest addition to the EMAs, which has celebrated the greatest artists in the world for the past three decades. 

The award recognizes artists who have engaged with their fans and communities beyond music. It is the first EMA award presented entirely on fan votes. 

Goodrem has been nominated for several EMAs in the past, including Best Australian Act, Best Pop, and Best Video, but has never taken home a trophy until now.

Denmark midfielder Christian Eriksen is in talks with superagent Mino Raiola over a possible move to Real Madrid, the BBC has learned. Eriksen, 29, is out of contract at Tottenham Hotspur at the end of the season and is able to speak to other clubs about a pre-contract agreement. Raiola will represent Eriksen if he moves to the Bernabeu, with the player keen to join the 13-time European champions.

The Denmark international has been free to negotiate a pre-contract agreement with non-English clubs since 1 January and can leave on a free transfer when his deal expires at the end of the month. Madrid have been closely monitoring Eriksen's situation and are confident they can get a deal done.

Eriksen has been plagued by injuries in recent months, and his future has been the source of intense speculation in recent weeks after he admitted it was "time to try something new". Madrid have been drawn to Eriksen's versatility and ability to play in several positions, including central midfield and the number 10 role.

The Denmark international has also been linked with a move to Manchester United and Paris St-Germain, but Madrid believe they have a strong chance of signing him due to their history of success in the Champions League and the appeal of playing in Spain.

Eriksen played a key role in Denmark's surprise run to the semi-finals of the European Championship last summer, where they suffered a heartbreaking defeat to England in extra time. He has made more than 300 appearances for Tottenham since joining from Ajax in 2013, but has been unable to agree a new contract with the club.

Britain's Cameron Norrie and Dan Evans sealed the team's victory against Australia after defeating Alex de Minaur and Luke Saville in the doubles rubber.

Evans is confident that the team can build on this success going forward, stating that "we've got a good group of guys who are all competitive." He went on to say that "everyone on the team can contribute in their own way."

This is the first time since 1936 that Britain has won the Davis Cup, and the victory comes down to the strength of the team as a whole. The British players have been supportive of each other throughout the tournament, which has contributed to their success.

Norrie, who won the first singles match against Australia, said that "it's never easy playing away from home in front of a loud crowd." He expressed his delight at being able to win the doubles match with Evans, stating that "it's great to get the win."

This victory demonstrates the strength of British tennis and sets the team up for success in future Davis Cup tournaments.

Sony revealed the PlayStation 5 in June 2020 ahead of its November launch. That was nearly three years ago, and since then, the $499 console has remained stubbornly out of stock. All the while, its list of games has grown at a glacial place, with each new title immediately becoming another highly sought-after commodity. Today, there are still only two PS5 exclusives: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart and Demons Souls (which is also available on PC). Meanwhile, the cheaper, less powerful Xbox Series S has enjoyed relative abundance, and Microsoft continues to rack up exclusive day-and-date releases, including several on Game Pass. Its clear at this point that the PS5 arrived before it was ready  but why? 

Sonys part of the blame is that it focused too much on hardware, but Microsoft also deserves credit for being more aggressive with Game Pass, and for giving its first-party studios more time to cook up AAA exclusives. Despite the PS5s lack of must-have games, Sony has sold 7.8 million units as of September 30th, according to its recent earnings report. Thats not an embarrassing number, given the stock issues the company has faced, but its also not a particularly impressive one either. By comparison, the Xbox Series X and Series S have sold a combined 30.2 million units. Sonys reveal that it sold more PS5s in the past fiscal year than in the previous one shows that the console is gaining momentum, but it still has a long way to go. 

Sonys strategy with the PS5 has been to offer new ways to play, with features like a built-in M.2 slot for expandable SSD storage and support for ray tracing. Those are certainly welcome additions, but theyre not unique to the PS5 or even console gaming anymore. Microsoft has since added M.2 support to the Series X and S, and ray tracing has come to some PS4 games via an update. As nice as those features are, they arguably shouldnt have been the focus when Sony was already falling behind in the games department. 

But 2023 could be a make-or-break year for the PS5. A number of exclusives are on the way, including Marvels Spider-Man 2, Hogwarts Legacy, and the next God of War, which will reportedly be the end of this

Cardiff secured their place in the last 16 of the FA Cup with a 3-1 win over Liverpool in a fiery third-round replay.

Bluebirds captain Mark Hudson headed in from a corner after just two minutes to stun the Reds at Cardiff City Stadium.

Liverpool equalised through a Dirk Kuyt strike but Michael Chopra's first goal since April 2012 restored Cardiff's lead before the break.

Chopra scored again early in the second half before Liverpool's Steven Gerrard was sent off for two bookings.

It was the first time in 13 years that Cardiff have beaten the Reds at home and the win took the Championship club into the fourth round for only the second time in 18 seasons.

It was also the first time in his career that Cardiff manager Malky Mackay had beaten Liverpool, having failed to do so in his previous spells with Norwich, Celtic and Watford.

The Scottish manager named an attacking side with four recognised forwards in his starting line-up as Liverpool captain Gerrard returned from a three-match ban to lead the visitors.

It was the home side who started the more brightly, pressing high and causing the Reds problems in possession.

And they took the lead after just 117 seconds when Hudson rose highest to power in Peter Whittingham's left-wing corner from eight yards.

It was no more than Cardiff deserved and Liverpool struggled to cope with the intense pressing of the home side, who threatened to add a second when Aron Gunnarsson's header was tipped over by Brad Jones.

The visitors gradually began to create chances and Martin Skrtel headed wide when well placed before Kuyt struck an excellent equaliser with the outside of his right boot from 25 yards.

But parity only lasted three minutes as Cardiff restored their lead when Joe Mason cut inside from the left before setting up Chopra to hit a first-time strike across Jones into the far corner.

It was no more than Cardiff deserved at the break but Liverpool could easily have gone in level had Jones not produced a superb save to tip Whittingham's free-kick on to the bar just before the interval.

Chopra doubled Cardiff's lead five minutes into the second half with a cool finish after being played in by Don Cowie.

Gerrard was dismissed for a second booking on 68 minutes for a late challenge on Cowie before Jones denied Mason a goal his performance deserved with a fine save.

The UK government has been urged to cut taxes to help consumers struggling with rising prices, with the Conservative party launching a review into the idea of lowering the basic rate of income tax by 20%.

Many Tory MPs and business leaders have backed the idea, saying it would boost the economy, increase spending and lift the spirits of the public, describing it as a "shot in the arm".

The review, led by Rishi Sunak, the chancellor, will consider whether to increase the threshold for the basic rate of income tax, which is currently 20p in the pound, to 12,500, with a higher rate for those with taxable incomes of over 50,000.

While Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the SNP have criticised the plan, some economists have said it could deliver a much-needed boost to the economy.

Schools across the UK are being encouraged to take part in a mock election to help pupils learn about the democratic process.

The election, which is being organised by the UK Parliament, will take place in schools on the same day as the local elections in May.

Pupils will vote for candidates in a made-up constituency, with the results announced on the same day as the local election results.

The scheme is part of a programme to boost young people's understanding of democracy.

Parliament's Education Service has produced teaching materials on the election process to help pupils understand how it works.

The Saudi Stock Exchange ended in the green on Sunday, supported by banking and petrochemical stocks, as the market reacted positively to the announcement of the kingdom's inclusion in the MSCI index.

The All Share Index (TASI) closed 1.5% higher at 11,634 points, after hitting a session high of 11,663 points.

The NCCI index, which comprises the largest and most liquid stocks, rose 1.7%. Saudi Basic Industries Corp (SABIC) jumped 3.1%, while National Commercial Bank (NCB) surged 4.1%.

The banking sector rose 2.1%, with Al Rajhi Bank climbing 3.1%. The petrochemical sector added 1.5% after Saudi Aramco raised the November official selling prices (OSP) for Arab light crude shipments to Asia.

Telecommunications firm Saudi Telecom jumped 7.4% after reporting a major increase in quarterly profits.

MSCI's decision last week to upgrade Saudi Arabia to emerging market status from frontier market is expected to attract billions of dollars of foreign investment to the kingdom's stock market.

"It is a historic day for Saudi Capital Market," said Khalid Al-Hussan, CEO of the Saudi Stock Exchange.

"Today's inclusion in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index is the result of hard work and the success of the many initiatives launched to develop the depth and liquidity of the market," he added.

The BBC can reveal the Premier League club paid him a total of 3,475,000, including 2,925,000 in deferred payments. The 775,000 interest-free loan - which has now been paid back - was the largest outstanding amount owed to any Premier League manager.

Figures released by clubs for the period between 1 February 2021 and 31 January 2022 show Hague's earnings ranked behind only Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola, who earned 10,275,000.

Hull were then relegated from the Premier League, finishing bottom of the table in the 2020-21 season.

The club earned 34,610,000 in total player wages during the period, including 6,870,000 in agent fees and have since been sold to Acun Ilicali for 37m.
