With a little over a week to go until the start of the Rugby World Cup, All Blacks legend Jonah Lomu has revealed he cannot wait to run out at Eden Park again.

The former New Zealand superstar has not played the sport since 2007, when a serious kidney condition forced him to retire.

But he has been selected in the All Blacks' squad to play a warm-up game against Tonga in Auckland on Saturday, 4 September.

And the man himself cannot wait.

"It's going to be massive, it's going to be exciting, it's going to be electric," Lomu told BBC Sport.

"I can't wait to run out at Eden Park in front of family and friends and do my thing on the rugby field again.

"I've missed it for a long time, I've been patient, and now I get another opportunity to live my dream again."

All Blacks coach Steve Hansen recently described Lomu as "a freak of nature", such is his stature and strength.

The New Zealand public have also welcomed the star back into the squad, with many supporters donating their own kidneys to the former player.

"It's been overwhelming," said Lomu. "When I received the call-up, the number of messages I received on social media, it was crazy.

"But the public coming forward, offering me their kidneys, it shows the love and support within the country. It's been amazing."

With the Rugby World Cup just around the corner, Lomu cannot contain his excitement at the prospect of representing his country again.

"To pull on that All Blacks jersey again will be amazing," he added. "Those are memories that are embedded in my head and I'll never forget them.

"But to create new memories, it's going to be even better."

The BBC has learnt that ministers will challenge Gordon Brown over a plan to raid the Cabinet's budget for extra cash to pay public sector workers.

The prime minister is reportedly planning to "top up" a special reserve fund for civil servants - known as the "bottomless pit" - using money allocated to departments. 

Several ministers told the BBC they were "incandescent" with rage when they were told of the plan.  They have asked to remain anonymous.

The idea, devised by the Treasury, would mean departments having to make up the shortfall in their budgets. 

The plan is due to be discussed at cabinet on Tuesday.

England's hopes of winning the World Cup were ended by a determined Iranian side, who edged through to the quarter-finals with a 2-1 victory in Doha. 

Iran, who had already shocked America, were unrecognizable from the team that struggled in the first half of the tournament. They were disciplined, organized, and motivated to pull off another upset. And they succeeded, coming from behind to score two set-piece goals and book a place in the last eight. 

There was no shortage of star names in the England squad. Among them were Manchester United's Rio Ferdinand and Michael Owen, as well as Liverpool's Steven Gerrard and Emile Heskey. They were expected to join the likes of Pele and Maradona in the roll of honor. But it was not to be. 

England dominated the early stages and took the lead when Owen scored with a header from a Gerrard free kick. It was no more than they deserved, having created several chances and hit the post twice. 

Iran grew into the game after the break, pushing forward in search of an equalizer. It came when Mehdi Mahdavikia scored with a powerful long-range shot that deceived David James in the England goal. 

Jermaine Jenas came on as England chased the game, but it was Iran who looked more likely to score. And, with two minutes remaining, Mehdi Taremi beat James at his near post with a superb strike from the edge of the area to knock England out and take Iran through to the quarter-finals.

Britain's most senior judge has warned that ministers risk undermining the legal system and eroding the public's faith in the rule of law by seeking to exert political control over the judiciary.

The head of the Supreme Court, Lord Reed, denounced "a drift towards executive sovereignty", meaning that ministers were seeking to increase their power and control over the courts.

He argued that judicial independence was a vital component of the rule of law and that the courts had to be free to decide cases without fear or favour.

His comments came in a lecture at University College London entitled 'The Limits of Law and the Rise of Judicial Power'.

Lord Reed said the government was 'seeking to put the executive entirely in charge of the system for determining whether or not a statute is constitutional'.

He said this posed a threat to the judiciary's independence because ministers could effectively make laws that trump the courts' ability to rule on their constitutionality. 

Lord Reed said that the courts should decide when Parliament has gone too far in restricting fundamental rights. 

Ministers, he said, had 'taken the view that the courts should not trespass on the province of the legislature by striking down statutes for constitutional reasons'. 

But he argued that Parliament had effectively given the courts that power by setting out rights in the UK's constitution and that ministers were trying to 'whittle away' at that.

Celtic have requested that their Europa League game against Bulgarian side Ludogorets on Thursday be postponed following the death of goalkeeper Vasilis Barkas.

The Greek, who joined the Scottish club in the summer from AEK Athens, died on Monday at the age of just 39.

Celtic said they had been "in contact with UEFA" over the situation.

The game is scheduled to take place in Sofia.

In a statement, Celtic said: "We have requested that UEFA postpone the game against Ludogorets, which at the moment is due to take place on Thursday, November 3.

"The club has written to UEFA expressing our deepest condolences on the loss of Vasilis Barkas and, given the unprecedented nature of this tragedy, we have requested that this game is rescheduled at a later date.

"This is a most difficult time for Vasilis' family and they should not be expected to travel under these terrible circumstances.

"We have offered our full support and assistance to Vasilis' family, and we shall continue to do so."

Xbox owners have been warned about the potential fire risk from a power cable used with some older consoles. The BBC has learned that Microsoft sent out replacement cables last year. The firm said the cable wasn't causing fires, but offered replacements to loyal customers as a precaution. One family, who wished to remain anonymous, told the BBC they were forced to throw away an Xbox console and television after their power cable caused a fire in their living room. Lancashire Fire and Rescue service has also confirmed that it has attended calls to deal with fires caused by the cables.

The Xbox 360 power cable, which was used with some earlier models of the best-selling games console, has a resistor fitted which can fail and overheat, posing a potential fire risk. Microsoft launched the Xbox 360 in 2005. There were various iterations of the console which ran on different sizes of hard drive, and the model number is on a label on the back of the device. Microsoft said that the cable fitted to Xbox 360s sold before October 2007 could pose a fire risk.

An Xbox spokesperson told the BBC: "With the launch of the Xbox 360 in 2005, Microsoft implemented measures to protect consumers, including physical markers on power supplies to differentiate between regional configurations, and additional warnings on the power supply unit and Xbox 360 product to advise consumers to replace older Xbox power supplies with a new universal power supply (UPS) when available.

"While many units were sold with the newer, safer power supply, we have continued to work with our customers on this issue, and have taken additional steps to reinforce these safety messages." The spokesperson added that anyone with an affected power supply should stop using it and contact Microsoft for a free replacement.

Britain's consumer electronics show is currently taking place in London's Docklands. Amongst the usual plethora of converntional gadgets, this year the MP3 player has taken centre stage.

"The MP3 player has quickly become the must-have gadget of 2004," said Kieran Morgan, editor of Computeractive magazine, which organised the event. "We expect 2005 to be the year of the MP3 phone, when these devices really take off in the UK."

See other stories on the event here.

Former world number one Andy Roddick defeated Russia's Marat Safin to reach the San Jose final.

The American, 29, beat the world number 39 6-4 7-6 (7-2) in one hour and 48 minutes.

Roddick will now play Serbia's Novak Djokovic, who saw off the challenge of France's Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

The top seed beat his French opponent - who had beaten him in their last two meetings - 6-3 6-4.

The final is set to be an interesting clash of styles, with Roddick's power against Djokovic's craft and guile.

To understand the drama that is unfolding at St James Park it is important to appreciate the combustible mix of owners, directors and managers that have converged on Newcastle United this season.

On one side there is the consortium of buyers that comprises the Saudi Public Investment Fund, PCP Capital Partners, and RB Sports & Media, the group that completed their takeover of the club in October 2021.

It is an unlikely alliance of the Saudi sovereign wealth fund  the centrepiece of Mohammed bin Salmans plans to diversify the countrys economy  and the Reuben Brothers, who built their property empire from scratch after arriving in the UK as refugees from Uganda.

It is easy to forget that the consortiums offer to buy the club was accepted by Mike Ashley in April 2020, only for the deal to collapse when the pandemic hit. It was revived and finally completed 14 months later with the buyers claiming to have pumped 350m into the club to clear debts and fund transfers.

On the other side there is the retained element of the old regime, chief executive officer Lee Charnley and executive director Kate Barnes, and more importantly, the man they appointed as manager in November 2020, Steve Bruce.

Bruce had been appointed eight weeks earlier, following the departure of Rafa Bentez, who had grown frustrated at the clubs failure to back his ambitions in the transfer market.

The new owners had every right to appoint their choice of manager and did so with a six-year contract, but in Bruce they chose a manager with no prior connection to the club, who had enjoyed only limited success at his previous clubs, and who had been relieved of his duties at Sheffield Wednesday and Newcastle United (the first time around).

Bruce said he needed a proper chance to prove himself and set himself a target of finishing 10th in his first season. They finished 16th.

This season began with more change as Bruces trusted No 2, Graeme Jones, left to be replaced by Eddie Howes younger brother, Jason.

Early results were promising with four wins and a draw in the first eight games but that form was always going to be unsustainable given the limitations of the squad.

Since then just two more wins have come in the following 18 games before yesterdays 3-0 defeat by Manchester City.

The longer the poor results went on, the more complicated the power struggle at the top

The body of a BBC news article titled "Text message record smashed" could begin with the following:

The record for the longest text message has been broken in Argentina, with a message that reads "Subversive plot against the footballer Armando Castellano". 

Conducting an interview with the psychologist and YouTuber Sebastin Grosso, the message which totalled 8000 characters was sent by a telecommunications company to mark 40 years since the launch of the first SMS. 

It took approximately four hours to transmit the message in full, which was sent on Tuesday to the phones of hundreds of passengers on an Argentine bus. 

The previous record for the longest text message was held by a telecommunications company in the Netherlands, who sent a message that totalled 5,600 characters.

The UK's broadband market is undergoing a period of rapid growth, with investments in infrastructure and competition from a number of providers driving the expansion.

The country's largest broadband provider, BT, has been investing heavily in upgrading its network, with the aim of providing superfast broadband to more than 95% of UK homes and businesses by 2020. The company has already rolled out fiber-optic technology to more than 26 million homes and businesses, with plans to extend this to more remote areas in the coming years.

In addition to BT, a number of other providers have entered the market in recent years, including Virgin Media, Sky, and TalkTalk. These providers have been competing to offer faster speeds and more reliable service, which has helped to drive down prices and increase coverage.

According to a report by the UK's telecommunications regulator, Ofcom, the country's average broadband speed has increased from 12.0 Mbps in 2012 to 67.1 Mbps in 2020, with a peak speed of 1.083 Gbps.

The expansion of broadband infrastructure has also helped to improve coverage in rural and remote areas, with the government investing 5 billion in a project to ensure that all areas of the UK have access to fast and reliable broadband by 2025.

Overall, the UK's broadband market is growing rapidly, with investments in infrastructure and competition from multiple providers driving the expansion. This growth is expected to continue in the coming years, as the country's broadband providers continue to invest in upgrading their networks and improving coverage.

The story of how Amanda Wilkinson, a 33-year-old single mom and travel blogger based in Seattle, Washington, got fired from her job as a flight attendant with a major American airline is, unfortunately, all too familiar. She was fired for posting a photo on Instagram of herself in uniform, standing in front of the plane's cockpit with the caption "Another day another dollar." She was reportedly suspended without pay for two weeks while the airline investigated the photo, and ultimately fired for violating the company's social media policy. 

Wilkinson told reporters that she understood the rules surrounding social media and aviation, and that she had received approval from her captain to take the photo, suggesting that the airline was overreacting. However, in a statement to CNN, the airline stood by its decision, saying simply that "the safety and security of our employees and customers is our top priority."

The situation has raised questions about whether employers have the right to control their employees' social media use outside of working hours, and whether these policies are fair and reasonable.

The report details how companies are using software to track employee productivity, monitor email and phone communications, and even listen in on employee meetings. While companies argue that this software is necessary to ensure that employees are working efficiently, privacy experts argue that it represents a significant invasion of privacy.

Barclays and Absa are continuing talks regarding a possible acquisition by the UK lender of its former subsidiary in South Africa, despite reports over the weekend that a deal had been agreed.

Barclays, which owns 62% of Absa, said on Sunday that discussions were ongoing and there could be no certainty regarding the outcome.

On Saturday, South African newspaper City Press reported that a deal, which would see Barclays acquire the remaining 38% of Absa, was likely to be announced this week.

Barclays disposed of its majority stake in Absa in 2005, but retained a minority interest.

The UK bank has been in talks with the South African lender for months regarding a possible buyout.

However, the proposed deal has been complicated by the fact that Barclays has been trying to sell its business in Africa for several years. The bank has already sold its operations in nine countries on the continent, including Egypt, Tunisia and Uganda.

Barclays is expected to refocus on its core markets in the UK and Europe as it seeks to reduce its global presence.

Absa, which was known as Barclays Africa until 2014, has operations in 12 countries on the continent, including Botswana, Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius, Mozambique, Seychelles and Zambia.

Barclays is due to report its third-quarter results on Thursday and it is likely that the bank will be asked about the latest developments in its talks with Absa.

While other countries have seen a steady decline in cinema attendance, Japan has seen an increase, thanks in part to a unique policy: allowing movie-goers to bring their dogs to theaters. 

"In Japan, it is now very common to take your pet dog to the cinema," said Yoshiko Matsuda, a spokesperson for Aeon Cinemas, a chain of movie theaters in Japan.

The practice has been in place since 2001, when it was introduced as a way to attract more people to the movies. It has been a success, with many theaters reporting an increase in attendance since its implementation. 

"We have seen an increase in the number of people coming to our cinemas with their dogs," said Matsuda. "They are coming to the movies with their friends and family, and they are also bringing their pets."

The policy has been welcomed by dog owners, who appreciate the opportunity to enjoy a movie with their furry companions. It has also been a hit with movie-goers, who enjoy the presence of dogs in the theater. 

"I think it's a great policy," said Mitsuru Yamashita, a movie-goer. "I like to bring my dog to the movies, and it's also nice to see other people's dogs in the theater."

However, the policy is not without its challenges. Some people have complained about the noise level of dogs in the theater, while others have said that they are afraid of dogs. 

"We understand that some people may not be comfortable with dogs in the theater," said Matsuda. "We ask that dog owners please be considerate of other movie-goers and keep their dogs quiet during the movie."

Despite these challenges, the policy has been a success overall, and it has helped to boost cinema attendance in Japan. It has also helped to create a unique movie-going experience that is specific to Japan. 

"It's a great experience to go to the movies with your dog in Japan," said Yamashita. "I think it's something that makes Japan unique, and I'm glad that we can do it."

The former Worldcom director who accused financial luminaries of scamming the company has dramatically halted his evidence mid-trial. 

 Bernie Ebbers, the former CEO of the telecommunications giant, had claimed that three former bankers had connived to defraud his company while it was struggling under the weight of billions of dollars of debt. The case has been compared to Enron and brought by the US securities regulator, which has recently taken a harder line on white-collar crime. 

The once high-flying Mr Ebbers has been fighting for his reputation after the collapse of his company through fraud. He is serving a 25-year prison sentence for his part in the scandal that brought down Worldcom, once the world's largest telecommunications company. 

The 71-year-old abruptly stopped testifying on Tuesday after a day and a half on the stand and with the prosecution nearing its end. The case had been expected to last another week. 

US District Judge Kevin Castel admonished Mr Ebbers after the former executive told him: "This is my fault, not yours". 

Judge Castel told him: "This is not the first time, to be perfectly blunt, that you have acted like this. This is the third time you have done this." He added that Mr Ebbers would be held in contempt of court if he did not continue testifying. 

The judge ordered a short break, and Mr Ebbers returned to the stand. He continued his testimony but suddenly stopped again towards the end of the day. The judge called an early end to the day's proceedings, telling the court he would hold a hearing on the matter on Thursday. 

Prosecutors had been questioning Mr Ebbers about a letter he wrote in 2015, from his prison cell, to the executive assistant of Martin Sullivan, the former CEO of the failed energy company Enron. 

Mr Ebbers had written: "I hope your client understands that I feel compelled to do whatever is necessary to prevent further injustice  It is my moral obligation to do so." 

The ex-Worldcom boss was apparently referring to claims he made in 2003 that the banks had pressured Worldcom to hide its debt by lending it money through a complex financing scheme. Mr Ebbers accused them of participating in the fraud that brought down the company. 

JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup have all denied any wrongdoing. Their lawyer, Dan Webb, told the court on Monday: "Mr Ebbers' claims are baseless."

French group Pernod Ricard is in talks to buy Spanish rival Domecq, boosting its presence in the crucial US market, where Domecq has strong brands. The deal values Domecq at $1.36bn (900m). Shares in the Spanish firm surged by more than a third on the Madrid stock exchange. Domecq's main brand is Jose Cuervo tequila, the world's biggest selling tequila. It also makes Kahlua and Sauza tequila. If the deal goes through, Paris-based Pernod Ricard's portfolio would swell to around 40 brands.

Pernod is best known for its aniseed-flavoured pastis and its best-selling vodka, Absolut. The group has been keen to expand its range of spirits and boost its presence in the important US market. "This is a good deal for us. It's a very good fit," said Pernod's chairman, Patrick Ricard. "It opens the US market for us, where Domecq is very strong." The deal would enable Pernod to achieve "significant synergies" in the key US, Mexican and British markets, he added.

All of Domecq's brands, except its sherry business, would be integrated within Pernod's portfolio. The deal could be completed within the next few months. The takeover talk lifted Domecq's shares by 35.7% to 63 euros in Madrid.

The Republican governor of Georgia, Brian Kemp, has announced plans to issue a pardon to people with previous marijuana convictions, despite pot remains illegal in the state.
 
In July next year, Kemp is set to automatically clear past convictions for possession of cannabis. Over 25,000 people in Georgia will have their records cleared owing to the move.
 
The planned pardon only applies to minor offences and does not affect those convicted of other drugs. Kemp's office said the move was aimed at giving people "a fresh start" and boosting the state's economy.
 
ideos showing police officers in Georgia being trained to recognise the difference between cannabis and hemp have circulated online, with some saying the police appear ill-equipped to implement the law.
 
Georgia's law enforcement officers have likewise shown reluctance to prosecute cannabis cases, with many prosecutors declining to pursue pot offences during the Democratic governor's last term.

The studio where American musician Ray Charles created some of his most iconic works has opened as a museum. 

Charles, nicknamed the "Genius", was one of the most influential artists in the history of American music, blending rhythm and blues, gospel, and country into his signature style.

His recording studio in Atlanta, Georgia, has been transformed into a museum, showcasing items including original manuscripts, letters and photographs. 

Following his death in 2004, the space was purchased by entrepreneur and philanthropist Paul Allen, who is behind the transformation.

The government has announced plans to streamline quangos, following a review by the Cabinet Office. The review recommended eliminating 157 out of 457 public bodies, with a further 91 undergoing reform.  The review claims the changes will result in an estimated 1.5 billion in savings for the taxpayer, and that the reforms will enhance the government's response to Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic. 
The plans have been welcomed by some, but others have expressed concern that the reforms could result in the loss of expertise and experience. It is unclear whether the planned reforms will result in the desired savings, or whether they will have the intended effects on the government's response to Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic.

The latest version of the Opera browser for Android has an optional built-in feature that can read aloud any article or website that you visit.

Called Opera Voice, the browser extension is an alternative to similar tools such as Apple's Siri or Google Assistant.

Instead of having to copy and paste text into a tool like Google Translate, users can simply click on a button in the browser to have the content read aloud to them. 

Opera said the feature could be useful for people who have vision impairments or when you want to give your eyes a break.

To use the feature, users will need to tap on the button with a figure of a person on it in the top right-hand corner of the browser, then select the opera voice option which looks like a speaker icon.

The browser will then read the content of the page out loud. Users can adjust the speed of the voice, and switch between a female or male voice. 

Opera Voice is available now in beta version of the Opera browser for Android. A version for iOS is in the works.

Friday 31 December marks one year since Ireland exited its longest-ever recession, but it has been a year to forget for many Irish people.

The economy is growing again, with an expected expansion of more than 7% in 2015, and the government is borrowing less, but recovery is still elusive for many.

Young people have borne the brunt of the recession and many feel that they are being left behind as the economy improves.

One in three under-25s are unemployed and nearly half of those in work are on temporary contracts, according to the Central Statistics Office.

Many have left to work abroad, with Australia, Canada and the UK popular destinations - more than 12,000 people left in the first three months of 2015 alone.

The Irish diaspora is vast with about 70 million people around the world claiming Irish ancestry, so it is no surprise that the trend of people leaving has continued for so long.

But emigration has changed.

"It used to be that people would leave for a few years and come back, now people are leaving and they don't know if they will come back," says psychologist and counsellor Susan Hegarty.

"The difference now is that people are emigrating because they have to, because they believe they have no other option."

Many of those who do return home find it difficult to settle back into Irish life.

"A lot of people who come back can't get a foothold back here again," says Ms Hegarty.

"They have lost their networks, their support systems, their friends and often their families have dispersed as well.

"They have lost their sense of belonging here, and it can take a long time to build that up again."

The lack of affordable housing is also a key issue.

Rents have soared since the economy started to improve, with prices in Dublin up by an average of about 20% since 2014, and up by more than 30% in some parts of the city.

The government has introduced new measures to try to ease the housing crisis, including a "help-to-buy" scheme which will see the state match savings made by first-time buyers.

But the effect of these measures will not be seen for some time, and prices are not expected to come down.

The lack of housing also affects people's quality of life, according to Mary Murphy, a counsellor who works with young people in the coastal town of Dn

Britain's booming housing market is expected to slow next year as rising interest rates and falling consumer confidence curb demand, though prices are not expected to fall, according to a report. 

The latest RICS (Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors) survey showed a sharp slowdown in buyer interest, with the number of enquiries from potential buyers falling to its lowest level since 2008.

It said that while prices were likely to continue rising over the coming months, they were unlikely to do so at the same pace as in recent months.

However, the report said there were reasons for optimism about the UK housing market. It said that a slowdown in price growth would make homes more affordable, and that a rise in interest rates would not be as damaging to the market as some had feared.

It said that the market was likely to remain resilient, as it had done in the past, and that there was no reason to believe that a slowdown in the housing market would lead to a recession.

The report said that while the outlook for the housing market remained uncertain, there were reasons for optimism, and that the market would continue to grow in the coming years.

Singer Jamie Ferguson is "facing eviction" from his 2m London home, according to his neighbours. The residence is allegedly being sold to a developer, with the singer's flat set to be converted into a series of luxury apartments. Ferguson, 65, known for his 1985 hit single "Parachute", purchased the property in 2017 for 1.35m. His neighbours, including comedian Harry Enfield, expressed their concerns about the singer's eviction to the local council in a letter that describes the situation as "an injustice".

The US arm of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's biggest retailer, was sued on Tuesday by a singer whose recording was used without her permission in a promotional DVD sold by the company.
 
Myra Jones says she agreed to sell Wal-Mart a few copies of her CD "It's Too Late," but never gave the company permission to use her recording on its DVD aimed at helping store employees learn to be polite to customers.
 
Jones, a Detroit-area resident, claims in her federal lawsuit that the use of her recording without her consent amounts to copyright infringement, unfair competition and fraud.
 
She is seeking unspecified damages.

The BBC has learned that the Chinese firm that was bidding to save Britain's last car maker MG Rover has had its offer delayed by the UK government.

The delay follows concerns being raised in parliament about the suitability of Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (SAIC).

It is understood that the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) wants more time to assess SAIC's plans for MG Rover, which went into administration in April. 

The government wants to know how many of the company's workforce would keep their jobs, and where the cars would be built. 

It is believed that SAIC has asked the DTI to keep the details of its rescue package confidential.

The Chinese company made a formal approach to the administrators several weeks ago and is thought to be the only party still in talks with them.

It is believed that SAIC wants to buy the Longbridge plant in Birmingham and retain a workforce of about 2,000 - mainly engineers - to help design a new range of MG sports cars.

The company also intends to use the site to build its own range of saloon cars which will be sold in Europe.

It is not thought that SAIC has made a formal offer for the company, but administrators PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC) have said they are confident that a deal can be done.

It is understood that SAIC has requested that the DTI does not make any announcement about the nature of its plans for MG Rover until after the Shanghai motor show at the end of this month.

But a spokesman for the DTI said it was not prepared to make a statement about the Chinese firm's plans until it had carried out a thorough assessment of them.

"We have not been approached by SAIC asking for confidentiality on this matter," he added.

A PWC spokesman said: "We are talking to a number of parties interested in MG Rover and no-one has yet made an offer.

"We are confident that a deal can be done to save the company."

The future of MG Rover, which has been making cars at Longbridge for more than 80 years, has been uncertain since it stopped production in April.

More than 6,000 people have lost their jobs at the plant and at dealerships around the UK.

Arsenal held on to win a dramatic Premier League match against 10-man Chelsea on Saturday, extending their advantage in the race for fourth place. The Gunners were cruising after goals from Emile Smith Rowe and Bukayo Saka left them comfortably ahead at the interval, but Chelsea's fightback after the break ensured a tense conclusion.

Arsenal were dealt a blow when Granit Xhaka was sent off in the 37th minute for a lunging challenge on Mateo Kovacic, leaving themselves with a mountain to climb. Chelsea improved after the break but were unable to find a way through until deep into stoppage time when Eddie Nketiah scored an own goal to give them real hope of taking a point.

That hope was ended seconds later when Gabriel Martinelli scored Arsenal's third on the counter-attack to make sure of the three points in the 93rd minute. The win takes Arsenal above Manchester United into fourth, five points clear of Tottenham with a game in hand on both of their rivals. Chelsea's top-four challenge is all but over, remaining 10 points behind Arsenal with six games to play.

The visitors made the brighter start to the match, but it was Arsenal who took the lead against the run of play in the 18th minute. Chelsea failed to clear a corner and the ball fell to Smith Rowe, who drove into the box and beat Chelsea keeper Edouard Mendy at his near post with a powerful finish.

The Blues responded well and created several chances to level before Xhaka was sent off. Christian Pulisic flashed a shot just wide and Jorginho hit the post from the edge of the box, with Arsenal 'keeper Aaron Ramsdale beaten.

The Swiss midfielder was shown a red card for a lunging challenge on Kovacic, catching the Croatian in the knee as he tried to win the ball. It was a tough decision for referee Michael Oliver to make, and Arsenal were suddenly facing a tough last hour.

To their credit, the Gunners nearly doubled their lead straight away when Saka forced another good save from Mendy, but the Chelsea keeper was finally beaten again just before the hour. Arsenal launched a counter-attack and Saka cut inside from the left before curling a wonderful finish into the far corner to make it 2-0.

That goal sparked Chelsea into life and they should have scored when Mason Mount set up Pulisic, but the American snatched at his shot and dragged it wide with the goal gaping. Chelsea were given a lifeline in the

The renowned rock guitarist, Johnny Ramone, is being sued by his former girlfriend, Adriana Smith, for alleged domestic abuse.

Smith, who was married to the guitarist for two years, claims that he would often verbally and physically abuse her throughout their relationship, which began in 1984. 

In the complaint, Smith details a traumatic incident where Ramone allegedly struck her in the head with a cordless telephone, causing her to sustain a bloody gash on her forehead that required stitches. 

Smith also claims that Ramone would often intimidate her with aggressive behavior, such as destroying her personal belongings and scaring her with gunshots. 

She further alleges that Ramone would often force her to have sexual intercourse with him up to three times a day, and that he would use contraceptive sponges without her consent. 

Smith is seeking unspecified damages in the lawsuit, as well as a restraining order against Ramone. 

Ramone has yet to comment on the allegations.

Here is a sample of the article:

Russian pole vaulter Yelena Isinbayeva has claimed a new world record, clearing the bar at 5.06m at a meeting in Zurich.

The 30-year-old, who already held the indoor, outdoor and Olympic records, finally beat the 5.05m outdoor mark set by American Stacy Dragila in 2004.

Isinbayeva, who won gold at the 2004 and 2008 Olympics, had twice failed to beat the record at previous meetings in 2013. But she finally achieved her aim at the Weltklasse meeting, beating the rest of the field by more than 40cm.

"I am happy it happened in Zurich, where I broke my first world record," she said. "This is the best place to break a record."

The UK ended 2023 with more jobs, lower unemployment and faster economic growth than expected, despite a gloomy outlook for the global economy.

The latest data showed a sharp rise in the number of people in work in all four nations of the UK in the three months to November, with a record quarterly rise in payroll numbers, notably in England.

The uptick came despite economists warning that the UK is heading for a recession next year as households face a perfect storm of higher living costs, inflation and interest rate rises.

Despite this upbeat data, the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) has urged the government to do more to support firms struggling with soaring energy prices. 

The business group said that without further support, firms could choose to shutter locations or move abroad, resulting in higher prices and less choice for customers.

France will this week become the first country to require televisions to include digital tuners, in a move that could boost sales of LCD and plasma screens. The digital switchover, which begins on Tuesday, has been widely publicised in France for months and has prompted a surge in the sale of flatscreen TVs. From Tuesday, broadcasters will stop broadcasting on the country's four analogue channels, which for years have been able to be received anywhere in France. Full details of the digitisation process, and the names of the towns where analogue transmission will end, can be found on the website of France's public service broadcaster, France Televisions. Those who do not receive their television signal via satellite or cable, and who watch analogue broadcasts on a cathode ray tube TV, face having to buy a digital decoder or a new digital TV. 

Digital decoders, which cost about 100 (65), are slightly cheaper than a basic LCD TV, which starts at about 150. Digital tuners are already included in all LCD and plasma TVs and sales have benefited from the run-up to the switchover. "This catalyst for digitising television has allowed us to regain market share in television sales, which had been slipping since the beginning of the year," said Patrice Brehmer, an executive at Fnac, the French high-street electronics retailer. About half of all French households already have digital television, either because they receive satellite or cable television, or because they have bought a TV with a digital tuner. 

According to the latest figures from GfK, a market research company, about 40 per cent of the French population plan to buy a digital TV or decoder in the next year. "The French have reacted reasonably to information campaigns conducted by broadcasters since the beginning of the year," said Franois Barrault, the director of the digital economy at the Ministry of Industry. "The French are aware of the digitisation process." The experience in France will be closely watched in Britain, where a digital switchover is due to take place in 2010. 

British broadcasters have already started to run information campaigns, but full-scale trials will not take place until next year. Michael Grade, the BBC's chairman, said last week that the corporation was working on the assumption that people would have digital television by 2010. "That is why we have consciously driven forward the take-up of digital television," he said. "Some 52 per cent of the population has already converted, and that will grow."

The switch to digital television will reach its final stage on Tuesday when the older analogue signal is finally turned off throughout most of Britain. It is the culmination of a long and remarkably smooth process, driven by the twin engines of technological advance and market competition. Britain has succeeded in becoming the first country in the world to embark on such a radical transformation of its television infrastructure. That it has done so without significant disruption or complaint is a tribute to the planning and investment of the broadcasters and the work of the regulator, Ofcom.

The benefits of digital television are clear: better pictures and more choice, with up to five channels compared with the current two; more interactive services; and the ability to free up spectrum for other users, such as emergency services and broadband providers. The digital dividend, as it is called, could make a significant contribution to the government's target of delivering broadband to every home by 2020.

But for viewers the change means having to buy a digital box if they want to keep watching television as they do today. They face the prospect of having to pay a monthly subscription for dozens of channels they do not want if they fail to switch to digital. This article will answer the key questions about the switch to digital and what it will mean for viewers.

What is digital television?

Digital television, or DTV, is a way of transmitting television signals that reduces interference and allows for better quality pictures and more channels. It is based on the same technology as the internet and computers. The digital signal can carry lots of information, far more than the older analogue signal.

How will I know if I need to switch?

If you have a digital TV or a digital box, you will not need to do anything. If you do not have a digital TV or box, you will need to buy one in order to keep watching television. You can get a digital TV or box from any electronics store.

When will the switch happen?

The switch to digital will happen on Tuesday, April 18. The older analogue signal will be turned off throughout most of Britain. In Northern Ireland, analogue will be switched off on June 24. 

People who do not switch to digital will lose their television service when the analogue signal is turned off in their area.

What if I cannot afford to buy a digital box?

People on low incomes can get help from the government to pay for a digital box. Anyone who receives the pension credit benefit, or income-based jobseeker's

**Concerns remain** as France take on Argentina in the World Cup playoffs

Looks like some fears have come true at the FIFA World Cup as defending champions France were knocked out from the tournament on Saturday after a shocking defeat from Argentina. While the French played brilliantly throughout the tournament, they lacked the determination and grit they showcased during the last World Cup tournament back in 2018.

According to French midfielder Aurlien Tchouamni, "Fear will help France" when facing Argentina and he couldn't have been any more correct. After a shocking defeat, the French national football team now knows what they need to work on in order to proceed further in upcoming tournaments. These four consecutive goals from the Argentine squad were a wake-up call for the French team who have been fairly comfortable in their previous matches.

While this may come as sad news for the French, the Argentina national football team should be proud of their performance during the match. Superstar Lionel Messi managed to score a hat trick which has been a great contribution to the team. They've proven themselves as a strong squad with exceptional players who are capable of challenging France.

This is not the end for France and there is a lot to be hopeful for in the future. The team has realized their mistakes and is more than willing to work on their weaknesses. France will come out stronger than ever before, there is no doubt about that.

Liverpool manager Rafael Benitez is set to launch a 3m bid for his former player Fernando Morientes.

The Spain striker, 34, played under Benitez at Valencia and is keen to team up with him again.

Morientes' contract at Valencia expires in the summer and he would be available at a reduced price in this transfer window.

Benitez believes the former Real Madrid striker, who has also played for Monaco and Juventus, would be an ideal substitute.

Smoking has been linked to tuberculosis for decades, but a lawsuit argued that tobacco companies had failed to adequately warn about the risk. However, a court has rejected the $280bn lawsuit. The case, which was filed in Nigeria by a group of victims of tuberculosis and their families, argued that the companies had broken Nigerian law by not including warnings about the risk of tuberculosis on their products. The plaintiffs argued that the companies had failed to meet their obligations to warn consumers of the health risks associated with their products. 

The defendants, which included some of the largest tobacco companies in the world, argued that they had no responsibility for the plaintiffs' illnesses. They claimed that smoking was a known health risk and that the plaintiffs had been aware of the dangers when they decided to smoke. The defendants also argued that the Nigerian law did not require them to include warnings about the risk of tuberculosis on their products. 

The court rejected the lawsuit, ruling that the defendants were not responsible for the plaintiffs' illnesses. The judge said that the law did not require the companies to include warnings about the risk of tuberculosis on their products. He also said that the plaintiffs had not provided enough evidence to show that the defendants had failed to meet their obligations to warn consumers of the health risks associated with their products. The judge concluded that the plaintiffs had not proven their case against the tobacco companies.

Movie industry executives were reportedly blown away by the initial reactions to Oceans Twelve, the much-anticipated sequel to Oceans Eleven. Viewership for the heist thriller broke records in America, with nearly 25 million tickets sold during its opening weekend. It has eclipsed the previous record-holder, Avatar, by almost every measure. With a worldwide gross of over $375 million, the film is already one of the most successful releases of the year, trailing only local productions in its home territory. 

An industry expert said: These figures are extraordinary. They show that the public has an insatiable appetite for this kind of film. Another analyst agreed, adding: There is no question that these films are hugely popular. The question is why they are so popular. What is it about them that appeals to people? 

Although the film is widely expected to be one of the highest-grossing releases of the year, critics have been less kind. Reviewers often highlight the films lack of originality and reliance on well-worn tropes. One critic wrote: The plot is paper-thin, and the characters are stock types that have been seen many times before. There is nothing original or surprising in this film. 

Despite the critical drubbing, there is little doubt that the film will continue to perform well at the box office. Industry experts believe that the film will break even before it is released on DVD, making it one of the most successful films of the year in purely commercial terms. Fans of the franchise will simply have to wait and see if the anticipated Oceans Thirteen will be made.

The Labour Party has announced that, if elected, its government will abolish the House of Lords. This has been Labour's longstanding plan, yet it has never been popular with the public. According to a recent YouGov poll, only 17% of Britons support the policy, compared to 32% who strongly oppose it. However, Labour argues that the House of Lords is an outdated and undemocratic institution that needs to be reformed. It has promised to replace the House of Lords with an elected Senate, which it claims will make the legislature more democratic and representative of the people. Labour has also suggested that the Senate will be more efficient than the House of Lords, as it will allow for specialist committees to scrutinize legislation more effectively. However, critics have argued that the proposed Senate will not be any more democratic than the House of Lords, as the majority of senators will be appointed by the Labour Party once it has won a general election. Furthermore, some have suggested that the Senate will be more prone to partisan gridlock than the House of Lords, as the Senate's members will likely have more extreme views on politics.

The BBC news article body:

The former home secretary David Blunkett has warned that the row over his comments about the impact of immigration on communities risked distracting from the government's efforts to build a cohesive society.

Mr Blunkett, who was speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, also said he had never claimed that immigration strengthened society.

The Labour former cabinet minister has been accused of causing offence with his comments in a speech on Wednesday.

But he said that "in the heat of debate, things are said".

He added that he had never "disrespected or dismissed" the fact that people had genuine concerns about immigration.

The Japanese capital Tokyo on Tuesday clarified that its recent data showing a decline in consumer prices does not mean it is facing deflation, after correcting the calculation method for its core consumer price index.

Deflation is a dangerous downward spiral for an economy, as it can encourage people and businesses to put off purchases, hoping prices will fall further. It can also make it profitable to hold money instead of investing it.

Tokyo's data for August showed its core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food prices, fell 0.5% from a year earlier, marking the first year-on-year decline since 2016.

The metropolitan government said it had changed its calculation method for the index, prompting the fall. The revised data showed core consumer prices rose 0.1% year-on-year in August.

The number of jobs added to the US economy rose above expectations in the first week of 2023, according to new data. The labor market showed promise as the week closed on February 19, with the addition of 479,000 jobs, compared to the 350,000 estimates. The figures suggest that the US economy is on a steady path to recovery from its shortest recession on record, caused by the pandemic and subsequent lockdowns. 

The hospitality industry saw a particular boost, reflecting the renewed consumer demand following the lifting of restrictions. Hotels and restaurants added 146,000 jobs, bringing the total to pre-pandemic levels. Meanwhile, professional and business services contributed to a gain of 100,000, with employment in the sector now surpassing its February 2020 level. 

The labor market participation rate remained unchanged at 62.4 percent, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.8 percent. These figures indicate a tight labor market, marked by a shortage of available workers despite the robust job growth. The data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed a steady trend of job growth over the past year. 

In the past three months, the US has added an average of 550,000 jobs per month. That said, there are still about 5 million fewer jobs than before the pandemic. The data showed a slight increase in the average hourly earnings from the previous month, up to $32.10, indicating a potential rise in wages due to the increasing demand for labor. 

The job numbers come as the Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates to combat inflation, with the latest increase of 0.25 percent taking the rate to 4.5 percent. These moves are intended to slow down the economy and reduce the demand for goods and services, which could potentially lead to job losses. However, the data suggests that the labor market remains robust despite the rate hikes. 

As the job market continues to evolve, the focus shifts to the upcoming wage growth data and the consumer price index, which will provide further insight into the state of the economy. The report is a positive start to the year, showing a much better-than-expected job market performance and indicating a resilient US economy.

The former England captain took rugby's greatest prize at the sport's highest level but remained his own most demanding critic throughout a glittering career. 

A World Cup winner, a Grand Slam champion and a two-time Lions tourist, Lawrence Dallaglio won everything there was to win in rugby union, yet still described himself as "a bitterly disappointed sportsman".

Even in retirement, the most ferocious of forwards remained his own most demanding critic. "I expect a lot more of myself than anybody else could," Dallaglio said shortly after ending his international career in 2002. "I am hard on myself because I want to be the best, and I never thought I was one of the best players in the world."

It was typical of Dallaglio's self-effacing nature that, even as he was announced as an inductee into the World Rugby Hall of Fame in 2021, he was quick to praise those he had played with and against.

Speaking to the BBC after receiving the honour, Dallaglio said: "There are obviously a lot of great players that haven't been inducted into the Hall of Fame. It was probably more emotional than I thought it was going to be, partly because you look at all the great players that have been inducted, and it is a very select group.

"When you look at the players I was lucky enough to play with and against, the calibre of player is absolutely phenomenal. I am very proud to be part of that group."

A prodigy who learned his trade at Harlequins, it was not until Dallaglio moved to Wasps - first as a loanee and then on a permanent deal - that his career took off.

The switch to Loftus Road transformed Dallaglio into one of the most complete back rowers in the world. He was a totemic figure in a golden era for the club, forming a formidable back row with Richard Hill and Joe Worsley, and winning a hat-trick of league titles and a European Cup.

Dallaglio's 14-year international career included trips to South Africa in 1995 and 1997, as well as Australia in 2001, but it was his role in England's 2003 World Cup triumph which cemented his place in rugby union folklore.

Despite struggling with injury ahead of the tournament, Dallaglio started against Australia in the final, producing a towering performance in a game many believed would be his last.

It was indicative of Dallaglio's

Sony has announced its new PlayStation Portable (PSP) will go on sale in the UK on 1 September, with the handheld gaming console being touted by some as a "must-have" gadget. 

The PSP can play games, but also shows films and videos in high definition, and comes with connectivity to Sony's PlayStation 3 games console, as well as its other services. 

It is being marketed as a handheld console for people on the move, and for that reason does not replace the PlayStation Portable (PSP) console already on sale.

At 209 for the console, and with over 80 games already available, many are tipping the PSP as a must-have gadget.

The number of people in the US who are employed or looking for work rose unexpectedly in September, official data shows. The labour market was expected to weaken after a burst of hiring in August as coronavirus cases surged, but data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) showed further gains in the unemployment rate. The rate rose to 4.8% in September from 4.5% in August, according to the BLS data released on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the number of non-farm payrolls increased by 194,000 in September, beating estimates of about 155,000. 

In the report, BLS noted that there was a decline in government jobs last month, with state and local education seeing job losses. But the worst of the layoffs appeared to be over, as most school districts have started the new academic year and hired staff. The report also showed that the number of jobs in the food services and drinking industry declined, as well as in the arts, entertainment, and recreation industry. 

The report was released as Federal Reserve officials concluded their latest two-day policy meeting. The central bank said it would soon start reducing its monthly bond purchases, but held off on raising interest rates, saying it was still assessing the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the labour market. 

The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note rose following the jobs data release, reaching 1.6% ahead of the Fed's decision.

The future of Derby's much-loved footballer, Mason Mount, looks uncertain. Mount has been absent from the team since picking up an ankle injury in a 4-0 win against Fulham back in August; a victory that pushed the Rams to the top of the table. It was the last time they'd taste victory. 

Mount has been ruled out of Derby's next two matches at least, with the Chelsea star struggling to be available for selection until mid-January. With the transfer window now closed, it looks like Derby could be without their star player until virtually the end of the season. Manager Wayne Rooney is confident that he'll be back sooner rather than later, but this confidence is not shared by the club doctor.

Derby faces an interesting run of fixtures in December, with QPR away and Sheffield United and Middlesbrough at home. These next three fixtures all look winnable on paper, but they'll need to get the better of promotion candidates such as Fulham and Bournemouth in the coming months if they want to taste Championship football again next season. 

Derby has felt the absence of Mount greatly, with the team picking up only 1 point since his departure.

**Conservative MP defects to Labour** - A Conservative Party MP has announced that they are switching to the Labour Party, becoming the latest in a string of lawmakers to defect from the Conservative government. 

The announcement comes as a blow to the Conservative government, which has seen a number of MPs leave the party in recent months. The MP, who has not been identified, is the latest to switch to the Labour Party, which has been gaining support in recent weeks. 

The move is a significant one, as it marks the first time in years that an MP has switched from the Conservative to the Labour Party. It is unclear how the decision will impact the political landscape, but it is sure to have an effect on the Conservative Party's standing in the House of Commons.

The immense volume of data on the internet is constantly evolving. Some of it is legitimate, but scammers are also creating deceptive apps and websites to lure people into giving up their personal information. The teams at Barclays are constantly on the lookout for fraudulent behaviour, using cutting-edge technology to try to stay one step ahead. But how do you spot the deception? To the untrained eye, it can be almost impossible.

One of the most reliable ways of identifying a scam is by analysing the so-called 'digital footprint' it leaves behind. Every time you visit a website, information is collected. It might be the model of your device, your IP address, or information about the browser you are using. This data can help IT professionals spot a scam. The challenge is to collect and analyse data without infringing on privacy.

We spoke to Benborough about the techniques his team uses to uncover scams. "One thing we do is look at the infrastructure of the website," he explains. "Sometimes you can see quite quickly whether a site is professional or not. You can see who registered the domain, and when. You can see where the site is hosted, and whether that host is typical."

But this is just the start. The digital footprint can guide professionals like Benborough in the right direction, but it can't reveal everything. "The sophistication of the criminal organisations is growing all the time," he says. "They're very good at exploiting the latest technologies. A lot of scam sites are simply ripped from the legitimate businesses themselves. The only difference is that they will usually have a slightly different URL, so instead of being Barclays, it will be Barcleys or Barcalays. Or they will have a zero instead of an 'o'." 

At this point, it requires human intervention. The website might look like Barclays, but it doesn't take long for a human to spot the slightly mismatched URL. "We have a lot of human intelligence in what we do," says Benborough. His team of analysts might also notice that a website is being hosted in a strange location, or that a lot of other scam sites are being hosted on the same server.

This isn't just about protecting customers from scams. This is serious stuff. According to UK Finance, 583 million was stolen by criminals through fraud in the first half of 2021. When Dalton Lynch first acted alongside his father in a movie, he wasn't sure if the experience was enjoyable. In his first film, "Uncle Drew," the young actor shot a scene with his dad, NBA legend Shaquille O'Neal, playing basketball. "I was like, 'Oh, I got this,'" Dalton, 10, recalls. But with shooting ongoing, "I was like, 'This is hard.'" 

Shaquille O'Neal played basketball for 20 years, spending most of his career with the Orlando Magic and the Los Angeles Lakers before retiring in 2011. He won four NBA championships and was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2016.

The younger Lynch is now generating his own awards buzz for his breakthrough performance in "Triangle of Sadness," a satirical comedy-drama about the fashion industry. The film, written and directed by Ruben stlund, follows a model couple who go on a luxury cruise and are befriended by a philanthropist, played by Woody Harrelson. Their equilibrium is disrupted by a series of dramatic events. 

In the cast of the film, which world-premiered at September's Venice Film Festival, are a large number of children, including Lynch, whose character has been created to provide some perspective on the adults' absurdity. 

"It's crazy because I've never worked with kids my age," Lynch says. "It was great because we had a chemistry immediately."

His co-stars agree. "I loved working with Dalton," says Charlbi Dean, who plays his mother in the film. "He's so professional, and what a bright, amazing kid. He was like a little sponge just absorbing everything around him and taking it all in."

stlund says that on set, "Dalton was very confident. When I directed him, I didn't feel I had to behave in a childish way. He was very easy to work with."

Lynch was cast in "Triangle of Sadness" after a long search by the film's team. "We saw a lot of kids and tested a lot of kids," stlund explains. "And with Dalton, he had a presence, a kind of magic. You can't really describe it. Also, he has this special relationship with his father, which you can see in 'Uncle Drew,' and we thought that was interesting to explore in the film."

Shaquille O'Neal has been supportive of his son's acting career

Council tax rises in parts of the UK have been described as "reasonable" by the local government secretary. Jonathan Djangoly said increases in councils' tax bases meant hikes should be kept to "affordable levels". He was speaking after a BBC investigation found several local authorities had put up bills by 5%. Labour and some Conservative-controlled councils said higher taxes were needed to protect services.

The investigation found nearly 400 councils are planning tax rises this year, with several setting higher bands than last year. The 5% increase means a bill of almost 1,800 for an average band D property. cheap moncler jackets

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Djangoly said increases were down to councils needing to "strike a balance" between tax rises and service provision. burberry replica bags

He said: "Many councils have seen increases in their tax base, their populations, income levels and house prices and that should be reflected in setting a balanced and affordable council tax level. "

The government has limited councils' ability to raise taxes by placing a cap on increases. cheap north face

The BBC investigation, which involved analysing financial plans of councils, found that 392 out of 399 councils were planning tax rises this year. The average rise was 3.6%.

Defending the increases, Councillor Dan Humphreys, executive member for resources at the Labour-led Hammersmith and Fulham Council, said: "If we did not put council tax up we would have to make significant cuts to services which would be unacceptable to residents. "

The leader of Conservative-controlled Westminster City Council, Councillor Nickie Aiken, said costs were rising and it was important to have a "fair" system. cheap thomas sabo

She said: "It's unfair to put it on the wealthy - it's got to be a balance across the whole community. "

The BBC has lined up a stellar cast for its latest ambitious drama, which tells the story of the 2004 Asian tsunami.

The eight-part series, titled Tsunami: Survival Island, was announced by the BBC on Tuesday.

It will star Martin Clunes, Matthew Macfadyen, and Jill Halfpenny from BBC One's hit drama Showhide, and Bollywood star Shahzad Latif.

They will be joined by Peter Guinness, Amara Karan, and Joe Claflin.

The series will be produced by Ireland's Dancing Ledge Productions for BBC One and BBC iPlayer.

It tells the story of the massive wave that devastated parts of Asia and how it affected people from different countries and backgrounds.

The cast will play characters with different relationships and stories who are holidaying in Thailand when the tsunami hits.

They must fight for their lives as they are swept back to the hotel and taken to a nearby island.

The show will be executive produced by Dancing Ledge's CEO, Anne Brogan, and co-executive produced by Christian Smith.

Brogan said: "This is a powerful story of survival and human resilience in the face of unimaginable tragedy, told with sensitivity and respect for the events that took place 15 years ago."

Macfadyen said: "I'm really looking forward to working with this talented group of actors and I'm so excited to be part of this show."

His Showhide co-star Clunes added: "I'm thrilled to be back in the BBC One Showhide family and I'm looking forward to telling this story with a great cast and crew."

Fiona Harvey, Head of Politics at BBC News, writes:

"A bitter row has erupted between Labour MPs and the party leadership over the handling of a recall bill designed to stop MPs fleeing the party.

The party's national executive committee (NEC) issued a three-line whip - a strong instruction to MPs to back the bill - after a flurry of Labour MPs announced they were quitting the parliamentary party to sit as independents.

But Labour's shadow minister for international trade, Sarah Champion, resigned from her role, saying the move threatened the principle of freedom of speech. Many others spoke out against the proposal.

In an apparent U-turn, party leader Sir Keir Starmer said he did not want to "restrict the rights of MPs to speak their minds".

But one senior Labour MP told the BBC the party had been "held to ransom" by the NEC, which they said was "running the party" and "more interested in punishing colleagues than winning votes".

Another said they feared the recall bill would not pass because of the way the party was dealing with the issue.

And a third said the row had made Labour look "absolutely ridiculous".

It all started when Bury South MP Christian Wakeford quit the Labour party, saying he did not "recognise" the party under Sir Keir's leadership.

Within hours, Labour's NEC proposed changes to the rules on whipping - essentially telling MPs how to vote - to introduce a three-line whip on the wakeford amendment, which would make it easier for MPs to switch parties.

But in her resignation letter, Ms Champion said she feared the move would have a "chilling effect" on debate.

And one senior MP told the BBC the decision to issue a three-line whip was "evidence of the stupidity and lack of judgement of people who shouldn't be in charge of a political party".

Another said the move threatened to make Labour "look insane".

It came after Labour MPs threatened to boycott the parliamentary Labour Party (PLP) - a group of Labour MPs and peers who meet weekly to discuss policy and strategy - in protest at leader Sir Keir Starmer's refusal to discuss the scale of the threat from the far right.

Earlier this week, Sir Keir suggested that talks about the wakeford amendment could take place between the party leadership and MPs who have left Labour, to see if there was a way forward.
