The Conservatives have pledged to offer every English primary school child access to free sports lessons if they are re-elected.

The party said the weekly lessons would be taught by specialist coaches and would take place after school.

The scheme - estimated to cost 160m per year - would begin with an initial 10m investment if the Tories win the lottery on Thursday. 

Sports schools and clubs have welcomed the pledge but point out that facilities will need to be improved to meet demand.

Madrid, November 6th, 2023. David Owen, the British goalkeeper of Madrid Football Club, is determined to stay in the Spanish capital beyond his contract expiry in June 2024, despite speculation about his future. Madrid FC confirmed on Monday that Owen had rejected a recent contract offer, but the club remains optimistic that a new agreement can be reached.

"I'm not interested in going anywhere else," said Owen. "This club has been amazing to me from the start, and I'm determined to stay here and help Madrid achieve its goals. I love the fans, and I love the city. It's a great place to play football, and I want to be a part of it for as long as possible."

Owen joined Madrid FC in the summer of 2022 from Manchester United, where he served as a backup goalkeeper for most of his tenure. Since moving to Spain, he has established himself as the starter under manager Cristiano Bianchi and made over 30 appearances for the club.

His impressive performances have caught the eye of several top European clubs, including Manchester City and Paris Saint-Germain, who have been linked with a move for the goalkeeper. However, Owen has made it clear that he wants to stay in Madrid and is hopeful that a new contract can be agreed upon.

"We're still in talks with the club," said Owen. "I'm confident that we can come to an agreement that is good for both parties. I'm not interested in leaving, so I'm hoping that we can get it done soon."

Madrid FC has reportedly offered Owen a contract extension with a significant salary increase, but the goalkeeper is seeking a longer deal. The club is optimistic that a deal can be reached before the end of the year, as they look to keep their squad together and compete for trophies in the coming seasons.

In the meantime, Owen remains focused on his performances on the pitch, as Madrid FC prepares for a crucial week in the league and a cup competition. With his future secured, he is determined to help the team achieve its goals and bring success to the club.

The number of people in the US who are either working or looking for work increased by 179,000 in February, but still remained far below pre-pandemic levels.

The labour market data - which also showed that the number of jobs added to the US economy fell far short of predictions - could influence the decision on interest rates taken by the US Federal Reserve later this month.

Average hourly earnings increased 0.4% from January, in line with predictions. But compared with February 2022, wages were up 5.1%, well below the 5.8% forecast.

Despite the improvement in the labour market, it is still far from returning to normal, analysts said.

Google has launched a new service that allows users to search for TV shows and movies across different platforms. The service, called "Google TV", is integrated with the company's other products, such as Chromecast and Android TV. It allows users to search for content across multiple streaming services, such as Netflix, Hulu, and Disney+. The service also includes a personalized home screen that recommends content based on the user's preferences. 

Google TV is available on select Chromecast and Android TV devices, and will be available on more devices in the future. It is also integrated with the Google Assistant, allowing users to control their TV with their voice. 

The launch of Google TV comes as the company faces increased competition from other tech giants, such as Amazon and Apple, who have also launched their own streaming services. Google has struggled to compete in the streaming market, with its YouTube TV service losing millions of subscribers in recent months. The company has hopes that Google TV will help it to gain a stronger foothold in the industry.

The most popular funeral song in Britain has been revealed in a study  and it might not be what you expect. 

Classic pop ballad Angels by the Australian duo, The xx, has been named as the top choice for loved ones leaving a funeral, with one in six people (16%) selecting it as their favourite.

The song, a staple of many a funeral playlist, saw support from people across all age groups with those aged between 18 and 24 most likely to pick it as their top choice (24% of people in this age group).

Beyond the classic hits, Queen's We Will Rock You and Freddie Mercury's Bohemian Rhapsody were also among the favourites.

The study, commissioned by funeral plan provider Perfect Choice, was prompted by the firm's analysis of more than 6,000 of its customers' funeral plans, which revealed Angels was the most popular song among those who had chosen a song for their funeral.

Perfect Choice then polled 2,000 people to explore further and found one in six (16%) selected Angels as their favourite funeral song  the highest of any song.

The study also found that one in four (24%) of people would choose a classical song for their funeral, with Verdi's La donna  mobile from Rigoletto the most popular (11% of people).

When it comes to the memories that people most want to leave loved ones with, the study found that 52% of people most want to be remembered for their sense of humour.

Nearly half (49%) said they want to be remembered for their kindness, while a third (32%) hope to be remembered for their achievements.

Just under a quarter (24%) of people said they would like to be remembered for their cooking skills.

Mark Hall, of Perfect Choice, said: "Music is a key part of our lives and can be a great comfort when we lose loved ones, which is why it's important to consider our funeral plans and what we want for our service.

"It's interesting to see that classical music is still a popular choice among those planning their funeral, but songs like Angels show how tastes are changing.

"Our advice to those planning their funeral is to consider what music means the most to you and choose a song that will be a fitting tribute and which will leave your family and friends with a lasting memory of you."

The Manics are taking charge of BBC Radio 6 Music today in a special show to celebrate the release of their upcoming album. 

They will host their show on October 7, 2023, titled Manic Millennium, celebrating the 20th anniversary of their iconic album, Millennium. 

During the show, the band will play songs that have influenced their career as well as discussing Millennium, with exclusive stories behind the album and the bands favourite tracks. There will also be a live session from the studio with songs from their new album Music Complete, which comes out on October 14. 

We are overjoyed to have been asked to host our own programme on 6 Music, said the band. Playing our favourite songs and discussing our favourite records whilst reflecting on our Mero journey from Swansea to San Francisco has been a real privilege. 

The show will be repeated on Saturday, October 8, at 9pm, and will be available on BBC Sounds.

DaimlerChrysler, the German-American car maker, said on Thursday that it had achieved its best sales result in 2004, improving on its target with a rise of 11 percent to reach total sales of 1.99 million cars.

The group, which is the world's fifth-largest car maker, said it had achieved double-digit growth in the United States, where its Chrysler unit sold more than 1.5 million cars, and in Japan, where its Mercedes division sold more than 127,000 vehicles.

Sales in Europe rose by 7 percent, driven by demand for Mercedes cars, which were up by 17 percent, and by the Smart brand, which increased its sales by 28 percent.

DaimlerChrysler said it had achieved its target of increasing unit sales by more than 200,000 vehicles, with gains in all its divisions. The goal, it said, had been to improve on 2003's adjusted result, when sales were 1.78 million.

"We're very satisfied with these figures," said Hans-Dieter Ptsch, a DaimlerChrysler board member responsible for finance. "They're a good indication for the future."

But Mr. Ptsch warned that the industry was facing challenges from rising raw material prices and currencies, and said the company would remain cautious in its forecasts for 2005.

"We're not expecting a dramatic slowdown, but we're not expecting to see the kind of growth rates of the past two years," he said.

Having issued two apologies that failed to calm the furor, Mido decided on a third attempt to apologize. In a statement released by his publicist, Mido expressed his deepest regrets for his behavior, which he described as "completely inappropriate and unacceptable." He took full responsibility for his actions and acknowledged that he had harmed and offended many people. He stated that he had learned a valuable lesson and that he was committed to making positive changes in his behavior. 

Mido also thanked those who had held him accountable for his actions and expressed his hope for forgiveness. He understood that this process may take time and that he had work to do to regain the trust of the public. He was determined to grow from this experience and become a better person as a result.

A blind student from Bristol, UK, says he "hears in colour" after receiving a bionic eye. Tom Williams, 25, has only ever seen shadows and shapes  but now, after receiving the implant, he can identify colours in food and on clothes. The retinal implant goes over the top of his eye, with a video camera feeding information to a microchip which then sends signals to electrodes on the retina. It does not restore vision but allows Mr Williams to detect light and shade and determine the presence of motion.

The device was developed by the company Second Sight, and while it has been available in the US for some time, it is yet to be approved for use in the UK. It has been used in more than 300 people. The device was originally designed for people with a condition called retinitis pigmentosa, which affects the cells that detect light in the retina. However, it has also been tried with success in those with total blindness. 

Mr Williams has optic nerve hypoplasia, a condition where the optic nerves are underdeveloped. He hopes to gain even more sensation through training on the device. Currently, he uses a long cane to get around and listens to the sound of his footsteps to judge where he is.

"I knew it was going to be an extremely slow process, but I was willing to give it a go to help the next generation of visually impaired people," he told the BBC. "However, the sensations I experienced were much quicker and stronger than I expected. Being able to see motion and detect shades of grey has been amazing, but the colour is really something else."

Mr Williams is a classically trained musician and he immediately recognised the difference in colour on his piano keys.

"To be able to see the difference between my black and my white keys on the piano, and to see if my shirt is white or grey, is amazing," he said. "It's a whole new world." 

Mr Williams' bionic eye has a small video camera which is held on top of his eye by a magnetic clasp. This camera sends information to a microchip, which then transforms this data into signals that are sent to electrodes on the retina. The electrodes stimulate the retina's remaining cells, allowing the user to see. 

While the device does not provide the same vision as 20/20 eyesight, users can detect light and motion, differentiating between shades of grey and, in some cases, colour. 

Second Sight's vice president, Dr Robert Greenberg

The esports industry has grown exponentially in recent years, with top video gamers competing in high-stakes tournaments for millions of fans around the world. Now, a new competition is offering a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for the best players to travel the world and face off against the toughest competition.

The World Tour is an all-new esports tournament organized by leading industry brands that aims to bring together the best video gamers from across the globe. The competition will feature a series of regional tournaments, with the winners of each event advancing to the World Tour Finals, where they will compete for a grand prize of $1 million.

"The World Tour is a truly global competition that will showcase the best of the best in the esports industry," said Justin Kenna, CEO of Esports Entertainment Group, one of the organizers of the event. "We're excited to offer players the opportunity to compete on the biggest stage and show the world what they're capable of."

In addition to the competition, the World Tour will also feature a number of other events, including meet-and-greets with top players, exclusive interviews, and behind-the-scenes content from the tournament.

Tickets for the World Tour are now on sale, with prices starting at $99 for a three-day pass. For more information and to purchase tickets, visit the World Tour website.

The EU is set to unveil a new aid plan worth 15bn (13.6bn) over seven years to support the development of African countries. The project, called the "Global Gateway Strategy", aims to bolster the bloc's offer to developing countries, as it seeks to counter the influence of China. It is also set to rival the Chinese Belt and Road infrastructure strategy, which has invested billions in the development of transport and trade links with Africa. The scheme forms part of the EU's attempt to become a more coherent actor in international development, using its economic weight to assert its interests and values.

"The Global Gateway Strategy is a flagship EU initiative to support smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in partner countries," the European Commission said in a statement. It said the project would help "bolster ties and values" and "show the world that Europe is here to deliver". The strategy is expected to include investments in areas such as digital technology, climate and energy, as well as transport and health. It is likely to be discussed at a summit of EU and African leaders in February. 

Developing countries are increasingly turning to China for investment, and Europe fears it is losing influence. The EU has also launched a rival to China's Belt and Road initiative, which aims to improve trade and transport links with Asia, the Indo-Pacific and Africa. The strategy has been seen as a way for the EU to exert its influence and become a more coherent actor in international development. The UK has already committed to the project, despite having a strained relationship with the EU following Brexit. It is believed that the project will help to strengthen ties between the UK and the EU, as they seek to counter the influence of China.

Ukraine has signed a gas deal with Turkmenistan, ending its reliance on Russian supplies.

The deal, signed in Kyiv by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and Turkmen President Serdar Berdimuhamedow, involves the supply of up to 1.5 billion cubic metres of gas per year, with the first supplies expected in April 2024.

Mr Zelensky called the deal "an important step" towards Ukraine's energy independence.

Ukraine has been heavily reliant on Russian gas, but Moscow has cut off supplies to punish Ukraine for its resistance to Russia's 24 February invasion.

The country has also faced an energy crisis with its own reserves depleted and infrastructure damaged by Russian missile and drone attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure.

The deal with Turkmenistan is expected to reduce Ukraine's dependence on Russian gas to 30% from 70%.

Mr Berdimuhamedow said the deal would contribute to Ukraine's "energy security and independence".

"Today, Ukraine and Turkmenistan begin a new page in our cooperation," Mr Zelensky said at the signing ceremony.

"This is an important step towards Ukraine's energy independence. Thank you, dear President Berdimuhamedow, for coming to Ukraine to take part in the signing of this historic document."

Mr Berdimuhamedow added that "despite difficult circumstances", Turkmenistan would "do everything possible" to provide Ukraine with gas.

"This shows that Ukraine is a reliable partner, and Turkmenistan is a reliable gas supplier," he said.

Ukraine had been one of the most important routes for Russian gas to Europe, but Moscow has been forced to sell its gas to Europe via other routes since the invasion of Ukraine.

Many European countries have announced plans to reduce their dependence on Russian gas, and Moscow has been forced to drop its prices in order to entice buyers.

Dmitry Mazepin, the owner of the Russian oil company Yukos, has filed a lawsuit against Russia seeking $28bn in compensation for the expropriation of his company. The lawsuit was filed in the Hague on Monday, Nov. 6, amid widespread criticism of Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.

Mazepin claims that the Russian government's seizure of Yukos in 2004 was illegal and that the company's assets were improperly transferred to the state-owned Rosneft oil company. He also claims that Russia's actions violated the European Convention on Human Rights, of which Russia is a signatory.

The lawsuit seeks compensation for the losses incurred by Yukos and its shareholders, as well as for the company's environmental clean-up costs and the costs of freezing its assets. Mazepin's lawyers said the lawsuit was filed in the Hague because Russia has not accepted international arbitration on the matter.

Russia has denied any wrongdoing in the case, and has said that Yukos' problems were the result of the company's own mismanagement and corruption.

The lawsuit comes as Russia faces widespread sanctions and isolation in the wake of its invasion of Ukraine. Many countries have imposed sanctions on Russian companies and individuals, and Russia has been forced to sell off its assets in order to raise money to fund its war effort.

Mazepin's lawsuit is one of the largest and most high-profile attempts to hold Russia accountable for its actions, and it could have significant implications for the country's reputation and ability to do business internationally.

The Korean government has announced a spending package worth $430bn as officials warned that without urgent measures, the economy would shrink by more than 1% next year and fall into a technical recession.

The announcement followed data showing that in the third quarter of 2022, the economy contracted by 0.4%. It added to concerns that the economy is slowing after growth slowed to 0.7% in the second quarter.

"The economy is facing serious challenges," said finance minister Choo Kyung-ho. "This package is a pre-emptive, transformational investment for the future."

The plan includes money for public sector pay rises, subsidies for heating costs, and a one-off payment for families with children.

There will also be funds available for small businesses struggling with the rise in interest rates, and extra government borrowing has been ruled out.

South Korea is a major player in the global economy as an exporter of semiconductors which are used in products ranging from smartphones to cars.

But its economy has been hit by the Covid-19 pandemic, the war in Ukraine, and a slowdown in China, one of its major trading partners.

The government has been reluctant to restore its pandemic stimulus measures for fear of adding to rising inflation.

The central bank has raised interest rates six times since August last year, with the latest hike coming last week when it lifted them to 2.5%.

The UK is deploying hundreds of troops to the Ivory Coast to provide security for the country's presidential election this week, the Ministry of Defence has said.

Britain says the move is to help the west African nation "defend its sovereignty".

 Ivorian President Alassane Ouattara has accused France of trying to interfere in the vote.

The MoD said the deployment was in response to a request for assistance from the Ivory Coast government.

The troops will provide "engineering and logistics support" for the election, due to take place on Saturday, it added.

The announcement comes after Britain and France issued a joint statement saying they were "concerned about the risk of interference" in the election and calling for the "safety and security" of all voters.

France has previously denied claims that it is trying to interfere in the election.

UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said the troops' deployment was in the nation's interests as instability there would have "potentially serious consequences for the UK and relationships with our African partners".

"Seed clouds" of contraband tobacco are being sprayed across the UK by drones, with gangs using the GPS coordinates of known smoking hotspots to target their illicit shipments, police say.

The trippy footage shows a number of different colourful seed pods being flung out of the drone as it flies over a residential area.

Police say that the professionally-produced footage was taken in the Middle East and sent to them as an example of how the drug trafficking operation works.

Commentators on the video, which has been seen thousands of times, suggest the seeds are khat  a stimulant grown in Yemen and Somalia.

A senior officer described the footage as concerning and said that while the method of dispersal is not currently being used in the UK, there is evidence that it has been considered.

Mr. Ebbers was aware that his company was engaging in fraudulent activity and attempted to hide evidence of it from auditors, officials said.

The once high-flying company, long considered a star of the stock market as it gobbled up rival communications companies, collapsed into bankruptcy on July 21, 2002, after admitting that it had improperly accounted for $3.8 billion in ordinary expenses as capital expenditures, allowing it to falsely report profits.

Mr. Ebbers was arrested on Friday evening at his home in New Jersey after he had been questioned for hours at the Securities and Exchange Commission's Manhattan office, agency officials said. He was expected to be charged with fraud as early as today, they said.

It was unclear late Friday who might represent Mr. Ebbers, though litigation attorneys said he was likely to be represented by a high-powered lawyer since he owned valuable assets, including a large yacht. A call to his home was not returned.

Two years ago, psychologist Juan Antonio Prez Lpez left his home in the Mexican city of Guadalajara to volunteer in Ukraine, helping people overcome trauma from the war with Russia.

While he was away, his wife uploaded a video of their eight-year-old son, Juninho, to her Instagram feed. It was quickly inundated with comments from masseurs, chefs and nannies pleading for jobs. Their employer? Juninho.

"The video was of him screaming and crying, saying he wanted his father back," Mr Prez Lpez says. "I came home three days later and found out from my neighbours that my wife had been employing people to look after Juninho. I was shocked that she did this without consulting me."

Juninho was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (Adhd) and autism spectrum disorder (Asd) at the age of four. Mr Prez Lpez says that his son's conditions have made it difficult for him to make friends. "He has lots of anxiety," he says. "He's a sensitive boy."

Since that day, Mr Prez Lpez has filmed more than 170 videos of his son, often uploaded several times a day to his own Instagram account, TrackdownJuninho, set up to help find his son a job. They feature Juninho singing, doing yoga, playing with toys, making pizza and helping tidy his bedroom. Each one is accompanied by the same plea: "If you need a chef, a footballer, an assistant, a carer or garden help, he's your guy."

The account has more than 82,000 followers and a flurry of ads, interviews and TV appearances. Mr Prez Lpez says that he is surprised by the reaction. "I didn't expect it to become as big as it has," he says. "I thought it would get maybe 100 followers, max."

His son is embarrassed by the attention. "He says: 'Papa, I want to be a normal boy'," Mr Prez Lpez says. "I tell him: 'You are normal. You are extraordinary, but you are normal.'"

 Ironically, the demand for carers has decreased as the strain of looking after Juninho has eased, Mr Prez Lpez says. "Now that we have all these ads out, we have people approaching us, offering to look after him," he says. "He's got four or five people wanting to be his friend." 

Juninho, Mr Prez Lpez says, has learnt to adapt to the attention. "He

The US Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, has sparked a row after he joked about making alcohol more available to lawmakers to encourage them to stay in Washington for longer. 

McConnell's remark came after the Senate passed a roughly $1.5tn (1.2tn) spending bill. Speaking to reporters afterwards, he complained about how long it took to pass the legislation. 

"I wish we could get all our colleagues furloughed under the previous rules, which meant when we were doing overtime we got partially paid or we got Hilton hotels when we were here, or we got two-for-one well drinks," he said. 

"I think what we're going to have to do is make sure members of Congress spend more time in Washington." 

McConnell's comment about making alcohol more available drew immediate criticism from Democratic Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia. 

"Absolutely disgraceful," he wrote on Twitter. "This is profoundly irresponsible, circulation-stopping stuff from McConnell. Drinking as a way to get through legislative work? Lethal. Fatal. Compounding tragedy." 

McConnell's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

It could crush them, literally. Traditional DVDs could meet their demise if the movie industry decides to go all-in on high-definition formats. In 2015, Blu-ray discs accounted for more than half of the $6.2 billion in sales of physical video entertainment, according to the Digital Entertainment Group. DVD sales, meanwhile, dropped by more than 20 percent. The numbers indicate that Blu-ray, which can store far more data than a DVD, is quickly becoming the preferred way for people to buy physical copies of movies and TV shows. But it isn't just consumer preference that could kill the DVD. Warner Bros., which has sold DVDs for two decades, says it may stop pressing DVDs altogether in the near future. The company says it wouldn't spend the money to upgrade its DVD production infrastructure  a costly endeavor  when it could funnel that money into the development of 4K, high-definition video. 4K, which offers four times the resolution of standard high-definition video, could give Blu-ray a run for its money. Streaming 4K video over the internet has already become a reality, and the format of physical 4K video discs is currently under debate by the Blu-ray Disc Association and the DVD Forum, a group representing the interests of DVD manufacturers. Either way, it's clear that the future of home video is in high-definition. So what does that mean for the lowly DVD? It could simply mean there will be less demand for the format. Andy Parsons, a professor of digital economy at the University of Bristol in England, says it's unlikely DVDs will disappear overnight. But he says the format will become largely obsolete as high-definition technology improves. ``When we moved from standard definition to high definition, there was no reason to keep standard definition going,'' Parsons says. ``When we move to ultra-high definition, which is considerably better than Blu-ray, then there's no reason to keep Blu-ray going.'' ultra hd stock image Think about how much data a DVD can hold. It's roughly 4.7 gigabytes, which is enough to store a couple of MP3 songs. Standard Blu-ray discs, by comparison, can hold 25 gigabytes. But ultra-high-definition video requires even more data. Ultra-high-definition TV, which offers four times the resolution of current high-definition TV, already is on the market. And ultra-high-definition video discs could offer resolutions of up to 8K, or roughly 16 times the resolution of current HD. That

The Sundance film festival has joined the ranks of other movie showcases like the Oscars and the Golden Globes by creating a new international category. 

The festival, which began as a platform for indie films has grown over the years to become one of the most prestigious film festivals globally. Like other movie festivals, Sundance has struggled to maintain its identity as streaming services have flooded the movie market with content. 

These changes have only been accelerated by the pandemic which caused many festivals to be canceled or postponed. Because of this, Sundance has had to adapt, and so the creation of a new international category is born. The new category is to make room for international films that were excluded from the U.S. dramatic competition.

Sundance has always been a platform for international films to make their debut on a global stage. With this new change, more films will be showcased from various international regions.

Britain's quadruple Olympic champion Mo Farah will be part of the 5,000m and 10,000m teams at the European Championships in August.

The 34-year-old finished third in the 10,000m at the London Stadium on Saturday - his first competition since switching loyalty from Somalia to Britain.

Farah, who completed the 5km leg of Sunday's London Marathon in a time of one hour and eight minutes, has yet to represent Britain at a major international competition. He qualified for the 5000m and 10,000m at the 2015 IAAF World Championships in Beijing but opted to compete for Somalia, the country of his birth.

He said in a BBC interview last month that he was "ready" to race for Britain again. 

Farah, who won 5,000m and 10,000m gold at the 2013 World Championships in Moscow and the 2015 World Championships in Beijing, joined the exclusive club of four-time Olympic champions after retaining his 5,000m and 10,000m titles at the 2016 Rio Olympics. 
No other British athlete has won as many Olympic golds as Farah, who is also a six-time world champion.

Are there any other British athletes you would like to see compete?

Households across the UK are suffering from an "explosion of junk mail", according to a parliamentary committee.

The Environmental Audit Committee (EAC) said almost half of all British adults had received more unsolicited postings this year.

Committee chair, Philip Dunne, called for a "total overhaul" of the system, including better enforcement of opt-out rules.

Mr. Dunne said: "Householders are bombarded with irrelevant junk mail which is a nuisance and a waste of their time and money."

He added that aluminum cans and paper currently accounted for over half of all household waste in the UK.

The EAC heard evidence that, on average, adults receive six unsolicited items every week.

Committee member, Sarah Wollaston, said: "Junk mail is clearly a nuisance to households across the country and causes unnecessary irritation and frustration, not to mention the unnecessary use of paper."

In addition to a crackdown on irresponsible companies who bombard people with junk mail, the committee also called for measures to increase the number of items which can be recycled. at the moment, only half of all paper mailed to UK households is recycled. 

UK Mail chief executive, Guy Buswell, said his company was already working to reduce the amount of unsolicited mail sent out by its clients.

He said: "We have long supported the growth of opt-out registers and will continue to work with our clients to ensure that they only communicate with people who want to receive their mail."

Royal Mail said it had recently launched an opt-out service for customers who did not want to receive unsolicited mail.

A spokesman said: "Royal Mail fully recognizes the importance of protecting the environment.

"We are confident that the steps we are taking, including the launch of the Door-to-Door Opt-Out, will help to reduce the amount of addressed mail that people receive, and lead to more items of mail being recycled."

Ethiopia's crop production has increased by 24% this year, according to the country's Ministry of Agriculture, which released data for the entire 2021-22 harvest year.

The total harvest was 38.2 million tonnes, comprising field crops such as wheat, barley, sorghum and maize, and vegetables and fruits.

The increase is a significant boost for the country, which has been struggling with hunger and food shortages. It is good news for the government, which has been implementing reforms to boost the country's agriculture sector.

The ministry attributed the increase to favourable weather conditions, an expansion of irrigation facilities, and the introduction of high-yielding crop varieties. 

It also said that the government's efforts to improve the country's road network had helped to transport crops more efficiently.

However, the ministry also warned that the country still faced challenges in terms of food security. It said that the number of food-insecure people had increased from 16 million to 20 million this year, due to the impact of the war in the northern region of Tigray and the COVID-19 pandemic.

Ref decisions in Scotland are once again under scrutiny after a controversial call by referee John Beaton in Glasgow Rangers' win over Celtic on Sunday.
The SPFL has promised to investigate the incident where Beaton appeared to punch Rangers fan James Kelly outside Ibrox on Sunday. And Celtic have written to the Scottish Professional Football League (SPFL) to ask why Beaton was not reported to police. However, the Scottish Football Association (SFA) says it will not discipline the referee as he was not employed by the governing body at the time. 

Beaton was suspended by his employers, the Scottish Football Association (SFA), on Monday. An SFA statement read: "Referee John Beaton has been suspended pending an investigation into his conduct during the match between Celtic and Rangers at Ibrox Stadium on Sunday 6 November 2022. "Mr Beaton was not appointed by the SFA or SPFL to officiate this match. However, as he is a registered referee with the SFA, he is subject to the governing body's disciplinary procedures."

The incident occurred shortly after Beaton waved away strong Rangers claims for a penalty in the second half with the score at 0-0. He then brandished a red card at Rangers manager Michael Beale, before ordering Celtic manager Ange Postecoglou to the stands when he argued against the decision.

Celtic's appeal to the SPFL will put pressure on the body to explain why Beaton was not reported to police. The SPFL had issued a statement on Sunday saying its compliance officer would investigate the incident. But it later emerged that Beaton was not an SPFL employee, which raises questions about the governing body's ability to sanction the referee.

The BBC's new mobile TV service has launched, allowing viewers to watch live television on their smartphones for the first time. The service is available on any device that supports the BBC's iPlayer app, including iPhones, iPads, and Android phones. It will enable viewers to watch live programming on their devices, as well as a selection of on-demand content.

The BBC's mobile TV service is part of a wider strategy to make its content more accessible to viewers across a range of devices. The corporation has also launched a new version of its iPlayer app, which allows viewers to watch live television on their smartphones. This new version of the iPlayer app will be available on all devices that support the app, including smartphones, tablets, and smart TVs.

The BBC's move into mobile TV is likely to be a hit with viewers who want to stay up-to-date with the latest news and events while on the move. It is also expected to be popular with those who want to watch live television on their smartphones while travelling.

Movie industry executives were reportedly blown away by the initial reactions to Oceans Twelve, the much-anticipated sequel to Oceans Eleven. Viewership for the heist thriller broke records in America, with nearly 25 million tickets sold during its opening weekend. It has eclipsed the previous record-holder, Avatar, by almost every measure. With a worldwide gross of over $375 million, the film is already one of the most successful releases of the year, trailing only local productions in its home territory. 

An industry expert said: The box office performance of Oceans Twelve is a significant milestone for the film industry and a testament to the enduring appeal of this beloved franchise. This is a testament to the drawing power of the films star-studded cast and the proven formula that the creative team has developed over the years.

Despite mixed reviews from critics, Oceans Twelve has proven to be a hit with audiences, with many praising the films entertainment value and the performances of its ensemble cast. The film has particularly resonated with younger audiences, with many taking to social media to express their excitement and share their experiences of watching the film.

Industry projections suggest that Oceans Twelve will continue to perform well in the coming weeks, with a strong chance of becoming one of the highest-grossing films of all time. The future of the franchise is already the subject of much speculation, with many fans eager to see where the characters will go next.

The BBC must "get ahead of the curve" and make sure it considers the impact of new technologies on its output, former director-general Greg Dyke has said.

Mr Dyke, who led the BBC from 2000 to 2004, said the "enormously exciting" metaverse would be "integral" to people's lives in the future.

The virtual world, which "mutates" the internet, involves augmented and virtual reality and is accessed via the internet.

The BBC has created several virtual spaces in the metaverse, including a Caribbean-themed hub promoting its new drama series, and an "EastEnders" avatar bar.

But Mr Dyke said the BBC should not be "doing stuff just because it's new", but must "think through" how these technologies are used.

Writing in the Daily Mail, he said: "The truth is none of us know how the metaverse will develop, so the BBC, along with other broadcasters and platforms, needs to experiment.

"But it must do so in a way that is authentic to the corporation's values, in a safe and secure way, and in a way that protects children."

Last year, the BBC announced that around a quarter of its executive committee members would leave the organisation at the end of January, with some getting senior roles outside of the BBC.

At the time, director-general Tim Davie said the BBC had to "retain and attract the best senior leaders" and offer them "fresh challenges and opportunities" or they may leave for other roles.

In his article, Mr Dyke said it was "disappointing" to see so many senior managers leaving the BBC "when they are needed most".

He added that the BBC must "be bold" and "take risks" with new technologies, but with "our values at our core".

 Meta Platforms Inc, the company formerly known as Facebook, launched itself into the metaverse in 2021.

Millions of people already access the metaverse using Meta's VR headset, Oculus, which can transmit virtual reality through a smartphone.

Voters flock to the Blog Awards site to submit their favorite blogs and influencers for the 2023 awards. The deadline for submissions is Friday, and the awards ceremony will take place in June. 

The Blog Awards is a popular event that recognizes the best blogs and influencers in a variety of categories, including fashion, beauty, food, travel, and lifestyle. This year, the awards ceremony will take place in London and will be hosted by TV presenter and influencer, Zoe Sugg. 

 Voters can submit their favorite blogs and influencers online, and the winners will be chosen by a panel of judges. The awards ceremony will feature a red carpet, special guest performances, and an after-party. 

Tickets for the awards ceremony will go on sale in April, and bloggers and influencers from all over the world are expected to attend.

The Irish markets have reached an all-time high, with the benchmark index, the Irish Stock Exchange (ISE) Overall Index, up over 10% in the past year. This growth has been driven by a strong performance in the country's technology and healthcare sectors, as well as a resilient economy and attractive corporate tax rates.

The technology sector in Ireland has been particularly strong, with a number of companies experiencing significant growth. For example, the software company Salesforce has announced plans to create 1,500 new jobs in the country, while the online food delivery service Just Eat has opened a new hub in Dublin.

The healthcare sector has also performed well, with a number of companies making significant investments in the country. For example, the pharmaceutical company Pfizer has announced plans to invest $75 million in a new manufacturing facility in Dublin, while the medical device company Medtronic has opened a new research and development center in Galway.

The Irish economy has been resilient in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the government has implemented a number of measures to support businesses and protect jobs. This has helped to maintain investor confidence in the country and contributed to the strong performance of the markets.

Additionally, Ireland's corporate tax rates have continued to attract businesses to the country. The government has recently announced plans to further reduce the corporate tax rate, which is expected to further boost investment in the country.

Looking ahead, it is expected that the Irish markets will continue to perform well, with the benchmark index potentially reaching new highs in the coming months. However, there are some concerns about the potential impact of rising interest rates and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

The Lib Dems have called on the government to take action on problem debt, as figures show it has reached record levels.

Party leader Ed Davey said "urgent action" was needed to help people in trouble.

The Liberal Democrats' call came as figures from charity StepChange showed average problem debt had reached 17,000.

The charity said it had heard from many people who were "trapped" in their debt, with no hope of paying it off.

In response, the government said it had taken a "number of steps" to help people with debt problems. These included freezing the basic rate of tax, as well as energy prices, until April 2023.

Is there anything else I can help you with?

The EU parliament has once again delayed the patent reform package known as the unitary patent. Estimates suggest that the original legislation could have led to up to a 1.5 trillion boost to the EU economy, and prompted the creation of some 460,000 jobs. The legislation has been stalled for years now, due in part to lobbying from tech firms, who are concerned about the threat of software patents. The legislation could be approved before the end of the year, however, supporters of the law have already attempted to push this through parliament twice before.

 Supporters of the patent reform package aredesperate for its approval as the economy tries to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. More than two-thirds of EU businesses that apply for patents are small and medium-sized enterprises, with patent reform potentially offering cheaper and easier patent protection, particularly for SMEs.

Opposers of the legislation, which include large tech firms such as Apple and Microsoft, argue that the reforms would expose European software developers to unfair litigation, particularly those working on open-source software. There are also concerns that the unitary patent would undermine democratic principles by bypassing national legislatures.

Earlier this year, the EU agreed on a compromise that would see software patents excluded from the unitary patent package, however, the legislation could still allow for future inclusion.

According to a recent study by the University of York, lifestyle choices are the primary determinant of the type of mobile phone one owns in Britain. The study found that there are six distinct mobile user groups in the country. These are:

- The Technophobes: They are typically unattached and often retired. This group tends to have little or no digital skills. Members are usually over 65 and tend to have lower incomes.

- The Traditionalists: They are usually over 45 and tend to be female. This group primarily uses their mobiles to make phone calls and send text messages.

- The Simplicities: This group uses their phones for calls, texts, and pictures. They tend to be female, over 65, and have middle incomes.

- The Communicators: This group sends more messages than the average user and more pictures than the Simplicities. This group's members are usually female and aged between 16 and 24.

- The Photographers: As the name suggests, the members of this group use their phones to take pictures and share them on social media. Over 55s tend to dominate this group.

- The Super Users: This group uses all the functions of a smartphone, particularly internet services and apps. This group is dominated by the 16 to 24 age group.

Sajid Javid has rejected suggestions the Conservative Party is on the verge of splitting after criticism from one of its most high-profile MPs.

The health secretary accused Crispin Blunt of "blowing up from 40,000ft" with his warning that the Tories could lose hundreds of seats at the next general election.

Mr Blunt, MP for Reigate, has urged his party to embrace pro-Brexit supporters - including those who voted for Jeremy Hunt in the Tory leadership contest.

But Mr Javid accused him of "backseat driving" and said the Conservative Party was "getting on just fine". 

He added that the party was "more united than ever" and that he had "never seen that". 

In an interview with The Telegraph, Mr Blunt said the party could lose up to 400 seats unless it "opens its eyes" to changes needed to win the next election.

The Conservative Party has held onto power as a minority government since the last election, but many of its MPs represent constituencies that voted to leave the European Union - including Mr Blunt.

Mr Hunt, who finished second to Boris Johnson in the leadership contest, won the backing of many pro-Brexit MPs and members. 

But since the result was announced, some Conservative MPs have expressed concern that the party is not doing enough to embrace figures like Mr Hunt.

Mr Blunt told The Telegraph that the party "needs to open its eyes and realise we're in danger of losing 400 seats".

He added that the party had "got itself into a position where it is ignoring everybody who voted for Jeremy Hunt".

He said this included "a lot of people who voted for Boris Johnson in the final round but were voting for someone else before that".

In his own interview with The Telegraph, Mr Javid said there was "no shortage" of people in the Conservative Party who were pro-Brexit. 

"Crispin Blunt MP seems to enjoy blowing up from 40,000ft but I'm not going to be drawn into that," he said.

"I think backbenchers, the government, the whole party is getting on just fine. We're more united than ever. I've never seen that."

Discipline increasingly ' vulnerabile' to the replication crisis, says committee

The UK's Royal Society has expressed concern over the future of the social sciences, claiming that the discipline is at risk of facing a crisis similar to that in psychology, which has seen many findings fail to be replicated.

The warning comes in a new report looking at the impact of the research excellence framework (REF), a system used by UK higher education institutions to assess the quality of their research.

The report highlights particular concern over the future of the social sciences, with the committee citing the "growing threat" of misinformation and the public perception of scientific research. It warned that the discipline was becoming increasingly "vulnerable" to a replication crisis and that the validity of research in the field was being undermined. 

The report reads: The committee heard that the social sciences were vulnerable to a replication crisis akin to that seen in psychology and that the digital revolution and proliferation of social media meant that validation of findings was increasingly difficult.

The committee is concerned that the weighting of research versus teaching in the REF could negatively impact the research culture in the sector and deter talented staff from staying in the UK.

The Royal Society has called for further investigation into the impact of the REF on the social sciences and for greater investment in the discipline. It also urged the government to consider the potential impact of Brexit on the social sciences and to take steps to protect the field post-Brexit.

Adults often get criticized for acting childish. But most of these adults have literally grown up being surrounded by children.

We expect adults to act like mature adults all the time, even though mature adults are actually the exception and not the norm. Look at the parenting style most parents use these days. They fail to set boundaries for their children and hope their children will somehow turn out to be well-behaved adults.

Then these same parents are surprised when their children end up being ill-mannered and acting out when they grow up. Of course, acting out does not necessarily mean doing something that might be considered "bad". It merely means doing things that are unconventional, or against the social norm, or unpopular, etc.

Not everyone can be mature however. Being mature requires a lot of mental and emotional stability and self-control. Not everyone is capable of that. So you end up with two types of adults. Those who were taught to be mature and those who aren't mature by nature.

Then you have a third type of adult. Those who act childish because they were raised in a childish environment. When you have children, there's a good chance those children will turn out to be childish adults as well. It's a cycle. It's not a cycle that's impossible to break however. But it does require someone to want to break it.

In this episode of "Delusional Discussions" we are discussing the idiomatic expression "looking Spanish".

Surely, someone has said this to you as a compliment. You might have several hypotheses as to why they said this to you: skin tone, hair texture, name, etc.

It makes zero sense. 

Spanish people are a diverse group of people with many different features, skin tones, and hair types. Naming a couple of well-known Spanish people like Penelope Cruz or Javier Bardem doesn't help, because you're still grouping a multitude of different looking individuals into a single "Spanish" look. 

Moreover, this expression could be considered as an example of othering. Othering is dividing people into an "us vs. them" mentality. Generally, the "them" in this scenario would be any minority group. Othering can create a hostile climate for the minority group, as well as reinforce the divide.

If you hear someone say "you look Spanish", maybe you can kindly inform them of the ridiculousness of that statement, and how it can be considered as othering.

Three years ago, I received a full scholarship from my provincial government to pursue an undergraduate degree in the field of my choice. These scholarships are competitively awarded based on a combination of academic performance, extracurricular involvement, and financial need. I was incredibly proud of myself for earning it and relieved to have my tuition fully covered for all four years of my degree.

I am currently in my third year of my degree, and several of my friends have received the same scholarship as me. Luckily, I've managed to avoid talking about it with any of them, but lately, I've been seeing posts on social media about them using the money to buy expensive clothing, electronics, and take exotic trips. Every time I see these posts, it makes me so angry and upset that my friends are abusing this opportunity they've been given. They are wasting the money that could have gone to someone who needs it and undermining the opportunities of other students. It also makes me feel like I'm not doing enough to help. 

I feel like I shouldn't be getting angry at my friends. I don't know if it's my place to say anything, and I don't want to come across as a snob or mean-spirited. I also don't want to seem like I'm trying to brag about my own achievements. 

Am I overreacting? Should I just mind my own business and let my friends enjoy their money? Or should I say something and risk ruining our friendship?

4/16 notation, in which the hour is overlaid on top of the minutes, is a terrible, stupid system for, like, literally the only reason it exists is because we don't want to admit that we use a 60-based system because we like round numbers. It's unnecessary. 60 is not a nice number to work with. 20 is nice. 10 is nice. 5 is nice. 3 is nice. 2 is nice. 1 is nice. 0 is nice. 59 is nice. But 60? 60 is, at best, the average of 35 and 25.
(As an aside, how cool would it be if we split the difference and made the hour 30 minutes? 30 is a nice number, and it makes conversion from minutes to hours and back again incredibly simple. If somebody feels compelled to say "but then the minutes would be 30 instead of 60", I give you permission to smack them in the face with a fish. Not a real fish, mind you--that would be rude and unsanitary. A metaphorical fish.)
So why do we have 60 as the base for time? It comes from the fact that we have 12 hours and 60 minutes per hour (and, if you insist, 60 seconds per minute). But wait! Why do we have 12 hours? Well, historically it was because there are 12 signs of the zodiac, and this was allegedly important for astrology, but by the time time the system was cemented we were past the point of worrying about whether somebody's personality was going to be influenced by whether they were born in an Aries hour or a Taurus hour.
So why do we persist in dividing the day up into 12 chunks? Well, because it's convenient. It's nice. It's evenly divisible by 2, 3, 4, and 6, which means that we can easily divide up our day into the various chunks that are important to us: mornings, afternoons, evenings, and nights. It makes sense from an average-person perspective. The important thing here is that we don't have some stupid, artificial reason like "the number 12 is sacred and holy because it's the number of apostles so we should use it even though it's stupid and makes less sense than the alternative."
We don't have that for 5-based time, or base-20 time, or base-10 time, or 3-based time (though base-3 would be kinda cool and we kinda already do it with metric prefixes like kilo- and centi-

I am cautious about everything in life, from walking down the street at night to investing in the stock market to drinking a glass of water because I think it might be poisoned.

As a result, I live life with a constant, low-grade fear. I am obsessive about checking the locks on my doors and am always scanning my environment for danger.

A few years ago, I came to the realization that I would never be able to alleviate my fears by being cautious. There's only so much I can do to prevent bad things from happening to me, and worrying about every possible thing that could go wrong wasn't making my life better. It was making me miserable.

I decided to make a conscious effort to let go of fear. When I thought about the things I was afraid might happen, I reminded myself that there was nothing I could do to prevent them and that I could not predict the future. When bad things do happen, I resolve to deal with them as they come and not waste time worrying about them in advance.

This didn't solve my problems overnight. Every day since then, I've had to make a conscious effort to not be afraid. Sometimes I fail and find myself consumed by fear again. But most of the time, I succeed. I still have bad days, but they're getting fewer and farther between.

I believe the author of Proverbs 29:25 was correct when he wrote, "Fear of man will prove to be a snare, but whoever trusts in the Lord is kept safe." Let go of your fears and trust in God.

I'm not a doctor but was just diagnosed with HI and the only symptoms I get are digestive issues including stomach pain anddiarrhea.  My doctor put me on a bland diet and that has helped a lot.  Basically just chicken broth-based soups, green bananas(the kind that make your mouth feel fuzzy), and toast for the first month.  Slowly reintroducing other foods. No dairy, spicy food or fatty foods. It's made a huge difference.  Also, for diarrhea, prescription medicine called loperamide(brand name: immodium) has been a lifesaver. Helps with stomach pain too. Hope that helps!

When a white person criticizes a black person's hairstyle, it can be extremely harmful and offensive due to the long history of white people policing black bodies and the widespread ignorance about black hair. 

Many white people believe that they have a right to comment on or criticize any aspect of a black person's appearance, including their hair. This is deeply problematic because it reinforces the idea that white people are the authority on all matters, including black hair. 

Black hair is often stigmatized and discriminated against in society. It is frequently portrayed as unprofessional and unmanageable in the media, leading to unfair judgments and expectations. When a white person adds to this stigma by criticizing a black person's hair, it can be extremely damaging and reinforcing. 

Furthermore, many white people are ignorant about black hair and the challenges it presents. They may not understand the importance of hair products, styling techniques, or the significance of hair in black culture. This lack of understanding can lead to thoughtless comments that hurt and offend black people. 

In conclusion, when a white person criticizes a black person's hairstyle, it not only reinforces the idea that white people are the authority on all matters but also demonstrates their ignorance about black hair and culture. It is crucial for white people to educate themselves and refrain from commenting on or criticizing black bodies.

I'm glad you've realized the cause of your self-esteem issues, but it's probably not because of anything you've done. It's most likely due to the way you were brought up, and how your parents treated you. 

When you were younger, did your parents make you feel unworthy or not good enough? Because if so, then that's the reason for your self-esteem issues. And once you understand the root cause, you can start to work on improving your self-esteem.

Just remember, you are worthy and good enough just as you are. You don't need anyone else to validate you.

Weddings have become these ridiculous over-the-top festivals of consumerism. I went to a friend's wedding a while ago and it was at this fancy vineyard with a view of the mountains. They had a band, a photobooth, a giant wedding cake, and little gift bags for everyone with a bottle of wine from the vineyard and a $50 gift card to the spa where the bride got her hair done. invitations were these ornate letter-pressed cards with gold foil. Honestly, although it was a beautiful venue and all of the little details were very thought out.. the whole day felt forced and contrived. The bride and groom spent like $50,000 on their wedding but they couldn't even pay for their own open bar? And honestly, the gift cards were so unnecessary especially because the invitations said "No gifts please!" Um, okay? And the band was playing the most random assortment of songs, everything from Taylor Swift to Journey to Luke Bryan. It was so weird. The whole event was just a showcase of how much money they spent on their wedding, but they couldn't even enjoy it because they were so busy making sure that everyone else was having a good time. It was so irritating. I mean, weddings are supposed to be about the bride and groom, not the guests! And honestly, I would have been just as happy with a nice, simple wedding at a park or something. I don't need to see how much money someone can spend on one day of their life.

I think a lot of us are confused and apprehensive about the current job market and our own readiness for a job. It seems like there are a lot of moving pieces and unknowns, and on top of that, there's the ever-looming threat of the automation of tomorrow. It's hard to know if you're ready for a job when you don't even know if the job market is going to be around in five years.

As an intern, I've been working alongside people in the industry for about a year now, and it's given me some insight into what the job market is like today, and what I need to do to be ready for it. For one, it's clear that the job market is changing rapidly, and that the jobs of the future are going to require a different set of skills than the jobs of the past. In particular, I think that soft skills are going to be increasingly important, as machines and AI continue to take over more and more tasks.

Another thing that I've learned is that it's never too early to start preparing for a job. Even if you're still in school, it's important to start building your skills and your network. That way, when the time comes to start looking for a job, you'll be ready.

So, if you're not sure if you're ready for a job, my advice is to start building your skills and your network, and to keep an open mind about the types of jobs that you're interested in. Who knows, maybe in a few years you'll be ready for a job that doesn't even exist yet.

The idea that hate speech and misinformation are somehow equivalent to 'spoilers' for political events is ridiculous and deeply unserious. Nobody deserves to have their identity or beliefs 'spoiled' for them because other people hold abhorrent views. If you have enough context in your life where someone saying "X won" or "Y said A, B, and C" destroys any joy you had in learning it for yourself, you're basically living in a bubble, and that's on you.

And before anyone even tries to argue that people 'deserve' to know the bad things their favorite politicians do, remember that we're talking about human beings with feelings here. Even if you don't agree with the sentiment, trying to force feed someone the truth because you feel they have a 'need to know' is an absolutely monstrous thing to do, and I hope you're proud of yourselves.

The amount of irony and lack of self-awareness it takes to go "OH MY GOD SPOILERS!" over literally facts and events is astounding. It's like pressing Control-Alt-Delete and restarting your computer because your Excel spreadsheet isn't calculating properly. Except this is reality, with actual humans, and actual consequences.

I'm not sure if this has been suggested before, but here's an idea for a convenience mod that connects the Mothership Zeta and Big MT teleportation functions.

In Mothership Zeta, the player can build a teleporter room that allows them to quickly travel between different parts of the ship. However, the teleporter room is only accessible from within the ship, which can make it difficult to get back to the ship if the player is exploring outside of it.

My idea is to create a mod that allows the player to build a teleporter terminal on the outside of the ship. This terminal would have a button that, when pressed, would activate the teleporter in the ship's teleporter room, instantly transporting the player back to the ship.

This would be a great convenience for players who want to quickly return to the ship without having to walk all the way back or use a vehicle. It would also be a fun way to encourage exploration of the ship and its many different areas.

Ok so I play fantasy football with a group of friends and as usual, I am doing terrible this year. I realize that I made a mistake in the draft and overlooked an important player that would definitely help my odds, and he was drafted pretty late. However, he was picked by a rival friend of mine, and every week he does amazing and is now one of the top performers in the league. We are at the point where he is almost certainly going to win, should I "borrow" his player?

I know it's technically against the rules, and for smaller leagues, it might seem like a bigger deal, but when you play in a league with 100+ people, the stakes are different. There is no real penalty for losing aside from personal pride, and the league commissioner (who is also a friend) has said that in the past when this has happened, it is allowed for the sake of the game. It would also be a huge swing in my overall standing and make the season more interesting.

I'd say 95% of the people in the league do this, and the 5% that don't usually don't do well anyway.

So my question is, is this cheating, and if it is, how can I justify it to myself?

Carrying increases your overall FPS and makes you more aware of the game. It helps you "get in the zone" as you are now playing the game on a higher skill level than your own. It also helps you to not "tunnel" or stare at one spot too intently.

As a bonus, you might just learn something from the carrier (or at least confirm some things you suspected).

Leather armor is generally considered the lightest type of armor, and due to its flexible nature, it would presumably be the easiest to sneak in. No where in the Bible does it say "homosexuality is condemned". There is only one reference to the subject, namely 1 Corinthians 6:9-10, which says: "Do you not know that wrongdoers will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived: Neither the sexually immoral nor idolaters nor adulterers nor men who have sex with men nor thieves nor the greedy nor drunkards nor slanderers nor swindlers will inherit the kingdom of God. That is what the sexually immoral do."

Here, the Bible does not say that homosexuality is condemned, but that "men who have sex with men" (meaning pederasts) are condemned. This is not at all the same thing. Also, the Bible does not say that all "men who have sex with men" are condemned - only that they are not to inherit the kingdom of God. Perhaps they are condemned to hell, but there are many other categories of people who are also condemned to hell, namely those in categories 1 to 8 of the previous verse.

Later in the same letter to the Corinthians, Paul says: "For just as the body is one and has many members, and all the members of the body, though many, are one body, so it is with Christ. For in the one Spirit we were all baptized into one bodyJews or Greeks, slaves or freeand we were all made to drink of one Spirit."

Here, Paul is saying that there is no longer distinction between any persons in Christ. Homosexuality is not even implied as being condemned. Rather, Paul's emphasis is on the inclusion of all persons in Christ, regardless of nationality, economic status, or sexual orientation.

The only person who ever loved me was my grandfather. He defended me from my father, who viewed me as an object for his anger and frustration. Whenever my father was drunk, which was most days, he would scream and throw things at me. He never hit my mother or my older brother, just me. I think that because I was small and female, my father viewed me as someone he could dominate. I tolerated the abuse until I was 13, when I finally told my grandfather about it. My grandfather told me that he would deal with my father, but that I should never let it happen again. The next time my father approached me, I fought back. I had always been a small and weak child, but that summer I grew four inches and suddenly had the height and strength to fight back. It felt good to stand up for myself, to push him back and slap him. But of course, that made him angrier. The next day, my father waited for me alone in the woods behind our house. He was drunk as usual. He told me that he loved me, that he was sorry for how he treated me. He did not hit me that day. Instead, he pulled out a knife and tried to kill me. I ran, screamed, and fought back as best I could, but he was a strong man, and I was only a 13-year-old girl. He managed to stab me in the belly and in both my arms. As I bled onto the ground, he tried to slit my throat. I managed to get away and crawl back to the house, where my brother found me. I lived, but I will never forget the feeling of my own blood spilling out of my body. That was ten years ago. My grandfather died a year later, and my father never apologized. I tried to press charges, but my mother protected him as always, and he walked free. I often think about killing him. I know that as a woman, I will never be as strong as a man, but I refuse to let that stop me.

I am devastated. I know 99% of ppl would think I'm stupid and say I'm better off, and I agree on paper... but my emotions don't seem to get the memo. I knew it was bad, heaps of red flags from the start, I told myself "it could be worse" and convinced myself it was only a fling so I shouldn't get too invested... but I got too invested. 

I cared about him a lot and I thought he cared about me the same way, figuring out it wasn't the case sucks. I knew it was bad for my mental health to be with him but I still tried to make it work... I knew deep down it would eventually end, and now that it has I feel lost. I feel like I failed at being in a relationship again, I'm a mess. Why am I like this? Why does getting out of a bad relationship hurt as much as, if not more than, getting out of a good one? 

Did I attach too fast? Is it because I knew it was bad for me and that's why my brain is trying to tell me it was good so I wouldn't have to face the fact that I wasted months of my life on a guy who didn't care about me in the same way? Why did I ignore all the red flags? 

I knew he had commitment issues, I knew he had a bad history with his ex, I knew he was immature and didn't care about his future... so why did I still try to make it work? I feel like such an idiot.

Kids are always being told to "listen", "be quiet", and "do as you're told". As they grow older, they are taught to "follow the rules", "respect their elders", and being compliant and obedient is seen as being "well-behaved". This teaches people to ignore their innate senses and instead replace them with the mandated rules imposed by society. Being assertive, thoughtful, and skeptic to the rules (unless they make sense) is cast out and deemed as "being difficult", "controlling", "unreasonable", or even "crazy". 

This translates into adults expecting kids to not speak up when they are uncomfortable or being told to do something they think to be wrong. Being a "good" kid means "getting along" and "playing well with others" regardless of whether or not the other "players" are being respectful. Being compliant with authority is prioritized over standing up for oneself and learning to think independently. This yields a society of people who prioritize following the rules over thinking independently and disagreeing when warranted. 

How does this relate to stubbornness? Well, stubbornness is deemed as a "bad" thing because it tends to go against the societal norms we've just discussed. Stubborn people will question an instruction when they feel it is wrong or not in their best interest. They will assert themselves even when it is uncomfortable or inconvenient for those in authority. They will prioritize their own thoughts and opinions over those of others, especially when they feel as though their own position hasn't been adequately considered. In other words, stubborn people have not been "properly trained" to ignore their own thoughts and feelings in favor of those in authority. Through this lens, it's easy to see why society tends to look down on those who stand up for themselves. Being stubborn signifies a fresh, independent way of thinking that has gone untrained and unchallenged. Through exposing and questioning rules instead of just accepting them, stubborn people can highlight societal "rules" that are unfair, unreasonable, or flat out wrong. 

Being stubborn may be "undeserved" in the sense that people who are assertive and question authority haven't been "bad" enough to warrant the hate they get. If anything, society should embrace those who can think independently and question authority when warranted. These people have likely experienced years of conditioning and social pressure to "be quiet and listen" even when they knew something was wrong. They have overcome this conditioning and asserted themselves in the face of pressure. If anything, society should applaud

I thought it was just the wheel balancing weights they put on so I took it back to the shop and asked them to take a look, they drove it around and said that it was because my front wheels were bent and that it wasn't done there, but rather through normal use and that I must have driven over a pothole at some point. My guess is that the pothole story is a made-up excuse, and that they simply screwed up and unbalanced the tires when they replaced it, and that they are trying to save face by lying about it. Should I pursue this or am I just being paranoid/dumb?

Afro, cornrows, bantu knots, flat iron, perm, lace front wig, extensions controversial topics, right? Well, not unless you're a white person. Growing up as a white woman, I never thought much about my hair. It's straight, fine, and pretty low maintenance. As a kid, I got annual trims to remove split ends and that was it. In terms of style, I basically wore it the same way all the time: down, maybe in a ponytail if I was playing sports. 

Then I got to college and a friend asked me if I'd ever straightened my hair. What? Why would I do that? This is dumb, but it had never occurred to me that people voluntarily subjected themselves to heat and chemicals for fun?! 

Flash forward a few years, to when I started dating my now-husband. Eddie is a proud African-American man, with an amazing family, and cornrows that he gets touched up every couple of weeks. When we started dating, I asked him why he got his hair braided rather than just leaving it how it was. He laughed and explained to me that he couldn't leave it how it was because that would mean wearing a durag (aka a wave cap) every day to maintain the waves. 

Wait, what?

If you aren't familiar, wave caps are essentially satin hoods that you wear to bed so that your hair maintains its wavy pattern. Sounds crazy, but when you've been doing it your whole life, it makes sense. And even though Eddie has never made me wear a wave cap, I have noticed a lot of other things about hair maintenance that I never thought about before.

For example, the fact that some products will leave a white residue on your hands if you touch your hair which alerts you to the fact that you have product in your hair which means you better grab a towel to wipe your hands off before you touch anything else because that shit is gonna get all over the place. The fact that you need at least two types of hair brushes, one with soft bristles for your natural hair and one with sturdier bristles for when you're wearing a wig. The fact that sometimes you just want to touch your hair because it's so damn cool. 

Don't get me wrong, I'm not complaining. It's truly fascinating to me how much nuance can exist in something that seems so simple. Having a front row seat to the evolution of black hair has

"Ending things properly after sex on the first two dates is important to establish respectful and honest communication.

Here are some suggestions:

1. Thank your partner for a great time and let them know that you had a wonderful experience but you don't want to give them the wrong idea about your intentions. Explain that you'd like to get to know them better as a friend, or that you're not ready for a relationship right now.

2. If you'd like to be more direct, express that you don't want to lead them on or hurt their feelings, and that you think it's best to go your separate ways.

3. It's important to be clear about your intentions and to treat your partner with respect. Avoid using vague language or giving mixed messages, as this can only lead to confusion and hurt feelings.

4. After ending things, give your partner some space and respect their decision. Avoid contacting them or trying to stay in touch, as this can be confusing and disrespectful.

5. If you feel the need to explain yourself further, do so honestly and respectfully. Avoid making excuses or placing blame on your partner, as this will only make the situation worse.

6. After ending things, take some time to reflect on the experience and learn from it. Use it as an opportunity to grow and improve your communication skills.

Remember, it's important to be clear, honest, and respectful in these situations. By ending things properly, you can avoid hurt feelings and maintain a positive relationship with your partner."
