The idea of exiting the United States, an idea proposed by some of those who are anti-Trump, is not something I agree with. 

I love this country, with its diversity and its ideals. Of course, America is not a perfect country. Who knows, maybe the land of the free and home of the brave didn't become great until after it committed grave injustices against the native peoples who called this land home for thousands of years before Europeans showed up? There is no country on this planet that does not have a checkered past. That is part of our shared history. 

The anti-Trump movement seems to be fueled by the legitimate concerns that many Americans have regarding Trump's temperament and mental stability. Those are valid concerns, but America already has a system in place that will protect us against a President who is unfit for office. That system is the 25th Amendment. The 25th Amendment already has a process in place that will remove a President from office in the event that he or she is no longer capable of fulfilling the duties of the office. 

If there are concerns about Trump's ability to lead this country, the 25th Amendment provides a legitimate, democratic, and legal way to deal with that. Another popular proposal from the anti-Trump movement is to encourage Americans to move to Canada if Trump is elected. This idea shows a fundamental misunderstanding of American democracy. Voting for Trump is not equivalent to America losing its collective mind and becoming a horrible place to live. If someone does not like Trump, their concerns can and should be expressed at the ballot box. American democracy is built on the idea that we elect leaders to represent our interests. If we don't like those leaders, we elect new ones. 

That is the beauty of American democracy. If someone is not happy with the state of affairs in America, they can work to change those things through the political process. American democracy is not an all-or-nothing proposition.

There is a distinct difference between the manner in which those in Eastern and Western cultures deal with illness, both in terms of societal norms and personal perspectives.

Upon falling ill, the first thought that comes to mind for most Eastern people is of the healing properties of food. Consequently, the primary objective in this situation becomes to seek out the best possible food to heal the body. On the other hand, those living in Western societies might consider taking medication or seeing a doctor as their initial course of action. In this way, the focus is more on addressing the symptoms rather than healing the body as a whole.

For Eastern cultures, the decision on where to eat is strongly correlated with healing. As such, it is common to hear statements such as "This restaurant's food cured my illness" or "The spices in that dish cleared up my cough." The culinary choices available are perceived as having both the power to heal and to cause harm. On the other hand, for Western cultures, food is more of a pleasurable pastime than a means of healing. As a result, statements about the curative properties of food are less likely to be heard.

While it's clear that the approach to illness varies between Eastern and Western cultures, it's also evident that both sides believe that food has the power to heal. This is perhaps the most important insight to be gained from this understanding, as it can help us appreciate the role that food plays in maintaining good health, regardless of cultural background.

Meet my wife. She's a physician and together we have 4 kids, 3 schools, 2 dogs, and 1 income. Here's how we make it work.

My wife went part-time once our first was born. It was really important to both of us that she be present for the kids, and carving out time during the work week wasn't doing it. She was exhausted and depleted, and not the mom or wife she wanted to be. Luckily, we were able to structure her job so that she could go part-time, and still provide a good income for our family. 

I ended up taking on more responsibility with our finances. I pay all the bills and manage our budget. It's not perfect, but we've found a system that works well for us and we're always making adjustments to try and make it better. 

The biggest thing we do is prioritize our spending. We don't buy fancy cars or expensive jewelry. We try and spend our money on experiences and making memories. This year we're taking the kids on a Disney cruise for Christmas. It's been our dream to take them on a Disney cruise, and we're excited that we're able to make it happen. 

We're not perfect and we've had to make sacrifices. But overall, I think we've figured out a good balance that works for us.

Two years ago, both of my grandparents were diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Nobody expected this as they were healthy throughout my entire life. They lived an hour away which wasn't a problem as I visited them several times a month. Now things have changed and they don't remember who I am. They don't remember much of anything. It breaks my heart to see them like this and the fact that they don't remember who I am destroys me emotionally.

I understand that it's the disease and it's not their fault. My parents understand this as well. However, my mother seems to have taken on the belief that because my grandparents don't remember who I am, I cannot see them. It makes zero sense to me. I can still talk to them, hold their hands, love them, and show them I love them. I can still sit with them even if they don't remember who I am.

I would understand if it was dangerous for me, but it's not. My grandparents are not violent, they're just confused and unhappy a lot of the time. When I'm there, I can cheer them up. Or at least I could if my mother would let me. She doesn't seem to understand how important they are to me and she's refusing to let me see them. She says she's doing what's best for me but frankly I don't believe her. I don't understand why she's being like this.

I saw you today, on the subway. I almost didn't recognize you because of how different you looked. Your hair, which I remembered as short and neat, was long and untamed, cascading down your shoulders. And you were wearing glasses, which somehow made you look even more intelligent than I remembered. 

I almost didn't approach you because I knew you were sitting with someone, probably your partner, and I didn't want to interrupt. But when I got off at my stop, I couldn't just let you go without saying something. So I turned around and called out your name. 

Your eyes lit up in surprise as you recognized me, and you smiled, a smile that I had forgotten was so warm and inviting. We talked for a few minutes, catching up on each other's lives. I told you about my job, and you told me about your studies, and we both agreed that it was a shame we didn't live in the same city anymore. 

Eventually, it was time for me to go. We said our goodbyes, and I watched you disappear into the crowd, wondering if I'd ever see you again. But I knew that even if we never met again, I would always cherish the brief encounter we had on the subway that day.

I would love to live in a log cabin in the woods with Matt Barzal. One of my closest friends is gay, and he tells me that whenever people ask him if he has a husband, he says "no, but I live with the most beautiful man on earth." And apparently, nobody has ever objected to this statement or asked any further questions, because, duh. So I think if I lived with Matt Barzal, and people asked if I were gay, I could just say "no, but I live with the most beautiful man on earth" and everybody would just leave it at that. We could have a delightful life of tranquility in the woods, away from the prying eyes of the media and away from the millions of screaming fans who are always swarming around him. 

Of course, I'd have to take some time to learn how to live off the land. And perhaps we would have to hire a chef who could come to our cabin sometimes to prepare gourmet meals, since neither of us are much of a cook. Of course, the only way this could ever work is if I could convince Matt Barzal to leave Brooklyn and leave all of his friends and family behind. And apparently, he hasn't been able to find anyone in Brooklyn who can make bagels as good as the ones back on Long Island, so he's already basically living out in the woods in exile anyways. 

So yes, hopefully Barzy and I can live our best gay-adjacent life in a log cabin in the woods.

Her zaman hayatmdan fazla kymsanz ve srekli bir ey deimeden nce bir deyie girdiklerini dnyorsanz bile, aklmdan itibaren ey olur. Ben iman etmedim, zledim, gzledim, kymetli olup olmadn sanyordum, nk kendisi de ok gzel. Aada ekilmi olduum iin ok nemli, ve bunu syleyerek aklmdan itibaren ey deitirdim. 

Elbette bu kymlklarn, kendisine de ait olduum kymlnn (elbette kendisine de ait olduumda bulunan hereyi de aada kyasla) kyasla gerekten ok nemli ve ok kymetli. Kendisine de ait olduum kymlnn, kendisine de ait olduum zlediimde bulunduklarnn, kendisine de ait olduum gzlediimde bulunduklarnn, kendisine de ait olduum kymetlie baladmzdan nce kendisine de ait olduum bir ey olup olmadn sanyordum.

I absolutely adore my OnePlus 7 Pro, but being stuck on oxygenOS 13 with no hope of an OS update and only monthly security updates once a month mainline releases (which are usually late) is just sad. I love the design, the 120Hz fluid display, the connectivity options (US version has every major band), the RAM management is great, and the overall software experience is amazing. No app preloading, no aggressive or unnecessary battery management features, etc.

The cameras are just good enough for me, not too bothered by the lack of a 2x or 3x telephoto lens replacement for my DSLR. However, it's clear that Google's camera algorithms and processing is far ahead of the competition, so if there was a way to get those on a non-Google device, that'd be amazing.

In terms of size, 410g and 8.8mm thickness is just about perfect. It's a big screen, but the device itself does not feel unwieldy, and the included case is beautifully done.

Must-haves:
- Fast, responsive, clean software with no bloatware
- Regular, reliable security updates
- Preferably, regular OS updates as well, or at least timely updates to the OS
- Camera performance that at least matches my OP7Pro, preferably better
- Battery life that matches or exceeds my OP7Pro
- Display with at least 90Hz refresh rate
- Great build quality, preferably metal and glass
- IP rating for water and dust would be amazing, but not necessary
- Minimum of 6GB RAM, preferably 8GB
- 5G preferred, but not required
- MicroSD card slot

Nice-to-haves:
- Wireless charging
- Reverse wireless charging

Young girls are mostly taught that they have to sacrifice a lot for their families and this is seen as completely normal.

For example, girls are given less healthy food than boys and are made to eat whatever remains after the boys and men in the family have eaten. They are also given the worst jobs in the household like washing dishes, doing the laundry, and cleaning the toilets. This is seen as preparation for marriage, where women are expected to do all the housework while the men relax or work outside.

Another example is that girls are often not allowed to participate in extracurricular activities like sports or clubs because they are needed at home to help with siblings or do household work. This limits their opportunities for fun and socializing with peers, which can lead to feelings of isolation and loneliness.

Furthermore, young girls are often expected to help with household income by working part-time jobs or helping in the family business while still attending school full-time. This can cause them to have less time for studies and extracurricular activities, which can affect their academic performance and future career prospects.

The movie adaptation of Hamilton just doesn't do it for me. Don't get me wrong, I love the musical itself, but the way it was adapted for the screen just doesn't do it justice.

To me, the music is the star of Hamilton. The lyrics are clever and witty, and the tunes are catchy and memorable. I could listen to the soundtrack on repeat for hours on end.

But when it comes to the movie, something just feels off. The choreography is often awkward and the camera work is shaky. It's hard to get into the story when you can't even see what's going on half the time.

Don't get me wrong, there are some parts of the movie that I think were done well. I like the way the actors played their roles and I think the set design was pretty cool.

But overall, I think the movie could have been better. It had the potential to be a great adaptation of an amazing musical, but it just didn't live up to my expectations.

Sure! Here is a draft of a Reddit post addressing the question "Are there any repercussions for Un adopting a child?":

We adopted our daughter when she was just 4 months old. My husband and I have always known that we wanted to have kids, but we were unable to do so naturally. After 2 years of trying and multiple fertility doctors telling us we most likely would not be able to have our own kids, my husband and I turned to adoption. It was a long, difficult, and emotionally exhausting process, but after 4 long years, we finally got the call that a baby girl was waiting for us. We were overjoyed. A year later, our daughter is now a happy, funny, and smart 2-year-old. She has brought so much love and light into our lives and we are forever grateful for her.

However, lately, I've been feeling like maybe we made a mistake. Don't get me wrong, I love my daughter more than anything and I'm so grateful for her, but taking care of a toddler is extremely hard. My husband and I are exhausted and overwhelmed most of the time. We went from a life of freedom and spontaneity to a life of strict schedules, endless tantrums, and sleep deprivation. Don't get me wrong, we are not regretful, but recently I've been wondering if we made a mistake.

I've been seeing a therapist and she suggested that maybe I'm just experiencing postpartum depression. After doing some research, I think she may be right. I'm still struggling though, because on top of PPD, I can't help but feel ungrateful and guilty for even thinking these things. I love my daughter, but is it wrong of me to wish that we could send her back? Is something wrong with me for feeling this way? Am I a bad mom for thinking this? Is unadoption a real thing? Are there any repercussions for un adopting a child? 

I am terrified to tell my husband and parents how I've been feeling. I love my daughter, but I can't shake these feelings of regret and ungratefulness. I don't know what to do or where to go from here.

Honestly, I don't know how I ended up with such a wonderful therapist. When I first started going to therapy, I was incredibly nervous and scared. I had no idea what to expect, and I was terrified of opening up to a complete stranger. But from the moment I sat down in her office, she made me feel at ease. She has a way of making you feel like you're talking to a friend rather than a therapist. She listens without judgment, offers insightful feedback, and provides helpful tools and resources. I always feel like I can be honest and open with her, and that she truly cares about my well-being. So thank you, therapist. You've helped me more than you'll ever know, and I'm so grateful to have you in my life.

The idea that "bigger is better" is a pervasive one, found across many aspects of life. In general, people seem to associate size with quality and importance, whether it's the size of a city, the engine size of a car, or the size of a person's bank account. However, this way of thinking can be problematic when it comes to making meaningful and accurate comparisons.

For example, comparing the size of cities based on their population can be misleading. While a larger city may have a higher population, it doesn't necessarily mean it's a better place to live. A smaller city may have a more tight-knit community, a lower cost of living, and better access to nature. Likewise, when it comes to purchasing a car, it's easy to assume that a car with a bigger engine is more powerful and faster than one with a smaller engine. However, this isn't always the case. A smaller engine can be more fuel-efficient, require less maintenance, and be just as fast as a larger one.

The same principle applies to financial wealth. A person with a larger bank account may seem more successful and financially secure, but this doesn't take into account their debt, spending habits, or overall financial health. A person with a smaller bank account may be more financially responsible, have a lower debt-to-income ratio, and be on track to achieve their financial goals.

In conclusion, bigger doesn't always mean better. It's important to consider the context and other factors that may influence the quality, value, and effectiveness of something. It's time to shift our mindset and stop making assumptions based on size alone.

Many people frequently question why, despite the existence of speed limits, automobiles are rarely driven at the legally permitted maximum speed.

The fundamental reason is that speed limits are established taking into account a variety of variables and assumptions that are not always true or practical in real-world situations.

First and foremost, speed limits are set with the assumption that the road is completely straight, which is rarely the case in reality. Curves, changes in gradient, and other obstacles all have a big impact on how fast a car can safely go.

Secondly, speed limits take into account the worst-case scenario in terms of road and vehicle conditions. They assume that the road is slick with rain or snow, that there may be unexpected obstacles in the road, and that the car's brakes may not work as well as they should.

Finally, speed limits are often established by local governments with an eye toward improving traffic flow and reducing congestion. They may not always reflect the fastest or most efficient speed at which a car can travel.

In conclusion, while speed limits are an important tool for keeping roads safe, they are not always the most practical or efficient choice for regulating automobile speed in real-world situations.

Family can play a critical role in the recovery of an eating disorder. While loved ones often want to help, they may not know how to, and the individual with the eating disorder may not know how to ask for help. This can cause tension and frustration between the family members. Experts recommend educating themselves about the eating disorder and seeking support from a professional counselor or therapist. Even with professional help, however, families may still have a long road ahead. One 28-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa detailed her experience with her parent's obesity as a trigger for her eating disorder.

Even though her parents loved and supported her, they were unaware of how their behavior, specifically their weight gain, was affecting her. Family gatherings, holiday parties, and other events created high-pressure situations in which the woman felt unable to separate her parent's weight from her own. She believed that their weight gain was a direct result of her eating disorder, and she felt immense guilt. Despite having a supportive network of friends and professionals, the woman found that her parent's weight continued to be a source of anxiety and depression.

Individuals with eating disorders and their families may benefit from support groups and counseling to learn how to communicate and address these disorders.

It turns out that preheating the oven isn't always necessary, and occasionally can even be detrimental to your cooking. 

Food takes longer to cook when you start with a cold oven, but the outcome can be the same provided you adjust the overall cooking time. If your recipe calls for 20-25 minutes of cook time, you can put the food in a cold oven and turn it to the designated temperature. Then, just calculate how long it will take your oven to heat up typically (this varies based on the oven, but is usually between 10-20 minutes for most home ovens), add that time to the expected cook time, and that's how long you should let your food cook. 

Every oven is different, and therefore requires different lengths of preheating. If your oven is gas-powered instead of electric, it will generally reach desired temperatures faster. Similarly, convection ovens with fans that circulate the air are also quicker to preheat and cook food. If you have a pizza stone or other heavy cooking vessel, it will take longer for your oven to heat up, as the stone will hold some of the heat. 

There are some things you should always preheat the oven for including:

- Breads
- Cakes
- Cookies
- Homemade desserts

This is mainly because these foods require very specific temperatures in order to rise and cook properly. 

There are myriad reasons to avoid preheating, not least of which is the energy savings. Not preheating the oven for recipes that give you the option can reduce your cook time, and subsequently your energy consumption. Personal experience and comfort also play a role here, as some experienced chefs swear by not preheating, while others are more comfortable with the security of a hot oven.

It's good that you want to battle your low self-esteem. Many people go through their entire lives without learning to love themselves and it makes their lives so much harder than they have to be.

You don't want to jump to feeling superior, because all that will do is give you a different kind of unhealthy attitude that will hurt you in a different way.

Here are some ways to improve your self-esteem without feeling superior:

- Take care of yourself physically. Exercise, eat well, and get enough sleep. Taking care of your body will help you feel better about yourself.
- Celebrate your successes. No matter how small they may seem, take time to celebrate your successes every day. This will help you feel more confident and capable.
- Write down your positive qualities. Make a list of your positive qualities. This will help you recognize your strengths and remind you that you have a lot to offer.
- Set realistic goals. Setting unrealistic goals can lead to feelings of failure and low self-esteem. Set goals that are challenging, but also realistic and achievable. This will help you feel more successful and capable.
- Help others. Doing things for others can help you feel good about yourself and improve your self-esteem. Find ways to help others in your community or in your personal life.
- Practice self-compassion. Be kind to yourself and understand that everyone makes mistakes. Don't be too hard on yourself when you make a mistake or have a setback. Instead, practice self-compassion and remember that you are doing your best.
- Seek professional help. If you are struggling to improve your self-esteem on your own, consider seeking the help of a professional therapist or counselor. They can provide you with additional tools and support to help you improve your self-esteem.

Game: Baba Yaga

Update 1.1 adds a new system where, when certain conditions are met, an objective to "Find Baba Yaga's House" appears. This leads the player to a small island with a mysterious little house surrounded by trees and a few rocks. There is an objective marker on the ground that looks like a magnifying glass. Interacting with this prompts the player to use their camera to look around. Doing so reveals a faint picture of a doll with an objective marker over it. This leads to a small patch of dirt surrounded by stones with the doll buried underneath. The doll cannot be interacted with, and there is no further objective.

I thought this was a really neat touch. It fits the theme of the game very well and gives the player just a little bit more of a reason to explore this new area. However, it isn't at all clear what the reward for completing this objective is. I don't believe there is any lore relating to the doll or the house, but it would be neat if there was a unique artifact that could be found here. Even if there isn't, it would be nice to get some kind of in-game reward, even if it's just some exp. Maybe a unique filter for the camera? Regardless, I'd love to hear the devs thoughts on this little touch. Did they consider adding more to it? What about expanding this system to other parts of the game?

It is important to note that while it is certainly possible for a person to develop self-preservation and logical reasoning skills later in life, it may be more challenging for someone who has not previously exhibited these traits. In order to develop these skills, it is important to first understand the underlying motivations and thought processes that lead to the lack of these skills. For example, if a person has a tendency to take unnecessary risks or make poor decisions, it may be helpful to explore the underlying causes of this behavior, such as a lack of self-awareness or an impulsive personality.

Once the underlying causes of the behavior have been identified, it may be possible to develop strategies to address them. For example, a person with low self-awareness may benefit from activities or therapies that encourage self-reflection and understanding of one's own thoughts and actions. A person with an impulsive personality may benefit from learning techniques for slowing down and considering the potential consequences of their actions before making a decision.

In addition to these strategies, it may also be helpful for a person to seek out support from friends, family, or a mental health professional. Having a supportive network of people can help provide accountability and encouragement as a person works to develop their self-preservation and logical reasoning skills. Remember, it is never too late to make positive changes in one's life, but it may take time and effort to see results.

Today is day 6 of my 30 day challenge to get healthy and today I want to come clean about how hard this journey is. Not just because of the physical aspects of it, although those are very real, but more so because of how it is affecting my mental health. 

I have always had a rocky relationship with food and my body. I have struggled with an eating disorder in the past and have worked hard to overcome that. However, this challenge is bringing up a lot of those unhealthy thought patterns and it's been really tough. 

I am constantly battling thoughts of self-loathing and shame when I look in the mirror or when I see myself in pictures. Even though I know that these thoughts are not rational, they still haunt me. I feel like I am not good enough, that I will never be good enough, and that I should just give up. 

I know that these thoughts are not healthy and that they are not true. I know that I am worthy of love and respect, just as I am. But still, these thoughts haunt me. It's hard for me to look at myself in the mirror some days, Hard for me to accept that my body, with all its curves and rolls, is something to be proud of.

I am trying to push through these thoughts and continue on with the challenge. I know that it is important for me to do this for myself, to prove to myself that I can do it. But some days, it's just really hard. 

Sorry for the rant. I guess I just needed to get it off my chest. Anybody else struggling with this?

No deity has ever required or demanded worship. Religion is a belief system of when where and how to worship a deity, or deities.
If you feel the need to worship something, then you are interpreting signals from your own brain, and projecting them outside of yourself. 
There is no independent verification that any deity exists, and no corroboration of any communications from a deity to any believer.
Religion serves many practical purposes, and fills many psychological needs. 
The need to worship can be fulfilled by adopting a suitable religion, or by understanding these needs and finding other ways to fulfill them.
Worshiping an imaginary friend will not fulfill those needs.
Hopefully this will help explain why no deity worthy of the name, or deserving of your allegiance and worship, would ever require or demand it.

The Senator's Son is a trilogy of books following the adventures of Roan West, the son of a Texas senator, who is forced to go on the run after witnessing a gruesome murder. He is aided in his escape by his friend Sam, and the two of them embark on a journey to uncover the truth about the murder and clear Roan's name.

The first book, The Senator's Son, follows Roan and Sam as they travel across Texas trying to stay one step ahead of the people who are trying to kill them. They encounter a variety of characters along the way, including a group of survivalists who take them in and teach them important skills for their journey.

The second book, The Whispers of the Trees, focuses on Roan's struggle to come to terms with his past and the secrets that he is keeping from Sam. He is forced to face his inner demons as he battles with the guilt of his actions and the fear of being caught.

The third book, A Gathering of Shadows, follows Roan and Sam as they return to Texas to confront the people who are trying to kill them. They must rely on their skills and allies to take down the powerful forces arrayed against them and clear Roan's name once and for all.

As Easter approaches, many stores are starting to put out their Easter items for sale. This includes everything from chocolate eggs to stuffed rabbits. But why do we even have Easter items?

The answer lies in the Bible. In the New Testament, Jesus is said to have been resurrected from the dead on the third day after his crucifixion. His resurrection is believed to symbolize new life and hope. So, it makes sense that Easter, which marks the resurrection of Jesus, would be associated with items that represent new life and hope.

Items like chocolate eggs and stuffed rabbits represent new life because they are often associated with spring, which is a time of renewal and rebirth. They also represent hope because they remind us that winter is over and that warmer days are ahead.

So, if you see Easter items for sale at your local store, you can now understand the significance behind them. They aren't just there to make us feel guilty for eating too much chocolate, but to represent a meaningful holiday.

Live streaming is a technology that allows you to broadcast real-time video and audio content over the internet to viewers all over the world. This is achieved by encoding the video and audio data into a digital format, which is then transmitted over the internet to a live streaming platform or service. The live streaming platform then decodes the data and broadcasts it to the viewers, who can watch and listen to the content in real-time.

To begin live streaming, you will need to set up an account with a live streaming platform or service, such as Twitch, YouTube Live, or Facebook Live. Once you have an account, you will need to download and install live streaming software on your computer or device. This software will allow you to capture and encode the video and audio data, which can then be transmitted over the internet to the live streaming platform.

Once you are live streaming, you can interact with your viewers in real-time through a chat feature or by answering questions. You can also incorporate other elements into your live stream, such as screen sharing, live polls, and interactive games.

To conclude your live stream, you will need to end the broadcast by closing the live streaming software on your computer or device. The video and audio data will then be encoded and stored on the live streaming platform, where it can be accessed by your viewers for future viewing.

Best,

Two significant trends are (1) increasing use of AI and other technologies to automate key tasks and (2) the widespread expectation that workers should have the opportunity and flexibility to work from home (or from wherever they desire). These trends are creating substantial value and they are also creating significant issues. First, the trends are creating value because the new technologies  including AI, robots, etc.  are augmenting the human workforce: in many cases, the new technologies are enabling workers to be more productive and to achieve higher quality outputs. Moreover, allowing workers to work from home  again, in many cases  is increasing worker satisfaction and retention. The trends are also creating significant issues, however. As tasks are automated, the number of available jobs is declining or, at the very least, the number of jobs that require a human worker is declining. This is leading to displacement of workers. While some of the displaced workers will be able to find other jobs, others will not.

I know identifying as Jewish would imply certain things (like ethnic background, culture, and ancestry), but I feel equally connected to the culture as I do most of my actual ancestry (last name aside).

I'm an atheist, and I feel almost spiritual when I read about Jewish culture, history, and philosophy. I know there are a lot of different Jewish denominations, but there's still a lot of exclusivity in the faith itself  you can't just convert to Judaism and consider yourself Jewish, is my understanding.

I know I can't just decide that I am Jewish, but is there any situation where it would be appropriate for me to identify as such? Is asking this question offensive in itself? 

I hesitate to even ask this, because I've dated Jewish women in the past and considered marriage, but never wanted to impose on their culture/faith and possibly hurt them or their families by misleading them as to who I actually am. 

I know this is a confusing, multi-faceted question, but any guidance would be appreciated.

Take for example, Harvey Weinstein. He was accused of hundreds of accounts of sexual assault, but he still fought against it. He knew that he could afford to fight it, and that eventually enough people would give up, and he'd be left unscathed. And when the punishment does come, it's a mere slap on the wrist. 

Now, I'm not saying that everyone should go out and try to murder each other, but the point remains that the system is built to protect the rich. The idea that the rich can 'buy' their way out of situations is commonplace because it's true. We live in a capitalist society that is by design, slanted in favor of the wealthy.
If you are a member of the upper echelon of society, the wealthy, then you have nothing to worry about.
This is just one of many examples of how the system is slanted in favor of the wealthy, but it is the most egregious because it pertains to the law, and our society's conception of justice.

Learning to "put it all together" requires taking a systems thinking approach, which means understanding how different actions and events impact one another, and how they come together to create a function, a process, or in this case, a workable, sustainable, and thriving homestead, or farm.

There's the old saying, "give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish, and you feed him for a lifetime." Well, assuming the man in question has access to a viable body of water with an adequate population of fish, it would make more sense to first dig a well, or build a springhouse, so that he has access to clean water. With his newfound water security, he could then build irrigation systems, and a fish pond or reservoir from which an adequate fish population could be established. Teaching him to fish would come last.

As another example, we have kept chickens for years as a part of our integrated rotational pasture system, which includes rabbits, fruit trees, bees, and vegetables, and a small goat herd, all on just under an acre. The chickens till the soil, eat bugs and weed seeds, provide us with eggs, and turn our kitchen scraps into rich compost. Last spring, we bought two mature laying hens from a local hatchery as a complement to our young layers. We had a warm spring and our fruit trees and berry vines exploded with growth. We had so much growth, that we didn't have the time to keep it all trimmed back and tended. When our raspberries began to produce, we had so many canes that we couldn't keep up with picking them. So we "got smart". We trimmed the canes back hard, and tied them up in rows with some twine, so that we could actually get into the patch and pick the berries. We figured all of this out by observing the chickens. The hens in our rotational pasture system tend to spread out and "till" the soil when they're in a new spot, but they tend to flock together and tear up the ground in the spot where they've been cooped up for a few days. When we saw what they did to the raspberry canes, we realized that we needed to trim the canes back severely, and tie them up, making it easier for us to get to the berries. 

You can see here how an event (our raspberry canes growing like gangbusters), impacted a process (our raspberry picking), which impacted the function (our homestead

Having raised our kids fairly responsibly between both my spouse and me, I find myself incredibly frustrated with my adult children. 

I think the challenge, as I see it, is that there's this fairly large gap between what kids need in terms of supervision, monitoring and guidance, and what is actually possible for most parents to deliver, especially if both parents are working. Kids these days seem to be much less independent than kids were when I was young. The freedom of being a kid these days seems to be vastly different. Kids these days do so much less. Constant access to entertainment, including video games and social media, and the colleges, the schools, and the parents enabling this, has led to a generation of kids that seem to have fewer life skills and a diminished capacity for independence.

I sometimes wonder if the parents of my generation were just better at hiding their mistakes from us, or if the world really has become a more challenging and complicated place to navigate as an adult.

I raise these points because I want to hear your thoughts. What say you?

Variables in linear regression are rescaled or normalized to have 0 mean and unit variance or any other dispersion metric. This is analogous to how neural networks "learn" in the realm of deep learning.

Without normalization, gradients in the neural network tend to 0 as any given variable converges to its average, making improvement slow down or stop.

In the case of linear regression/machine learning, leaving the variables untransformed makes the estimator biased and poorly scaled. The bias comes from the dispersion of the variables. A variable with a wider range "pulls" the estimator more than a variable with a narrower range. This causes the estimated coefficients to be biased.

Taking the square root of the variance does not solve this problem because the variables can still have a range greater than 1, causing the same problems. Taking the square (or any other even power) of the residuals remedies this because it guarantees that the variance of every variable is always less than or equal to 1. This allows the estimator to be properly scaled and unbiased.

This is not to say that taking the square is the only viable option. Other transformations are used as long as they satisfy the condition that the variance is always 1. Some models use the absolute value of the residuals instead. In any case, it is important that this transformation is applied to all variables to maintain a common scale.

Okay, so you failed to get your benefits and have been deemed ineligible after applying for unemployment? You have a right to appeal this decision, and you can do so successfully if you know what to emphasize.

First: Why do you think you were found ineligible? Did they decide you quit your job without good cause? Did they say you were fired for misconduct? Understand why they made you ineligible, because this will help you determine how to argue against it.

Second: Follow the instructions on how to properly file your appeal. This will often include a deadline, a written submission, and potentially a hearing.

Third: Gather your evidence. If you were fired, collect any documentation that shows that it was not due to misconduct. If you were let go, provide any proof of your ongoing good performance. If you quit, make sure the appeal board understands the circumstances that led to your decision to leave.

Fourth: Attend the hearing. Dress neatly, be polite, and make your case clearly and concisely.

Bluetooth audio lag can be really annoying, but there are a few things you can do to reduce it.

First, make sure that your headphones are fully charged and that they're paired correctly with your device. Sometimes, a simple solution like this can reduce the lag.

Second, check if there are any updates available for your headphones or device. Updates can often fix issues like this and improve the performance of your devices.

Finally, if the lag is still present, try resetting your headphones and re-pairing them with your device. This will often fix any lingering issues and get your headphones working smoothly again.

I don't fully understand differential equations so maybe someone can help out. I know the basic definition of a differential equation is a equation that contains a derivative. But why is this important? Why do we care about solving these?

If we have a function v(t) that represents the velocity of a moving car at time t, then at each point in time we have an associated velocity. If we know the function f(t) that represents the speed of the car at which point we can find the derivative of this function with respect to time, and hence we obtain a function v(t) that can be thought of as the instantaneous acceleration at any given time.

One way to see the usefulness of this is by example. Suppose you're on a train platform and a train is scheduled to arrive at 10:45. You only know the schedule, which lists the arrival time of the train as 10:45. This single number gives you no information about how fast the train will be moving at 10:43 or 10:46, and hence whether it will arrive early or late. This is where a differential equation comes in: if you know the function v(t) for the velocity of the train at any point in time then you can find the derivative at any given time, and hence obtain an estimate for how early or late the train will arrive.

Today my friend and I went on a hike outside of town, and man did we pick the wrong time of year to do so! I'm 14 and my dad just had a vasectomy two months ago. My mom kept pushing him to get fixed 'for the kids', and now they're surprised that my brother and I are upset that we'll never have any brothers or sisters. Like, they knew what they were doing when they had us fixed. I know it's not the same, but it feels pretty damn close. They kept pushing for another baby and now they're mad that we're pushing back. I feel like they just want us to be trophies since we're both pretty good students, athletes, and musicians. Am I wrong for not wanting a sibling?

Edit: Thanks for all the responses! Most of you seem to agree thats its kinda selfish to get fixed then expect their kids to be ok with them having regrets. My mom blew up at me saying she 'never expected us to be happy about it' which.. sure? She blames my dad for 'lying' to her about his post-vasectomy symptoms but it sounds like she wanted a baby more than she wanted a functional husband. 
She says she'll get a hysterectomy but can't until the pandemic dies down, and until then we're just supposed to be ok with the idea of them having another kid. Like, they're acting like their reproductive choices are more important than our relationship with them. 
They say they'll still love us and treat us the same but.. they already treat us like we're their pets, trying to get us into the best schools and forcing us to practice our instruments 4 hours a day. I doubt having a new baby would change that but.. I don't want to have to find out. I don't want to be an only child but I also don't want a sibling, so I think I'm just gonna have to be content with my dog

One thing I've been doing that's been working well is pairing him with Quinn in the top lane. Udyr gets beat up a lot in lane since he's so melee, but Quinn can harass from afar while staying safe. Also Quinn's dash helps Udyr last hit under tower, and Udyr's sustain helps Quinn not die while dashing forward. Attila the Hun, arguably the most renowned leader of the Hunnic Empire, has long been portrayed as a fierce, ruthless warrior in mainstream history. While his military achievements and conquests are well-documented, another side of Attila emerges when examining his political and economic policies: a pragmatic leader committed to maintaining stability and prosperity within his empire, albeit through relatively conservative means.

When we examine Attila's policies on trade and diplomacy, we can see evidence of his conservative approach. For instance, Attila valued maintaining positive relationships with the Eastern Roman Empire and sought to negotiate mutually beneficial terms in their diplomatic dealings. While his contemporaries often resorted to military force to achieve their goals, Attila chose to pursue more stable and sustainable arrangements through negotiation and compromise.

In terms of economics, Attila implemented policies that prioritized stability and sustainability over rapid expansion. He understood the importance of maintaining a strong and well-organized administration, and his policies focused on ensuring the efficient collection of taxes and the fair distribution of resources among his people. These measures helped to create a sense of stability and continuity within the Hunnic Empire.

Furthermore, Attila showed a remarkable ability to adapt to changing circumstances. When the Western Roman Empire collapsed, he worked to establish diplomatic relations with the successor states that emerged. This adaptability allowed him to maintain stability in his empire and avoid unnecessary conflicts.

While Attila the Hun is often remembered as a ruthless conqueror, a closer examination of his political and economic policies reveals a more complex and nuanced figure. His commitment to stability, diplomacy, and adaptability provide a glimpse into his pragmatic and conservative approach to governance.

Ok, here's the rundown. horrendous management and unrealistic expectations from upper management at many gaming studios. At the same time there is also a massive oversupply of developers in the industry which drives down wages and makes working conditions toxic since developers have to compete for jobs. Since the industry is so oversaturated with developers, a majority of the smaller studios/indies survive on corporate sponsorships and investment money. When these investment groups pull out their money (since there is no way to sustainably earn money through gaming alone without a massive existing audience or a runaway hit) the studio will collapse, yet because it took so many investments to even get off the ground, there is often no product or code for the developers to take with them to another company and show that they are capable of doing the job. Programming is very results-oriented and non-transferable (each company has their own specialized codebase so previous experience with a different codebase is useless) which makes it so that developers who worked at these failed studios are forced into taking entry-level jobs despite having years of experience, just to get a job in a different studio. When they do get a job, they are so desperate to prove themselves that they will work unsustainable hours for little pay because they are simply grateful to be employed. Eventually, this drives them to burnout and they leave the industry. Additionally, many studios rely on staying ahead of the technological curve, yet due to the previously mentioned factors, they often don't have the time/resources to properly learn and implement new technologies, so they end up buying outs other studios as an alternative, which results in monoculture in the industry since there are fewer and fewer unique studios.

Sorry, but no. IMO, it's not his place. Regardless of how anyone feels about the circumstances of his death, George Floyd was not a public official. He owes us no explanation for how he lived his life, and we owe him none for how he died. It doesn't matter if you think he was a "good" person or a "bad" person, or if you think he "deserved" to die. We're not the moral arbiters of the world, and we sure as hell are not of each other. It is not our place to demand answers from anyone, let alone a random dead man who happened to be arrested once for selling loose cigarettes.

Furthermore, regardless of whatever one thinks of the police, Derek Chauvin is one of them, and allegedly murdered someone. Every cop, active or retired, agrees that you do not, under any circumstances, cover for another cop who has done wrong, even if you have to testify against them. Covering for another cop endangers the lives of innocent people, and jeopardizes the reputation and effectiveness of the entire institution. There is no scenario in which covering for Derek Chauvin is anything but wrong.

So no, Kyle, you don't get to wade into this. You're not a cop, you're not a lawyer, and you're not the judge. You don't get to decide that you somehow have a "duty" to protect someone who you disagree with, and to hell with everyone else. You don't. If you want to kneel or make a donation or something, that's all well and good, but this isn't something you get a say in. You don't get to decide that your personal feelings about George Floyd outweigh the entire justice system. You don't get to decide that your feelings about Derek Chauvin are more important than either of their lives. You don't get to do that.

This is why I wouldn't vote for Kyle.

Ok so this is a super long story and I wish I had read about this in every single forum and article about insurance before I made the mistake of listening to the adjuster and signing the form. 

Background: Car was stolen and recovered with damages. No police report was made because it was stolen from my garage and I had no idea when or how as well as my toddler was inside with the car so I didn't want to wait for police. It was a very traumatic experience. Car was recovered safely with baby and all, but with damages. Adjuster came to look at car, took photos, and assured me that they will cover the damages under comprehensive coverage. That was Oct 6. He said it will take about 10 days for appraisal. Oct 18, I get a call that the damages are not covered under comprehensive and that I needed to sign a form to "exclude" the damages from coverage. They said that the damages were caused by "acts of vandalism" and are not covered. My comprehensive coverage has zero exclusions. I have been going back and forth with them for 2 weeks trying to get this resolved. They keep saying the same thing in different ways and finally today they sent me a check for the full comprehensive limit minus the deductible (as if I should be grateful) and said that this closes my claim. Should I deposit the check or send it back? I feel like they are trying to bully me into accepting this check and that they are acting in bad faith. There are some damages that are not repaired - is it reasonable for me to keep the car as is and just take the check as partial payment? Who should I be speaking to? Please help. This company is the worst. I have been on hold for hours speaking to different reps and no one knows what they are doing.

Filipinos are warm and affectionate by nature, and physical contact is a big part of their culture. If you're not used to being hugged or kissed on the cheek by people you may not have met before, this can take some getting used to. But it's important to remember that it's just a cultural difference, and there's no need to be alarmed or uncomfortable. Simply smile and return the gesture if you can. 

Another thing that might be different is the way Filipinos express their emotions. They're known for being very loud and outspoken, and they often use gestures and body language to convey their messages. This can be a bit overwhelming if you're not used to it, but it's just a part of their culture. 

Overall, the best way to deal with a small Filipino person is to remember that they're just as human as you are. They have their own unique culture and ways of doing things, but that doesn't make them any less worthy of respect. So try to be open-minded and understanding, and you'll be just fine.

Im feeling upset about what happened when I ordered food for takeout at my local taco place. I have been going there for years, and Ive never had an issue before. I always order the same thing: two chicken tacos, chips, and a soda. It comes out to $8 with tax and its pretty much the perfect amount of food for one person, especially since I have a decent appetite. There were two people working that night, the cook and the cashier, and I was the only person there aside from a few people who came in after me and ordered burgers. So yeah, this place is more than just a taco place, they do like five or six different types of cuisines, and apparently their Thai food is really popular because the cook was on the phone taking an order for Thai food most of the time I was there. Anyway, after I paid for my order and was waiting for them to finish it, the cook asked me if I wanted taquitos added to my order and when I said no, he insisted, saying they were on the house. This turned into a fairly big argument because I was trying to explain that I didnt want any taquitos and he kept insisting and saying that they were free and that I just didnt understand because Im not from here. Sir, Ive lived here my whole life, why are you trying to insult me by saying Im not from here? Eventually he just shrugged and gave me the taquitos anyway while giving me this insulting look, and they were very good taquitos, but I was so upset that I just took my food and left. No one teaches you anything. Not really. Your parents can try but they eventually give up, partly because they can't be bothered and partly because getting a teenager to do anything is next to impossible. Being a teenager is just a collection of sociopathic tendencies underpinned by a self-involved insecurity so vast as to be unimaginable to any adult who hasn't been a teenager since the 1980's.

People treat you like you're fragile. Like one wrong word might snap you in two, so they tiptoe around theissues that you desperately need to have addressed. Issues that they created in the first place by treating you like you're made of glass. You're not. On the outside, you look like a finished product. You have hair and teeth and abs. You smell nice and you dress well and you make polite conversation. You conceal your weaknesses and insecurities so well that they are invisible to the naked eye.

Medicine doesn't care about your age. If you have a tumor or a infection or an autoimmune disease, they don't stop treatment because you're 22. You can be helped regardless of your age, despite what you may have been led to believe. Age isn't a barrier. It doesn't give you a free pass at all.

And you know what else doesn't give you a free pass? Just because you haven't experienced much and you don't know a lot doesn't mean you can just shit on everyone else's circumstances because you're too lazy to learn about them. Just because you're a sociopath doesn't mean you get a free pass to be a jerk. You can be polite. You can be considerate. You can think before you speak. You can try to understand rather than just discharging your verbal weaponry because you're upset that someone called you out for being a selfish prick.

Konami is a company that deserves more credit and appreciation than what it gets from gamers and the gaming community. Their work over the years has been remarkably innovative, increasing accessibility, and always pushing the boundaries of gaming, whether it be with beloved franchises like Metal Gear Solid and Silent Hill or newer releases like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Regardless, Konami has made its mark on the gaming industry and it is about time we give due recognition for their significant contributions. 

In terms of innovation, Konami was pioneering in the use of CD-ROMs in console games with titles like Metal Gear Solid and later with the release of the PlayStation. Additionally, they were also one of the first companies to introduce a comprehensive loyalty program with the Konami Code. Its impact is still felt today as it grants players access to special bonuses, power-ups, and other hidden features within games. 

Furthermore, Konami has made significant strides in increasing accessibility in their games. With features such as adjustable difficulty in Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain and options for colorblind gamers in Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots, they have demonstrated a commitment to making their games accessible to all players. 

Overall, it is clear that Konami is a company that deserves more appreciation than what they receive. Their innovative spirit, increases in accessibility, and boundary-pushing releases solidify them as a company that has made significant contributions to the gaming industry. Let us take the time to recognize and appreciate their impact.

It sounds like you're looking for ways to find older games that are no longer being sold or supported by their original developers. Here are some methods you can use to find and play these "abandonware" games:

1. Go to the websites of classic gaming magazines that are no longer in print. These websites often have archives of reviews for older games, and they may even have download links for the games themselves. Some examples of these magazines include Computer Gaming World, Electronic Gaming Monthly, and GamePro.

2. Search for "abandonware" websites that specialize in hosting downloads for old games. These websites often have a large selection of games to choose from, and they may even have patches or other modifications that you can use to improve the performance of the games on modern systems. Some popular abandonware websites include Abandonia, My Abandonware, and abandonware.com.

3. Try using a search engine to find old game downloads. You can use keywords like "abandonware" or "classic game downloads" to find websites that host old game downloads.

4. If you're looking for a specific game, try searching for it on websites like the Internet Archive's Console Living Room or the Classic Gaming Museum. These websites have extensive collections of older games, and they may have the game you're looking for.

5. Finally, if you're having trouble finding a specific game, try looking for fan-made recreations or remakes of the game. These recreations may not be exactly like the original game, but they can give you a similar experience.

When I was younger (around 10), I used to live in this tiny little town in the middle of nowhere. No big cities or anything like that within a few hours drive.

Anyways, my sister and I were sitting in our dining room having lunch when we witnessed what we thought to be a floating orb outside the window. It was completely see-through, about the size of a basketball, and drifted across the sky until it disappeared. It stayed close to the ground and sort of hovered over the roof of some apartments across the street. It was a pretty cloudy day so I assumed it was just a weird cloud at first, but it remained in the same spot and was more disc-shaped. It definitely was not a cloud.

To this day, I'm not sure what we saw. I've never seen anything like it before or since. The only thing I can think of is that it was some sort of weather balloon, but it was see-through and pretty fast moving for a balloon.

Has anyone else seen something like this? Any ideas on what it could have been?

It's been a few months since I started my first "real" job after finishing college. Donburi18 (https://www.reddit.com/user/Donburi18/)

I thought that once I started working, I would finally be at peace since I have been struggling with insomnia for several years now, and it has been really hard for me to stay focused and energized throughout the day (I am currently taking classes for my master's degree remotely). I thought that once I start working, I would be tired enough every day so I can finally have an adequate sleep.

However, it seems like once I get home after work (I commute for about an hour), I am wide awake for the rest of the night, and it is even harder for me to fall asleep than when I was just a student. I still have about 2 more hours every day where I just lie in bed and can't fall asleep. I feel so tired the next day, and the cycle just repeats.

I am just not a person who can fall asleep easily. Even when I was a student and didn't have to get up early, it would still take me about 1-2 hours to fall asleep, and I would wake up at odd hours in the middle of the night. I thought that once I started working, this would change, but it seems like it's getting even worse.

Does anyone have any suggestions or tips? I've tried maintaining a consistent sleep schedule, exposing myself to sunlight during the day, limiting screen time before going to sleep, and cutting out caffeine after 5 pm (it doesn't have much of an effect on me anyway). Sometimes I still take naps during the day on the weekends, but it's still difficult to fall asleep at night.

Thanks for any help or suggestions you can provide. Fingers crossed that I can get a good night's sleep at some point!

It stems from the inherent uncertainties of language and how it cannot truly express or define the experiential and ever-changing world around us. There are countless experiences that one may have which do not have a concrete definition or explanation in our existing lexicon, and even further, these experiences are almost certainly unique to the person experiencing them. This presents a problem when attempting to discuss these extraordinary experiences with others, as there are no words to describe them in a way that could possibly make sense to someone else, and it becomes infinitely difficult to coherently explain something so indescribable. Therefore, it leaves us with a strange, seemingly insurmountable paradox  we are unable to discuss the things we experience because of our inability to speak about them. 

It's an interesting philosophical quandary that many people have likely experienced at some point in their lives. For me, it's a frequent occurrence that happens almost daily. As someone who has experienced an array of bizarre, extraordinary, and indescribable things, I often find myself struggling to articulate these experiences to others, knowing that there are no words that can do them justice. I become trapped in my own mind, grasping at straws to try and explain these intangible concepts, but it seems almost futile. Language is an incredible tool, but it falls short when it comes to capturing the true depth and complexity of human experience. 

In these moments, I can't help but feel a sense of disconnect between my own experiences and the ability to communicate them to others. It's as if there's a barrier between what I've witnessed and the words that I need to describe it. I often wonder if other people have felt this same sense of frustration and limitation when trying to speak about what they've experienced. It can be a confusing and isolating feeling, but it's also a reminder of the mysteries of the human experience and the limits of language. 

Ultimately, the inability to speak about what we've experienced isn't a failure of our communication abilities or a sign of madness, but rather a fascinating and mind-boggling aspect of the human condition. It challenges us to explore new ways of expressing ourselves and to find comfort in the shared experiences that bring us together, even in the face of the things we cannot speak.

I'm prior service, joined the AF as a PM but felt like I wasn't doing anything and the job was boring (I fixed printers and troubleshooted user accounts, and that was it for 8 hours a day). I was a prior Marine and it just didn't feel the same. When I EAS'd I decided I was done with the military, but then I realized I missed the sense of purpose, and brotherhood/sisterhood the military offers. I am prior enlisted so I knew being an officer was the only way I was getting back in. I considered going back as an enlisted member but ultimately decided against it because I like sleeping in my own bed and having a life outside of the military, which is super important to me. I've always been fascinated with the Navy and the seas. When I was little, my grandpa was in the Navy and told me stories about being on a carrier. I always thought it was so cool. When I was in the AF, the base I was at butted up to a Navy base and I loved seeing the ships come in and out of port. To me, the Navy just seemed like a good mix of the other branches, there's a little bit of everything in the Navy and that intrigued me. The decision for me to go Navy was also heavily influenced by the fact that my now fianc is a Sailor. We met stateside when he was stationed where I was, and we've been together since. When he decided to get out, we decided we didn't want to be apart. Personally, I like that the Navy's mission is both sea and shore based. You can be in the Navy and never set foot on a ship, or you can be at sea for months at a time. The variety of jobs also offered was a big draw for me as well. The CG and AF just didn't offer the same opportunities in terms of what I wanted to do. I knew if I went AF, it would basically be doing the same job I did as an enlisted member, just with more schooling and a different badge. The CG just didn't have anything that really interested me, and I didn't want to just be an officer because I wanted to be an officer. Does that make sense?

Hunter has so many cards that it can feel like you're always a few cards short. Especially when it comes to those sweet interactive cards. There is never enough slots for the good stuff. Having only one copy of Deathrattle Hunter is a bummer but it is still possible to make it work. There is just one question remaining. Where is my deathrattle hunter?

Into the Jungle will give you the most options. There are many cheap beasts that can fill you a nice deck with a ton of cheap deathrattle targets. This will make your lone copy of Deathrattle Hunter a lot more reliable. Being able to play it turn 1 or turn 5 doesn't matter as much when you have a ton of cheap options to choose from. This also lets you cut some of the more expensive cards like Huffer.

There are a few beasts from other sets that can also be used. Zombeast is a classic but it is a bit expensive. It is still a great top end that can be splashed in easily. Gilbenau Dragon can be a nice addition to the deck since it can be cast immediately after Deathrattle Hunter. This can be a nice surprise since most people will expect you to have a beast in hand. 

Going heavier on the deathrattle theme is possible with cards like Necromechanic and Risky Skipper. These can be great with Deathrattle Hunter but will make the deck more inconsistent. Sometimes you just want to play your under-played cards. This can also be solved by just playing a second copy of the card. However, this is not always an option.
