Once upon a time, there was a young girl who lived on a lonely sea shore. She spent her days peacefully, watching the waves and the sea gulls flying overhead. One day, she got the wonderful idea of selling shells to the few tourists who passed by her. She gathered some of the prettiest shells she could find and set up a little table at the edge of the shore to display her treasures.

At first, she didn't get many customers. Most people passed by without giving her a second glance. But the girl was determined. She rearranged her shells and cleaned them until they shone. She studied the tides and learned when to expect tourists to pass by. She even invented some games to keep the children entertained while their parents browsed.

Soon, news of the shell seller spread, and she started to get more customers. Some people even came specifically to see her and admire her beautiful shells. She earned enough money to buy a tent and some furniture, and she was able to buy more shells from other sea shore communities. She even hired some of her friends to help her with her business.

Ich mchte gerade ein paar Tage Urlaub in meinem neuen Auto entspannen. Ich bin gestern Abend in die Garage gegangen, mein altes Auto zu parken und meinen neuen zu beschleunigen, und ich bin berrascht, wie laut und lautes mein altes Auto ist. Ich habe mich ber die Erwartungen von meinem neuen Auto gefreut und habe vieles erwartet. In der Tat, hat sich meine Erwartung erfllt, aber ich bin auch erstaunt, wie laut und lautes mein neues Auto ist. Ich bin gespannt, ob sich meine Begeisterung fr diesen bleiben wird.

Im a 24 yr old woman and Im pretty sure I have had TS all my life but only in the last 4 months has it become constant. Im not sure whether this is normal .....

Basically all my life I have had odd tics here and there, different random muscles around my body. If I concentrate hard enough I can suppress them but its a huge effort and as a child this is how I dealt with them, I would just try and ignore them. But if I became distracted or tired then I would have what I call tic attacks, where I cant control myself and its a mixture of vocal and physical tics which are rapid and sudden. These would happen once every few months but never lasted longer than say 20 minutes. As I got older they became fewer and further between (maybe once every 6 months) and I began to think maybe I had grown out of them.

But this year they are constant. There is not one minute of my day where I dont have a tic, its usually a quiet one but very persistent. However every now and then it will be extremely strong and I cannot stop it no matter how hard I try, when this happens it feels like a demonic force taking over my body and its scary. They can be any where from 5 seconds to 5 minutes. Its becoming a real issue in my life because its constant and because of the intensity and because I have no idea why its happening. 

Could it be TS? I know TS comes in many forms. My mum and grandma both have OCD (which I also have) so could it be genetic? Could it be stress? Ive been very stressed this year due to personal issues.roleum

2012 Dodge Charger R/T - key fob problem

So, I recently bought a 2012 Dodge Charger R/T, and it's been a great car, except for one weird thing. When I use the key fob to unlock or lock the car, it doesn't always work. It seems to happen more often when it's colder outside, but it still doesn't work sometimes when it's warmer too. I have tried changing the batteries in the key fob, but that didn't help. Any suggestions on why this is happening and how to fix it? 

EDIT: fixed! Seems like there was an electrical issue unrelated to the key fob itself. Thanks for all your suggestions!

Went to interview for a Baker/Fryer position and when we got there they said they are looking for a dishwasher and not a baker. It's an hour drive and they were supposed to call to confirm, obviously they didn't. Just wanted to know if this is normal? Seems really weird.

The grid is lit up with neon lights as the Recognizers patrol in sync; Replicants are somewhere out there, they know it, their mission is to hunt them down and eliminate them. In their sleek black uniforms and their helmets with blinking lights, they are the masters of the arena.

Thunder rolls as LIGHT CYCLES approach. They're hunting too; their game is to destroy the other cycles by edging closer and forcing their opponents into their TRON lights, which when collided with, destroys the cycle and sends the rider flying across the grid. In their brilliant glow, the riders approach, hunting for the tags of the Recognizers and Replicants to gain an edge in their chase. They're not after the humans, though; they want the data they carry.

Still, the humans are pinned between the two forces as they desperately try to outrun the pursuing horde. A Recognizer is caught in the crossfire and its data, a glowing, pulsing orb, is snatched up by one of the riders; a Replicant, the rider must be. The humans stop and watch as the data orb explodes, wiping out the cycle and launching the rider through the air. The grid is awash with streaks of light and neon glow.

The humans know they have to get out of there before they get caught in the crossfire. They can hear the Recognizers and the Replicants barking out orders and snarling as they close in. The riders have disappeared, but the chase isn't over yet.

Body:

I am recently divorced after a 29 year marriage and my husband divorced me to marry a woman he met online after a month of chatting. My adult children are devastated and gravitate towards me which is making his new wife very upset. She wants my husband to "choose" her and essentially disown his children and I. He chooses her often, so much so that the children and I rarely see him, and when we do it's obvious he's choice her over us. Sadly, before meeting this new woman he left Christianity (which we raised the kids in) and now believes in nothing, and seems to be suffering from NPD where he's entitled to do whatever makes him happy, despite the pain it causes others. The kids and I are devastated and struggle to understand why he's doing this. We were a close family before. I never expected this from my husband especially since he was the one who wanted the divorce initially (not the other way around). I think I'm depressed. How do I help my children when I can't even help myself? And how do I deal with the new wife who keeps trying to make the kids and I the "bad guys" when we're the ones who are hurting? It's so unfair. 

Thank you for listening.

Im so confused with myself. Heres the story. Im a man in my mid-20s. I live alone in a city far from where I grew up. Sort of moved here spontaneously because I was bored with where I was and the people around me. Didnt know anyone here but felt like it was a good fit. Been here for about 2 years now and still dont know that many people. A lot of the friends I made shortly after moving here have slowly distanced themselves from me. They got significant others and spend their time with them mostly and not as much with me. Which I get and fully support. Im happy for them. I guess the thing thats confusing to me is that I thought I would be in a relationship by now as well or at least talking to someone regularly. Ive been dating off and on but most of the women I date dont really catch my interest, and nothing really serious has come from it. I think my problem is Im not really interested in most of the people I meet. I have this image of someone Id really like to date and frankly dont see that person anywhere within sight. I feel like Im not going to meet anyone like that here. For a while, I thought I might be asexual since I just dont seem to be attracted to anyone I meet lately. Then I start dating someone and get attracted to them. Its happened enough times now that I dont think thats it. I guess Im just confused and kind of lonely. I feel like most people my age are settling down with someone they care about and Im still out here bouncing around from person to person never really connecting with anyone. Sometimes I wonder if Im just super asexual and thats why I dont connect with anyone, but then I have feelings for people when I date them so I dont know.

The neku are the souls of the dead who are reborn into the world through the power of magnetic fields. Each neku has a set destiny it must fulfill before it can move on and transcend to a higher plane of existence. This is the basis for the story of Neo TWEWY.

Neku, the main character, is a special type of neku. He is a "wildcat", meaning he is a soul who has been reborn without a set destiny. This allows him to freely choose his own path and shape his own future. At the start of the game, Neku is absorbed into the Reaper's Game, a battle of fate between different teams of Shoujos and Reapers. Each team has a Book of Fate, which contains the destinies of all the neku who are absorbed into the Game. The goal of the Game is to erase all other Books of Fate but your own.

Neku's lack of a destiny allows him to interfere with other players' battles and change the outcome of the Game. Throughout the story, Neku allies himself with a team of Shoujos and Reapers and together they try to survive the Game and uncover the mystery of its origin and purpose. In the end, Neku discovers that he was destined to transcend with Shibuya's lost "Noise", which are fragments of thoughts and feelings that have been lost over time.

By absorbing these Noise, Neku fulfills his destiny and transcends, finally moving on to a higher plane of existence. The game ends with Neku's departure, leaving his teammates behind in Shibuya.

I recently tried to adopt a dog from my local shelter, but the difficult process deterred me from following through. First, I had to fill out a detailed application form. Then, I was asked to provide references. After that, I had to schedule an interview with a member of the shelter staff. And finally, I had to wait for a decision from the shelter. This entire process was just too difficult and time-consuming. I understand that shelters have a responsibility to find good homes for their dogs, but their current process is preventing dogs from finding homes. There are so many people who want to adopt dogs but are discouraged by the difficult process. Instead, these people buy dogs from breeders or pet stores, which only exacerbates the problem of overcrowding in shelters. More people should be encouraged to adopt from shelters, but the shelters need to make it easier for people to do so. There is a shortage of adoptive families at the same time as shelters euthanize healthy, adoptable dogs on a daily basis. Obviously, something needs to change.

Arkham City is a masterpiece. It's the best game period. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is addictive, and the story is incredible. You can tell that the developers put a lot of love and care into this game. The voice acting is top-notch, and the soundtrack is unforgettable. This game truly deserves all the praise it gets. If you're a fan of action-adventure games, then you need to play this one. You won't regret it!

I'm really not sure what to do anymore. Been dealing with a lot of anxiety lately and today it kind of hit a new high. I haven't been to the doctor's about it because I hate taking medicine and frankly do not have the money right now to be going to the doctor for something that might be considered not serious enough. Especially since I'm pretty sure if I go in and tell them about my anxiety they're going to want to put me on some kind of medication and I just really don't want to go down that road. It wouldn't be anything against the medicine itself, I'm just skeptical of its effectiveness when it comes to my own personal issues. I guess what I'm asking is, if there are any all natural remedies for anxiety? Or maybe somewhere I can read up more on the subject and learn how to properly cope with it? I feel like lately it's just been getting worse and worse and I wanna get a handle on it before it gets even worse. Be nice to hear any responses you guys might have. Thanks.

I'm 32, single, and feel like I've completely failed at life. I feel so behind my peers who are now all settling down, getting married, and having kids. I never found "the one", I'm still living at home with my parents, and I'm starting to worry that I never will. I feel like I've missed my chance at finding love and happiness and creating a life for myself. All of my friends are settling down and I feel so left behind. uncontrolled rant I'm just so tired of feeling like I failed at life and like I'll never be happy. 

Edit: Thanks for all your kind words and support, guys. It really means a lot. Polyfragmentation? I like it. Maybe I'll try that. I'm going to try and shift my perspective and take some time for myself and focus on self-improvement. Maybe I'll even try dating again. Who knows? Life's weird. Anyway, I appreciate all the love and support you guys are giving me. Thank you.

The most annoying thing about Harvey and Roz is how self-centered and hypocritical they both are. Despite consistently speaking on how much they love each other, their actions indicate that they are more concerned with benefiting from their relationship with each other than actually caring about the other person. It's exhausting to watch characters who are so obviously only interested in themselves and makes me wonder why the hell they're still together.

His inability to accept feedback is astonishing. Everyone around him can see it, and yet, whenever confronted, he denies it. He lacks self-awareness and refuses to acknowledge his weaknesses. It's frustrating to see someone unable to see how their actions affect those around them. At this point, it's obvious he's just trying to convince himself that everything's fine. He needs to take a step back and reflect on his actions.

Three years ago, I received a full scholarship from my undergraduate school that covered tuition, mandatory fees, and room and board. This scholarship was renewed each year as long as my GPA remained above a certain threshold, which it did. 

Being awarded this scholarship altered the trajectory of my life. My family was struggling financially at the time, and I worry that I would not have been able to attend my dream school without it. It honestly feels like a second chance at life for me. 

A few months ago, I had dinner with one of my best friends from undergraduate school. I was shocked to hear that he was abusing his scholarship funds. He was using the money meant for tuition and fees to invest in his startup company, and was planning to drop out of school in a few months to work on it full time. 

I want to say that I confronted him that night, but I didn't. I made an excuse and left early. I was too scared of making things weird between us. But ever since then, I've been thinking about how many other people might be misusing scholarship money, and it's eating away at me. 

I feel so betrayed by my friend. He knew how much that scholarship meant to me, and continues to misuse the funds, knowing that it's not right. Every time I think about it, it hurts me so much. It's one thing if someone wastes their own money, but this is different. 

I feel like I should tell my friend how I feel, but I don't know if that's worth ruining our friendship. What do you guys think?

Ok, Reddit. Let's talk about something that ticks me off. Smurf accounts. We all know them, we all hate them. They're the accounts that are created by companies or individuals to promote a product, service, or themselves. They usually have generic names like "Joe Smith" or "Jane Doe", and they always have a website or a link to their social media accounts in their bio.

The problem with smurf accounts is that they undermine the integrity of the Reddit community. They pollute our feeds with spam and self-promotion, and they make it difficult for genuine users to stand out.

It's time for a change. I propose that we ban smurf accounts from Reddit. If a company or individual wants to promote their product or service, they can do so through sponsored content or by creating an official account.

Let's take a stand, Reddit. Ban smurf accounts and keep our community honest and authentic.

Ok so the documentary was eye opening but the one thing that stood out to me towards the end was the amount of heavy metals in the seafood industry. Mainly mercury and lead. It was stated that consumption of swordfish wasn't safe because of this and that sushi restaurants were starting to use farmed tuna instead of wild because of this.

I know that mercury and lead are bad for us but how bad are we actually talking? Is it something to be concerned about when eating seafood? Because seafood is supposed to be healthy and all but if the benefits of seafood are outweighed by the risk of these heavy metals it kind of makes seafood not worth it.

A reasonable career in technical theatre is one that provides a stable and sustainable income, as well as opportunities for growth and development. There are many jobs in technical theatre that can provide these opportunities, depending on an individual's skills and interests. Some examples include:

- Stage manager: A stage manager is responsible for coordinating and managing the production during rehearsals and performances. They work closely with the director and other members of the creative team to ensure that the show runs smoothly.

- Lighting designer: A lighting designer is responsible for creating the lighting plan for a production. They work with the director and other members of the creative team to understand the vision for the show and create a design that helps to convey that vision.

- Sound designer: A sound designer is responsible for creating the sound design for a production. They work with the director and other members of the creative team to understand the vision for the show and create a design that helps to convey that vision.

- Set designer: A set designer is responsible for creating the set design for a production. They work with the director and other members of the creative team to understand the vision for the show and create a design that helps to convey that vision.

- Technical director: A technical director is responsible for overseeing the technical aspects of a production. They work with the director and other members of the creative team to ensure that the technical elements of the show are executed properly.

These are just a few examples of jobs in technical theatre that can provide a reasonable career. It is important to note that technical theatre is a collaborative field, and many jobs require working with others to create a successful production.

Bluetooth lag is a common issue that can be caused by a variety of factors, including the device's distance from the router, the number of devices connected to the router, and the strength of the router's signal.

To reduce Bluetooth lag, you can try moving your device closer to the router, limiting the number of devices connected to the router, and making sure the router's signal is strong. You can also try resetting your device's Bluetooth connection or updating its firmware.

If these steps do not work, you may need to contact your device's manufacturer for further assistance.

Sure! Here is the body of an IMDb review for *Mary and Max*:

Max, a 40-year-old man living in Sydney, Australia, is struggling with the responsibilities of caring for his elderly mother. Feeling a void in his life, he decides to create an imaginary friend, Mary, who is a free-spirited eight-year-old girl living in Minnesota. Over the course of several years, Max and Mary share an increasingly intimate friendship, sharing secrets and helping one another through difficult times. As their friendship deepens, Max's mother's health declines, leading Max to make a difficult decision.

The film is a heartfelt and comedic portrayal of the complexities of human relationships and the power of imagination. It is praised for its unique animation style and clever writing, and is a must-watch for fans of independent and foreign films.

The movie follows the story of a group of prisoners played by Ben Affleck, who are sent to a prison camp in Siberia. This movie is a real-life story of the basketball team that was formed by the prisoners and played against the guards. This movie is a great example of how people can come together to overcome adversity. It is also a great example of how a movie can be both entertaining and inspiring.  There are minimal details about the prisoners' backstories, but the audience doesn't really need it. This cast also carries the film due to excellent directing.

IMDb captures the excitement of watching She's The Man, a hilarious update of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night packed with romance, sports and an irresistible cast. 

 Viola Hastings (Amanda Bynes) is an average teenager who lives with her parents (Charles Rocket, Julie Hagerty) and absorbs sports like a sponge. When her school's basketball team makes it to the state championship, Viola realizes it's her big chance to finally be noticed by her crush, team star Duke Orsino (Channing Tatum). As a skilled player in her own right, Viola talks her friend Lucy (Alexis Bledel) into posing as her and taking her place on the team, while she poses as Lucy to observe Duke from the sidelines undetected. Things get more complicated when Viola falls for Duke and gets tangled up in a love triangle with her alter ego, Lucy, and Duke. Adding to the chaos, Viola's twin brother Sebastian (James Kirk) suddenly and mysteriously shows up, and no one seems to notice he looks just like her.

The Emperor's New Groove is a hilarious animated movie that will have you laughing from beginning to end. It is a classic tale of a selfish emperor who gets turned into a llama and must learn to be a better person in order to get his old body back. The movie is full of clever jokes and witty dialogue that will keep you entertained throughout. The animation is top-notch and the characters are incredibly well-developed. The Emperor's New Groove is a must-watch for fans of animated comedies.

The Adventures of Tintin is a classic movie based on the beloved comic book character Tintin. This film follows Tintin and his loyal dog Snowy as they embark on a journey to find a priceless treasure. Along the way, they encounter a variety of colorful characters, including the villainous Ivan Ivanovitch Sakharine. The movie is full of action and adventure, and it is sure to keep viewers entertained from beginning to end. 

The animation in The Adventures of Tintin is truly impressive. The characters are brought to life with a mix of traditional animation and computer-generated imagery, creating a unique and visually appealing style. The movie also features a memorable score and a host of catchy songs that are sure to get stuck in your head.

Overall, The Adventures of Tintin is a fun and exciting movie that the whole family can enjoy. It is a must-watch for fans of the comic book character, and it is sure to become a classic in its own right.

(No title)

Akira can be describes as a visionary masterpiece of animation, a landmark in the career of its director, Katsuhiro Otomo, and an enduring work of science fiction that touches on the themes of power, adolescence and conformity. Otomo's visceral depiction of a future Tokyo inhabited by motorcyclists, hackers and nefarious government agencies is grounded in a morally complex narrative that will linger in your thoughts long after the end credits roll. 

The plot follows the journey of two teenage friends, Tetsuo and Kaneda, as Tetsuo gains telekinetic powers through a government experiment and becomes the subject of a clandestine investigation. As Tetsuo's powers grow and his friendship with Kaneda falters, their lives take a dangerous turn when they find themselves confronting a government that will stop at nothing to suppress Tetsuo's extraordinary abilities. 

What sets Akira apart is its nuanced exploration of power, conformity and responsibility. The film challenges us to consider the consequences of unchecked power and the importance of empathy in a world where fear and aggression are often the first responses to those who are different. 

Furthermore, the animation is groundbreaking for its time and still holds up as some of the best animation ever put on screen. The detail and fluidity of the animation is astounding, and the action sequences are thrilling and immersive. 

In conclusion, Akira is not only a visually stunning and groundbreaking animation, but also a thought-provoking and emotionally powerful science fiction classic that will leave a lasting impression on its audience.

Without the nostalgia boost of the preceding films in the franchise, "WALLE" comes across as a mildly intriguing tale of a dystopian future that lacks the punch of, say, "Snowpiercer." It's got neat visuals and that retro-futuristic look that's common in nowadays science fiction (think "Blade Runner"). That said, "WALLE" is by no means a visually intricate film, rendering it reliant on its story and charactersthis is where it falters. While Wall-E himself is pretty cute, he's not exactly a nuanced character, and this applies to almost all the characters in the film. Doesn't help that most of them are CGI, skeletal robots whom the audience likely won't empathize with, despite their half-human forms. From a narrative standpoint, "WALLE" is serviceable but not especially compelling. That it was made in 2008 is surprising, as its vision of the future lacks the sharpness of similarly-themed films like "Minority Report" and "Brazil." Not without its merits, especially for younger viewers, but "WALLE" feels less ahead-of-its-time than one would expect from a Pixar film.

Turkic impersonator Sacha Baron Cohen delivers a blistering indictment of American culture in Borat, posing as a Kazakh journalist on a goodwill tour of the United States. Having previously stumped with his ignominiously sacked Ali G persona  a mockery of bourgeois trendsetters wedded to his publisher's reception  Baron Cohen here goes much further in pursuing his "war on shame", single-handedly taking on homophobia, religious intolerance, racial prejudice, and the Ku Klux Klan. Not all of this is pretty. In fact, some of it is downright ugly and it provokes uneasiness as well as laughter. Baron Cohen confronts his interviewees with bile and nonsense so relentlessly and single-mindedly that it becomes frightening. Yet however destabilizing and confrontational his performance, it's hard to deny its comedic effectiveness. Many of the stunts are so outrageous that the movie threatens to lose control, and the question of whether it does so on purpose or not remains unanswered. In the final analysis, however, this madness is hooked to a coherent, satire-dense commentary on American cultural and political mores. Again, it's not pretty, but it is often brilliantly funny and even a little bit brave.

Without giving any specific spoilers away, I can say that "Us" is a movie that nails the atmosphere, the tiny details, and the vivid recollection of what it's like to be a child, and that is repeatedly trounced by jumpscares that would be right at home in any conventional horror film. It is a film that is altogether more interesting when examined in hindsight after reading others' interpretations, but is hardly worthwhile to sit through a second time. 

A film like "Us" is what aspiring filmmakers might make in their first or second year of film school. It is derivative of far better films by far more accomplished directors, and it doesn't hold a candle to the director's own earlier work. "Us" is a film with flashes of brilliance surrounded by pages of dull, pointless, meandering filler. Its budget was $20 million. Its box office take was $255 million. Go figure.

esoteric cinema at its finest. riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma. flaunts a tone and style unlike any movie i have ever seen basking in beautiful, bizarre, bone-chilling imagery that delivers a delirious, dream-like effect comparative to the witcher 3's imaginary sequences filtered through jacob's ladder and a league of their own; weaving a tapestry of symbolism centered around fertility lore that acts as a stunning albeit grim metaphor for pregnancy and childbirth spanning a near-three hour runtime that never feels its length thanks to confident direction, a brazen commitment to its singular vision and exceptional performances from a well-rounded ensemble cast; flaunts a potent blend of black comedy and horror cinematography sporting a rainbow-colored color palette and some truly gonzo angles canted at odd angles reminiscent of ren & stimpy "beach partyblob" while retaining a tactile, organic texture impressing upon the viewer a sense of palpable danger and mounting tension; innovative, impressionistic and intoxicatingly alienating despite its relatively conventional climax, Midsommar is a genre-bending cult classic in the making

For SCARY MOVIE 2, the acclaimed comedy troupe Wayans Brothers treads in the same satirical footsteps of its popular predecessor, sending up the conventions of mainstream horror flicks. It's been three years since the first film, andCheryl (Shannon Elizabeth) and Ray (Simon Rex) have managed to survive the events that featured a killer doll and an ax-wielding maniac. Since then, the couple has moved into a posh high-rise apartment and started a family. Ray has been busy juggling his job as a radio morning show host with being a new dad, while Cheryl has been struggling to write her first novel. Unfortunately for Ray, his obnoxious co-host, Manson (Marlon Wayans), has moved into his apartment and is determined to drive him insane. And things go from bad to worse when Cheryl learns that her new best friend, Rebecca (Denise Richards), is having an affair with her husband. Adding to their troubles, a strange supernatural force starts gobbling up everyone in the building. SCARY MOVIE 2 delivers the laughs again with an assortment of parodies that includes nods to THE EXORCIST, THE AMITYVILLE HORROR, and POLTERGEIST.

Without the presence of the legendary Bruce Campbell, and with a comparatively subdued approach to the gore, this reboot of the Evil Dead franchise doesn't stand up to the original trilogy. But that doesn't mean it's not a lot of fun.

This reboot is a lot creepier, and it benefits throughout from a strong commitment to a stripped-down, old-school style. The plot is almost identical to the original: a group of 5 college kids go to a remote cabin in a forest to party, and accidentally unleash demonic forces. This time around, though, it's a woman's mental illness that causes her to inadvertently unleash the demons, and it's a lot more compelling as a result.

The creature effects and gore are impressive, but it lacks the over-the-top flair of the original. With its steady pace, strong performances from a game cast, and compelling ambiguity, this is a solid horror film in its own right. But it's hard not to compare it to the original, and on that measure, it falls a little short.

Spider-Man 2 is a 2004 American superhero film directed by Sam Raimi and written by Alvin Sargent. It is the second and final installment in the Spider-Man trilogy, and it stars Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst, and Alfred Molina. The film follows Peter Parker as he struggles to come to terms with his new identity as Spider-Man, while also trying to save his love interest, Mary Jane Watson, from the clutches of Doctor Octopus.

The film was a box office success, grossing over $800 million worldwide. It received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised its action sequences, visual effects, and performances. 

The film's cast features an ensemble of well-known actors, including Tobey Maguire, Kirsten Dunst, and Alfred Molina. Maguire delivers a solid performance as Peter Parker, showcasing the character's struggles with power and responsibility. Dunst also gives a strong performance as Mary Jane Watson, adding depth to the character's emotional journey. 

One of the film's highlights is its action sequences, which are thrilling and well-executed. The film's visual effects are also top-notch, adding to the overall excitement of the film. 

Overall, Spider-Man 2 is a fun and exciting film that delivers on its promise of action and adventure. It is a worthy successor to the first film in the trilogy and a must-watch for fans of the superhero genre.

 Archibald "Archie" Andrews (played by Luke Spencer) is inadvertently brought into the Spider-Man mythos, with Spider-Man rescuing him from a fallen water tower.

The film is a gripping, inspirational story about a man named Vince Papale. It's a true story about how he managed to overcome long odds and transform his life through his incredible determination and effort. Without any professional football experience, he managed to beat out thousands of other players for a position on the Philadelphia Eagles roster. Beyond his incredible sports story, the film is a beautiful meditation on following your dreams and never giving up. There's nothing overtly philosophical about the movie but the story itself it's a testament to the power of dreams and personal achievement. The bottom line is that Hollywood tends to botch these kinds of inspirational stories with cheap, cloying sentimentality but "Invincible" is a very well-made and effective film about a real-life sports miracle that will inspire and move you.

"12 Monkeys" is a brilliant and sophisticated film, showcasing the depth of Brad Pitt's acting range and the visionary directing of Terry Gilliam. It is both a gripping thriller and a thought-provoking science fiction film, exploring the themes of time travel, memory, and the possibility of changing the past. The film's intricate plot is expertly woven together, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats until the very end. 

The film also features an impressive supporting cast, including Bruce Willis, Madeleine Stowe, and Christopher Plummer. The visual effects and set design are equally impressive, creating a stark and unsettling vision of the future. 

Overall, "12 Monkeys" is a must-see film that will leave a lasting impression on viewers.

The movie 'Get Him to the Greek' is surprisingly witty, given that it's a crude Adam Sandler comedy. Of course, the fact that it's basically a remake of 'The Hangover' doesn't hurt. The plot is amusingly simple. A young man, Aaron Green (Russell Brand), is entrusted by his boss, who is also his girlfriend's father, to retrieve the famous rock star, Aldous Snow (Jonah Hill), from a rehabilitation clinic and deliver him to the Greek to play at a concert put on by the millionaire. The task is not at all easy because Aldous does not want to go, and Aaron has to resort to trickery and persuasion. As expected, the pair get into all sorts of trouble, and crazy shenanigans ensue.

What makes the movie worth watching is the excellent chemistry between Brand and Hill. Their hilarious banter is a treat to watch, and they make a great pair. The movie also has plenty of funny moments, mostly due to Hill's excellent delivery. Even though the movie is pretty much a remake of 'The Hangover', it's still a fun watch, mostly thanks to the performances of Brand and Hill. If you're looking for a movie that's similar to 'The Hangover' but with a different setting and cast, then 'Get Him to the Greek' is the one for you.

The movie is a fun and wild ride from start to finish. It has a great cast, including Margot Robbie and Idris Elba, who are both fantastic in their roles. The film is packed with action and never slows down. It's a great film to see with friends or family, and perfect for a movie night. The film's plot concerning a group of supervillains who are given a chance at redemption by completing a dangerous mission is unique and interesting. 

Overall, "Suicide Squad" is a great addition to the DC Universe and an excellent film in its own right. It is a must-watch for fans of the genre.

This movie is a powerful and thought-provoking portrayal of Edward Snowden, the man who exposed the NSA's mass surveillance programs. It is a gripping and emotional account of Snowden's journey from a young soldier to a controversial whistleblower.

The film is directed by Oliver Stone, who is known for his controversial and politically charged films. He does an excellent job of bringing the story of Snowden to life, and of exploring the complex issues surrounding mass surveillance and the balance between national security and personal privacy.

The acting in the film is top-notch. Joseph Gordon-Levitt gives an incredible performance as Snowden, capturing the man's passion, determination, and courage. Shailene Woodley also gives a strong performance as Snowden's girlfriend, Lindsay Mills.

The film is not without its flaws. The pacing is sometimes slow, and the film could have been trimmed down by about 20 minutes. Additionally, the film's portrayal of Snowden as a near-perfect hero may be too simplistic for some viewers.

Overall, however, "Snowden" is a thought-provoking and powerful film that explores some of the most important issues of our time. It is a must-see for anyone interested in politics, privacy, and the balance between the two.

Before seeing "Jackie," I thought the movie would be a biography, or something chronological in nature, about the days surrounding the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. I was surprised to find that it focused on one aspect of those days, and probed deep.

Starring Natalie Portman as Jacqueline Kennedy, the movie begins immediately after the assassination. Mrs. Kennedy is shown restocking the contents of the refrigerator, making herself useful. We see her clothing stained with her husband's blood, and we hear rumors that a Secret Service agent is engaging in sexual relations with her.

The movie follows Mrs. Kennedy as she plans President Kennedy's funeral. She clashes with Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy (Peter Sarsgaard), who feels that her choices are overly expensive and showy. She butts heads with Presidential aide Kenny O'Donnell (Kevin Bacon), who attempts to minimize her role in the planning. And she struggles to console her brother-in-law, who is drinking too much and unable to sleep.

"Jackie" is a bold portrayal of a woman teetering on the edge. It is a portrayal that differs from the stoic, elegant image she presented to the world. But it is also a portrayal that reveals the strength and determination behind the image. 

Make no mistake, this is not a fluff piece. Nor is it a straight biography. Director Pablo Larrain and screenwriter Noah Oppenheim focus on a brief period of time. They present a fictional account based on recorded interviews from Mrs. Kennedy. Make no mistake, this is a probing look at a woman dealing with unimaginable grief, anger, and despair. 

Portman is amazing in the title role. She completely transforms herself, from the lingo to the facial expressions. At no point does she resemble the character she played in "Vox Lux," or any of the other characters she has played. It is a stunning, award-worthy performance.

Sacared of taking advantage of Mrs. Kennedy's vulnerability, other actors in the movie treat her with deference and delicacy. Sarsgaard and Bacon are both excellent in their roles. John Hurt is superb as a priest who comforts Mrs. Kennedy. And Greta Gerwig has a small, but pivotal role as a close friend. 

"Jackie" is a brief movie, running only 92 minutes. But it is an intense, emotional movie. By the end, you feel as if you've been through an emotional wringer. The music is loud. The camera work

Al Pacino and Keanu Reeves deliver intense and powerful performances in this gripping and sophisticated legal thriller. It is a thought-provoking and visually stunning film, with a complex and multi-layered plot that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. 

The film follows a young lawyer (Keanu Reeves) who takes a job at a prestigious law firm in New York City, only to discover that the firm is linked to a mysterious and powerful organization that is manipulating him and his colleagues for its own sinister purposes.

As he struggles to uncover the truth and fight for his own survival, he is aided by a former colleague (Al Pacino) who has his own dark past and a strong desire for revenge. The two of them must navigate a dangerous and complex web of lies, secrets, and corruption in order to expose the truth and put an end to the organization's sinister plans.

The film is a visually stunning and thought-provoking thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The performances of Al Pacino and Keanu Reeves are both intense and powerful, and the complex and multi-layered plot will keep you guessing until the end.

Without getting into spoilers, I'll just say that Neil Armstrong almost wasn't in the mission that made him famous. It's evident early that he's a brilliant engineer and pilot but something's holding him back from the cutthroat world of American space exploration. 

This irony is just one of many this film by Damien Chazelle (Whiplash, La La Land) is packing. It offers up a visceral and nervy re-imaging of the Space Race of the 1960s, eschewing familiar epic spectacles in favor of intense, immersive and gritty visual language. Above all it chooses to focus not on the 'one small step' of the famous Apollo 11 mission but the ' giant leap' of faith that made it possible.

The entire supporting cast is superb. Claire Foy continues to stun after her magnificent performance in Unsane and the always-welcome Kyle Chandler is again terrific here. But this is a Ryan Gosling vehicle and despite a weak American accent, he gives a powerful performance, imbuing Armstrong with a soulful introspection befitting a legend. 

Chazelle reportedly struggled to finish the movie and it shows in the edit which is a little cluttered. Some shots seem to go on a beat too long and the run time could easily have been trimmed by 10-12 minutes. But these are minor quibbles. This is a substantial and meaningful tribute to an important moment in human history.

Spielberg masterfully directs this classic tale of a stranded extra-terrestrial and the 10-year-old boy who helps him get back to his home planet. The cinematography is stunning, and the music is unforgettable. The cast is perfectly chosen, especially Henry Thomas, who gives an incredible performance as Elliott. This movie is a must-see for anyone who loves science fiction or emotional dramas. It's uplifting and heartbreaking, funny and sad, and altogether magical.

"We're the Millers" is a hilarious and heartfelt comedy about a fake family turned real. This movie captures the challenges of family life while making you laugh throughout. The story follows a struggling pot dealer, David (played by Jason Sudeikis), who creates a fake family as part of his plan to transport a large amount of marijuana across the country. He is forced to rethink his decision after finding an actual family to go in for the deal, and ends up on a road trip with them. This movie features an all-star cast, including Jennifer Aniston, Emma Roberts, and Will Poulter. It's a must-see for fans of comedy!

The film is a rollercoaster ride of clever deception and intrigue, with a twisting and turning plot that will keep viewers guessing until the very end. The cast is fantastic, with Jesse Eisenberg, Woody Harrelson, and Mark Ruffalo giving standout performances. The film's premise is inventive and unique, and the action sequences are thrilling and suspenseful. However, the film's conclusion feels a bit anticlimactic and leaves some questions unanswered. Nonetheless, "Now You See Me" is a fun and entertaining heist film that will keep audiences engaged from beginning to end. 

Would you like to know anything else about this film?

The Sound of Music is a classic family film about love, hope, and finding where you belong. The film is a heartwarming story of Maria, a young woman studying to become a nun who is sent to take care of the seven mischievous children of Captain Von Trapp. Captivated by the beauty of the Austrian Alps, Maria teaches the children to sing and brings joy and laughter back into the family home. However, as the Nazis occupy Austria, Captain Von Trapp joins the resistance and brings his family along as they escape across the mountains. With its unforgettable songs like "My Favorite Things," "Do-Re-Mi," and "Climb Ev'ry Mountain," this film will have you tapping your foot along with the music and cheering for the Von Trapp family as they find their way home.

The 2012 kid's movie 'Rio' starring Jesse Eisenberg, Anne Hathaway, and Jamie Foxx, deserves 5/5 stars for its stunning animation, vibrant colors, and valuable life lessons taught throughout the movie. 

As Blu, a domesticated macaw from Minnesota, is suddenly forced to fly to Rio de Janeiro to meet the first female bird he has ever seen, Jewel. However, Blu has never flown before and hurts his human owner's chances of going to Rio with him to save the rainforest. This movie takes you on a fun-filled adventure following these two birds as they learn about love, friendship, and the importance of preserving the environment. 

Not only is this movie entertaining for children and families, but it also showcases a beautiful representation of Latin culture. The vibrant colors of Brazil and Latin music make this movie a celebration of culture. 

Overall, 'Rio' is a must-watch, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and meaningful movie for the whole family.

The movie Saturday Night Fever is a classic story of a young man's journey to find his place in the world. I really like movies that make you realize that families aren't always biological, and 'August Rush' does that in a beautiful way. "From Here to Eternity" is a classic film that captures the essence of war and the price of its mortal toll. The film tells the story of a group of soldiers stationed in Hawaii on the eve of Pearl Harbor, and the events that follow the attack. It is a story of love, loss, and the human condition. 

The film is directed by Fred Zinnemann and stars Burt Lancaster, Montgomery Clift, and Deborah Kerr. The film is known for its intense and emotional performances, as well as its stunning cinematography. The film was nominated for eight Academy Awards and won for its adapted screenplay. 

"From Here to Eternity" is a must-see film that has stood the test of time. Its powerful message and unforgettable performances make it a classic.

Having witnessed the safe landing of US Airways Flight 1549, under the guidance of Captain Chesley Sullenberger, the movie takes us through the investigation of the incident and personal struggles of its protagonist. The movie "Train to Busan" is a heart-pounding, armrest-gripping, and adrenaline-pumping experience. From the opening scene to the final frame, the film keeps you on the edge of your seat and leaves you breathless.

The story follows a group of passengers on a train from Seoul to Busan who find themselves trapped in a living nightmare as a zombie outbreak sweeps the country. The film showcases the raw, visceral horror of the zombie apocalypse while also exploring the humanity and bravery of its characters.

The cast is stellar, with standout performances from Gong Yoo and Jung Yu-mi. They bring depth and humanity to their characters, making it easy to root for them and care about their fate.

The action sequences are expertly choreographed and executed, with nail-biting tension and breathtaking visuals. The film's pacing is also top-notch, with a perfect balance of horror, action, and character development.

Overall, "Train to Busan" is a must-see film for fans of horror and action. It is a thrilling, emotional, and ultimately satisfying experience that will leave you craving more.

Overall, Ford v Ferrari is a enjoyable movie. It has many elements of an inspirational drama with a touch of automobile racing. It seems to straddle the line between inspirational drama and full on racing movie, and not fully commit to either. It is not as inspirational as other movies in the genre such as Secretariat or Dream Big, and it is not as focused on the racing as movies like Rush or Speed Racer. It has a bit of a "based on a true story" feel to it, which can be disappointing if you are expecting a lot of accurate details about either the Ford or Ferrari companies, or the racing scene of the 1960s. Conversely it is refreshing if you are looking for a loosely inspired story about teamwork, perseverance, and accomplishing the impossible. 

The movie is well cast. Matt Damon and Christian Bale are both very good in the film, and do a great job of portraying the rivalry between the Ford and Ferrari companies. It is also well directed, with some beautiful shots of the cars and the racing scenes. The sound editing and mixing are also very well done, making the racing scenes feel intense and immersive. 

Overall, Ford v Ferrari is a good movie but it could have been better. It had the potential to be a great movie, but it fell a bit short of that mark in my opinion.

Lucky Number Slevin is a stylish and witty film that manages to combine elements of crime, comedy and mystery to create a unique and entertaining experience.

The film adaptation of Stephen King's "It" is a masterful combination of horror, comedy, and tragedy. This movie takes a deep dive into the lives of seven childhood friends who are haunted by a shape-shifting entity, personifying their worst fears. This entity, often taking the form of a sinister clown named Pennywise, forces these kids to confront their deepest insecurities and face their worst nightmares. 

The film excels in its portrayal of the friendship between the seven main characters. The chemistry between them feels genuine, and their interactions are both hilarious and heartbreaking. The audience is left rooting for them to overcome their fears and defeat Pennywise, who is constantly lurking in the background. 

However, the true star of the show is Bill Skarsgrd's performance as Pennywise. His portrayal of the sinister clown is both terrifying and mesmerizing. He manages to make the audience feel a deep sense of fear and unease, while also making them laugh with his comedic timing.

Overall, "It" is a must-watch for fans of the horror genre. It is a film that will keep viewers on the edge of their seats, while also delivering a powerful message about the power of friendship and the strength of the human spirit.

The movie Gladiator deserves a 5-star rating for its epic battle scenes and captivating story. The film, directed by Ridley Scott, follows the journey of Maximus, a powerful Roman general who is betrayed by the emperor and forced to become a gladiator. As he fights for his life in the colosseum, Maximus must also battle the evil emperor's son, who is determined to take over the empire. 

The film features incredible performances from Russell Crowe as Maximus and Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus, the emperor's son. Both actors bring depth and complexity to their roles, making them some of the most memorable characters in the film. 

In addition to its stellar performances, Gladiator also features stunning visuals and incredible action sequences. The film's battle scenes, which take place in the colosseum and across the Roman countryside, are expertly choreographed and executed, making them some of the most thrilling and exciting sequences in the film. 

Overall, Gladiator is a must-see film that deserves its 5-star rating for its epic battles, captivating story, and outstanding performances.

The Cabin in the Woods is a cleverly crafted and thoroughly entertaining film that turns the typical horror movie tropes on their head. It begins much like any other horror film, with a group of five college friends heading to a remote cabin in the woods for a weekend of fun and relaxation. However, it quickly becomes clear that this is not your average horror film. Instead of relying on cheap scares and gore, the film takes a more nuanced and intellectual approach to the genre. 

The film is filled with plenty of twists and turns that keep viewers on the edge of their seats. The plot is well-paced and moves along at a steady clip, with each reveal adding a new layer of complexity to the story. The acting is solid across the board, with each member of the cast bringing their own unique flair to their respective characters. 

What sets The Cabin in the Woods apart from other horror films is its willingness to break the fourth wall and directly address the audience. This technique adds a layer of metafiction to the film, forcing viewers to consider their own role in the genre. It is a refreshing and unique approach that is sure to please fans of the genre. 

Overall, The Cabin in the Woods is a fun and engaging film that offers a fresh and unique take on the horror genre. With its clever writing, solid acting, and clever use of metafiction, it is sure to please fans of the genre.

The movie is non-stop action, with virtually no let up. It's well directed and the actors, particularly Vin Diesel, do a good job. I just saw Iron Man 3 and it was amazing! It's been ten years since Tony Stark announced himself as Iron Man to the world and forever changed the landscape of superhero movies. Iron Man 3 is a much more personal film than its predecessors, with Tony Stark's struggles and insecurities taking center stage. The Witch is a movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Its portrayal of witchcraft and the occult, together with its realistic and gritty portrayal of 17th-century life in New England, creates an atmosphere that is both captivating and chilling.

The movie follows a family who are exiled from their plantation and forced to live in the wilderness. The family encounters a variety of terrifying and dangerous events, including the disappearance of their baby and the emergence of a witch in the woods. The movie's exploration of themes such as fear, suspicion, and the fragility of faith adds depth and complexity to its narrative.

The Witch is a movie that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Its combination of a strong narrative, a powerful atmospheric, and a thought-provoking exploration of its themes makes it a must-see for fans of horror and drama.

The filmmaker dissects American imperialism and racism Albini, Da 5 Bloods is about the exploitation and marginalization that people of color experience in a white-dominated world, but it's also about how these characters fight back against their marginalization and attempt to take charge of their own destinies. There are moments of incredible tension and stark violence, but the film's sober and intelligent approach to these subjects makes it one of the most vital and important films of the year.

The film is an insightful look into the female experience, both in and out of the workplace, and the challenges of balancing the two. The acting is top-notch, with Jessica Alba giving a particularly powerful performance as the film's protagonist. The film's message is both timely and important, and it is a must-see for anyone interested in films that tackle complex issues with intelligence and sensitivity. Having thoroughly documented the history of the Cuban missile crisis, Roger Mudd presents a crisp, coherent, and occasionally hortatory account of the decisive week in October 1962, when the fate of the world hinged on the decisions made by John F. Kennedy and his advisers. Against the backdrop of rising Cold War tensions and some aggressively rash moves by the Soviet Union, Mudd describes in exhaustive detail the developments of those thirteen days, culminating in the quarantine of Cuba and the Soviet decision to back down. This is history as it should be written--fast-paced, insightful, and unerringly fair-minded.

In "Meet Joe Black," a mysterious man (Brad Pitt) materializes in the lives of a widower (Anthony Hopkins) and his daughter (Claire Forlani) with the promise of teaching them lessons in how to live. Looking like a glam rock God with his white-blonde hair and shimmering cloak, he proceeds to seduce the daughter while comforting the father in his grief, soon revealing his true mission and threatening to tear the father-daughter duo apart. It's a twisted take on "It's a Wonderful Life," and, despite a few slow spots and an over-the-top denouement, it's a smart, sensitively directed drama with a few neat surprises. And Pitt is astonishing. He dominates every frame with a performance that's both physical and ethereal, giving a virtuoso, shape-shifting display of acting. At times he's playful and gentle, at others commanding and ominous, and he makes the transition from one to the other seamless. Hopkins, Forlani, and Jake Weber (as her boyfriend) are all excellent, too, and the sparse, shimmering photography is stunning.

The movie was directed by Brian De Palma and starred Tom Hanks, Edward Burns, and John Heard. It received generally positive reviews from critics and was a commercial success, grossing $47 million against a $15 million budget.

The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a joyful and uproarious adventure that triumphs despite its unconventional plot and characterization. Along the way, they encounter a series of colorful characters and learn valuable lessons about love, friendship, and the meaning of family.

The film's message of acceptance and understanding is one that resonates deeply, and it is a testament to the power of storytelling to open minds and hearts. The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a must-see for fans of unconventional cinema and anyone looking for a fun and uplifting adventure.

The movie 127 Hours is an incredible journey through the human spirit's ability to survive. It is a true story of a man who is trapped in a canyon while hiking alone and the struggles he faces to survive. Overall, 127 Hours is a must-see movie. It is a powerful and moving story about the human spirit's ability to survive, and it is a testament to the strength of the human will.

Now that's what I call a proper action film. Bruce Willis is back as John McClane, the New York cop who is tough as nails and as smart as a fox. This time, McClane must face a group of cyber terrorists who are trying to bring down the United States. They use their computer skills to take control of vital infrastructure, including power plants and traffic lights. It's up to McClane to stop them before it's too late.

The movie is packed with thrilling action sequences, including a spectacular helicopter chase. The cast is top-notch, with Bruce Willis giving an excellent performance as always. The movie is also smart and witty, with plenty of humor to keep things light. If you're a fan of action movies, then "Live Free or Die Hard" is a must-see.

Humbling former NFL star quarterback Paul "Wrecking Ball" Crewe (Adam Sandler) serves jail time for his involvement in a violent brawl. While incarcerated, Crewe struggles to adapt to his new surroundings and goes head-to-head with the prison's corrupt warden (James Cromwell), who forces him to assemble a football team to take on the prison's existing team, putting Crewe's skills and his teammates' lives at stake.

Trying to recap the plot of "Donnie Darko" is exercises in futility. Honestly, it's almost better going in knowing as little as possible. The less you know, the more you'll appreciate the masterful way its twists and turns unfold.

The basic premise? A disturbed teenager named Donnie (played by a very young Jake Gyllenhaal) is haunted by a man in a terrifying rabbit suit, who convinces him that the world is going to end in 28 days.

From there, "Donnie Darko" descends into anarchy. cloned pets, time travel, frank discussions of existentialism, and a dangerously healthy dose of teen angst converge to create one of the most unique, challenging, and thought-provoking films of the last 20 years.

Is it all an hallucination? Did Donnie actually travel through time to prevent the apocalypse? Did the rabbit suit guy cause it all?

"Donnie Darko" doesn't provide many answers because it doesn't have to. It forces us to confront our own fears, insecurities, and notion of destiny. Then it kicks us in the teeth with the unavoidable truth that sometimes, stuff just happens. And there's nothing we can do about it. At least not until it's too late.

I really enjoyed this film. It's a great coming-of-age movie and provides an interesting look at the origins of skateboarding culture. The acting was good and the story was interesting. It also has a great soundtrack. I would recommend this film to anyone who is interested in skateboarding or coming-of-age stories. As a caution, the mature content makes this film a hard sell for an underage audience, so a parent might consider giving it a watch before deciding if it's appropriate for the whole family.

Still dazzlingly on form after 15 years, Michelle Pfeiffer shines in this engrossing, elegantly-realised sequel to Batman (1989).

Along with a typically committed performance from Michael Keaton as the Caped Crusader - despite initially struggling to shake off his prior role as Beetlejuice - Pfeiffer's feline feline villainess, Catwoman, is the main attraction.

With her razor-sharp claws and even sharper wit, she proves a formidable opponent for both the Dark Knight and, in an unexpectedly hilarious scene, steals the show from the egomaniacal, over-the-top Penguin (Danny DeVito).

Though its story might not be quite as strong as the previous film, Batman Returns benefits from a darker, more sophisticated tone and some dazzling set pieces, including a breathtaking rooftop chase and an exhilarating climax atop a giant snowflake tower.

Along with a typically stellar cast and some brilliant action sequences, the film's strong emotional core and intelligent, knowing humour ensure it remains a thrilling watch.

There are films which attempt to tackle the interplay of ideology, greed, and self-interest and there are films whose depth and visceral imagery can only be matched by the ramifications of their subject matter. There Will Be Blood is one of the rare films that managed to impress upon me both simultaneously.

Paul Thomas Anderson achieves a cinematic nirvana in There Will Be Blood with a deep focus on the intricacies of human character and a steady detachment from the simplicities of plot. This is a film infused with philosophical heft and the weight of its own introspection, featuring a career-best performance from Daniel Day-Lewis, who is devastating in his portrayal of Daniel Plainview, and a mesmerizing turn from Paul Dano. It is a film suffused with Biblical allusions and an awe-inspiring score from Jonny Greenwood that sounds like nothing else. And it is a film of unforgettable moments, the canvas too broad for the finer details to ever fade from memory. A masterpiece.

The Great Dictator is a brilliant, satirical masterpiece of a movie. It is a film that is equal parts hilarious and heartbreaking, a film that is as relevant now as it was when it was released in 1940.

The story follows the rise and fall of a ruthless, dictator named Adenoid Hynkel, whose oppressive regime has turned the country into a dystopian nightmare. The film is a searing indictment of totalitarianism and the dangers of blind obedience to authority.

The comedy in the film is dark and biting, and the acting is top-notch. Charlie Chaplin is superb as Adenoid Hynkel, and the supporting cast is also excellent.

The Great Dictator is a film that will make you laugh, make you cry, and make you think. It is a film that is as relevant now as it was when it was released, and one that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

The Witch is a movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Its a suspenseful movie about a brood of witches in a realistic depiction of 17th century New England. Its a fascinating tale of suspicion, paranoia, and witchcraft. 

The movie follows a farming family who are banished from their plantation and forced to live in the wilderness. Is the isolation and harshness of their new surroundings causing the family to unravel? Or is it something far more sinister? 

The film is a great example of atmospheric horror. The cinematography and sound design work together to create a sense of unease and foreboding. The acting is also top-notch, with the entire cast giving convincing performances. 

Overall, The Witch is a gripping and unsettling movie. Its a great choice for anyone who enjoys a good scare.

Few movies scream " EXEPTION" from the typical biographical comedy than "Man on the Moon.", the story of Andy Kaufman told by Jim Carrey.

This movie fires on every possible level. The story, direction, and especially the acting are far and away the best I've seen in a comedy of this type. It's impossible to watch this movie and not laugh your tail off, while at the same time being so moved that there aren't many movies you'll ever see that will make you cry harder. 

I still can't believe Jim Carrey didn't win an Oscar for this role. In fact, this movie has SO many great performances it's just packed with them. The only small flaw in this movie is Carol Cole's portrayal of Lynne Margulies. It wasn't bad, it was just the only performance that didn't seem to transcend the typical expectations for a movie of this type. Still, she was good in the role.

If you haven't seen this movie, you need to stop what you're doing and watch it right now. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll be entertained. This movie has it all.

Sure! Here is the body of an IMDb review for the movie "Coco":

Through its evocative storytelling, "Coco" dives into a world populated by the memories of loved ones and the mysteries of ancestry. As young Miguel journeys into the Land of the Dead, he uncovers family history and reconnects with long-lost relatives. The film's celebration of Mexican culture is a treat, expressed through vibrant visuals and a captivating soundtrack that draws on the rich heritage of Mexican music. With its heartfelt themes of family, legacy, and following your dreams, "Coco" delivers a resonant and emotionally powerful story that captures the full range of the human experience. It is a must-watch for audiences of all ages.

The movie "Sausage Party" is a hilarious and irreverent comedy that takes a unique approach to adult animation. The story follows a group of sausages who live in a supermarket and are eager to be chosen by a customer and brought to the great beyond (aka outside of the supermarket). The film features a star-studded cast including Seth Rogen, Kristen Wiig, and Jonah Hill. 

The animation is incredibly well done and the characters are incredibly relatable. The story is both hilarious and thought-provoking, and the film's message is one that will stay with you long after you leave the theater. Whether you're a fan of adult animation or just looking for a good laugh, "Sausage Party" is a must-see.

The film depicts the life of Howard Hughes, a reclusive, obsessive-compulsive billionaire with a primary focus on his air- enthusiasms. So we see Hughes as an airplane designer whose most famous creation is the magnificent H-1 hydroplane racer. We see him as a pioneer in aviation, as he strives to break speed records. Most of all, we see Hughes as a manic-depressive who has tacitly chosen to exile himself from mainstream society and decline into a haunting, harrowing isolation.

The acting is first-rate. Leonardo DiCaprio delivers a grand performance, committing himself to the challenging task of portraying an enigmatic, contradictory personality. Cate Blanchett gives an outstanding performance as Katharine Hepburn, capturing the actress's flinty, feisty, larger-than-life personality. 

The film itself traverses the boundaries of factual history and gripping drama. The Aviator is an astonishing, superb film: captivating, absorbing, and visually stunning.

It's a wonderful film. It's adventurous and thrilling with a touch of comedy which makes it a perfect movie for all ages. It's always interesting to watch Alice embark on yet another quest, to find herself having a conversation with a rabbit about a race while she herself is late for a very important date. The twist is always unexpected and catches you off guard every time. Looking forward to another adventure with Alice and her friends.

The film is a thrilling ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. It's a true story of determination and perseverance, with a cast that delivers powerful performances. 

The film follows the story of two men, Carroll Shelby and Ken Miles, who are tasked with building a car that can beat the legendary Ferrari race team. It's a story of innovation and engineering, as the two men work to create a car that is both fast and reliable. 

The film also explores the personal sacrifices that the two men make in order to achieve their dream. It's a story of passion and determination, and it's sure to inspire audiences. Overall, the film is a thrilling and inspiring ride that will leave you wanting more.

Unable to discern between reality and fantasy, Edith Piaf's life was shrouded in anecdotes, capped by her death in her forties due to years of substance abuse. She was a true phoenix, rising from the ashes again and again. Her gravelly, haunting voice reflected her life story in its depth and passion; she modulated effortlessly from a whispered confession to a full-throated roar, often within the same song. Her life and art were one, the music flowing from her as a river flows to the sea. 

Frnois Ozon's "La Vie en Rose" is the story of that life, as seen through the eyes of Piaf herself. It is a subjective narrative, a fragmented series of memories and images, some no more than a shot or two, others lingering. When Piaf (portrayed as a child by Mariannel Elie) is thrown atop a pile of refuse, the audience doesn't see it happen; they see the result, Piaf buried, desperately trying to push her way to the surface for a breath of air. A hand reaches down, pulls her out. The hand belongs to Mother Superior (Helena Noguerra), who takes the young girl to the convent. The viewer doesn't see the sequence of events that led to the infant's abandonment; what's important is the result, and the forgiveness that follows. The past isn't investigated; it is evoked. 

The entire film is constructed in this fashion. When Piaf (played as an adult by Marion Cotillard) has a breakdown on stage, the audience doesn't see her disintegrate; they see the audience' reaction, and the reflection in the mirror of her dressing room. The camera holds on the stunned faces of the audience members, then slowly tracks to the right, following the reflection in the mirror. The audience sees itself, reflected in the mirror, watching the action. The viewer is included in the action, part of the audience watching Piaf's breakdown. The camera continues to track to the right, and the audience watches as Piaf's manager, Raymond (Louis-Do de Lencquesaing), walks to the mirror, follows the reflection to the right, and exits the frame. The audience is left alone in the theater with Piaf. 

This inventive, poetic style is perfect for the story being told, giving the sense of a life without chronological order, a life perceived as a series of vivid images and emotions. The viewer is not given the entire story --

The movie is a classic. It has a great story, and the acting is top-notch. It adequately portrays the griminess of the city these "heroes" operate within, a refreshing change from other more "family-friendly" versions of these characters. It knows when to be funny and when to be serious. However, the movie's biggest strength is its characters. 

These "Suicide Squad" members are nuts, and Hamada delivers impressive performances from top to bottom. From Margot Robbie's gleefully evil Harley Quinn to Viola Davis's no-nonsense approach to commanding a team of convicts, every actor shines. But Joel Kinnaman deserves special mention for his rendition of a man trapped in a terrible superhero costume. 

The movie's not perfect. It's overlong and the final battle feels like it's been lifted straight out of a Transformers film. But these minor flaws don't matter because the characters are so damn fun. There are flashes of brightness throughout, indicating a unique visual approach to the well-known comic universe. 

Overall, "The Suicide Squad" is an unexpected treat and a return to form for the franchise.

IMDb reviews for movies are short, and aim to summarise the highlights of a film. Here is an example of a possible review for the movie Terminator 2: Judgment Day:

"James Cameron's sequel to his own sci-fi/action hit is a superb example of a film that improves on the original in every way. The special effects are even more incredible, the action sequences are even more thrilling, and the performances are even more powerful. Arnold Schwarzenegger gives an even better performance here than in the first film, and Linda Hamilton is superb as Sarah Connor, showing great emotional range and depth. The film's plot is clever and imaginative, and the direction is taut and efficient. This is a great sci-fi/action film and an excellent sequel."

No way this movie skips the top spot in my list of favorite movies of all time. This is such a powerful true story of the legendary law clerk Erin Brockovich and her small-town legal firm against the huge Pacific Gas and Electric Company. Having lived in that area of California myself, it is jaw-dropping how this story took place right in my backyard. The fantastic performance by Julia Roberts spices up this already amazing true story. This movie goes through several emotions with her and her team working tireless hours trying to figure out clues leading to their big case while dealing with hardships happening in their personal lives. This is one of those movies I could watch over and over again and recommend it to anyone who is interested in a true story about an everyday working-class hero. This movie deserves all the awards it got and then some.

The movie is a classic. It's a fascinating view of a dystopian future and presents a very interesting concept of a society governed by violence. The movie follows Alex, a young delinquent who is subjected to a psychological conditioning technique called Ludovico technique. This technique is designed to eliminate his violent impulses. He is then released from prison and monitored as he re-adjusts to society. 

The movie is a classic and is a must-watch for fans of science fiction and Stanley Kubrick. The performances of the actors, particularly Malcolm McDowell as Alex, are excellent. Despite the absence of a typical plot structure owing to the non-linear narrative, the movie is a compelling watch.

Robert De Niro portrays Jake LaMotta, a middleweight boxer struggling to come to terms with his brother and his wife. It's a performance that encapsulates the brutality, the intensity, and the vanity of the boxing world. It is also a study of a man who is vicious and brutal, both in and out of the ring. De Niro perfectly captures LaMotta's self-destructive side, as he batters his wife and brutally beats up a stranger in a nightclub. And he also captures the athlete's self-delusion, his belief that he can make a comeback as a boxer when he is clearly past his prime.

The film itself is gripping. It's a brutal and unrelenting portrayal of the boxing world, as well as the toll that it takes on its participants. It's also a visually stunning film, with director Martin Scorsese using a variety of techniques to create a vivid and intense portrait of LaMotta's life. 

Whether you're a fan of sports movies or not, Raging Bull is a classic film that is both deeply moving and thought-provoking.

The film opens with a group of friends traveling home from a wedding. While the bride and groom are on their honeymoon, the friends decide to play a game, with the prize being a night with the friend of their choosing. The friends agree to participate in this game, and the film follows their interactions as they try to win the game. 

The friends include Dylan, the bride's brother, who is a successful businessman. He is engaged to Claire, a wealthy and beautiful woman. There is also Jamie, Dylan's brother, who is an unemployed slacker. Jamie has a one-night stand with Mia, a free-spirited and spontaneous woman. The group also includes Andy, who is a successful lawyer. He is dating Alice, a beautiful and intelligent woman who is also Dylan's ex-girlfriend. 

As the friends attempt to win the game, they begin to realize that the night is not as innocent as they thought. The film follows their journey as they try to make the most of their night together, and as they begin to question their relationships and their future. 

The film is a lighthearted and fun-filled romantic comedy. It is a great choice for a date night or a girls' night out. It is a film that will make you laugh, cry, and cheer for the characters as they find their way through their relationships.

Sure! Here is the body of an IMDb review for the movie *Donnie Brasco*:

In the 1990s, the FBI sends an undercover agent, Donnie Brasco, to penetrate the Mafia. The story, based on a true story, centers on how difficult it is for Donnie to balance his family life and his job as an undercover agent. The tremendous performance by Johnny Depp deserves an Oscar. It's too bad Al Pacino didn't have a larger role. He is excellent as the Mafia leader who takes a liking to Donnie. But despite a runtime of two hours, the movie moves at a fast pace and is engaging from beginning to end. This movie deserves an 8 out of 10.

The film is a modern reboot of the classic Marvel comic book series, telling the story of four young friends who are exposed to a mysterious substance that grants them each incredible superpowers. Reed Richards gains the ability to stretch his body to inhuman lengths, Sue Storm can turn invisible and create force fields, Johnny Storm gains the power of fire, and Ben Grimm emerges as a super-strong rock creature.

The movie follows the group as they learn to master their new powers and cope with the pressures of being celebrities. They must also face a group of evil aliens who are intent on destroying Earth.

The cast is excellent, with Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan, and Jamie Bell all giving standout performances. The special effects are also top-notch, with the film's visuals consistently impressing.

However, the film's plot is fairly standard for a superhero movie and there are some logic issues throughout. The movie also suffers from a lack of character development, as the audience never gets to know the characters on a deeper level.

Overall, "Fantastic Four" is a fun and enjoyable superhero movie that is worth watching, but it could have been even better with a more thoughtful and nuanced approach to the story and characters.

I recently watched the movie "Horrible Bosses" and was thoroughly entertained by this hilarious and timely comedy. The film centers around three friends who are each struggling with their own terrible bosses. Needing a way to get away from their bosses, they decide to embark on a criminal enterprise that has unintended consequences.
