Having revived the evil spirits of the Necronomicon in the forest during an unsuccessful exorcism, Sally and her friends are haunted by evil entities that possess each of them, forcing them to participate in a violent struggle for survival as they face their own deaths.

The film follows the story of a fictional NFL team, the Miami Sharks, and their coach, Tony D'Amato, as they struggle to overcome a poor start to the season. The film features an all-star cast, including Al Pacino, Jamie Foxx, and Cameron Diaz, and is directed by Oliver Stone.

"Any Given Sunday" is a thrilling and emotional film that captures the intensity and passion of the NFL. The film's cast is superb, and the direction is top-notch. It's a must-see for football fans and non-fans alike.

Despite being flawed by an overly-complex plot, Howl's Moving Castle is a fun, fantastical adventure. Incredible animation quality compensates for a simple story and bare-bones characters. The plot and setting will be too much for younger kids, but teenagers and adults will enjoy imaginative creatures and surprising story developments.

Without the late great Daniel Craig, this latest installment in the James Bond series would suffer in comparison to its predecessors. It's not that Craig saves this film, but rather that he elevates the action and story beyond the norm for this franchise. 

Too often, the Bond films rely on the charisma and charm of its leading man to make up for a lack of compelling storytelling. While the scripts for the previous two films, "Casino Royale" (2006) and "Quantum of Solace" (2008), managed to pair well-choreographed action sequences with a believable, emotional bond between Bond and his love interest, "Skyfall" relies much more on the former than the latter. 

This film feels at once fresh and nostalgic. It's exhilarating to see Craig's Bond deliver both irreverent one-liners and bone-crunching hand-to-hand combat. But the film also marks the return of a familiar Bond villain: Silva, a former MI6 agent who turns traitor and becomes a deadly adversary with a personal vendetta against M. 

The best way to describe "Skyfall" is a return to form for the Bond franchise. It feels like a throwback to the classic films of the 1960s and '70s, with an emphasis on character development and storytelling. And for that reason, it may also be the best Bond film since "Goldfinger" (1964).

The Proposal is an amusing comedy film led by impressive performances from its well-chosen cast.rouse laughter and emotion in a lighthearted but meaningful way. With a star-studded cast including Sandra Bullock, Betty White, and Neil Patrick Harris, the film's performances shine through as its strongest aspect. 

The plot follows a boss who convinces her assistant to enter into a fake marriage after her visa expires and she faces possible deportation back to Canada. Despite some clichd moments and an unlikely storyline, the chemistry between the two leads keeps the plot engaging and fun. 

Overall, The Proposal is a light and enjoyable romantic comedy with two attractive leads and an intelligent, quick-witted script. While it may not stand out among other classic romantic comedies, it is a worthwhile watch for fans of the genre.

The movie Deadpool is an amazing film that will have you laughing throughout. It has a great plot with lots of action and fighting scenes, as well as plenty of funny moments that will keep you entertained. The actors did an incredible job portraying their characters, and the film's visuals were stunning. Overall, Deadpool is a must-see movie that will leave you wanting more.

I really liked this movie. It had a great cast and a really interesting story. The chemistry between the two leads was excellent, and the soundtrack was amazing. OsmanAbbasali absolutely crushed it with this movie. This is definitely a movie that I would recommend to others. There were some really intense parts and other parts that were more lighthearted. It has a little bit of something for everyone.

The movie starts with the gang preparing for Doug's (Justin Bartha) wedding. The trio of Phil (Bradley Cooper), Stu (Ed Helms) and Alan (Zach Galifianakis) take a road trip to Las Vegas for Doug's bachelor party. Of course, they wake up the next day and have no clue what happened the night before. 

One of the movie's most iconic scenes is when the trio wakes up in their hotel room and sees the wreck they made: clothes and cards scattered on the floor, a tiger in the bathroom, and Doug missing. As they piece together the previous night's events, they realize they went on a wild journey through Las Vegas that involved drugs, a tattoo parlor, a police station, a wedding chapel, a gang of criminals, and a missing tooth for Stu.

As they try to find Doug before his wedding, the guys get into several misadventures, including getting high with a stranger, getting into a car accident, and getting into a fight with a pack of dogs. Their journey takes them to a variety of locations around Las Vegas, including a chapel, a house, and a golf course.

Is it just me, or does it seem that The Hangover trilogy is one of the most iconic movie franchises of the 2010s? Every time I re-watch these movies, I discover something new about the characters that I love. Not to mention that this movie is also a who's who of famous celebrities. For example, Mike Tyson plays an inmate who was briefly imprisoned due to wilding out at Stu's face. 

In conclusion, The Hangover is a hilarious and wildly entertaining movie that features a great performance by the cast. It's a must-see for fans of comedy and anyone looking for a good time. Just remember to always keep an eye on your friends because you never know what kind of trouble you'll get into the night before!

The film "Wedding Crashers" is a hilarious and heartwarming comedy about the adventures of two friends who crash weddings for fun, until they meet the sisters of the bride-to-be and discover that there's more to crashing weddings than just having fun.

The film is directed by David Dobkin and stars Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn as the intrepid wedding crashers. Together, they form a hilarious duo, skillfully navigating their way through a series of outrageous situations, from awkward exchanges with strangers to dancing with beautiful women. As the movie progresses, the pair become involved in a more serious story when they meet the sisters of the bride-to-be, played by Rachel McAdams and Isla Fisher.

The supporting cast is also notable, including wedding guests such as Bradley Cooper, Tipper Gore, and Dwight Howard. The movie also features cameos from celebrities such as Kanye West and Stephen Colbert.

Overall, "Wedding Crashers" is a hilarious and heartwarming comedy that will have you laughing and rooting for the characters from beginning to end.

Although the violence depicted in war movies is often grim and brutal, Hacksaw Ridge stands out by presenting it in a graphic and overtly gruesome manner. While this approach established a refreshing contrast with the typical restraint employed by directors of WWII films, the violence itself became gratuitous and distracting from the main story. It seemed as though the filmmakers wanted to shock the audience with extremity, undermining the emotional impact of the narrative. Overall, the movie left me with a disappointing aftertaste, as I felt that the excessive focus on gore distracted from the intended tribute to the veterans' bravery and sacrifice.

The movie is aptly named due to the main characters repeatedly being stopped from completing their mission, going home, and in one case even being stopped from leaving. Arnie, playing Specialist Town, is frustrated by the military's use of Stop-Loss, which in this movie is indefinitely extending the time soldiers are deployed, despite a war which appears to have already been won. Specialists Ditz, played by Rami Malek, and Bale, played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt, serve as counterpoints to Town, providing moments of comic relief and lunacy throughout the movie. Town's fellow soldiers includeLim, played by Spike Jonze, who always seems to be around crazy events, and Rojas, played by Michael Pena, who is struggling with hearing loss. 

The movie begins with Town receiving news that his stop-loss has been activated again and he must return to Iraq. Meanwhile, back in the US, his girlfriend tells him she wants to break up due to his indefinite absence. Over in Iraq, Lim tells Town he found a UAV, or drone, and that there is a camera still attached to it. Later on, Town goes alone to a remote warehouse to investigate a possible weapons cache and instead finds a false wall with a hidden room. Within the room there is a mysterious, shrouded object. He calls in for backup but instead a bunch of insurgents arrive. After a lengthy gunfight, Town manages to escape with the object. Afterwards, he apologizes to his team for going off alone, but they dismiss it, relieved he is okay.

The object Town recovered turns out to be a body bag containing the remains of a pilot. Specialist612, played by Chris Evans, recognizes the pilot as a friend of his who was shot down recently. Town notices a webcam like device attached to the bag. Eventually, they find a USB drive attached to the device and plug it into a computer to see what is on it. The screen shows the pilot opening his eyes. Everyone is stunned, but it quickly becomes apparent the pilot is not actually alive. The pilot, upon hearing noise outside the bag, attempts to escape but is shot by the insurgents. The screen cuts to static and the pilot dies.

They take the pilot's body to a nearby medical facility. A local doctor, played by Martin Donovan, wants to inspect the body but Town protests, wanting to leave the body alone. The doctor eventually convinces Town to let him check the body and discovers that the pilot has been dead for about a week, which j

This movie has it all: action, intrigue, and a stellar cast. Gene Hackman and Michael Caine are at their absolute best, and the scenery is stunning. It's a rollercoaster ride from start to finish, with plenty of twists and turns to keep you guessing. The plot is tightly woven and offers a satisfying resolution. This is a must-see for fans of the genre. Considering when it was made, its gory action sequences have aged remarkably well.

In "From Dusk Till Dawn," Robert Rodriguez combines the thrills of a gangster film and the chills of a vampire movie. The result is an entertaining film with a unique combination of genres. 

The film follows the Gecko brothers, Seth and Richie, as they try to make their way out of a bank robbery and across the Mexican border, while being pursued by a group of supernatural beings, led by the powerful Master. The Geckos are aided in their escape by a mysterious woman named Luna, who has her own dark secrets.

The cast is strong, with George Clooney, Quentin Tarantino, and Harvey Keitel all giving excellent performances. The direction is also top-notch, with Rodriguez showing a keen eye for action and suspense. The film's visuals are also impressive, with the vampires' transformations and the overall look of the film being particularly striking.

Overall, "From Dusk Till Dawn" is a fun and exciting movie that offers a fresh take on the vampire genre. It's a must-watch for fans of both horror and crime movies.

The film is a gripping and emotional journey that explores the complexities of family, identity, and the consequences of war. It is a story that is both universal and deeply personal, and one that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

The acting in the film is top-notch, with the two leads giving powerful and moving performances. They are supported by a strong cast that includes veteran actors and rising stars.

The film's cinematography is stunning, with beautiful and evocative shots that capture the essence of the story and its settings. The score is equally impressive, with a haunting and emotional soundtrack that adds depth and emotion to the film.

"Incendies" is a film that will move and inspire you. It is a story of love, loss, and the power of the human spirit to endure and overcome even the most challenging of circumstances.

The Pianist is a beautifully crafted film that portrays the life of pianist Wadysaw Szpilman, who survived the Holocaust in Nazi-occupied Poland. The film is a testament to the power of the human spirit and the strength of the human will.

The film begins in Warsaw, Poland in 1939, where Szpilman (played by Adrien Brody) is a talented pianist and composer who is enjoying a successful career. However, with the onset of World War II, Poland is invaded and occupied by the Nazis. Szpilman and his family are forced to move into the Warsaw Ghetto, where they face brutal oppression and starvation. Despite these hardships, Szpilman continues to play piano, providing solace to himself and others.

As the situation in the ghetto worsens, Szpilman is forced to move to a concentration camp, where he is subjected to brutal torture and starvation. Yet, even in the darkest of times, Szpilman finds hope and strength in his music. He continues to play piano for his fellow prisoners, providing them with a moment of beauty and peace in the midst of their suffering.

The film concludes with Szpilman's liberation from the camp and his return to Warsaw. There, he is reunited with his family and begins to rebuild his life. Despite the horrors he has experienced, Szpilman continues to play piano, using his music to heal and inspire others.

The Pianist is a powerful and moving film that captures the strength of the human spirit and the power of music to heal and inspire. It is a testament to the resilience of the human will and the power of hope and courage in the face of adversity.

The movie "Transformers" is a classic for the ages. It's an epic adventure that takes you on a journey with unforgettable characters. The story is both engaging and thrilling, with plenty of action and fight scenes that are sure to keep you entertained from beginning to end. 

The acting in this movie is top-notch, with famous actors like Hanks and Pitt delivering powerful performances that add depth and emotion to the film. The visual effects are also incredible, with the Transformers themselves being brought to life in a way that is both awe-inspiring and terrifying. 

Overall, "Transformers" is a must-watch movie that will keep you entertained from beginning to end. It's the perfect film for both fans of the franchise and those who are new to the world of Transformers.

The movie is based on the true story of Jim White, the cross-country coach of the McFarland High School's cross-country team. The team became unified after White convinced the students that the united team could defeat the wealthy cross-country teams of larger cities. The students bonded together and became a family, which helped them win races and become state champions. 

The movie shows the importance of unity, family, and hard work. It is an inspiring and uplifting story that will leave you feeling hopeful and motivated. The acting was well done, and the story was well-written. Overall, it is a great movie that I would recommend to anyone.

The movie is about a group of American soldiers who are captured by the Germans during World War II. They are sent to a prison camp, where they meet a group of German soldiers who are also prisoners. The two groups of prisoners start playing football against each other, and they become friends. The movie is a classic example of how sports can bring people together. It's a touching and emotional story about the power of sports to heal old wounds and effect positive change in individuals. The performances of the actors, particularly the four main leads, are brilliant. Overall, an uplifting and humane film.

No introduction needed for La Vie En Rose, Gorgeously rendered and brilliantly performed, Marion Cotillard achieves something that I didn't think was possible anymore: She makes you care about a fictionalized version of a real person's life.

Cotillard plays Edith Piaf, the little sparrow, from her humble beginnings as a young girl singing on the streets of Paris to her rise as a music superstar. We see it all: her loves, her losses, her joys, and her pains. The film is a testament to the power of one person to overcome adversity through determination and passion.

The role of Piaf could have been an Oscar-winning performance, but it becomes so much more: a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for an actor to showcase their talent, their range, and their ability to embody a complex, multifaceted character.

The film itself is a masterpiece, with stunning visuals, a captivating story, and a soundtrack that will leave you humming along long after it has ended. La Vie En Rose is a must-see for fans of biopics, musical dramas, and anyone who loves a good story about overcoming the odds.

The film is a beautifully crafted and compelling portrayal of the Irish War of Independence and the subsequent Civil War, demonstrating a meticulous attention to historical detail and a nuanced understanding of the complexities of the conflict. 

The acting is top-notch, with an exceptional performance by Brendan Gleeson as the passionate and enigmatic revolutionary leader, Damien O'Donovan. Donal Gleeson also delivers a powerful performance as the young doctor, Tom Barry. 

The film's cinematography is stunning, with sweeping landscapes and intimate, emotional moments that capture the essence of the Irish countryside and the humanity of its characters. 

Overall, The Wind That Shakes the Barley is a thought-provoking and emotionally powerful film that explores the complexities of war, loyalty, and love, with exceptional acting and technical prowess.

Overall, I would recommend "Caddyshack." It's a hilarious golf comedy with a great all-star cast. Rodney Dangerfield's performance stands out as the arrogant, yet lovable, golf pro. The comedy is smart and holds up well after all these years. The con is the almost non-stop use of foul language which seems unnecessary and forced at times.

Without a doubt, "Hacksaw Ridge" can be considered one of the most intense and grueling war films to ever be produced, and that's all thanks to the insane dedication of its star, Andrew Garfield. The movie follows the true story of Desmond Doss, a man who served as a combat medic during the Battle of Okinawa in World War II, without bearing any kind of weapon. This, in itself, is an extraordinary tale of bravery, but what the film does exceptionally well is exposing the audience to the utter brutality of war, forcing us to endure it right alongside Doss as he saves an unfathomable number of lives. Garfield portrays the character with an astonishing degree of dedication, spending most of the film's runtime covered in blood and fighting with relentless intensity. It is an absolutely phenomenal performance that deserves to be recognized among the greatest ever recorded on screen. This film serves as a reminder that there are men and women of incredible valor scattered throughout history, whose courage and heroism define the very essence of humanity.

Rocky IV is a classic installment in the Rocky franchise, featuring the iconic fight between Rocky Balboa and Ivan Drago. The film centers on the rivalry between the two boxers, as they battle it out in the ring. It's a must-watch for fans of the franchise, as it features some of the most memorable moments in the series.

The film also features a cast of familiar faces, including Sylvester Stallone, Dolph Lundgren, and Carl Weathers. It's a great example of the classic 80s action movie, with plenty of fights and a compelling story.

Overall, Rocky IV is a great movie that is sure to please fans of the franchise. It has a great cast, an engaging story, and some of the most memorable moments in the series. If you're a fan of the Rocky movies, then this is a must-watch.

There are comedies, and there are comedies sharply attuned to the absurdities, horrors, and beauty of everyday life. Taika Waititi's Jojo Rabbit is the latter. This satire about Nazis eviscerates political evil through the everyday innocence of a child. It's a dangerous concept, absurdly and surprisingly executed with a fresh, energetic approach to how low-brow comedy should be executed. It's a film filled with humor and heart, and a lot of it stems from its star, Roman Griffin Davis. 

Out of all the things that constitute Taika Waititi's filmography, the one constant is that he always seems to find talent in youngsters. FromScout Troop to Ricky Baker, the kids are alright. Roman Griffin Davis steals the show as the titular Jojo. Unlike most coming-of-age stories, Jojo's journey to self-discovery is juxtaposed by an incredibly evil world. He is a bright soul in a dimming world. Each piece of dialogue he's given is perfectly constructed for a child's innocence, but cleverly points out the absurdity of the film's more sinister moments. From finding out the truth about Hitler to making a tough decision at a crossroads, every aspect of Davis' character arc is consistently surprising and smart. And the moments he shares with Rosie Collinge, who plays his on-screen sister, are incredibly believable and heartwarming. 

There's an incredibly fine line between humor and tragedy, and Taika Waititi walks it beautifully. There are instances where the film's comedy becomes incredibly bleak, and yet it always seems to pivot back to a place of hope. The story, while incredibly unique, does at times feel a bit too diluted. There are instances where the film's pacing feels slowed, ultimately making some of the film's reveals less impactful than they should be. The supporting characters, though performed by a fantastic ensemble, often fall into stereotypes, but that's ultimately pardoned by the performances of the young leads. 

Jojo Rabbit is a timely film, but hopefully never becomes untimely. It's a film that celebrates the beauty of diversity and encourages its audience to never let go of their humanity. It's a film that's tough to describe, but easy to enjoy. I've seen enough films this year to confidently say that it's one of the year's best.

Before starting, let's remember the genre of the movie. Grease is a romantic comedy released in 1978. The main story takes place in the 1950s and is about the love between two teenagers named Danny and Sandy. Already known as an iconic couple, their romance faces many obstacles, primarily because of the social gap between them and the expectations of their friends.

The movie starts with introducing us to Danny Zuko and his gang, the T-Birds, at Rydell High School. They are handsome, tough, and stick up for each other. Danny, played by John Travolta, is a cool, confident, and charming teenager. He has a strong presence and exudes charisma. From the start, we can tell he is the leader of the T-Birds. Then we meet Sandy Olsson, played by Olivia Newton-John, who just moved from Australia and is taken under the wing of the Pink Ladies, including Rizzo, the leader of the pack. From the first moment we see her, we understand that Sandy is a sweet, kind, and innocent girl. She has a bright, youthful appearance that captures the audience's attention.

The story advances, and we can see that Danny and Sandy have a lot in common, and eventually, they start dating. However, trouble arises when it's revealed that Sandy had lied about her background and is from a higher social status than Danny. This leads to tensions between the couple and their friends.

As the movie progresses, we see Danny and Sandy trying to overcome these obstacles and fighting for their love. They support each other and find ways to be together. The movie takes us on a journey of their relationship, showing us the challenges they face and the sacrifices they make for each other.

The cast of the movie is excellent. John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John have undeniable chemistry that makes their relationship believable and engaging. Their performances are captivating and memorable. The supporting characters are also well-cast and add depth and dimension to the story.

Overall, Grease is a classic romantic comedy that captures the essence of young love. Its memorable songs, lively dance numbers, and engaging story make it a timeless favorite. So that's why I think Grease deserves a high rating on IMDb.

The movie "Hero" is a great example of how to make a film that is both visually stunning and emotionally powerful. The story follows a young man who is struggling to come to terms with his past and find his place in the world. The film is full of beautiful shots of the Chinese countryside and the city of Beijing. The acting is top-notch, and the film's message is one that will stay with you long after you've left the theater. Highly recommended.

The film "Speed" is a fast-paced and thrilling action movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The story follows a group of passengers on a bus who are taken hostage by a criminal who sets off a bomb on the bus, forcing it to speed up to a constant rate of 80 miles per hour. The bus's speedometer is shown throughout the film, increasing the tension and adding to the sense of urgency. 

The bus's driver, Jack Traven (Keanu Reeves), does his best to keep the bus moving and protect the passengers, while also trying to negotiate with the criminal and figure out a way to save the day. The movie features a strong cast, including Reeves, Sandra Bullock, and Dennis Hopper, who all give memorable performances. 

The film's direction and cinematography are also notable, with the fast-paced action and intense scenes being well-crafted and executed. The film's score, composed by Alan Silvestri, adds to the excitement and tension of the movie. Overall, "Speed" is a must-see for fans of action movies, and its legacy has made it a classic in the genre.

( spoiler alert )
The movie Starts with a mysterious sender who wants to help lightning McQueen win again, he sends a high-tech vehicle to help him cheat. But when the vehicle arrives it is a female car named Fran. Fran soon starts developing her own conscience and helps Lightning McQueen lose instead, so that his rival doesn't win. #characterdevelopment. In the 2nd act, we see that the rival car has a hidden secret lab where he is creating enemy vehicles, the first one we see is a big truck. They have a pretty decent truck chase where Fran and Lightning use their fancy gadgets to dodge the trucks.
Eventually, they are captured and sent to the secret hideout. There is a big fight between all the vehicles where we learn that the enemy vehicles start to have feelings and join Lightning and Fran. The movie ends with all the vehicles making peace and becoming friends, and lightning figuring out that winning isn't everything.

I gave this movie a 5-star rating because there was a lot of character development, and the plot was exciting, with lots of action. This is a great movie for kids as well as adults, especially if you like cars and action.

Despite taking place almost entirely in Texas, 'Django Unchained' feels like it could be set in any state because its story is universal. It's a tale of a man trying to rescue the woman he loves, who has been unlawfully sold into slavery. That's a premise that transcends time and geography, and makes this film relevant to modern audiences. Yes, the film is violent and brutal. But it is also a powerful commentary on the evils of slavery. The characters are well-drawn and the acting is top-notch. This film is a must-see for fans of Westerns and action films.

After watching the film, I thought it was okay. The story was a bit all over the place occasionally feeling disconnected. The actions sequences were done well and there were some really good set pieces. The car chase was done really well and there was a great fight scene towards the end. 

The problem with having a familiar face like Tom Cruise is that the character becomes overshadowed by the star power. I feel as though the writing suffered when making this adaptation as I do not recall much of the source material having these kinds of plot holes and convenient setups. Either way, it was still entertaining and is worth a watch if it is on any streaming services you have.

The movie 300 is an epic graphic novel adaptation directed by Zack Snyder. It follows the story of King Leonidas, who led a group of 300 Spartan soldiers against the advancing Persians under King Xerxes.

The movie begins with the Persian army invading the coastal states of Greece and advancing towards the city of Athens. The Greek army, led by Spartan King Leonidas, decides to make a stand at the narrow Thermopylae pass, knowing that the Persians would have to fight them on their terms.

Throughout the movie, the audience is treated to breathtaking visuals and stunning action sequences. The movie accurately represents the graphic novel's dark and gritty tone, with the use of slow-motion and quick cuts enhancing the intense and brutal combat scenes. The characters are well-developed and the performances of the actors, especially Gerard Butler as Leonidas, are outstanding.

However, the movie has been criticized for its historical inaccuracies and its portrayal of the Spartans as nearly invincible super-soldiers. The movie takes significant creative licenses with the source material, and changes many key events and characters to fit the narrative.

Overall, 300 is a visually stunning and entertaining movie that captures the essence of the graphic novel. However, it is important to approach the movie with the knowledge that it is a fictionalized account of the historical events and not a completely accurate portrayal.

Watching Victory, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was watching a slightly worse version of Apollo 11. It attempts to tell the story of the race to space between the USA and the USSR from the start of the space race in 1957 until the USA's victory with the Apollo 11 mission in 1969, and it does so with a mixture of archival footage, newly shot dramatic footage, and interviews with people who were there. Unfortunately, while Apollo 11 had a clear focus on the people involved and their stories, Victory is content to just throw a bunch of facts at the viewer and hope that they stick. The end result is a film that feels both long and shallow, a disappointing and unintentional irony for a film about an important moment in human history. 

The film's archival footage is undoubtedly its best feature. Seeing the actual capsules that went into space, the mission control centers, and the other technological developments that made the space race possible is fascinating, and it's intriguing to see the people behind the scenes who made it all happen. Unfortunately, the dramatic re-enactments are often distracting from this archival footage and feel unnecessary. 

One of the biggest problems with the dramatic footage is the acting. Too often, it feels wooden and forced, with dialogue that sounds like it was written by a fifth-grader. It's unclear whether the script itself is to blame or if the actors simply aren't up to the task, but the end result is footage that is uncomfortable to watch and frequently takes you out of the film. 

Victory also feels oddly disjointed in how it tells the story of the space race. It jumps around from the USA to the USSR and back again, showing missions and developments in each country without much context. While this may be how the producers chose to structure the film, it does mean that the film lacks a consistent narrative throughline and instead feels like a series of loosely connected events. 

Overall, Victory is a disappointing and lackluster look at an important moment in human history. While its archival footage is fascinating, the poorly acted and written dramatic footage frequently takes you out of the film. Despite its lengthy two-hour-plus running time, the film feels rushed and disjointed, failing to truly explore the stories of the people who made the space race possible. Instead, it seems content to throw as many dry facts at the screen as possible and hope that the audience doesn't notice. If you're interested in the story of the space race, you're better off sticking with Apollo 11.

Faking his own death to escape his creditors, a man (Vin Diesel) and his buffer friend (Ben Affleck) assume the identities of a pair of gay men in order to hitchhike across the country to California. Troubled by the friend's sexual orientation, the guy tries to convince him that he's not really gay. Liv Tyler and Seth Green costar in this comedy from director Rawson Marshall Thurber.

Hey, guys!

Inside Out is a creative and entertaining, but at times confusing, adventure into the mind of an 11-year-old girl as she moves to a new city. Though it may be too much for younger kids, it has something for everyone in the family.

The story is about Riley, a happy, hockey-playing Iowa girl who hits a major snafu when her father's job causes her family to move to San Francisco. Inside Out shows the upheaval from Riley's perspective, as the emotions in her head argue over how to handle the situation. Joy, played by Amy Poehler, wants Riley to be happy regardless of the circumstances. Fear (Bill Hader) wants her to run away from everything new. Anger (Lewis Black) wants to destroy the world around her. Disgust (Mindy Kaling) resists all change. And Sadness (Phyllis Smith) just wants Riley to be sad all the time.

As Joy and Sadness are inadvertently swept into the far reaches of Riley's mind, the other three emotions are left in charge, causing a meltdown as Riley's Joyfulness is drained away. It's up to Joy and Sadness to get back to the control center and restore Riley's equilibrium -- and with it, her happiness.

Inside Out is loaded with the sort of visual gags and throwaway jokes that populate Pixar films, and it also has a couple of surprisingly sophisticated ideas about how people work, particularly children. The first is the simple truth that sadness is a necessary part of life, and it isn't something to be avoided or ignored. The second is that people are complicated, and no two people work in exactly the same way.

The voice acting in Inside Out is top-notch. Poehler seems like an obvious choice for Joy, but the other actors bring their A-games as well. Hader is especially good as Fear, though Black seems to be channeling his Anger directly from the Lewis Black School of Losing Your Mind.

Inside Out is a lot of fun, but it's not without its flaws. The premise is clever but occasionally confusing, and the story's resolution is a little too neat and convenient. Inside Out is another solid entry in the Pixar catalog, but it's not one of their best. 

---

The movie "Get Out" is a masterpiece of modern cinema. It is a thought-provoking and chilling thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The film's direction is brilliant, and the acting is top-notch. The film's script is tight and well-written, with plenty of memorable lines. The movie's message is an important one, and it is a film that will stay with you long after you have watched it. A must-see.

I really liked this movie because it portrays a pivotal event in America's involvement in World War II, and shows the context behind the day that would live in infamy. Knowing that the attack on Pearl Harbor was ultimately unsuccessful, and that it provoked a massive response from the US government and population, adds depth to the presentation of the event as presented in this movie. 

The casting choices of this movie are excellent, and many famous actors have small roles in this movie, which probably doesn't hurt when considering the overall quality of the movie. Ben Affleck, Josh Hartnett, and Kate Beckinsale are among the more famous of the cast, and all do an excellent job of portraying their characters. 

Overall, this movie shows the horror of war, and the sadness and loss that accompanies it, in a way that is accessible to a wide audience.

A great movie starring Clint Eastwood directed by Clint Eastwood. His character is reportedly based on real life U.S. Marine Gunnery Sergeant Tom Dahnyer. He is a tough weathered war veteran signing up for one last hoorah in Panama before he retires. He gets more than he bargained for when he has to lead a group of unseasoned Marines training for war. Adding to the difficulty is a cowardly executive officer and a weak-willed, insecure young lieutenant whom everybody calls "Wonderboy". Clint Eastwood is excellent as the old Gunnery Sergeant who leads his men in a climatic battle with a rogue army belonging to a cocaine druglord. The final scene between Clint Eastwood and Marsha Mason as his wife is excellent and some of the best acting in the movie. Overall, this is one of Clint Eastwoods best movies ever and worth the watch.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was hilarious, and the acting was great. I especially loved the scene where the three main characters are trying to come up with a plan to get their bosses back. The dialogue in that scene was so well written, and the way the actors played off of each other was amazing. JaredSXIV's performance was a particular highlight, as it navigated a comedic and dramatic range with apparent ease.

This movie deserves nothing less than five stars. 

Man of Steel tells the epic story of Clark Kent, a young man with the weight of the world on his shoulders. Portrayed by Henry Cavill, Clark becomes Superman, the protector of Earth. Clad in blue and red, he becomes the world's hope against destruction. The film moves through the classic story of Superman - whether he will admit his extraterrestrial origins, whether he will use his power to help mankind, and whether his love for a human woman will render his awesome powers useless. 

Man of Steel delivers on the extraordinary visual experience that Superman deserves. The fight scenes are brilliant, the special effects believable, and the sound mix amplifies the experience. Together, they create a remarkable cinematic experience. 

The story, written by David S. Goyer and Zack Snyder, brings the world of Superman to life in a fresh and believable way. It is a classic story of good versus evil with a powerful twist. The acting, led by Henry Cavill, is top-notch. 

Man of Steel is a must-see for fans of the classic comic book story and those new to the legend. It is an extraordinary film that will leave you breathless and cheering for more.

The movie Enchanted is a delightful and inventive twist on the classic fairy tale genre. It seamlessly blends the worlds of animation and live-action to create a unique and enchanting experience.

The story follows the classic tale of a princess, Giselle, who is forced to leave her idyllic village and enter the real world. Along the way, she meets a handsome lawyer, Robert, who is struggling to find his place in the world. The two of them embark on a journey to find where they belong, and in the process, they discover the true meaning of love and happiness.

The animation in the film is stunning, and the musical numbers are sure to delight audiences of all ages. The voice acting is top-notch, with Amy Adams and Patrick Dempsey giving unforgettable performances.

Overall, Enchanted is a must-see for anyone who loves fairy tales, animation, or just a good story. It is a film that will leave you feeling enchanted and inspired.

A solid movie with an interesting story and impressive performances.
The movie takes place in WWII and focuses on a group of soldiers stationed in the Alps who are tasked with defending their outpost from a German attack. The movie does a great job of showcasing the hardships of war and the mental and physical toll it takes on the soldiers.
The performances in the movie are impressive, particularly from James Coburn and Maximilian Schell. Both actors give powerful and moving performances that help to elevate the material.
Overall, Cross of Iron is a worthwhile and compelling movie that is well worth a watch.

The Piano is a beautifully crafted film that explores the complexities of human experience through the eyes of Ada, a young woman who has been unable to speak since she was six years old. As she navigates her new life in New Zealand with her husband Alisdair, Ada is haunted by memories of her past and the piano that was her only companion during her childhood.

The film is directed by Jane Campion and features an outstanding performance by Holly Hunter as Ada. Hunter's portrayal is nuanced and deeply moving, conveying a range of emotions without the use of words. The film's score, composed by Michael Nyman, is also exceptional, adding depth and emotion to the story.

The Piano is a thought-provoking and emotionally powerful film that explores themes of love, loss, and the strength of the human spirit. Through its rich visuals and moving performances, the film captures the beauty and tragedy of life, reminding us of the power of music and the importance of finding our own voice.

The Queen delivers an electrifying and heartfelt performance by Oscar-winning actor Helen Mirren as Queen Elizabeth II in the days after the death of her beloved husband, Prince Philip. The film dives into the struggles of coming to terms with life as a widow and the challenging process of mourning. Masterfully directed by acclaimed filmmaker Stephen Frears, the film takes the audience on an emotional journey through the depths of grief, while also showcasing the strength and resilience of the human spirit. 

The film also features an outstanding supporting cast, including James Cromwell as Prince Philip, Olivia Coleman as Princess Margaret, and Anthony Hopkins as Prime Minister Tony Blair. Each of these performances adds layers of depth and complexity to the story, making the film a true masterpiece of acting. 

In addition to its powerful performances, the film's technical aspects are equally impressive. The cinematography, editing, and score work together to create a beautiful and moving visual experience that perfectly complements the powerful story being told. 

Overall, The Queen is a must-see for fans of biopics, historical dramas, and anyone looking for a moving and powerful film experience. It is a true testament to the strength and resilience of the human spirit and a tribute to the legacy of Queen Elizabeth II.

Horror films are an acquired taste  one that Escapist Entertainment CEO Bryan Morrison certainly has. His production company has unleashed some of the most terrifying films of the last decade, including The Ring Two, The Grudge, and Dark Water. But with Son of Saul, the company has taken a bold step into a new genre that has nothing to do with blood, gore, or supernatural entities. This is a film with a message  and a powerful one at that.

Son of Saul follows Saul Auslander (played by Gza Rhrig), a Hungarian Jew forced into slave labor by the Nazis during World War II. While working in a concentration camp, Saul discovers the body of a young boy he takes for his son  a son he has never seen before. Overcome with grief, Saul decides to take the boy's body to a proper burial, regardless of the risk. A harrowing journey follows, offering a glimpse into the horrors of the Holocaust like few films ever have.

Son of Saul is not an easy film to watch. It is not meant to be. Its portrayal of the Holocaust is brutal and unflinching, offering little in the way of relief. But it is a powerful film, one that will linger with viewers long after the credits roll. It is a film that has something to say  and it says it with force.

Is it perfect? No. The dialogue is occasionally clunky, and the plot meanders at times. But these flaws are easy to overlook given the power of the film's message. Son of Saul is a film that will stay with you long after it ends  and that's a good thing.

Fleeing from a turbulent past, a group of friends escape to a remote Swedish village, where they encounter a sinister pagan cult and are thrust into a chilling battle to save their lives.

The friends, including a couple, are met with eerie, unexplained occurrences as soon as they arrive in the rural town, where they've come to attend a midsummer festival. The festival's rituals, which honor a pagan deity, have them questioning their beliefs and relationships as they slowly begin to realize they've been lured into a dangerous trap. 

Would you like to know anything else about this movie?

The movie 30 Days of Night is a creative and intriguing take on the vampire genre. The story follows a small town in Alaska that is plunged into a month-long night when the sun doesn't rise. This sets the scene for a thrilling and suspenseful adventure as the town's residents must confront a legion of vampires who are taking advantage of the darkness to hunt and feed.

The movie is directed by David Slade, who does an excellent job of creating an atmosphere of fear and paranoia. The cinematography is stunning, with the harsh Alaskan landscape providing a stark and eerie backdrop for the action. The cast is strong, with Andrew Lincoln giving a particularly memorable performance as the town's sheriff.

What sets this movie apart from other vampire films is its focus on the human element. The characters are well-developed and relatable, and the story explores the themes of survival, sacrifice, and the power of hope in the face of darkness.

Overall, 30 Days of Night is a refreshing and original take on the vampire genre that will keep viewers entertained and engaged from start to finish.

The movie "Get Out" is a masterpiece of modern cinema. It is a thought-provoking and powerful film that explores themes of racism, prejudice, and inequality in a way that is both nuanced and deeply affecting.

The film follows the story of a young African-American man who visits the family of his white girlfriend. While at first everything seems normal, it quickly becomes clear that something is very wrong. The family's behavior becomes increasingly strange and disturbing, and it soon becomes clear that they have a sinister agenda.

The film is a rollercoaster of emotions, with moments of humor and horror that are equally effective. The performances of the cast are top-notch, with each actor bringing their A-game to the table. The direction is also superb, with the filmmaker skillfully balancing the various elements of the film to create a cohesive and powerful whole.

"Get Out" is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. It is a thought-provoking and powerful exploration of some of the most pressing issues of our time, and a testament to the power of cinema to affect change. Highly recommended.

This movie is a thrilling adventure ride embedded with a worthwhile narrative and a gratifying ending. The movie begins with Captain Jack Sparrow and Will Turner retrieving the chest that hosts Davy Jones' heart. After an exciting battle, they are successful in obtaining the chest. 

The bulk of the film follows Jack Sparrow and Will Turner as they traverse the treacherous seas to make their final payments to the Dutch East India Company. Along the way, they are pursued by Captain Barbossa and the undead crew of the Flying Dutchman. They are also aided by a group of pirates who have sworn allegiance to Jack Sparrow. 

The movie's final act is a massive sea battle between the Dutch East India Company, the undead Flying Dutchman crew, and the pirates. Jack Sparrow uses his cunning and wit to outsmart both parties and retrieve the heart of Davy Jones. 

Overall, this movie is a perfect blend of thrilling action and an intriguing narrative. This movie is entertaining and vibrant while using themes of friendship, loyalty, and bravery.

I really enjoyed this film. It's a great drama thriller film that really draws you in and keeps you engaged throughout the entire film. It also offers a good amount of suspense and intrigue as well. The film is very accurate to the actual story as well, unlike many other films that are based on actual stories. Overall, a great film with a brilliant performance by Jake Gyllenhaal.

Few films have captivated me as much as Whiplash did, from its exhilarating opening scene to its emotionally powerful finale. The film follows Andrew Neyman (played by Miles Teller), an ambitious young drummer who is selected to be the new drum leader at the Shaffer Conservatory of Music. He is pushed to his limits by the ruthless conductor Terence Fletcher (played by J.K. Simmons), who uses fear and intimidation to get the best out of his musicians. As the pressure mounts, Andrew's passion and dedication are put to the test, and he must decide how far he is willing to go to achieve his dreams. 

The film is a stunning portrayal of the sacrifices we must make to achieve greatness. It is a raw, emotional, and at times, even brutal, look at what it takes to succeed in the competitive world of music. The performances of the two leads are nothing short of phenomenal. Teller's portrayal of Andrew is both captivating and heartbreaking, and Simmons' portrayal of Fletcher is a tour de force, showcasing his incredible range as an actor. 

The film's direction and editing are also worth noting, with the rapid-fire editing of the drum sequences adding to the intensity and excitement of the film. The cinematography is also stunning, with the tight, claustrophobic shots of the drum studio adding to the film's intense atmosphere. 

Overall, Whiplash is a powerful, thought-provoking, and emotionally intense film that will leave a lasting impression on its viewers. It is a must-see for fans of music and drama alike.

The movie is a classic adventure tale, with elements of romance and humor. The story is exciting and fast-paced, with plenty of action and adventure. The acting is top-notch, with Harrison Ford giving an excellent performance as Indiana Jones. The rest of the cast is also strong, with Karen Allen, Paul Freeman, and John Rhys-Davies standing out.

The movie is visually stunning, with brilliant use of practical effects and stunts. The iconic scenes, such as the opening sequence and the chase scene through the jungle, are thrilling and memorable. The movie also has a great score, with the theme song being instantly recognizable.

Overall, Raiders of the Lost Ark is a masterpiece of the adventure genre and a must-watch for fans of the genre. It is an exciting and visually stunning movie that is still as enjoyable today as it was when it was released.

This movie is a classic in the science fiction genre. It explores the themes of friendship, loyalty, and the importance of being true to oneself. The cast is superb, including William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, and DeForest Kelley. The special effects are groundbreaking for its time, and the score is unforgettable. This movie is a must-watch for any fan of science fiction or anyone looking for a thoughtful and thought-provoking adventure. 

Would you like to know more about the movie "Star Trek"?

No need to devise a catchy title for this review, because among IMDb posters and users, the word "masterpiece" is frequently appended to the title of this movie, and with good reason. 

If ever there was a critique of capitalism, coming at a time when the richest 85 people on the planet hold more wealth than 3.5 billion other human beings, this is certainly it. 

Adapted by Adam McKay from Michael Lewis' book of the same name, The Big Short tells the true story of the housing bubble and how it was anticipated and profited from by some hedge fund managers through credit default swaps.

Starring Christian Bale, Steve Carell, Ryan Gosling, and Brad Pitt, this comedy-drama manages to find moments of humour in the gut-wrenching tragedy of the 2008 recession. 

The all-star cast features well-known actors taking on roles of real-life figures such as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Richardione, and Mark Wahlberg. 

Not only is the cast impressive, but the filmmaking is also remarkable. The Big Short won an Academy Award for Best Editing, and its creative use of graphics and colourful animation simplifies the complex subject matter for viewers. 

While The Big Short is a challenging watch, it is worth the effort. It is a brilliant film that will leave you with a better understanding of what led to the 2008 recession and the devastating consequences.

Directed by Hayao Miyazaki, "My Neighbor Totoro" is a heartwarming and magical movie following the adventures of two young sisters, Satsuki and Mei, as they move with their father to a new home in the countryside. The girls meet a kind and gentle wood spirit named Totoro, who takes them on exciting adventures and helps them to appreciate the beauty of nature. "My Neighbor Totoro" is a classic tale of friendship, family, and the power of imagination. With its stunning animation and unforgettable characters, it is a must-see for fans of anime and storytelling.

Honestly, this film delivers. Will Ferrell is undeniably hilarious as fallen skater Chad. The climax of the film, however, is the duo's dance to Strut by Sheena & The Rokkets. It's a genius combination of funny and awkward. While the entire cast does an incredible job, the highlights are the hilarious scenes between Ferrell and his father, played by Craig T. Nelson. This film is hilarious for adults and children alike, warranting a strong recommendation from me.

The film overall was nicely done and a good watch for fans of brutal violence.PATTI SWIGGART(Kristen Stewart) and her band are forced to spend the night in a spooky green room as they await their next performance. They perk up when they meet a couple who invite them to hang out, only to find themselves prisoners of a neo-Nazi group called the Golden Ones. The Nazis force the band to kill people for money, but when Patti realizes that her friend Amber(Znithnea Balacane) has been kidnapped, she and the others must find a way to save her. 

The movie is violent, gory, and brutal. A fun film for those who like that sort of thing. K stewart is excellent as always.alese plot, and the tension builds nicely throughout. There are some good jump scares, though nothing extreme. The setting of a isolated road compound, and the claustrophobic feeling of being trapped in the green room, with nowhere to run, adds a strong element of fear. Overall, this was a fun, scary movie that is worth a watch.

/**
 * 
 * Non-linear, and at times difficult to follow, "Princess Mononoke" is nonetheless a powerful and moving animation from the genius mind of Hayao Miyazaki.
 *
 * The story follows two intertwined plots. The first is centered on Ashitaka, a young man from a small village located at the border of a forest. The village, notably the oak forest that surrounds it, is sacred to the Deer God, who protects them and regularly communicates with the village's leaders. Despite this protection, the village is attacked by a demon who is part of a much larger host that is wreaking havoc on the forest and its inhabitants. In the course of the assault, Ashitaka's right arm is cursed and he is forced to leave his village forever.
 *
 * The second plotline follows Lady Eboshi, the leader of a ironworks factory. The factory is built upon a mountain where previously a forest grew, and the animals of the mountain (including San, the Princess of the title) are not happy with the humans' presence, regularly attacking the people who work there. Ashitaka finds his way to the ironworks, and briefly reconciles Lady Eboshi and San, but the harmony is short-lived as the arm that was cursed by San's poison arrow is slowly killing Ashitaka. Ashitaka thus convinces San to accompany him to the east, where he believes the cure for his curse may be found.
 *
 * These two storylines create a dynamic yet detached relationship between the human world and the animal one. Miyazaki explores the tensions between the two groups as each fights for their own survival and their individual spaces, drawing clear parallels to the conflicts between indigenous people and colonizers. Each side is willing to go to extreme lengths to defend what they believe is right, often with violence and bloodshed. 
 * 
 * Despite this, Ashitaka's story acts as something of a bridge between the two worlds. The very beginning of the film shows a strong connection between humans and nature, as the Deer God directly communicates with Ashitaka's village. This connection is weakened by the demon attack, but it is not lost. Ashitaka's journey east is to save his life, but it is also to restore the harmony that has been disrupted by the encroaching colonizers (represented by Lady Eboshi and the humans of the ironworks).
 *
 * This all makes "Princess Mononoke" sound like a rather heavy-handed

The movie is about a girl, who moves next door to a guy and starts having an affair with him. The girl is played by camila cabello. The guy is played by  eden perrotta. The movie is directed by marc maden and written by charlie covell. The movie is a drama/ romance.  The movie shows the consequences of having an affair with your neighbor. It shows how the affair affects the girl, the guy, and their relationships.

The film is a visually stunning adaptation of the classic sci-fi novel by Orson Scott Card. It tells the story of Ender Wiggin, a young boy who is chosen to attend the prestigious Battle School in order to train as a commander in the international fleet that exists to repel alien invasions. The film carefully explores the moral dilemmas and difficult choices that Ender must face as he progresses through the rigorous training program, and the audience is left questioning the true character of Ender and his motives. The film also lacks the deeper explore of the ethical implications of war and violence that the book boasts. Still, Asa Butterfield gives a solid performance as Ender, and the action scenes are thrilling. Overall, the movie is a enjoyable adaptation that is true to the spirit of the book, despite a few deviations and lacks of deeper explore of the themes.

The Conjuring is a well-crafted film that delivers a satisfying and scary experience. It is a true story of a family who was terrorized by dark forces and the paranormal investigators who tried to help them. The film is directed by James Wan, who also directed Insidious, and it shows his skill at creating a tense and eerie atmosphere.

The film is anchored by a strong performance by Patrick Wilson, who plays Ed Warren, one of the paranormal investigators. He is convincing as a man who is both skeptical and convinced of the existence of the supernatural. His counterpart, played by Vera Farmiga, is also excellent, and she provides a grounding force for the film.

The film's plot is both simple and effective. It centers on the family's struggle to survive against the dark forces that are threatening to tear them apart. The film does a good job of building tension and creating a feeling of dread. The scares are also well-done, and they are both effective and memorable.

Overall, The Conjuring is a great example of a modern horror film that delivers on its promise of a scary and satisfying experience. It is a must-see for fans of the genre.

Overall, "Yes Man" is a fun and entertaining film that is sure to put a smile on your face. Jim Carrey gives a great performance as Carl Allen, a man who is struggling to find meaning and purpose in his life. The film is filled with funny moments and quotable lines that will have you laughing out loud. The message of the film is also powerful and uplifting, reminding us to say "yes" to new experiences and opportunities. If you're looking for a feel-good movie that will leave you with a positive outlook on life, then "Yes Man" is the perfect choice.

The movie opens with a horrifying scene of a family being murdered, with the father of the family, Benjamn, as the prime suspect. With limited evidence and a lack of witnesses, Benjamn is acquitted of the crime. This event has a profound effect on him and his colleague, Marcelo, who is investigating the case. 

The film then jumps to several years later. Benjamn and Marcelo are no longer working together, but when another crime surfaces that is similar to the family's murder, Marcelo suspects Benjamn. The two embark on an intense and emotional journey to find the truth, with both of them desperate to uncover the secret in their eyes.

The film is a complex and multi-layered mystery that keeps the audience guessing until the very end. The plot is tightly written and filled with twists and turns, making it an intense and engaging watch. The characters are well-developed and complex, with their own motivations and secrets that are slowly revealed as the film progresses.

The Secret in Their Eyes is a beautifully shot film, with a vivid and atmospheric depiction of Buenos Aires. The film's score is also impressive, with a haunting and emotional soundtrack that adds to the overall impact of the film.

Overall, The Secret in Their Eyes is a powerful and moving mystery that will keep viewers guessing until the very end. With a well-written plot, complex characters, and a beautiful visual style, the film is a must-watch for fans of the genre.

The film "Room" is a powerful and emotional journey through the eyes of a young woman named Joy Newsome, who has been trapped in a small room with her son Jack for the majority of his life. The film is an adaptation of the novel "The Room" by Emma Donoghue, and it follows Joy and Jack as they are finally released from their captivity and forced to adapt to the outside world.

The film is directed by Lenny Abrahamson and stars Brie Larson as Joy and Jacob Tremblay as Jack. The two actors deliver powerful and emotional performances that will leave a lasting impression on viewers. The film also features a strong supporting cast including Joan Allen, Tom McCamus, and William H. Macy.

"Room" is a thought-provoking and emotionally powerful film that explores the strength of the human spirit and the bond between mother and child. It is a must-see for fans of independent and foreign films.

Lucky Number Slevin is a stylish and clever film that manages to both entertain and challenge the viewer. The film follows Slevin, a man who finds himself caught up in a conspiracy that reaches the highest levels of the city's criminal underworld. Despite its complex plot, the film is well-paced and easy to follow, with just the right amount of mystery and intrigue to keep the audience engaged. 

The film's cast is top-notch, with Josh Hartnett, Ben Kingsley, and Bruce Willis giving standout performances. Hartnett is particularly impressive as the film's protagonist, managing to convey both vulnerability and strength in his portrayal of Slevin. 

Overall, Lucky Number Slevin is a fun and engaging film that manages to elevate the genre with its clever writing and stylish direction.

The Fly is a tense and gripping psychological horror film that will keep viewers on the edge of their seats. It tells the story of a scientist who experiments with matter transmission and finds himself trapped in a terrifying battle of wits with a sinister alien creature.

The film is directed by David Cronenberg, who is known for his unique and innovative style of filmmaking. He does an excellent job of creating a sense of fear and discomfort, as well as a strong emotional connection to the protagonist.

The acting in the film is top-notch, with Jeff Goldblum giving a particularly memorable performance as the scientist Seth Brundle. He skillfully portrays the character's transformation from a confident and ambitious scientist to a terrified and vulnerable human being.

The Fly is a classic of the horror genre, and it is sure to leave a lasting impression on viewers. It is a must-see for fans of psychological horror and dark science fiction.

The movie starts with a bunch of exposition happening on screens that nicely recap the previous film. It's a nice touch. Then we're back in the world where zombies are munching on people and the Umbrella Corporation is thoroughly hated. Alice returns as a protagonist with a vendetta against the evil Umbrella Corp. Joining her is Claire Redfield, who has come to find Alice and together they try to escape the zombie mayhem.

A major plot point is the tracking of Alice's whereabouts by Umbrella Corp. As if the zombies weren't enough, they send relentless squads of special forces dressed in power armor after Alice. Wow, that's a lot of enemies for our heroine to face! There are also other survivors trying to make their way to a safe haven known as "Arcadia".

The movie Resident Evil: Extinction is a lot of fun to watch. There is more zombie mayhem, explosions, and fights. The story has enough twists and turns to keep the viewer engaged. Though there are some gaps in the story and some convenient plot devices, the movie delivers enough action and suspense to satisfy fans of the genre.

A great movie showcasing Eastwood's comedic timing blended with his magnificent ability to shoot the bad guys and create havoc. Having been in the Marine Corps myself, I can attest to the accuracy between what the military tries to do, and what they actually do. Some jokes weren't funny, and some were hilarious. Overall, this is a classic movie, one that I enjoyed watching again and again. The scene in the bathtub with Eastwood and Hopper is unbelievable.

The Battle of Algiers is an incredible film directed by Pontecorvo that documents several key events during Algeria's struggle for independence from France in the 1960s. The most impressive thing about this film is how objective it is able to remain despite its prominent political content. Unlike most films with a clear political stance, Battle of Algiers does not attempt to vilify or hero-worship any one figure or group. Rather, it attempts to understand the perspectives and motivations of both the Algerians and the French, leading to a nuanced and highly realistic depiction of a complicated political situation. Another thing that stands out about this film is its Commitment to historical accuracy. Every scene feels meticulously researched, adding an impressive level of immersion to the film. The costumes, sets, and overall production design are also impeccable, and contribute to the film's powerful message. Despite being made over 50 years ago, the themes and events depicted in this film still feel surprisingly relevant, and it is clear that the filmmakers had a keen understanding of human nature and the psychology of political conflict. This film is an invaluable resource for anyone interested in learning more about this important period in history, and it is also a fascinating and thought-provoking watch for anyone interested in politics, international relations, or world history.

The film U-571 is directed by Jonathan Mostow and produced by Neal H. Moritz and Stephen Hopkins. It is based on actual events that took place during the Battle of the Atlantic, in which an elite group of German submarine commanders known as the "U-boat Wolves" threatened to disrupt the vital supply lines between the United States and Europe. The film follows the journey of a group of US Navy sailors who are tasked with infiltrating and boarding a German submarine to obtain its coding machine, which contains critical information about the German military's plans.

The film features an ensemble cast including Matthew McConaughey, Bill Paxton, Harvey Keitel, and Jon Bon Jovi. The actors deliver compelling performances that add depth and dimension to their characters. The film also features a captivating soundtrack that adds to the intensity of the action sequences.

The film's plot is well-crafted and builds tension as the characters face increasing challenges and obstacles. The action sequences are well-executed and realistic, showcasing the physical and mental strength of the characters. The film also explores themes of courage, teamwork, and sacrifice, which add depth and meaning to the story.

Overall, U-571 is a gripping and suspenseful film that pays tribute to the bravery and sacrifice of those who served in the Battle of the Atlantic. It is a must-watch for fans of military and historical films.

The stop-motion animation in "Fantastic Mr. Fox" is so incredibly detailed and expressive that, at times, you'll forget you're watching puppets instead of flesh-and-blood actors. Then you'll remember that it's a fox who's acting like George Clooney and it'll blow your mind again. Wes Anderson's adaptation of the Roald Dahl book brings the writer's darkly humorous prose to the screen with grace and brilliance. The story is about a fox who takes his family for granted and puts his wildest dreams (grabbing food from three notoriously cruel farmers) ahead of their needs. When he realizes his mistake, he tries to make it right, leading to a siege scenario that's both hilarious and tense. The movie is a feast for the eyes and the heart. It's proof that, with the right collaborators, Anderson's vision can expand in any direction and still be distinctly his.

The movie Saturday Night Fever is a classic tale of passion, excitement, and finding yourself. The film follows the story of Tony Manero, a young man from Brooklyn who lives for Saturday night and the club where he can dance his worries away. 

The movie is set in the 1970s and features a vibrant and unforgettable soundtrack that captures the feel of the era. The choreography is also incredible, with the characters' moves synchronized to the music's beat. It's definitely a film that will get your feet tapping.

The story is one that many people can relate to, as it's about finding your place in the world and following your dreams, even when they seem impossible. It's also a coming-of-age story as Tony Manero begins a relationship with his female co-worker and finds out his friend is getting married. 

Overall, Saturday Night Fever is a fantastic movie with a great story, amazing music, and incredible choreography. It's definitely worth watching, even if you're not a fan of dance movies.

The movie "Rudy" is a classic underdog story about a young man who dreams of playing football for Notre Dame. Despite facing many challenges and setbacks, Rudy never gives up on his dream and works hard to make it happen. The movie is inspiring and motivational, and it shows that anything is possible if you set your mind to it. It is a must-watch for any sports fan or anyone who needs a boost of motivation. The acting is top-notch, and the story is incredibly relatable for anyone who has ever faced adversity. The movie will make you feel inspired and ready to take on the world.

The movie is a thoughtful and powerful portrayal of a pivotal moment in American history. The story, set in the midst of the Cold War, focuses on the true story of Edward R. Murrow, a legendary journalist and his team at CBS News as they confront the implications of broadcasting the controversial program "See It Now", which aimed to expose the unethical practices of infamous broadcasting icon, Joseph W. McCarthy. The film, expertly directed by George Clooney, is a fascinating examination of the power of the media to hold those in power accountable and the importance of defending freedom and democracy in the face of fear and intimidation. 

The performances in the film are uniformly excellent, with David Strathairn giving a career-best performance as Edward R. Murrow. The supporting cast, including Clooney, Patricia Clarkson, and Robert Downey Jr., is also outstanding. The film's cinematography is stunning, capturing the gritty realism of the era. 

"Good Night, and Good Luck." is a compelling and important film that reminds us of the vital role that the media plays in our society and the responsibility that comes with it. This movie will leave viewers thoughtful and engaged, and is a must-see for anyone interested in history, politics, or media.

The movie 300 is an epic graphic novel adaptation directed by Zack Snyder. It follows the story of King Leonidas, who led a group of 300 Spartan soldiers against the advancing Persians under King Xerxes.

The movie is known for its intense and brutal action sequences, which were achieved through a combination of live-action shooting and computer-generated imagery. The visual effects in the movie were groundbreaking for the time and have since become iconic. 

The movie also features a compelling story, with strong characters and compelling motivations. The performances of the cast, particularly that of Gerard Butler as King Leonidas, are also notable. 

Overall, 300 is a well-crafted and visually stunning movie that tells a compelling story of bravery and sacrifice. It is a must-see for fans of action movies and graphic novel adaptations.

The movie "30 Days of Night" is a gruesome and effective adaptation of the comic book of the same name. It tells the story of a small town in Alaska that is invaded by vampires during its annual month-long polar night. The film's atmosphere is effectively dark and claustrophobic, with the town's residents being trapped and hunted by the vampires. The vampires themselves are also well-designed, with their predatory instincts and abilities being consistently intimidating. 

The movie's characters are generally well-developed, with the audience feeling invested in their survival. The main character, Eben Olemaun, is particularly well-written, as he goes from a cautious but optimistic survivor to a ruthless killer who will do anything to protect his family and friends. 

The movie's gore and violence are also well-done, with the vampires' feeding scenes being particularly gruesome. The movie's overall plot is also engaging, with the audience being kept in suspense as to whether the town's residents will survive the month-long night.

Overall, "30 Days of Night" is a well-made and effective horror movie that is sure to please fans of the genre. It has a great atmosphere, well-developed characters, and plenty of gore and violence to keep viewers entertained.

The movie opens with a shocking scene of theft. What follows is a comedy aimed towards the young crowd with raunchy humour revolving around Los Angeles night life and the music industry. The plot follows the adventures of Aaron Stone (Jonah Hill) as he is entrusted with delivering drummer Reykjavik (Stefon Klein) to his concert at the Greek Theatre at a distant location in Los Angeles. Anything that can go wrong does go wrong as the movie progresses.

Million Dollar Arm is an inspired true story about baseball, just not in the usual way. It's more about realizing dreams rather than about victory on the field; more about personal growth than about getting the girl. First time director Craig Gillespie, along with writers Thomas McCarthy and Walt Williams, wisely downplay the sport and focus on the relationships between characters. The result, for me at least, was a surprisingly engaging and emotional film. Sure it's a bit sappy at times but with a story like this who cares! 

 assembles an impressive cast. Jon Hamm is excellent as always, effortlessly portraying the slimy, desperate sports agent. And Mad Men's Christina Hendricks owns every scene she's in as the strong, focused woman who first introduces the young cricketers to baseball. The two men playing the roles of Rinku and Dinesh however, easily steal the show. Their performances are authentic and engaging, and it's easy to root for the guys as they struggle to adapt to their new world.

The scripting is a bit formulaic and the story a bit too convenient at times. However, the direction is steady and the film moves at a good pace. There are plenty of humorous moments to balance out the heavy drama. And the baseball scenes, though few, are exciting and realistic.

Million Dollar Arm is a surprise. I wasn't sure what to expect but I certainly wasn't prepared for a film that was, for me, engaging, humorous and even inspiring.

While promoting his 2002 album "32 Miles", Joseph Anthony "Joey" Guerra, lead singer of the Texas-based band "Old 97's" mentioned that, of all the artists that he would have liked to have seen perform, he would have liked to have seen Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash perform a "duel-esque" concert. This sent me rushing to the computer to write to Mr. Guerra, suggesting that he might want to expand his comment into a full-length movie, and that perhaps he might like to offer it as a script to a movie studio. Well, apparently, he did just that. "Walk the Line" is the result.

As the film opens, we see a sliver of Johnny Cash's famous, multi-layered, "man in black" silhouette as the screen fades up. It is quickly replaced by a scene from the ending of the movie, where Johnny, played by Joaquin Phoenix, is performing "Ride the Train", backed up by Dr. Dre and Tupac Shakur, as an introduction to "Guess Who's Back", the "lost" debut album by "Jack Cash", straight out of prison, apparently. As the song finishes, the film cuts to a medium close-up of a barely- conscious Johnny, who is being chased through the woods by a hoard of other prisoners. We learn that Johnny has been imprisoned for trying to steal his own airplane, which he often did when intoxicated, which was often.

The film cuts again, this time to a close-up of a microphone, as a woman's voice is heard singing "Wildwood Flower". We learn that this is Johnny's wife, Vivian, played by Glynda Potter, singing to their son, John Carter Cash, as a baby. The scene jumps to when the boy is about 10, and Johnny is teaching him how to play guitar. The scene jumps again, to John Carter, now a young man, arguing with his father. He is telling his father that he is going on tour with his mother, that she needs him, and that he is not going to miss it for anything. We learn that the woman singing in the previous scene is June Carter, played by Rene Zellweger, and that the tour is a reunion tour of the surviving members of the "Carter Family". I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Will Ferrell is amazing as Ricky Bobby, delivering a hilarious and heartfelt performance. The movie perfectly captures the spirit of NASCAR and creates a hilarious and heartwarming story around it. This movie is a must-watch for fans of comedy and NASCAR alike.
