The Terminator franchise took a major turn with "Salvation," the second installment directed by McG after "Terminator 3." Whereas that film had the advantage of continuing the story from the two preceding films directed by James Cameron, "Salvation" had neither Cameron nor the original cast (with the exception of Linda Hamilton) to lean on. It had to establish its own identity, and on that count, the film is a bit of a mixed bag. It's a competent sci-fi action picture, but it's also somewhat generic and, at 146 minutes, occasionally feels overextended.

At the outset of "Salvation," we learn that the film takes place in the year 2018, as man-machine hybrids called Terminators (played by Sam Worthington, Common, and Moon Bloodgood) stage an attack on a key military base. The target is no less than Kyle Reese (Jai Courtney), the son of a character played by Michael Biehn in the first "Terminator" film. Apparently, the time stream has been rewritten, and the Resistance fighter Sarah Connor (Hamilton) is no longer destined to save the world from the machines. That task now falls to her son, John (Christian Bale), who spent much of "Terminator 3" incarcerated in a mental institution.

The attack on the military base is just the first salvo in a full-scale invasion of Earth by the machines, and "Salvation" becomes a chase picture as John and Kyle attempt to make their way to the headquarters of the Resistance, with the Terminators hot on their heels. Along the way, they pick up a female soldier (Bryce Dallas Howard) whose father (Robert Patrick, reprising his role from "Terminator 2") goes missing early in the picture. 

"Salvation" delivers the goods as a sci-fi action thriller, with enough explosions, gunplay, and futuristic weaponry to keep fans of the genre satisfied. In contrast to the previous films in the series, though, the Terminator characters are largely kept in the background here. The story focuses on John and his quest to save the human race from extinction, and the film works best when it sticks to that formula. The franchise took an interesting turn with the introduction of the hybrid Terminators, who have the ability to disguise themselves as normal human beings. That leads to a few effective jump-scare moments, but the hybrids also tend to blend in with the rest of the cast, making it difficult to differentiate them from the good guys.

If ever there was a polarizing film that splits opinion down the middle then it is Full Metal Jacket. A film of two very distinct halves that both excel in their own way but also fail to ever reach the heights of their individual brilliance when combined as one.

The first half of the film is a glorious assault on the senses. The cinematography is so crisp and clear and the score pounds away in your ears as if your eardrums are about to burst. It is exhilarating to watch. The vast expanse of the Hue city is a wonder to behold as are the terrifying Vietcong traps that the US troops walk headlong into. The contrast between the two sides is immense and the brutality of the Vietcong is frightening. Kubrick seems almost pro-communist in his portrayal of the Vietcong as a terrifying force of nature that simply will not be defeated. Compared to the stupid, bullying, racist and ignorant attitudes of the US troops, the Vietcong come across as noble and just in their desire to expel the invaders from their country. Compared to the second half of the film, it is surprisingly emotional and you genuinely care about the grisly death of the protagonist.

The second half is a very different beast. The score disappears and is replaced by pop songs that are frankly annoying. The cinematography becomes dull and lifeless and the story slows to a crawl. It is no longer an epic war film but a basic training film. Whereas the first half was brutal and heroic, this half is petty and pathetic. The bullying drill instructor is a frustrating caricature of a villain and his interactions with the other characters become tiresome. The finale is anti-climactic and achieves nothing.

It is a shame that Full Metal Jacket does not live up to the promise of its first half but that is not to say it is not without merit. Both halves are very well made and showcase Kubricks brilliance behind the camera. It is arguably his most political film and it certainly provides an interesting counterpoint to the more traditional pro-US sentiments of most war films. Whereas most war films will make you want to fight for your country, Full Metal Jacket will make you want to leave it. 

Mediocre but well-made.

The movie begins with the excavation of a tomb in ancient Egypt. This immediately grabs your attention and sets the tone for the rest of the film. The storyline is well-written and engaging, with plenty of action and adventure. The acting is top-notch, with Tom Cruise delivering an outstanding performance as Nick Morton. The rest of the cast is also excellent, with great performances all around. 

The movie's special effects and set designs are stunning. The mummy's design is particularly well done, making it both scary and impressive. The film's score is also excellent, adding to the overall atmosphere and tension. 

Overall, The Mummy is a great action-adventure film that is both exciting and visually stunning. It is a must-watch for fans of the genre.

The Ringer is laugh-out-loud material. I was very surprised by how much I enjoyed this movie given the synopsis and the cast which to me albeit wrongly, elicits more of a drama than comedy vibe. The film centres on Rachel who realising she has hit rock bottom, invents a twin sister named Alice who suddenly comes back into her life with an opportunity to inherit a fortune. Of course this is all a lie but it goes surprisingly well until Rachel realises she may have bitten off more than she can chew. It's one of those cases where you think, how did this not go wrong? The chemistry between Keaton and Moore is undeniable, their witty banter and rapport on screen is a joy to watch. There are some really great one-liners and the supporting cast are also great, particulalrly Kenan who adopts a very 'Parks and Rec' type character which is refreshing and a style that suits him well. The Ringer has an unexpected twist which adds even more comedy to an already laugh-a-minute smart comedy!

The movie starts with an average guy named Frank, who is a retired black-ops agent that now lives a quiet life. That is until a bunch of corrupt agents show up, killing his girlfriend and stealing his retirement money. Frank then sets off on an exciting and perilous journey to get his money back and exact revenge on those who wronged him. Along the way, he teams up with an unlikely group of allies, including a young girl who is also a seasoned assassin, and a process server charged with delivering subpoena's that is right for his money and a chance at redemption. Together, they must battle a ruthless government official and his army of agents to save their lives and the day. This action-packed thriller will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.

In "Saw II," the body count continues to rise as the Jigsaw killer, aided by his apprentice Amanda, launches a new spree of murders, while FBI agent Eric Matthews begins to uncover the truth about the notorious killer's identity. This film is darker and more violent than the first, with the director promising "more blood, more gore, and more torture." The movie delivers on this promise with a series of gruesome and inventive deaths, including a woman trapped in a house full of razor wire and a man forced to choose between two doors, one leading to certain death and the other to a new challenge.

The movie follows the story of a Roman general who's mission is to conquer Britain. The plot develops when the legion is attacked by Picts led by an intense warrior who uses mad combat skills. The protagonist survives and decides to hunt down the rebel army. [U/10]

Horror films rely on a frightened, vulnerable protagonist pitted against a powerful, monstrous enemy: in this case, a bomb on a Chicago commuter train about to go off in minutes. COLIN FREEMAN (Mr. Gordon-Levitt) is a military pilot who wakes up on a train with no idea how he got there. A pretty female scientist, DR. LAROSE (Ms. Vergara), tells him he's been selected to be a "source code" pilot, whose eight-minute memory can be used to re-live a tragic incident over and over until finding the bomber and stopping him.

The setup is intriguing, for several reasons. First, it's clever to tie the film's tightly-structured time frame to the device that makes it possible: the protagonist's limited eight-minute memory, which pins the action and increases the tension. Second, it's a "found footage" film that doesn't rely on cheap tricks and jittery cinematography to scare the audience--in fact, the opposite is true, as the camera closely follows Colin in tight, confined spaces. It's an effective way to create discomfort. Third, it's interesting to see a sci-fi thriller set almost entirely on a train, which creates a closed world and pins the action.

There are two major weaknesses. The dialog is sometimes awkward, and the characters make stupid decisions to move the plot along. Toward the end, they make stupid decisions to increase the drama. It's hard to believe Colin would repeatedly endanger the lives of everyone on the train, instead of finding a way to stop the bomb without sacrificing himself several times. A character's crucial decision to remain on the train, which sets up the final scene, is difficult to believe.

But overall, "Source Code" is a smart, thoughtful sci-fi thriller with a strong finish and a clever premise.

The film is a classic tale of the challenges faced by three veterans as they readjust to civilian life after the Second World War. The film examines the physical and psychological scars of war and how they affect the individuals and those around them. It also explores themes of friendship, love, and loyalty. 

The acting in the film is top-notch, with Fredric March, Myrna Loy, and Dana Andrews giving powerful performances. The film also features a strong supporting cast, including Virginia Mayo, Cathy O'Donnell, and Harold Russell. 

The film's direction by William Wyler is also outstanding. He manages to create a realistic and emotional portrayal of post-war America without resorting to sentimentality or melodrama. The film's score, by Hugo Friedhofer, is also excellent, adding to the emotional power of the film. 

In conclusion, "The Best Years of Our Lives" is a classic film that explores the challenges of post-war life and the strength of the human spirit. With powerful acting and directing, and a moving score, the film is a must-see for anyone interested in classic cinema.

Happy Gilmore is a 1996 American sports comedy film directed by Dennis Dugan. It stars Adam Sandler as the title character, an unsuccessful ice hockey player who discovers a talent for golf and then becomes determined to win the PGA Championship. It is one of Sandler's earliest starring roles. 

The film was released in the United States on February 16, 1996, and received generally negative reviews from critics, but was a box office success, grossing $41.2 million against a $13 million budget.

Sandler's performance received some praise, and the film has since become a cult classic. 

Sandler collaborated with Dugan again on The Wedding Singer (1998) and Big Daddy (1999).

After making a difficult decision to enlist in the U.S. Army Medical Corps, young doctor Jimmy Porter (Tommy Lee Jones) reports for duty and is assigned to the M*A*S*H unit in Korea. Initially, Porter is annoyed by the arbitrary assignments and the two senior officers who are responsible for them. However, throughout his tour of duty, which is made even more arduous by the harsh weather conditions and daunting task of keeping so many people alive, Porter relies on his colleagues for support and camaraderie.

The movie Bloody Sunday is a powerful and moving account of the events of January 30, 1972, when British soldiers opened fire on a peaceful demonstration in Derry, Northern Ireland, killing 14 civilians. The film follows the story of the march and the aftermath, as the victims' families search for justice and the truth about what happened that day.

The movie is directed by Paul Greengrass, who is known for his gritty and realistic style of filmmaking. He brings that same approach to this movie, creating a powerful and visceral experience for the audience. The film is shot in a documentary-style format, with a lot of handheld camera work and a cinma vrit feel. This approach helps to create a sense of intimacy and realism, drawing the audience into the events of the film.

The acting in the movie is top-notch. James Nesbitt gives a powerful performance as a father struggling to come to terms with the death of his son in the march. Peter Mullan is also excellent as a priest trying to navigate the political and religious tensions of the time. The rest of the cast is also strong, with many of the actors portraying real-life figures from the time.

The movie is not without its flaws. The pacing is sometimes slow, and the film could have been trimmed down a bit. Additionally, some of the political themes can be a bit confusing for those not familiar with the history of Northern Ireland.

Overall, Bloody Sunday is a powerful and moving film about a crucial moment in Irish history. It is a must-see for anyone interested in the subject matter, and it is a testament to the strength of the human spirit in the face of tragedy.

The movie takes place in a world where a viral outbreak has turned most of the human population into flesh-eating zombies. It follows a group of survivors, including Milla Jovovich's character, Alice, as they attempt to find a safe haven. The movie is a non-stop action packed thrill ride. The plot is well thought out and interesting. The movie is packed with jaw-dropping stunts and special effects. It is a must see for fans of the genre.

The Departed is a film that leaves you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. It is a perfectly crafted thriller that keeps you guessing until the very end. The film stars a who's who of Hollywood talent, including Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson, and Mark Wahlberg. It is directed by Martin Scorsese, who is known for his thrilling and gritty films. The film's plot is based on the Chinese proverb, "See no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil." It follows two moles who are planted on either side of the law. It is a battle of wits and survival as each tries to outsmart the other. The film is packed with action and suspense, and the acting is top-notch. It is a film that will keep you entertained and engaged from beginning to end.

David Dunn is a security guard with a marriage that is falling apart. After being guarded by a mysterious stranger, Elijah Price, from a gruesome crime, he meets up with Elijah again months later. After sharing a beer, Elijah tells David that he has a superpower: he is unbreakable, immortal, and has never been sick a day in his life. This leads David on a search to find out more about himself, and figure out who this man is.

The film is a mystery, superhero, and drama all in one. It is a great film with a great twist at the end. The film was written and directed by M. Night Shyamalan and was released in 2000. It stars Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson, and Charlayne Woodard as the main characters.

The film is a brilliant parody of both the cop and horror genres, with references to a vast array of other films scattered throughout. The comedy is both slapstick and clever, and the movie never takes itself too seriously. With a brilliant cast including Nick Frost, Simon Pegg, and Jim Broadbent, Hot Fuzz is a must-see for fans of intelligent comedy. It's a film that's sure to leave you laughing long after the credits roll.

Before watching 'M*A*S*H', I had seen the CBS series come and go, but never caught any of the episodes. Knowing the series was based on this movie, I decided to watch it. After finally watching this classic, I can see why it produced such a successful series. It's dark, tragic, humorous, and evenbilical at times. This movie summons a hatred towards war, while making you laugh at the same time. Watching it now, simulataneously makes me happy and sad, as the topic is still timely, given our withdrawal from Afghanistan. This movie deserves its critical acclaim, and it's rewatchability.

The movie Straight Outta Compton depicts the true story of the influential hip-hop group N.W.A., whose groundbreaking music and outspoken lyrics changed the face of rap and challenged the establishment. The film follows the group's rise from the streets of Compton to the top of the music charts, as well as the personal and political struggles that they faced along the way.

The movie is directed by F. Gary Gray and written by Andrea Berloff. It stars O'Shea Jackson Jr., Corey Hawkins, Jason Mitchell, and Aldis Hodge as members of N.W.A., with Paul Giamatti as their manager. The film also features a supporting cast including Neil Brown Jr., Corey Reynolds, and Craig Young.

Straight Outta Compton is a powerful and impactful film that captures the energy and the essence of the group's music and their message. It is a must-see for fans of N.W.A. and for anyone who wants to understand the cultural and social impact of their music. The movie is an emotional and thought-provoking journey through the world of N.W.A. and their music, and it is a testament to the power of their message and their music.

The movie starts with a mysterious figure donning a skull mask, driving a motorcycle towards a secret underground location. We soon learn that this masked man is none other than Allan, the antagonist of the movie. Allan tells the person in charge that another team has arrived, and that they should be given the red carpet treatment. After an intense and comedic introductory scene, we meet Luke, the protagonist of the movie. He struggles to make ends meet by competing in low-paying martial arts competitions. While contemplating his life choices, he is suddenly attacked by Allan, who disrupts the event he is competing in and takes his wallet, which contains every cent he owns. Looking for a way to recover his money and his pride, Luke decides to take down the sinister martial arts competition circuit, which includes taking on ruthless opponents, fighting in unique and hilarious locations, and ultimately facing off against Allan to retrieve his money and teach him a lesson he will never forget. Throughout the movie, Luke's friends and family play a significant role in his journey, offering their support and help. The movie takes the audience on a thrilling and entertaining journey, with plenty of hilarious moments, impressive fight sequences, and a touch of romance.

The movie follows two brothers fighting in the Korean War. The older brother is captured by the enemy and tortured. The younger brother is determined to save him and reunite their family. The movie depicts the brutality of war and the sacrifices made for family. It is a touching and emotional story that will leave a lasting impression on viewers. The acting is top-notch, and the battle scenes are thrilling and realistic. It is a must-watch movie that will stay with you long after the credits roll.
